fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a note in our City briefing, page 23, May 17, we called Charles Darwin the originator of the doctrine of the survival of the fittest. The originator of the phrase was Herbert Spencer (Principles of Biology, pt iii, ch 12, 1865): "The survival of the fittest which I have here sought to express in mechanical terms, is that which Mr Darwin has called 'natural selection', or the preservation of favoured races in the struggle for life." Darwin acknowledged this in the 1869 edition of On The Origin Of Species: "The expression often used by Mr Herbert Spencer of the Survival of the Fittest is more accurate [than 'Struggle for Existence'], and is sometimes equally convenient." Both passages come from The Oxford Dictionary of Quotations.

Both passages come from The Oxford Dictionary of Quotations.

In our obituary of Barbara Cartland, page 20, May 22, we referred to the scientist FE Smith. We should have called him a lawyer and politician.

The National Botanic Garden of Wales is near Llanarthney, Carmarthenshire, not Dyfed as we said in a caption, page 13, May 25. Dyfed no longer exists.

In our piece about a documentary on Sierra Leone, shown at Cannes, page 12, May 25, we referred to UN-backed Ecomog troops. In fact, Ecomog is not a United Nations operation and when the documentary was made the UN had no troops in Sierra Leone.

David Lammy was selected to fight the Tottenham by-election for Labour with 51.9% of the vote, not 59.1%, the figure in a front page report, May 26.

fields.headline: And Mozart made five
fields.standfirst:
The Philosopher's Stone
St Jude's church, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Philosopher's Stone
St Jude's church, London
***
fields.body:
Sitting in a cramped, arse-numbing Lutyens church in Golders Green is not the ideal way to experience the UK premiere of one of the more curious musicological unearthings of recent years, though the Hampstead and Highgate festival deserves a medal for allowing us to hear The Philosopher's Stone in the first place. Premiered anonymously in Vienna in 1790, the opera soon vanished into limbo - where it might have remained had not American scholar David Buch discovered it to be a composite on which no less than five composers collaborated. Four have been relegated to the footnotes of musical history. The fifth happened to be Mozart.

The text (and some of the music) was by Emmanuel Schikaneder, who wrote the libretto for The Magic Flute, for which The Philosopher's Stone was, in some respects, a trial run. Allowing for shifts in gender, its plot - blending fairy tale, Freemasonic symbolism and whiffs of ancient Egyptian religion - is roughly the same. The benevolent, if emotionally-wounded deity Astromonte and his evil brother Eutifronte, battle for the life-conferring talisman of the title and for the souls of two contrasting pairs of human lovers, the aristocratic, virginal Nadir and Nadine, and the proletarian Lubano and his promiscuous wife Lubanera.

The score, however, has none of the sublimity or numinous quality of the later opera. Given that five composers were involved, it does have a remarkable homogeneity of style, though Mozart's own contribution (10 minutes in a work lasting well over two hours) stands out a mile in terms of subtlety and emotional ambivalence. What is apparent, however, is that Mozart clearly learned from its flaws. Having an Osirian deity like Astromonte spouting stratospheric coloratura is a bit hard to take. Eutifronte, meanwhile, is an eloquent bass. In The Magic Flute, the musical polarities of good and evil are mercifully reversed in Sarastro's cavernous pronouncements and the Queen of the Night's bravura demonism.

The performance, a concert version in an English translation by Barry Millington, is a hit-and-miss labour of love. Both Graeme Danby (Eutifronte) and Augustin Prunell-Friend (Astromonte, struggling with the role) camped it up rotten, when the piece should be taken seriously. The quartet of human lovers fared better. Carolyn Sampson's pure, crystalline Nadine sharply contrasted with Nicki Kennedy's deliciously sensual Lubanera. Nadir's hideously difficult, high-lying music was phrased with great beauty, if occasional strain, by Huw Rhys-Evans. Harry Bicket, favouring extreme speeds, conducted the Collegium Musicum 90, who compensated for some dodgy ensemble with some beautifully poised woodwind and brass solos.

fields.headline: Susan Blackmore's top 10 books
fields.trailText: Susan Blackmore's latest book is The Meme Machine, published by Oxford University Press
fields.body:
Susan Blackmore's latest book is The Meme Machine, published by Oxford University Press.
Buy The Meme Machine at Amazon.co.uk

"I am choosing mostly science books because they are what I enjoy. I sometimes think I should read more fiction for the health of my mind, but I find it too difficult. I can never remember who is who - except in the simplest children's books. So for pleasurable bedtime reading give me science books every time. The best are well written, not too long, and range from nit-picking detail to answering the grand questions of life such as who are we? Why are we here? Is there any point to it all?"

1. The Selfish Gene by Richard Dawkins
25 years old but still a wonderful book on evolution. At the end of the book Dawkins invents the "meme". Memes are ideas, skills, habits or technologies that are passed from person to person by imitation, evolving our minds and societies as they go. It is an idea that has captivated me and changed my intellectual life for ever.

2. Consciousness Explained by Daniel Dennett
Consciousness is a great mystery. It feels as though there is an inner subjective world that is quite separate from the objective world of "reality" but this kind of dualism doesn't make sense. Dennett scythes through muddled thinking on consciousness and writes a wonderful book - even if the title is a little OTT.

3. Guns, Germs and Steel by Jared Diamond
A wonderful combination of prehistory, history and science that explores how the physical features of geography have shaped human evolution - giving some people all the goodies and leaving others isolated from the spread of ideas and without the resources to develop their own. In my terms it is a book all about the history of memes.

4. The Red Queen by Matt Ridley
This one's all about sex - how we humans evolved to have the peculiar sexual preferences and behaviours we do, and why sex is such fun. Beautifully written, a fun read as well as an education on evolutionary thinking.

5. The Three Pillars of Zen by Philip Roshi Kapleau
I have been practising Zen for many years. Although I rarely read books about the subject I like this one because it not only covers the basics but also includes stories of ordinary people who have really seen "how it is".

6. The Language Instinct by Steven Pinker
I was never much interested in language until I read this book. Pinker inspired me not only to realise how fascinating human language is, but to start inventing theories of my own about how we humans came to be the only species who have it.

7. Phantasms of the Living by E. Gurney, F.W. Myers and F. Podmore (1886)
I used to love reading books about psychic phenomena but in the end got utterly sick of the whole subject. This wonderful classic from over a century ago shows great minds at work, exploring strange experiences. A dip into this one quickly reveals how little the subject has progressed since then.

8. Intellectual Impostures by Alan Sokal and Jean Bricmont
I have often been intimidated by people who use long words and incomprehensible logic to argue that truth is relative and any theory is as good as any other. Sokal not only got sick of postmodernist relativism but pulled off the stunt of getting a spoof article published in a prestigious postmodernist journal. This book tells the story. I loved it.

9. The Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Galaxy by Douglas Adams
What a laugh. I loved the radio series and then the book. Can be read again and again.

10. Winter Holiday by Arthur Ransome
Of all our family books to read aloud, my favourites are Arthur Ransome, Roald Dahl, Harry Potter and C.S.Lewis's Narnia tales. But if I have to pick one it is Winter Holiday in which there is snow and ice and fear, as well as sailing (and girls who do good boyish outdoor things and hate wearing dresses).

fields.headline: Blues of many hues
fields.standfirst:
Bishopstock Festival
Clyst St Mary, Devon
***
fields.trailText:
Bishopstock Festival
Clyst St Mary, Devon
***
fields.body:
If you come to Bishopstock, you'd better love the blues. For three days, ticket holders can wallow in slow blues, fast blues, electric and acoustic blues, and blues from both rural and urban traditions. This doesn't quite explain how Steve Earle and the Dukes, playing beefy rock'n'roll and country music, came to be topping the bill on Saturday night, but then again his new album is called Transcendental Blues.

The festival takes place in the grounds of Bishops Court Palace adjoining the Devon village of Clyst St Mary. The house dates back to the 13th century, though layers of subsequent upgrades have imbued it with a Fall of the House of Usher-ish air, and its owner, Helen Myers, hosts the festival merely because she adores the blues. Capacity is a mere 5,000, which means punters can enjoy an unusually civilised environment (including homemade ice cream). How close the event comes to covering costs is anybody's guess.

This was Bishopstock's fourth year, and the bill was a mix of reliable crowd-pullers (notably Earle, Taj Mahal and Sunday's headliner Van Morrison) and an array of acts with cultish followings of their own. Mavis "Mother Soul" Staples was left shouldering a large chunk of the Saturday bill after both Jonny Lang and Booker T Jones failed to turn up, and Mavis offered a crafty demonstration of how the veteran performer can delegate most of the work to her band while dropping in a few trademark wails at strategic intervals.

Pouring rain and plummeting temperatures made Saturday something of an endurance test, but the weather improved for Sunday, though it was still too chilly for The Blind Boys of Alabama. The Boys had arrived a day late, but this hadn't disturbed their aura of spiritual calm, expressed though their close-harmony gospel singing and a version of If I Had a Hammer featuring vigorous pogoing. Later, the Fabulous Thunderbirds (resembling a gang of Chicano low riders) plugged in for a barrage of power-blues and an extended harmonica onslaught by band leader Kim Wilson.

But I reckon the best value on offer at Bishopstock was the Blues Workshop tent, where you could pick up tips on finger-picking, guitar tunings and harmonica technique from bluesman Michael Roach and friends. Maybe this was the breeding ground for next year's bill.

webTitle: Cut tax with £14bn windfall, says think-tank

fields.headline: Cut tax with £14bn windfall, says think-tank
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown ought to use the huge £14bn-plus windfall from buoyant financial markets to restructure the revenue system in such a way as permanently to slash the overall tax burden, says the Centre for Policy Studies, the conservative think-tank, in a report published today.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown ought to use the huge £14bn-plus windfall from buoyant financial markets to restructure the revenue system in such a way as permanently to slash the overall tax burden, says the Centre for Policy Studies, the conservative think-tank, in a report published today.

The first step would be to take 12m people out of income tax altogether. The threshold below which people pay no tax ought to rise from the present £4,300 to £15,000. This would move "independence day" - the point in the year at which people earn for themselves rather than the state - from May 30 this year back to April. Three years ago tax independence day arrived on May 25, while on present trends the CPS reckons it will have moved on into June by next year.

To pay the £40bn annual cost of reversing the trend would ultimately mean rebuilding the tax and benefit system in such a way that those receiving benefits would normally pay no tax, and vice versa, the CPS said. But to smooth the transition, the think tank suggested, the chancellor ought to use the "financial markets dividend" of at least £14bn in 1999-2000.

This dividend comes from two sources: the increased tax paid by people who have made gains in the booming stock market and the savings on servicing the national debt ,made possible through historically low interest rates. But the CPS warned: "The income from this dividend is extremely capricious. It is not prudent to use exceptional items such as these to fund recurring expenses. Yet the chancellor ... is using them to pay for the permanent public spending commitments he has made for the next four years."

In the event of a stock market crash depriving the Treasury of the dividend, said the CPS, taxes may have to increase by as much as £30bn.

webTitle: Standard Life rallies members to reject rebel conversion

fields.headline: Standard Life rallies members to reject rebel conversion
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Insurance group Standard Life will today make a final impassioned plea for policyholders to deliver a resounding no to demutualisation as it prepares to mail voting papers to the 2.3m people who will decide its future.
fields.body:
Insurance group Standard Life will today make a final impassioned plea for policyholders to deliver a resounding no to demutualisation as it prepares to mail voting papers to the 2.3m people who will decide its future.

The insurer said it will be sending out a "call to action" to ensure a good turn-out for the vote over whether it should stay member-owned or con vert to a public company and pay windfalls.

Group managing director Scott Bell and finance director Iain Lumsden will set out the reasons at a City briefing why they say policyholders should reject the demutualisation proposal put forward by a group of rebel members led by Monaco-based investor Fred Woollard.

The rebels say conversion would spell windfalls averaging £5,000 to £6,300 to qualifying with-profits policyholders - a claim contested by Standard Life.

Voting forms start going out tomorrow, accompanied by what the company said would be a "brief document outlining the key facts as we see them". The ballot result will be announced at a special meeting on June 27

For demutualisation to go ahead, the conversion resolution needs to be backed by at least 75% of those members who vote - a threshold Mr Woollard acknowledges is high.

A vote for conversion of between 50% and 75% is being increasingly seen as the most likely result - an outcome that could leave the 175-year-old company's board in a perilous position as they would not have the support of the majority of members, despite technically having won the battle. Mr Woollard has said that in such an event, the Ed inburgh-based insurer would be vulnerable to a takeover approach, particularly as it has endorsed a £12bn valuation of the group in its recently-issued defence document.

It is understood Standard Life intends to treat any result up to 75% in support of conversion as a mandate for continuing as a mutual.

Standard Life spokesman Gordon Arthur said it was "very confident" that Mr Woollard would not win three-quarters of the vote. However, he was only prepared to say that it was "increasingly confident" of achieving more than 50% of policyholders voting to keep it mutual.

Ned Cazalet, an independent life insurance analyst, said Europe's biggest mutual life insurer faced a challenging few weeks. "I think Standard Life is going to find a great deal of difficulty in mustering significant numbers of people to turn down money."

fields.headline: Keeping your cool
fields.standfirst: The hot office survival guide
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: What you should wear, what you should eat and why you should never ask for a fan. Judi James presents the Work Unlimited hot office survival guide.
fields.body:
There should be a small department of hell called the hot office, reserved exclusively for managers too stingy or too sadistic to invest in air conditioning for their employees.

Swaddled in polyester, they will be forced to sift through hours of needless emails while breathing recycled air scented with lethal doses of body odour. Their screams for mercy will be met by a guy in a short-sleeved shirt telling them it's down to "seasonal fluctuations" and that the heating cannot be turned off until late August.

HOS - or hot office syndrome - can affect some workplaces throughout the entire year, while for others it is primarily a problem in the summer months, when the temperatures rise and fall again without warning. The British climate is fickle, but thus has it even been, and acknowledging that fact does not need a degree in atmospheric variations. We get winter one day and tropical the next. So why invest heating and cooling systems with such a stereotypical sense of seasonal assumption?

Windows in the modern office do not open, we know that. Temperature settings tend to be centrally controlled. (This is probably done globally, which means by someone like Bill Gates, who may have taken over God's job in that particular department.) Even if it is the building manager who decides whether to freeze or fry us, it means we are at the mercy of someone we rarely meet and who possibly has a penchant for saunas.

Survival rates of HOS depend on pre-planning and animal cunning. If your office suffers from a womb-like atmosphere that induces perspiring pits and brain-torpor you will need to start taking steps now.

Self help

An amazing amount of offices have individual wall controls for temperature but these are often either hidden from sight or too mystifying to use. Offer to work late one night and check out all the walls when no-one is around. If you discover one of the little devils note down the manufacturer's name and phone them for a spare set of instructions. You then have the power. Tell no-one else. Be omnipotent. Cool that office down to your own comfort levels.

Brown nosing

If the heating is governed centrally move mountains to discover who is in charge. They usually live in a broom cupboard in the maintenance department. Befriend them subtly and slowly. Phone them direct when the office gets too stuffy. Make up some jargon-esque excuse for why you office needs delicate monitoring, for example: "Our new computer virus de-bugging system is particularly sensitive to heat".

Dress tropical

Your choice of clothing will be vital. Eschew any man-made fibres and stick to cotton or linen workgear. Bare shoulders are usually frowned on but bare arms are often ok. Baggy stuff is coolest but watch gaping armholes for glimpses of greying bra. A number of designers make unlined work suits. There is little point investing in fabrics that breathe if they are lined in nylon or other man-mades.

Tights are a nightmare in the hot office. If bare legs are not seen as appropriate stick to the sheerest brands or sport long skirts or trousers with pop socks.

Spray away

Facial spritzers are great when the going gets sticky. These mist the face with spring water and cool you down without streaking your make-up. Cologne hand-wipes will cool down palms and arms if held on the pulse-point of the wrists. Avoid immersing face or hands in cold water or cold showers - if the company provides the facility - as the body will try to over-compensate and start to heat up afterwards. Cool or lukewarm is better than icy cold. If you wear your hair long, tie it back and let the air to your neck.

Create calm

Rushing, stress and anger can all raise the body temperature. Think cool and move calmly. Believe in the power of mind over matter and spend precious minutes with your eyes closed, imagining yourself sitting under a nice cooling waterfall.

Eat cool

Take small snacks during the day, rather than scoffing one large lunch. Stick to cooling foods, like fresh fruit and pasta or rice cakes. Avoid anything heavy or fatty. Tea is good and can be more cooling than iced drinks. Avoid alcohol.

Cool it If the heat really is intolerable you will need to take a consensus vote and then speak to the boss or health and safety monitor. Tell them you are all getting drowsy and unfocused. If you are offered the use of fans think hard before accepting. Your negotiated objective should be air conditioning units. Fans are better than nothing, but not as good. Accepting them may signal an end to the barter. You boss will imagine he/she has been hugely philanthropic, while you have to battle with dry eyes, wind-blown hair and scattered paperwork. Stick to your guns.

Swaddled in polyester, they will be forced to sift through hours of needless emails while breathing recycled air scented with lethal doses of body odour. Their screams for mercy will be met by a guy in a short-sleeved shirt telling them it's down to "seasonal fluctuations" and that the heating cannot be turned off until late August. fields.headline: All tastes catered for
fields.standfirst:
Bath Jazz Weekend
Various venues
***
fields.trailText:
Bath Jazz Weekend
Various venues
***
fields.body:
The meanings of the word jazz was stretched during the annual Jazz Weekend in Bath. The touring Contemporary Music Network package of Farmer's Market and Iain Ballamy's Food made Norwegian jazz the dominant sound of Saturday afternoon. Ballamy's rugged audacity, wit and instinct for unpredictable group interplay meant that he was disinclined to produce minimalist ambient music. A fondness for a skewed kind of straightahead jazz mingled with Bulgarian folk-song made quintet Farmer's Market an engaging contrast. Farmer's Market excelled in its virtuosity and fast-cutting vivacity, while Food was often hypnotic in its intensity and dark sonorities.

Farmer's Market features the astonishing timbres of its saxophonist Trifon Trifonov - who apparently auditioned for the band over the phone with a solo recital that included Turkish gypsy music, Paganini and Charlie Parker. Trifonov's atmospheric sound on the alto sax suggests a wooden rather than a metal instrument, and his sustained notes had a purity and stillness that superbly counterbalanced the roaring accordion-bop of Stian Carstensen. Free-improv, a kind of limping bluegrass music, straight-jazz and circus music all found their way into an animated set.

Food deployed more oblique resources, with Arve Henrikson's vocalised trumpet sound drifting through distant percussion and arco-bass rumblings. The themes sometimes suggested a kind of lamenting madrigal or fragments of a jaunty Django Bates motif. It was sometimes spookily compelling, though operating in a more private world than the other UK/Northern Europe collaboration of the day, US3 and Incognito saxophonist Ed Jones's nine-piece with trumpeter Mika Myllari's musicians from Finland. This dynamic project, entitled Burn, used drum'n'bass effects, loops and samples, crackling funk backbeats and punchy jazz-horns riffing to attempt a blend of straight-jazz and cutting-edge pop materials that got hotter as the set built to a climax.

The weekend's Euro-avant philosophy might be defined by the Italian Instabile Orchestra, which wound up Saturday night with an exhilarating collection of free-blasting, oompah music and Kurt Weilian cabaret themes. It was the first time this 10-year-old band has played the UK and it ought to be the first of many. Also on Sunday was the fine British pianist John Law's collaboration with the American percussionist Gerry Hemingway in Abacus, and Austrian saxophonist Max Nagl's mix of Viennese cafe music and free jazz.

Food and Farmer's Market play The Wardrobe, Leeds, tomorrow, and CBSO Centre, Birmingham, on Friday. Abacus is at the Conway Hall, London, tonight, Midlands Arts Centre, Birmingham, tomorrow, Band on the Wall, Manchester on Thursday and Djangology Recital Hall, Nottingham on Friday.

webTitle: Wasim fires warning to West Indies

fields.headline: Wasim fires warning to West Indies
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan 269 & 219
West Indies 273 & 62-2
fields.trailText: Fourth day report: The third and final test was headed towards certain victory when rain precipitated an early tea yesterday, though it would take a brave man or a weatherman to say who the winners would be.
fields.byline: B C Pires at St John's, Antigua
fields.body:
The third and final test was headed towards certain victory when rain precipitated an early tea yesterday, though it would take a brave man or a weatherman to say who the winners would be.

With a large rain cloud hovering over the ground, both the West Indies openers gone for 62 and Wasim Akram having added two wickets to his first-innings tally of six, the target of 216 might yet prove high enough.

The West Indies began with nearly two sessions and a full day's play to get the runs, but seemed more interested in sending a message to England, where they arrive on Wednesday, that the old Carribean aggression is back. There were eight fours and a six in the 62, although the flamboyance was rarely accompanied by a shot selection that included more in the repertoire than the pull.

Adrian Griffith attempted to end the series as convincingly as he ended the one against Zimbabwe, when he raced to a half-century and victory at Sabina Park. Having pulled Wasim for four, he decided to stay with that shot, even after Sherwin Campbell fell victim to it, and soon followed suit.

With room having to be made to accommodate Brian Lara in the batting order, the battle may be between one of the openers and Wavell Hinds, who came in at No3 yesterday and scored 13 without difficulty. Shivnarine Chanderpaul, the other man at the crease at tea, was on 19 off 20 balls.

Pakistan began the day on 157 for five with the nightwatchman Saqlain Mushtaq on two and the in-form batsman Yousuf Youhana on 41, but Youhana added only one to his score before falling plumb lbw to Reon King in the sixth over of the morning.

The nightwatchman also lasted longer than the next specialist batsman, Abdur Razzaq, though that wasn't Razzaq's fault. On Razzaq's call for a quick single, Mushtaq stayed put at the striker's end and Razzaq, with the whole strip to cover, could have been walked out at the bowler's end.

Mushtaq added 13 runs to his score before his 64-ball innings ended caught by Campbell in the slips off King. Wasim and Waqar Younis added 27 runs for the ninth wicket before Waqar was caught sharply by Jimmy Adams in the slips off Curtly Ambrose for 16. The West Indies captain later bettered that by flinging himself full-length to end Wasim's stay at the crease with a spectacular one-handed catch.

For all the excitement in the game and, as is traditional, with greatest attendance in St John's coming on Sunday, the ground was never close to even half-full. Ticket prices, though they have risen only for the weekend, have been considered high and Antiguans, who are passionate about their cricket even by West Indian standards, have voted with their feet rather than their wallets.

 Inzamam-ul-Haq has been fined 50% of his match fee by the referee Peter Burge of Australia for lingering too long after being given out caught behind in the second innings by the rookie umpire Billy Doctrove of Dominica.

webTitle: The morning call has had its day

fields.headline: The morning call has had its day
fields.standfirst: There were no surprises - for players or fans - in the squad for Trent Bridge
fields.trailText: This week's second test squad has been named, and much to Mike Selvey chagrin, even the naming of the team has become a dull affair.
fields.body:
For the great majority of the 400-odd professional cricketers plying their trade in this country, one of the game's great institutions was abandoned on the day last February when a dozen players were announced as having been offered England contracts.

No more suspense at 11 o'clock on a Sunday morning when the squad for a test the following week was made public, no more waiting to see if the phone would ring and the chairman of selectors offer his congratulations and no more smart-arse dressing-room upstart commiserating with an old stager given the heave-ho by piping up that he too had not been selected and that the chairman had not bothered to ring him either.

The announcement is done differently now as well. For the first test, David Graveney drove all the way up to Headingley to make his predictable announcement on Channel 4's Saturday morning magazine programme, whereupon the presenter Mark Nicholas, rather than the chairman, promptly phoned one of the new boys, Steve Harmison, announcing each digit as he dialled it, so that watching hacks who had been after the number for weeks without success were able to stick it into their contacts book.

Yesterday, for the benefit of Sky Sports, Graveney was closer to home at Gloucestershire's waterlogged ground in Bristol, but after the comprehensive shafting of Zimbabwe at Lord's the message was much the same.

The selectors had conversed by phone and the only resulting change was the enforced absence of Craig White, who suffered a blackout while walking in Scarborough last week and has undergone tests both to heart and brain. The results have not yet come back and White in any case has been ordered to rest for seven days. For this week's test at Trent Bridge he has not been replaced.

The only speculation then will be whether the same XI takes the field, or whether Harmison gets a game at the expense of Chris Schofield, who, because of the outstanding performance by the England seamers, did not get a bowl at Lord's.

Preparation of the pitch in Nottingham will have been hindered by the weather and the same damp conditions might reasonably be expected to apply: it will be another seam-dominated affair. Schofield will almost certainly be retained though for reasons of balance, and as an old-fashioned insurance policy.

One of the big points of central contracts is the continuity they should bring, with the selectors, for the first time ever, having put their judgment on the line with, in theory, no recourse to the chopping and changing of old.

Using a large number of players is not a recent phenomenon. In 1921, 30 players were used in five tests against Australia, 25 played during the four tests against West Indies in 1950 and 28 in 1988, when five matches were played against West Indies and one against Sri Lanka. Currently there are 67 players with England test caps registered for county cricket of whom 30 have fewer than five caps.

However, any hopes of England powering their way through this summer with the same group were shattered almost from the word go when Dean Headley's back failed him again and Michael Vaughan's finger was shattered.

Headley will not play again this summer, which would make him doubtful, presumably, for the first tour of the winter (to Pakistan, where his ability to reverse-swing the old ball would be invaluable), and although Vaughan should be batting for Yorkshire again soon, he has been overtaken by Nick Knight's moderate success at Lord's.

With White now crocked, 25% of those contracted are currently ineligible. By and large the system, which lends security to those chosen and additional incentive to the rest, would seem to be a good thing. Darren Gough and Andy Caddick, for example, will be roaring in on Thursday having endured neither arduous county matches between tests nor the frustration of watching the rain.

However, when injuries begin to bite and contracted players begin to show loss of form, then once more the pressure for a quick fix will mount on the selectors. The key to it then will be just how long they can hold on to their principles and their nerve.

England squad: * Hussain (Essex), Atherton (Lancashire), Ramprakash (Middlesex), Hick (Worcestershire), Stewart (Surrey), Knight (Warwickshire), Flintoff (Lancashire), Schofield (Lancashire), Caddick (Somerset), Gough (Yorkshire), Giddins (Warwickshire), Harmison (Durham).
fields.bodyText: For the great majority of the 400-odd professional cricketers plying their trade in this country, one of the game's great institutions was abandoned on the day last February when a dozen players were announced as having been offered England contracts. No more suspense at 11 o'clock on a Sunday morning when the squad for a test the following week was made public, no more waiting to see if the phone would ring and the chairman of selectors offer his congratulations and no more smart-arse dressing-room upstart commiserating with an old stager given the heave-ho by piping up that he too had not been selected and that the chairman had not bothered to ring him either. The announcement is done differently now as well. For the first test, David Graveney drove all the way up to Headingley to make his predictable announcement on Channel 4's Saturday morning magazine programme, whereupon the presenter Mark Nicholas, rather than the chairman, promptly phoned one of the new boys, Steve Harmison, announcing each digit as he dialled it, so that watching hacks who had been after the number for weeks without success were able to stick it into their contacts book. Yesterday, for the benefit of Sky Sports, Graveney was closer to home at Gloucestershire's waterlogged ground in Bristol, but after the comprehensive shafting of Zimbabwe at Lord's the message was much the same. The selectors had conversed by phone and the only resulting change was the enforced absence of Craig White, who suffered a blackout while walking in Scarborough last week and has undergone tests both to heart and brain. The results have not yet come back and White in any case has been ordered to rest for seven days. For this week's test at Trent Bridge he has not been replaced. The only speculation then will be whether the same XI takes the field, or whether Harmison gets a game at the expense of Chris Schofield, who, because of the outstanding performance by the England seamers, did not get a bowl at Lord's. Preparation of the pitch in Nottingham will have been hindered by the weather and the same damp conditions might reasonably be expected to apply: it will be another seam-dominated affair. Schofield will almost certainly be retained though for reasons of balance, and as an old-fashioned insurance policy. One of the big points of central contracts is the continuity they should bring, with the selectors, for the first time ever, having put their judgment on the line with, in theory, no recourse to the chopping and changing of old. Using a large number of players is not a recent phenomenon. In 1921, 30 players were used in five tests against Australia, 25 played during the four tests against West Indies in 1950 and 28 in 1988, when five matches were played against West Indies and one against Sri Lanka. Currently there are 67 players with England test caps registered for county cricket of whom 30 have fewer than five caps. However, any hopes of England powering their way through this summer with the same group were shattered almost from the word go when Dean Headley's back failed him again and Michael Vaughan's finger was shattered. Headley will not play again this summer, which would make him doubtful, presumably, for the first tour of the winter (to Pakistan, where his ability to reverse-swing the old ball would be invaluable), and although Vaughan should be batting for Yorkshire again soon, he has been overtaken by Nick Knight's moderate success at Lord's. With White now crocked, 25% of those contracted are currently ineligible. By and large the system, which lends security to those chosen and additional incentive to the rest, would seem to be a good thing. Darren Gough and Andy Caddick, for example, will be roaring in on Thursday having endured neither arduous county matches between tests nor the frustration of watching the rain. However, when injuries begin to bite and contracted players begin to show loss of form, then once more the pressure for a quick fix will mount on the selectors. fields.headline: Worcs go clear on top
fields.trailText: Worcestershire took a clear lead in the First Division of the National League by beating Northamptonshire by 47 runs in a rain-affected match at New Road yesterday.
fields.body:
Worcestershire, the runners-up to Lancashire last season, took a clear lead in the First Division of the National League by beating Northamptonshire by 47 runs in a rain-affected match at New Road yesterday.

Paul Pollard made 89 from 90 balls in a 34-over total of 207 for four, then Glenn McGrath took two wickets in successive balls as the visitors lurched to 133 for nine after being set a new target of 181 in 27 overs.

Pollard's highest score in all competitions for his new county set a tempo of six runs an over in a string of good partnerships against a disappointing attack.

For Northamptonshire the National League season is already beginning to look bleak after a fourth consecutive defeat.

 John Morris hit 73 against his former club Durham at Chester-le-Street as Nottinghamshire maintained their 100% record in the Second Division.

He also held on to a stinging pull at mid-wicket to remove Simon Katich for 45 when Durham needed 66 off 10 overs with seven wickets left.

Durham, seeking their first win of the season in this competition, were always ahead of the rate until Katich was out. Paul Franks then took three wickets in the penultimate over to finish with a career-best six for 27 as Nottinghamshire won by three runs under the Duckworth-Lewis method.

Durham finished on 190 for eight after rain had given them a revised target of 194 off 43 overs. Nottinghamshire had made 199 for six.

fields.headline: Maynard gives Glamorgan final shot
fields.standfirst:
Glamorgan 251
Surrey 212
Glamorgan win by 32 runs on the Duckworth-Lewis method
fields.trailText: Surrey v Glamorgan
fields.body:
Matthew Maynard's relationship with the Sophia Gardens crowd retreated from affection last summer. A group of insensitive supporters turned on him after a sorry performance by Glamorgan in the NatWest quarter-finals. He was close to walking away from the captaincy, watching in dismay as the county's flag was damaged in an abrasive, if unrepresentative, demonstration. Yesterday, on this same ground, he was embraced.

His hundred, full of nimble footwork and neat, delicate strokes, pointed Glamorgan to their first final appearance at Lord's since 1977. Along with Durham, they are the only county never to have won a limited-overs final there.

There was really no other candidate for the match award except Maynard, but Alec Stewart might have challenged with better support.

That Glamorgan were all out for 251 was attributable to the kamikaze inclinations of the late batsmen. Seven wickets went for 25, the last four for a single run. Four players were run out in indecent procession, almost as if they felt they could hardly wait to get at Surrey. That is a charitable view.

Just as well Maynard and Michael Powell played so well. The small, calculative skipper plonked one six over long-on, then was caught a yard inside the fence, in the same area, off Adam Hollioake.

Powell is one to watch. He is sturdily built with a penchant for on-side drives. The 200 on his debut, even at Oxford, was no fluke. He was out yesterday in an over of painful endeavour after an unfriendly delivery from Alex Tudor led to an enforced change of box. The replacement must have felt like an unfamiliar piece of furniture, for he was rapidly bowled.

Surrey's reply was given a bad start when Alistair Brown was taken brilliantly, low down at short midwicket by Matthew Elliott off Owen Parkin - who then had the promoted Tudor dismissed first ball. He was adjudged lbw, but was pointedly looking at his bat as he trudged back.

There were realistic hopes for Surrey as Mark Butcher and Stewart appeared to be building a stand in their own time. But by the 19th over, Robert Croft had joined the attack, full of absorbing variations and some unlikely physical innovations - as if he felt it was no day for the orthodox. At once he had Butcher superbly stumped, although the decision needed the verdict of the third umpire.

Surrey's requirements now rested with Stewart and Graham Thorpe, who quickly carted Croft straight for six. But by now rain clouds, which had limited play on Saturday, were threatening again, and the batsmen could be seen doing their anxious Duckworth-Lewis calculations, an exercise that lost its thrust when Thorpe was immediately bowled by Alex Wharf, the Yorkshire exile now with his third county.

Wharf's elation could not be disguised as he went on to pin Adam Hollioake and have his brother well held at deep square leg.

There were other stops and a final revised target of 245. But Stewart was last out for 85, bravely supported in a late, vain assault by Jason Ratcliffe and Martin Bicknell.

The fielding had been agile by both teams on the slippery surface. Typical were the late crucial catches by Steve James as Surrey attempted to mock the earlier predictions.

webTitle: Sullivan determined to displace Walker at Spurs

fields.headline: Sullivan determined to displace Walker at Spurs
fields.trailText: Neil Sullivan is determined to relegate the former England goalkeeper Ian Walker to the Tottenham bench after completing his move to White Hart Lane from Wimbledon on Saturday.
fields.body:
Neil Sullivan is determined to relegate the former England goalkeeper Ian Walker to the Tottenham bench after completing his move to White Hart Lane from Wimbledon on Saturday.

The Scotland international has joined Tottenham on a Bosman free transfer after the disappointment of relegation from the Premiership.

Sullivan said: "I want to be top choice - what's the point of me signing a contract to sit on the bench? I've been made no promises and I know if I let in goals I'll be out. But I hope I will be given the first chance.

"Ian will want my job and I want his. But I'm going there because I want to be the Tottenham goalkeeper. I had three or four offers from different clubs but Spurs were the ones who impressed me most and I can't wait to play for them next season."

The 30-year-old, thought to have signed a deal worth around £24,000 a week, insisted: "It looks like Tottenham are going places. They've just splashed out £11m on a striker and I want to be a part of it. By signing Sergei Rebrov and persuading Sol Campbell and Darren Anderton to stay, it looks like we can challenge next year."

Sullivan admits to a sense of sadness at leaving Wimbledon but is upset that fans have accused him of disloyalty at deciding to quit Selhurst Park.

"I'm 30 and as much as I love Wimbledon, I couldn't turn down a big club for them," he added. "I had been at Wimbledon for 16 years and given them everything. It's a kick up the backside in a way because I'll be in a good team full of ambition and potential."

Ugo Ehiogu is ready to turn his back on Aston Villa after nine years to stimulate his career and raise his chances of playing for England. He also revealed a growing personal rift with John Gregory, which began when the manager suggested the defender was making too much of an injury.

Ehiogu said: "I feel whatever I do goes unnoticed. It's something I have detected for quite a while. The manager doesn't talk to me too much and show his appreciation for me in the way he does for others. He can bear grudges."

webTitle: Owen: 'I aim to be a world beater'

fields.headline: Owen: 'I aim to be a world beater'
fields.trailText: On Saturday Michael Owen scored a well-worked goal but more importantly confirmed his return to sharpness after 18 months dogged by an injury that at one time threatened his burgeoning career.
fields.body:
The weather could not make up its mind if it wanted to rain or shine on Saturday. Kevin Keegan knows the feeling. He could not decide if the draw against Brazil clouded the selection issues or clarified them.

On the one hand there are concerns about the form of David Seaman, the Neville brothers and Sol Campbell. Plus there is still confusion over who should play on the left and in central midfield.

Thank goodness one area of debate was illuminated: Alan Shearer and Michael Owen will definitely start up front in Euro 2000.

That, anyway, is the view of Robbie Fowler, who will get his own chance against Ukraine on Wednesday but is happy to accept that his is a fight for a place in the final 22, not the first XI.

"I think we know what Kevin Keegan's front two is going to be," said the Liverpool striker. "In my opinion it will be Shearer and Owen. They played very well as a pair against Brazil."

They did indeed, though it was Owen who monopolised the headlines, scoring a well-worked goal but more importantly confirming with his overall performance his return to sharpness after 18 months dogged by an injury that at one time threatened his burgeoning career.

The 20-year-old was prepared to say, with some hope of success: "I want to be the world's best goalscorer. You look at players in the Brazil side and you think, 'I want to be judged on a world scale like them'. "

Owen sees the forthcoming finals as another chance to impress the world - and possibly Europe's biggest clubs - with his fresh-faced talent.

"I don't want to be someone who sits on one thing the rest of my life," he said of the goal against Argentina two years ago that made him an international pin-up overnight. "I've done it once but I need to reproduce it again and again at this level. That's why I'm the first person to say I've still got things to improve in my game."

But he knows it would be fatal to change his game too much, especially if it disrupts that rare ability and courage he possesses to take defenders on.

"It's the only way I can play," he says. "If you take some parts of my game away I'm not going to be the same player. I can't go and play like Alan Shearer or Emile Heskey. Alan is almost twice my size and almost three stone heavier. He is a target man and I am about getting in behind defenders and using my pace."

However, Owen is still taking nothing for granted. "I've helped myself with my performance against Brazil, certainly," he says. "But there are still two games for a lot of people to stake their claim."

One of those people is Fowler, another Liverpool player whose season has been blighted by injury. Keegan named him in the 28 even though he was still not match-fit. But a rigorous training regime in the last few days has left the player confident he can repay his manager's faith.

"I agree when people ask 'Is he fit, can he handle the pace and pressure of such a tournament?'," admits Fowler. "There's a lot at stake. But I personally don't think it would be a gamble to take me to the finals. I think I would be match-fit."

Paul Ince needed to prove himself in a different way, and he made an impressive job of it on Saturday. "When I left Liverpool people thought I would never play for England again, that I was going to Middlesbrough to graze. And it hurt," he said. "That's why it's important for me to prove I've still got the hunger at 32. I love a challenge. I was asked to do a job and I thought I did it well."

Seaman was also reluctant to listen to his critics. Despite fears that he is not the player he was, he predicted: "This will not be my last tournament. I want to play in the next World Cup at least. I have no doubts about my fitness. I can go on for a long time."

He surely will not if he continues to misjudge crosses as he did on Saturday. But Seaman's role in Brazil's equaliser was strangely missing from his personal analysis of the goal: "The marking was bad and Gary Neville came off his post."

Those concerned about the Arsenal goalkeeper's growing inability to make snap judgments will also be worried by his final observation: "It all happened so quickly."

webTitle: Dave the deliverer prepares for lift-off

fields.headline: Dave the deliverer prepares for lift-off
fields.standfirst: Barnsley's manager reveals the secret of promotion
fields.trailText: According to received football wisdom, the Nationwide First Division is the hardest to escape from. Dave Bassett's nickname of Harry must be in recognition of his Houdini-like qualities, since he has picked the lock so many times that rivals must suspect he is in possession of a set of skeleton keys.
fields.body:
According to received football wisdom, the Nationwide First Division is the hardest to escape from, at least through the top exit. In which case, Dave Bassett's nickname of Harry must be in recognition of his Houdini-like qualities, since he has picked the lock so many times that rivals must suspect he is in possession of a set of skeleton keys.

The rich owners of clubs such as Wolves, Birmingham and Blackburn Rovers have thrown resources, money and managers at the problem and remain frustrated. Yet on budgets that barely made it to shoestring level, Bassett has brought up Wimbledon, Sheffield United and Nottingham Forest, twice doing it at the first attempt and in a slothful two seasons with the Dons.

Today he hopes to conclude his first season at Barnsley by beating Ipswich at Wembley and returning the Yorkshire side to the Premiership, which would register a record eighth personal promotion. The record would already be his but for a last-minute goal by Leicester's Steve Claridge which denied Crystal Palace in a play-off final four years ago.

Perhaps those chairmen should long ago have sent up the cry: "Bring me Harry Bassett." But the man himself admits that his alchemy does not come in a form that he could bottle.

"Just as everyone is looking for the elixir of life, so in football I suppose they're all looking for the formula for success," he says. "Some people probably think I've got an Aladdin's lamp which I rub at the start of the season and I wish I had. But if there is a key to it, I would say that it is in creating the right atmosphere for success at a club.

"That involves good man-management and having the right people around you. I can't say to you 'Do this or play that way and you'll be successful'. It is something from within me which helps me to create that atmosphere. I have had that at all my clubs, even though I've had sets of players with different personalities and I've played different systems.

"The one common thing is that they've all had that bit of belief, that fear about them, as well as anticipation and determination. Some of the management techniques are private to me. But I'm just Dave Bassett. I work the way I've always worked and don't try to be anyone else."

There is something of the Brian Clough method-in-his-madness about Bassett. Thus, Clough-like, when he first arrived at Barnsley, he not only ripped up the system of play, changing a 3-4-1-2 to a 4-4-2, but forced players to switch to positions they had never tried before. He likes, he says, to put players under pressure, to see if they are adaptable and to probe at their character.

The process is helped by the fact that, showing another Clough trait, Bassett has a tendency to keep re-signing the same players. Clough took John McGovern and John O'Hare from Derby to Forest and to Leeds, even though they were not highly rated by most top-class managers. In the same way, Bassett has taken the under-regarded Neil Shipperley from Palace to Forest and now Barnsley, and Geoff Thomas from Forest to Oakwell.

Bassett says: "I know how those players work and I know their character. So what is the point of taking a chance on someone you think is similar but whose character you don't know?"

Clough would also have approved of Bassett's daring at St Andrew's in the first leg of the play-off semi-final against Birmingham, sending out his team to play 3-4-1-2 again and so confusing the opposing manager Trevor Francis that, by the time he had adjusted, his side were two goals down and on the way to a 4-0 humiliation.

It was such a brilliant wrong-footing move that George Burley, 150 miles away in Ipswich, also found himself caught on the hop, left wondering what formation Barnsley would favour today. Bassett had a gleam in his eye when he said: "George will just have to wait and see, won't he."

So, you feel, will his players. That is the Bassett-Clough way. Keep them on their toes, keep them guessing, do not allow anyone to believe that their spot in the team is a sinecure.

If Barnsley make it this afternoon, Bassett is under no illusions about what awaits the club in the Premiership: a season-long battle against relegation, although sometimes, he says, players can surprise you. Wimbledon, long odds-on to go down when they came up in 1986, finished sixth that season and survived another 13 years.

Bassett describes himself as "too much of a rough diamond" to be trusted with millions at a glamorous club, though he did turn down both Chelsea and Aston Villa while manager of Sheffield United. Two years ago, he also got to play a fantasy role as a big-spending manager for six months when Sir Alex Ferguson gave him a scouting job.

"All of a sudden, I was watching players I never thought I'd go to see at Monaco, Marseille, Bayern Munich and Juventus and deciding whether they were good enough for Manchester United to pay seven or eight million for," he says. "Naturally, when I came here, that file wasn't much good to me."

He may get half a shoelace to strengthen Barnsley in the summer but if they are back in the Premiership, we can be certain of one thing. They will not be going to Old Trafford, Highbury and Anfield as tourists this time. They will, says Bassett euphemistically, be approaching it slightly differently.

Probable teams:
Ipswich Town (3-5-2): Wright; Brown, Mowbray, Venus; Croft, Magilton, Holland, Scowcroft, Clapham; Johnson, Stewart.

Barnsley (3-4-1-2): Miller; Morgan, Chettle, Brown; Eaden, Appleby, Tinkler, Barnard; Hignett; Dyer, Shipperley.
fields.bodyText: According to received football wisdom, the Nationwide First Division is the hardest to escape from, at least through the top exit. In which case, Dave Bassett's nickname of Harry must be in recognition of his Houdini-like qualities, since he has picked the lock so many times that rivals must suspect he is in possession of a set of skeleton keys. The rich owners of clubs such as Wolves, Birmingham and Blackburn Rovers have thrown resources, money and managers at the problem and remain frustrated. Yet on budgets that barely made it to shoestring level, Bassett has brought up Wimbledon, Sheffield United and Nottingham Forest, twice doing it at the first attempt and in a slothful two seasons with the Dons. Today he hopes to conclude his first season at Barnsley by beating Ipswich at Wembley and returning the Yorkshire side to the Premiership, which would register a record eighth personal promotion. The record would already be his but for a last-minute goal by Leicester's Steve Claridge which denied Crystal Palace in a play-off final four years ago. Perhaps those chairmen should long ago have sent up the cry: "Bring me Harry Bassett." But the man himself admits that his alchemy does not come in a form that he could bottle. "Just as everyone is looking for the elixir of life, so in football I suppose they're all looking for the formula for success," he says. "Some people probably think I've got an Aladdin's lamp which I rub at the start of the season and I wish I had. But if there is a key to it, I would say that it is in creating the right atmosphere for success at a club. "That involves good man-management and having the right people around you. I can't say to you 'Do this or play that way and you'll be successful'. It is something from within me which helps me to create that atmosphere. I have had that at all my clubs, even though I've had sets of players with different personalities and I've played different systems. "The one common thing is that they've all had that bit of belief, that fear about them, as well as anticipation and determination. Some of the management techniques are private to me. But I'm just Dave Bassett. I work the way I've always worked and don't try to be anyone else." There is something of the Brian Clough method-in-his-madness about Bassett. Thus, Clough-like, when he first arrived at Barnsley, he not only ripped up the system of play, changing a 3-4-1-2 to a 4-4-2, but forced players to switch to positions they had never tried before. He likes, he says, to put players under pressure, to see if they are adaptable and to probe at their character. The process is helped by the fact that, showing another Clough trait, Bassett has a tendency to keep re-signing the same players. Clough took John McGovern and John O'Hare from Derby to Forest and to Leeds, even though they were not highly rated by most top-class managers. In the same way, Bassett has taken the under-regarded Neil Shipperley from Palace to Forest and now Barnsley, and Geoff Thomas from Forest to Oakwell. Bassett says: "I know how those players work and I know their character. So what is the point of taking a chance on someone you think is similar but whose character you don't know?" Clough would also have approved of Bassett's daring at St Andrew's in the first leg of the play-off semi-final against Birmingham, sending out his team to play 3-4-1-2 again and so confusing the opposing manager Trevor Francis that, by the time he had adjusted, his side were two goals down and on the way to a 4-0 humiliation. It was such a brilliant wrong-footing move that George Burley, 150 miles away in Ipswich, also found himself caught on the hop, left wondering what formation Barnsley would favour today. Bassett had a gleam in his eye when he said: "George will just have to wait and see, won't he." So, you feel, will his players. That is the Bassett-Clough way. Keep them on their toes, keep them guessing, do not allow anyone to believe that their spot in the team is a sinecure. If Barnsley make it this afternoon, Bassett is under no illusions about what awaits the club in the Premiership: a season-long battle against relegation, although sometimes, he says, players can surprise you. Wimbledon, long odds-on to go down when they came up in 1986, finished sixth that season and survived another 13 years. Bassett describes himself as "too much of a rough diamond" to be trusted with millions at a glamorous club, though he did turn down both Chelsea and Aston Villa while manager of Sheffield United. Two years ago, he also got to play a fantasy role as a big-spending manager for six months when Sir Alex Ferguson gave him a scouting job. "All of a sudden, I was watching players I never thought I'd go to see at Monaco, Marseille, Bayern Munich and Juventus and deciding whether they were good enough for Manchester United to pay seven or eight million for," he says. "Naturally, when I came here, that file wasn't much good to me." He may get half a shoelace to strengthen Barnsley in the summer but if they are back in the Premiership, we can be certain of one thing. They will not be going to Old Trafford, Highbury and Anfield as tourists this time. They will, says Bassett euphemistically, be approaching it slightly differently. webTitle: Aberdeen suffer with the luck of Leighton

fields.headline: Aberdeen suffer with the luck of Leighton
fields.standfirst:
Aberdeen 0
Rangers 4
Van Bronckhorst 35, Vidmar 47, Dodds 49, Albertz 50
fields.trailText: Aberdeen 0 - 4 Rangers
fields.body:
Rangers won their 29th Scottish Cup - and their 100th major trophy, according to fatigued historians who have had trouble totting them all up - but Scottish football's showpiece event was marred by a fractured jaw and smashed teeth left scattered around a goalmouth.

The painful departure of Jim Leighton, Aberdeen's ageing goalkeeper, supposedly playing his last senior match, was in keeping with the rest of his storm-tossed career. Scottish newspapers all week had been bursting with exhausting paeans to this last great stand by the bandy-legged trooper, two months shy of his 42nd birthday.

In the end, poor Leighton hardly had time to spit into his hands and rub them together: with not yet two minutes gone on Saturday he was entangled in an innocent collision with Rod Wallace, leaving the goalkeeper in agony with blood all over his face.

Only upon this gnarled survivor could such a fate have been visited. Starting from his early glories with Aberdeen, through fall-outs with Alex Ferguson at Manchester United, being dumped from a poor Dundee team and then finding restoration with Hibs, Leighton has endured every taunt and torment in a 23-year career. As a Scottish goalkeeper of famed stereotype, making great saves but also dropping clangers, he has even added to his legend by revealing that his eyesight is so poor that he requires contact lenses in goal.

Leighton is expected to leave hospital today, after an operation on his double fracture of the jaw described by his club as "100% successful". And he may not be finished just yet. Another aspect of his career has been his ability to deny every death warrant and just when everyone thought Leighton's gloves would be stowed away, Ebbe Skovdahl, Aberdeen's ravaged manager, suggested there might be more. "Jim was going to retire and start coaching with us," said Skovdahl. "But now we will offer him a new playing contract for six months."

In a match that from the outset was glaringly unbalanced by the gulf in the quality of these teams, Leighton's early departure only reduced the spectacle. Rangers had finished top and Aberdeen bottom of the Scottish Premier League with 57 points and 109 goals between them. So then what? The cup could have offered redemption to Aberdeen, but they had to play 88 minutes with a striker in goal.

Poor Skovdahl had chosen not to select a goalkeeper among his three substitutes, although to prevent other managers being thrown into his plight in future, the Scottish Football Association will this week discuss proposals to increase the number of substitutes in the cup to five from next season.

On came Robbie Winters, just 5ft 9in and a player who, since his transfer from Dundee United to Aberdeen two seasons ago, has forgotten how to score goals, let alone stop them. Rangers proceeded to whack shots past him like Scud missiles.

In the 35th minute, Giovanni van Bronckhorst rushed through to meet Jörg Albertz's clever free-kick and blast his shot past Winters. By the 47th minute, Tony Vidmar had made it two, lofting his left-foot shot high past the striker. A Billy Dodds header and an Albertz drive from 25 yards, so fast and venomous that Winters seemed to cower out of the way, completed this rout.

Aberdeen (4-5-1): Leighton (Winters, 2min); Anderson (Belabed, 31), Solberg, Whyte, McAllister; Guntveit, Rowson, Jess, Bernard, Dow; Stavrum.

Rangers (4-4-2): Klos; Reyna, Moore (Porrini, 71), Vidmar, Numan; Kanchelskis, Ferguson, Van Bronckhorst, Albertz; Dodds, Wallace (McCann, 67).

Referee: Jim McCluskey (Scotland).

webTitle: Gills save their best for last

fields.headline: Gills save their best for last
fields.standfirst:
Wigan 2
Haworth 52
Barlow 99pen
Gillingham 3
McGibbon 35og
Butler 114
Thomson 118
After extra-time: 1-1 at 90 minutes
fields.trailText: Wigan 2 - 3 Gillingham
fields.body:
The septuagenarian Gillingham supporter in Australia who planned to phone a Kent radio station and listen to live commentary of this match certainly got his money's worth. If celebrations down under were otherwise muted, there was no mistaking the joy among his 50,000 fellow fans here.

With seven minutes of extra-time remaining, Gillingham were heading for defeat by a 10-man Wigan. But headers by Steve Butler and Andy Thomson changed all that. A year ago Gillingham were heartbroken as Manchester City scored two late goals and beat them on penalties. This time it was their turn to turn a final on its head and secure promotion to the First Division.

As Wigan's players sunk to the turf in disbelief, Gillingham's danced around as if they had not only taken the club to unprecedented heights but also won millions in the lottery. "At 2-1 down I thought it was Wigan's day," the manager Peter Taylor admitted, dripping wet after being pushed into the bath by his squad.

"But the players have this inner strength. They never know when they are beaten. They deserve this, especially those who were here last year."

Few could begrudge Taylor this success, having guided the team to third place in his first term. But Wigan will reflect angrily on the officials' failure to spot that Arjan de Zeeuw's header in the 65th minute, with the score 1-1, had crossed the line. "It was well over," said their manager John Benson. "You feel a bit cheated."

Yet Benson can take pride from his team's contribution to a thrilling match, full of chances, neat football and controversy. Even Taylor admitted Wigan were the better side, and much of their passing play was impressive. But in Andy Hessenthaler, Gillingham had the outstanding performer.

He was involved in the opening goal, finding Carl Asaba, whose low cross was diverted past his own goalkeeper by the sliding Pat McGibbon. De Zeeuw, ironically, just failed to clear off the line.

By then Andy Liddell had hit the bar for Wigan and they deserved their equaliser through a stunning strike from Simon Haworth. After flicking up a De Zeeuw cross with his left boot, he used the outside of his right to volley over Vince Bartram and into the far corner.

When De Zeeuw was denied his "goal", Wigan might have felt it was not their day. That seemed to be confirmed when Kevin Sharp was sent off in the 86th minute for a second booking, a foul on Nicky Southall which followed a caution for dissent.

Stuart Barlow made nonsense of that idea, slotting in a 99th-minute penalty after Barry Ashby had fouled Darren Sheridan. But then Gillingham, courtesy of two substitutes, stirred.

The 38-year-old player-coach Butler delivered the equaliser, heading in from Junior Lewis' cross. And then Ty Gooden's centre was met at the near post by a flying Thomson. He cost £25,000. This week Taylor hopes to agree a new contract, but there will have to be a lot more money to spend than that. For now, though, such concerns can wait.

Gillingham (3-5-2): Bartram; Ashby (Butler, 104min), Pennock, Butters; Southall, Hessenthaler, Lewis, Gooden, Edge (Smith, 61); Onuora (Thomson, 97), Asaba.

Wigan Athletic (3-5-2): Stillie; McGibbon, Balmer, De Zeeuw; Green, Redfearn (Barlow, 84), Kilford, Kilford, Sharp; Liddell (Bradshaw, 104), Haworth (Peron, 105).

Referee: R Styles (Waterlooville).

webTitle: O'Neill to join Celtic this week

fields.headline: O'Neill to join Celtic this week
fields.trailText: On Saturday Martin O'Neill officially opened negotiations with the Scottish Premier League club. It would now appear that the 47-year-old Irishman will shortly fulfil his ambition of assuming control at the club he supported throughout his childhood.
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill yesterday appeared to be on the brink of confirming his move from Leicester City to Celtic. It would now take the sort of 11th-hour change of heart which has, in truth, characterised his career in recent seasons to extend his stay at Filbert Street.

After more than a week of rumour and denial, speculation moved to the verge of becoming hard fact on Saturday when O'Neill officially opened negotiations with the Scottish Premier League club.

Although the Leicester board remains optimistic that O'Neill will remain loyal to the club he has almost single-handedly moved from the hard shoulder into football's fast lane, it would now appear that the 47-year-old Irishman will shortly fulfil his ambition of assuming control at the club he supported throughout his childhood.

John Elsom, the Leicester chairman, spoke at length to several of his directorial colleagues yesterday, the likelihood being that he was discussing not the bank holiday weather but the rather gloomy prospect of finding a new manager.

O'Neill met with Celtic officials early on Saturday, when he was offered a contract valued at £2million a year. If he does become Celtic's fifth full-time manager in less than three years, following in the footsteps of Tommy Burns, Wim Jansen, Joseph Venglos and John Barnes, Kenny Dalglish, caretaker manager at Parkhead since Barnes's dismissal three months ago, will probably leave with a handsome pay-off so that O'Neill can be given full control over coaching and player recruitment.

Unfortunately for Leicester, O'Neill would not hesitate to take some of Leicester's best players with him from Filbert Street, with the midfielder Neil Lennon and the Scottish international defender Matt Elliott likely to figure prominently on his wish list. It is believed that O'Neill has been promised a budget well in excess of £15m to fund his attempt to end Rangers' domination of Scottish football.

O'Neill has told Celtic that he wishes to bring his own back-room staff with him, something which could present a problem as neither John Robertson, his current assistant manager, nor Steve Walford, Leicester's first-team coach, have in their contracts the sort of escape clause that their manager has now used to his advantage.

Fully aware that O'Neill has a track-record of confusing and unexpected changes of mind, Celtic would like to complete a deal within the next 72 hours. In the last two years O'Neill has turned down the chance to manage both Everton and Leeds United after initially indicating that he was ready to leave Filbert Street.

If O'Neill does finally sever his Leicester ties after four-and-a-half eventful years, the news of a managerial vacancy in the Premiership will most certainly interest Joe Kinnear, who is expected to announce tomorrow whether he intends to succeed Danny Wilson at Sheffield Wednesday.

webTitle: Defiant but dull England live on hope

fields.headline: Defiant but dull England live on hope
fields.standfirst:
England 1 Owen 38
Brazil 1 Franca 45
Observer match report
England man-by-man ratings
Comment: Ian Ridley
fields.trailText: England 1 - 1 Brazil
fields.body:
Perhaps England ought to reconsider the choice of Jerusalem as their theme song for Euro 2000. Surely they should be departing for Belgium on Thursday week to the strains of It's A Long Way To Tipperary.

For the BEF, which in this case means the Best England can Field, there is indeed a long, long way to go and one can only hope that the casualty list among reputations will be lighter than those of previous European Championships abroad.

As Saturday's mildly encouraging draw with Brazil showed, Kevin Keegan's expeditionary force will go into the tournament equipped with the traditional English virtues of advancing in straight lines with bayonets fixed and, when necessary, defending stubbornly with their backs to the wall.

There was, however, a depressing lack of the qualities needed to make significant progress at this level of international competition. Too much of the passing was predictable and after a promising start too much of the movement unimaginative. The defence hardly played a decent ball from the back all afternoon and as attacking full-backs the brothers Gary and Phil Neville achieved about as much penetration as Tweedledum and Tweedledee.

England took the lead with an exceptionally good goal, only to lose it seven minutes later by conceding an exceptionally dumb one. Michael Owen, the scorer, re-established himself as the most likely partner for Alan Shearer but the position of Sol Campbell, the principal culprit when Brazil equalised, alongside Tony Adams at centre-back may now be under threat from Martin Keown.

Certainly Keegan will seek an improved performance all round when England return on Wednesday to play Ukraine, after which he will announce his squad of 22 for Euro 2000. "It was a good display today," he said, "but there will be games when we need to play a lot better. I was more pleased with the performance against Argentina."

Two of those who will miss the cut on Wednesday night have more or less been decided by injuries. Ray Parlour limped out of the Brazil match in stoppage time with damaged knee ligaments and Jamie Redknapp was already struggling with a knee problem.

Andy Cole has reported fit after seeing a specialist about a toe injury, although on Wednesday Keegan will be more keen on sizing up the chances of Robbie Fowler, his only striker with a natural left foot. "Robbie doesn't have to prove to me that he can get through 90 minutes," Keegan explained, "but I am thinking about starting him against the Ukraine."

England's best player on Saturday was Paul Ince, who before collecting a painful set of studs from Amoroso early in the second half made a powerful case for being used as the anchor man in midfield. Once Ince left on the hour, with David Beckham moving fruitlessly to the middle, England lost their balance and Brazil kept the ball.

England's best period in the game was brief but exuberant and followed a well-worked goal after 38 minutes. From Gary Neville's throw Beckham headed the ball on to Shearer, who chested it down and found Owen in a gap. Owen's drag-back had Ze Roberto lunging at thin air and the Liverpool striker calmly beat Dida from close range.

Earlier headers from Keown and Shearer, each set up by Beckham's free-kicks, had tested the Brazilian goalkeeper and punctuated the period when England were under greatest pressure. Paul Scholes, told to sit tight in midfield, was swamped by Brazilian movement as Emerson, Ze Roberto and Rivaldo exploited the space around him.

Perhaps England should have been grateful that this was one of those friendlies when Brazil were content to go on manoeuvres while preserving their ammunition. Their corners, crosses and final passes often lacked the precision of their passing and when they did score in first-half stoppage time it was almost by accident.

Seaman came blindly for Rivaldo's corner and Campbell missed it. The ball fell to Franca, who headed in on the bounce at the far post despite the presence of Gary Neville, who should not have allowed it to slip past him. Keegan described the goal as "very sloppy".

More problematic will be the knowledge that even when Adams, who will not be risked against Ukraine if his back is still aching, returns none of England's defenders will bring the ball out from the back with ease or pass it with any great perception.

"The defence's use of the ball was disappointing," Keegan admitted. "More than anything their selection of passes was wrong. Brazil were crowding the midfield waiting to win the ball in areas where they could cause us problems. We needed the vision to see that."

Ah vision, a word often mentioned when Paul Gascoigne was in his brief prime and before him Peter Beardsley, Trevor Brooking and a busy little man called Kevin Keegan. Perhaps Steve McManaman will bring this quality to Wembley on Wednesday, but his game is more about pace and aggression than stealth and subtlety.

Keegan's BEF will wear its heart on its sleeve - but inside said sleeve there are as yet few tricks to surprise Euro 2000.

England's best player on Saturday was Paul Ince, who before collecting a painful set of studs from Amoroso early in the second half made a powerful case for being used as the anchor man in midfield. Once Ince left on the hour, with David Beckham moving fruitlessly to the middle, England lost their balance and Brazil kept the ball. England's best period in the game was brief but exuberant and followed a well-worked goal after 38 minutes. From Gary Neville's throw Beckham headed the ball on to Shearer, who chested it down and found Owen in a gap. Owen's drag-back had Ze Roberto lunging at thin air and the Liverpool striker calmly beat Dida from close range. Earlier headers from Keown and Shearer, each set up by Beckham's free-kicks, had tested the Brazilian goalkeeper and punctuated the period when England were under greatest pressure. Paul Scholes, told to sit tight in midfield, was swamped by Brazilian movement as Emerson, Ze Roberto and Rivaldo exploited the space around him. Perhaps England should have been grateful that this was one of those friendlies when Brazil were content to go on manoeuvres while preserving their ammunition. Their corners, crosses and final passes often lacked the precision of their passing and when they did score in first-half stoppage time it was almost by accident. Seaman came blindly for Rivaldo's corner and Campbell missed it. The ball fell to Franca, who headed in on the bounce at the far post despite the presence of Gary Neville, who should not have allowed it to slip past him. Keegan described the goal as "very sloppy". More problematic will be the knowledge that even when Adams, who will not be risked against Ukraine if his back is still aching, returns none of England's defenders will bring the ball out from the back with ease or pass it with any great perception. "The defence's use of the ball was disappointing," Keegan admitted. "More than anything their selection of passes was wrong. Brazil were crowding the midfield waiting to win the ball in areas where they could cause us problems. We needed the vision to see that." Ah vision, a word often mentioned when Paul Gascoigne was in his brief prime and before him Peter Beardsley, Trevor Brooking and a busy little man called Kevin Keegan. Perhaps Steve McManaman will bring this quality to Wembley on Wednesday, but his game is more about pace and aggression than stealth and subtlety. Keegan's BEF will wear its heart on its sleeve - but inside said sleeve there are as yet few tricks to surprise Euro 2000.

fields.headline: How Keegan's men rated
fields.trailText: Martin Thorpe gives his marks out of ten for the side that faced Brazil on Saturday.
fields.body:
David Seaman

Doubts still persist about whether his talent is on the wane. Misjudgment on the cross contributed to Brazil's equaliser. Kicking erratic. 5/10

Gary Neville

Not as imposing as he used to be. Lost possession a few times. Strayed from his post, allowing Franca's header to squeeze in for Brazil's equaliser. 5

Martin Keown

Defensively solid throughout, strong in the air and on the ground. However, his distribution from the back still leaves a lot to be desired. 7

Sol Campbell

Some crucial interceptions, some uncharacteristic errors. Usually quick enough to recover the situation but lost his man for Brazil's goal. 5

Phil Neville

The jury is still out. He got forward well but too often lumped the long ball rather than spotting the more astute pass. 6

David Beckham

Great delivery from set plays, less impressive in open play, though he was involved in England's goal. Anonymous when moved into a central role on the hour. 6

Ceaseless running subdued Brazil's central threat but it stopped him making those characteristic runs into the opposing area. 7

Talents completely wasted on the left. Still did well, though every time he moved inside, England's attacking acquired vibrancy. 7

As good as the service he got, which dried up in the second half. Went close to scoring twice, laid on the pass for Owen's goal and foraged with determination. 7

Michael Owen

Back to form and full fitness. A lovely drag-back created his 38th-minute goal and had a great effort saved. Also won free-kicks in dangerous positions. 8

Not good enough for this level. 3; Robbie Fowler (84); Kevin Phillips (84); Nick Barmby (90).
