webTitle: England no match for Italy's superior style

fields.headline: England no match for Italy's superior style
fields.standfirst:
England U21 0
Italy U21 2
Comandini 24
Pirlo 45pen
fields.trailText: England U-21 0 - 2 Italy U-21
fields.body:
After their third defeat in four years at this level on Saturday, the England Under-21 side must immediately register their first win in their European Championship if they are to retain any hope of reaching Sunday's final.

Their failure to take the chances presented to them in their opening game, especially during a spell of domination early in the first half, ultimately cost them dear as the Italians responded with a performance that was nearly as sleek as their brand new Lycra shirts. But given that they started with 10 players from various Serie A clubs it was hardly surprising.

Yet England boasted exactly the same number of Premiership players - and the odd one out, Manchester City's Nicky Weaver, will be there next season - and while they retained most of the possession they were not as polished in front of goal as the men in blue.

England escaped a heavier beating only through the excellence of Weaver and some wasteful finishing late on by Italy, who are managed by their former World Cup-winning midfielder Marco Tardelli. In the end a well-taken headed goal by Gianni Comanbini after 24 minutes and a disputed penalty converted by Andrea Pirlo on the stroke of half-time - after a challenge by Jamie Carragher on Nicola Ventola - was enough to give Italy the three points.

Tardelli's English counterpart Howard Wilkinson must now raise his side's spirits before this evening's match against Turkey, who also need to win as they lost their opener against the Slovak hosts 2-1.

Tonight's game has been overshadowed by the recent violence between fans of English and Turkish clubs, and as a result Uefa has been extra vigilant in this tournament in trying to track the few fans of both countries who have made the trip to Eastern Europe. A Uefa spokesman has claimed that the supporters are being tracked as they arrive in the country and will be shepherded out of Slovakia when they leave.

But Wilkinson has simply concentrated on the task in hand. "We've got to go for the win and then we can worry about playing Slovakia on Thursday," he said. "The players were disappointed after Italy, but there were some players out there in new positions and for some of them by necessity it was a practice game."

Wilkinson has denied, however, that his captain Frank Lampard is all set to find himself installed in a new position - with the full England squad. With the injury that Jamie Redknapp picked up last week Lampard, who has one cap with the senior side, has been touted as a possible replacement in central midfield.

Wilkinson simply said there had been an exchange of messages between him and Kevin Keegan but no suggestion of Lampard returning to England in time for the friendly against Ukraine on Wednesday.

Lampard, 22 next month, claimed on Saturday to have not even heard of Redknapp's injury and was simply looking forward to ending this, his final involvement with the Under-21s, on as high a note as possible. He came close to scoring against Italy but close will not be good enough tonight if England are to have any more meaningful participation in this tournament.

England Under-21: Weaver (Manchester City); Mills (Leeds), Carragher (Liverpool), King (Tottenham), Thompson (Liverpool), Lampard (West Ham), Hendrie (Aston Villa; Dunn, Blackburn, h-t), Murphy (Liverpool), Johnson (Derby), Cort (Wimbledon; Jansen, Blackburn, 66min), Jeffers (Everton).

Italy Under-21: Abbiati; Grandoni, Zanchi, Cirillo, Gattuso (Perrotta, 87 ), Baronio, Zanetti, Coco, Pirlo, Ventola (Spinesi, 72 ), Comandini.

fields.headline: Dutch worry over Davids
fields.trailText: The tournament favourites' dynamic midfielder Edgar Davids will undergo surgery for an ingrowing toenail, but is still expected to be fit for the opening game.
fields.body:
Holland, assisted by a goal from Marc Overmars and a much-improved display from Dennis Bergkamp, beat Romania 2-1 in their last home friendly before co-hosting Euro 2000. But the tournament favourites suffered a blow the same day with their dynamic midfielder Edgar Davids having surgery for an ingrowing toenail.

The absence of Davids, who is not expected to be match fit for eight days, was not of great significance on Saturday night in a slow-paced warm-up against England's final Group A opponents.

Les Reed, one of the Football Association's observers, was in Amsterdam to monitor the Romanians before they meet Kevin Keegan's team in Charleroi on June 20.

But Emerich Jenei's side scarcely declared their hand, many of his players, among them Gheorghe Hagi, content to play only when the mood took them. Afterwards Jenei admitted that his team needed to improve in all areas but stressed they were reserving energy for the finals.

A long-range Overmars shot in the 43rd minute and an individualistic second-half goal by Patrick Kluivert gave Frank Rijkaard only his third win in 16 games as Dutch coach.

Romania exploited Dutch hesitation after 70 minutes. A Hagi free-kick was diverted by Viorel Moldovan's chest for their consolation goal.

In Oslo, Norway warmed up for Euro 2000 with goals from Manchester United's Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Tottenham's Steffen Iversen in the 2-0 win over Slovakia.

Solskjaer scored from a 21st-minute penalty and Iversen volleyed in the second goal from 16 yards after 84.

Norway's coach Nils Johan Semb, who names his squad today for their Group C campaign, said: "We'll have to play better when we face the likes of Spain and Yugoslavia."

In Spain, the stunning form of Real Madrid's teenage goal keeper Iker Casillas and Valencia's midfielder Gerard Lopez has prompted the national coach Jose Antonio Camacho to call up the two youngsters for Euro 2000.

Casillas, 19, and the midfielder Gerard, 20, were named after facing each other in Wednesday's European Cup final, won by Real, who have five players in the 22-man squad.

 Ryan Giggs has been ruled out of Wales's game in Portugal on Friday after a scan revealed a torn thigh. Wimbledon's defender Kenny Cunningham and Charlton's midfielder Mark Kinsella are injured and miss the Republic of Ireland's match with Scotland in Dublin tomorrow.

Spain squad: Goalkeepers: Canizares (Valencia), Casillas (Real Madrid), Molina (Atletico Madrid). Defenders: Abelardo (Barcelona), Engonga (Mallorca), Hierro (Real Madrid), Paco (Zaragoza), Aranzabal (Real Sociedad), Sergi (Barcelona), Velasco (Celta Vigo). Midfielders: Guardiola (Barcelona), Salgado, Helguera (both Real Madrid), Mendieta (Valencia), Fran (Deportivo La Coruna), Gerard (Valencia). Strikers: Raul (Real Madrid), Urzaiz, Exteberria (both Athletic Bilbao), Munitis (Racing Santander), Valeron (Atletico Madrid), Alfonso (Real Betis).

webTitle: Against Brazil, Paul Ince proved himself key to Kevin Keegan's Euro 2000 plans...

fields.headline: Against Brazil, Paul Ince proved himself key to Kevin Keegan's Euro 2000 plans...
fields.standfirst: ...but for these players, time is running out: It will be do or die against Ukraine.
fields.trailText: ...but for some other players, time is running out: It will be do or die against Ukraine, writes Richard Williams.
fields.body:
Paul Ince gave the Brazilians a few problems at Wembley on Saturday, but he may have given Kevin Keegan a bigger one.

Before he was substituted, an hour into the 1-1 draw that began England's three-match warm-up to Euro 2000, the 32-year-old Ince had provided the team's midfield with a sense of focus and purpose. When he departed, reluctantly, with an opponent's stud marks in his calf, those virtues disappeared with him, reawakening the debate over the formation that England will take into the tournament.

While the country was regretting Keegan's decision to postpone Steve McManaman's return until the match against the Ukraine on Wednesday, it was the other former Liverpool man, in his 49th appearance in an England shirt, who stepped in to make an unexpected impact on the pre-tournament campaign.

Ince captained England under Glenn Hoddle, but had seemed to be among the symbols of a receding era. He had last played for England in the dismal 1-0 defeat by Scotland at Wembley in last November's Euro 2000 play-off and might have expected to be among the six names omitted when the final 22 is announced later this week.

Instead he used the opportunity to confirm his ability to make a significant contribution to the squad, at least so long as Keegan persists in sending out a side to play in a 4-4-2 formation, with Ince as one of the central midfielders.

At a press conference in the days leading up to the Brazil match, Ince expressed his intention to make the cut with a quiet but impressive intensity.

"They tell me Incey's not as noisy as he was," Keegan said on Saturday, reflecting on the former captain's showing, "but I think his performance spoke volumes for him. He did everything we asked and more. His desperation to be a part of the squad hasn't surprised me, but it is very welcome.

"A lot of people have said that he won't be in the squad, and he's come back in later than some other players, but he's staked his claim. It was a difficult role for him today, because the Brazilians were moving all over the place. But he did it fantastically."

Ince's disciplined performance at the base of the midfield diamond earnt him warm praise, beginning with Keegan's reaction to a thunderous first-minute block on Emerson.

"I thought it was Sol Campbell," the coach declared. "I said, 'Well done, Sol.' But Arthur [Cox], whose eyes aren't the best, told me that it was Incey. People talk about great shots and great goals, but great tackles win matches too."

Yet Ince, whose combativeness has sometimes led him astray, never took it too far on Saturday, thanks to Keegan's advice. "I told him beforehand: 'I don't want you going all over the pitch fighting everyone else's battles. We've got other people now who have got the ability to do that. I want you to win your own.'

"I wasn't being unkind to him when I said that. It was just stating something that was obvious to me but maybe not obvious to him. In training he wanted to go and win that one over there, this one over here, and we were getting a little bit out of shape. But he did fantastically today."

His withdrawal, bearing the marks of Amoroso's boot, was at Keegan's insistence. "He didn't want to come off. But sometimes it's up to the coach to protect the player. Would there be any sense in leaving him on? I felt, looking at the injury, that if I left him on for another half-hour, what that could do to him might put him out of Euro 2000."

By making it clear that Ince has become a significant part of his planning for the tournament proper, Keegan's words also indicated to the remaining fringe players that it is not yet too late for them to claim a berth in the final selection. Wednesday night's candidates include Robbie Fowler, one of six strikers competing for five, or possibly four, places.

Only three - Alan Shearer, Emile Heskey and Michael Owen, the scorer of the goal against Brazil - are certain of inclusion after proving themselves capable of playing together in any combination. Fowler, a Keegan favourite whose domestic season was ruined by injury, came on for seven minutes as a substitute on Saturday, but will now be given an extended chance to show that he deserves a place at the expense of Andy Cole, whose injured toe has healed. Kevin Phillips, the Premiership's top scorer last season, may receive similar consideration.

The fringe players who will be hoping for a chance to make an impact against the Ukraine include Kieron Dyer, who was among Keegan's early enthusiasms, and Gareth Barry and Rio Ferdinand, either of whom would be useful additions if the coach decided to retain the option of the three-man defence that many still feel would best equip England to face the severest tests of the coming month.

Keegan would not rule out the possibility of trying a 3-5-2 alignment this week, and he will be obliged to find a way of answering the popular demand to integrate the fluid movement of the reborn Steve McManaman into the line-up.

McManaman will definitely play on Wednesday, although not necessarily in the problem position, wide on the left, which seemed to have been booked for him before his starring role in last week's European Cup final, and which Dennis Wise filled - to Keegan's expressed satisfaction - on Saturday.

"Anywhere I decide to pick Steve," Keegan said, "he'll add to what we're doing." How you take that depends on whether, after Saturday's enthusiastic but uneven performance, you see England's cup as half full or half empty.

webTitle: Doubtful Dravid flies back to a nation with plenty to prove

fields.headline: Doubtful Dravid flies back to a nation with plenty to prove
fields.trailText: On Saturday Rahul Dravid exchanged the heavy downpours of Kent for the torrential rain of Bangladesh when he flew to Dhaka to take part in the Asia Cup.
fields.body:
On Saturday Rahul Dravid exchanged the heavy downpours of Kent for the torrential rain of Bangladesh when he flew to Dhaka to take part in the Asia Cup.

It will be the first time he has played for India since the Hansie Cronje betting scandal questioned the integrity of cricket not only in his own country but throughout the world.

"I arrived in England to play for Kent a few weeks ago on the day the Cronje story was in all the papers," he said. "And I have not been home since, so I can only imagine what everyone is going through.

"I can honestly say no one has asked me to get involved in any betting situation. The difficult thing with all this is that no one really seems to know what is going on."

It is exactly such peripheral one-day tournaments as the one this stylish Indian batsman will be playing in over the next 12 days that have been blamed by many commentators for the rapid spread of the current match-fixing problem.

Dravid, 27, a graduate of Bangalore University, has been appointed vice-captain of India for the tournament and is seen as a prospective future captain.

"When we are playing we cannot bother our minds with what the spectators might be thinking," he said. "As long as we have a clear heart and a clear conscience we must play on and just hope the ICC succeeds in getting to the bottom of it.

"The Asia Cup is important to the India players because when we look back at last year's World Cup we clearly did not achieve what we might have, even though personally I had a very satisfying tournament."

Dravid was the leading run scorer in the World Cup, with 461, and also topped the tournament's averages with 65.85. With Sourav Ganguly, he shared a second-wicket stand of 318 against Sri Lanka at Taunton, setting a record for any wicket in one-day cricket.

"The Asia Cup will be quite competitive because this has not been a particulary good time for the teams involved. We all have something to prove."

webTitle: Cricket's credibility is on the line as never before as the Asia Cup gets under way

fields.headline: Cricket's credibility is on the line as never before as the Asia Cup gets under way
fields.trailText: Yesterday's scheduled opening match in the Asia Cup, between the Bangladesh and Sri Lanka, was washed away. These are not ideal conditions for cricket. But then these are not ideal times at all.
fields.body:
The monsoon has arrived early in Bangladesh. The streets have been submerged with water. Rickshaw drivers have found themselves sloshing through mini-lagoons. Above the Bangabandhu national stadium in Dhaka, the sky has been stormy and tumultuous, turning at dusk to pink-black. Down on the pitch, it is hot and crazily humid - and wet. Yesterday's scheduled opening match, between the home side and Sri Lanka, was washed away.

These are not ideal conditions for cricket. But then these are not ideal times at all.

It is against an unsettled and steamy backdrop that this seventh Asia Cup between India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka is trying to take place. It is the first test of subcontinental cricket since Hansie Cronje last month made a late-night confession to an evangelical pastor that he had been involved in match-fixing. Since then cricket's fortunes have sunk.

Over the past week in particular they have been falling especially fast: India's coach, Kapil Dev, has denied fresh claims by his former team-mate Manoj Prabhakar that he tried to bribe him to underperform in a match against Pakistan six years ago. "I will give him one on his jaw," Kapil said, shrugging off the suggestion he should withdraw from the Dhaka tournament. The allegations were "baseless and malicious". So far only one Indian player has supported Prabhakar's claim.

The Indian squad arrived yesterday to fresh allegations by Prabhakar. An undercover investigation, recorded on a secret camera and screened on Saturday, revealed senior Indian officials and players privately admitting that match-fixing was rife.

In Pakistan, the former national team captain Salim Malik and the all-rounder Ata-ur-Rehman were last week banned for life by the Pakistan board following the publication of judge Malik Qayyum's report into match-fixing. His conclusions were scathing. "Doubts of varying intensity have been cast on the integrity of some members of the team in their individual capacity," Qayyum found.

Six other players were censured or fined either for bringing the game into disrepute or failing to cooperate with the inquiry, including Wasim Akram, Waqar Younis, Inzamam-ul-Haq and Mushtaq Ahmed, all now due to return from Pakistan's tour of West Indies.

In previous years the Asia Cup has been a low-key affair. The one-day tournament, won by Sri Lanka when last held in 1997, had occupied a marginal place in the cricketing calendar. At various times in the past both India and Pakistan have declined to take part.

But this time things are different. The satellite channel Star TV has been pumping out trailers for the event in India. "It's all about honour," they point out. Seasoned cricket journalists who would normally be somewhere cooler are flying into Dhaka. And millions of ordinary Indian cricket fans are poised on their sofas, zappers ready, mildly depressed at the state of the game, but curiously expectant.

Even before last week's shattering developments, Indian cricket was in an unprecedented mess. Its ruling body, the Board of Cricket Control in India (BCCI), is at war with itself and busy fending off allegations of corruption.

Several other Indian players have come under suspicion besides Kapil. They include Mohammed Azharuddin, Ajay Jadeja and Nayan Mongia - all bar Mongia in the Asia Cup squad. No one could feel absolutely sure that the Indian squad is really interested in winning any more.

With a giant question mark hanging over the probity of the entire sport, most commentators expect the Asia Cup to be the most transparent tournament for years.

"I think there will be enormous pressure on the players to play to their full capacity. I would be surprised if the Asia Cup is anything other than clean," Harsha Bhogle, one of India's leading cricket commentators said yesterday. "There is no place for an innocent mistake at the moment, sadly. Everyone is watching," he added.

Other commentators agree. "It will be fascinating to see how the tournament unfolds," Pradeep Magazine, a cricket writer with the Indian Express, said. "The players will be under great pressure to play properly. If they drop an easy catch or are run out, questions will be asked."

"Enjoy it, for it'll be the first clean tournament for some time," Surjit Bhalla wrote in last week's Outlook, the Indian magazine that first accused Kapil of corruption.

Best behaviour

While the allegations of malpractice continue to swirl, the four teams involved in the Asia Cup are expected to be on their best behaviour. Bookmakers, who might normally congregate in the air-conditioned lobbies of Dhaka's Pan-Pacific and Sheraton hotels, where the players stay, are expected to be diplomatically absent. Over in the dressing rooms, the players will think twice before answering their mobiles.

But for the vast underground betting industry which flourishes from India to Pakistan and the Gulf, the Asia Cup is business as usual. No concrete steps have been taken against the bookies in the wake of the Cronje affair. A proposal that betting on cricket should be legalised was ruled out by the Indian prime minister Atal Behari Vajpayee. While scandal enveloped the South Africa cricket captain, a few bookmakers - principally in Bombay - vanished for a while. Now they are back, sources suggest.

Dr KK Paul, the head of Delhi police who released the Cronje tapes to an initially incredulous world audience, concedes as much. "Illegal betting is still alive. These people continue to operate surreptitiously. Betting has been going on for a long time. You have to remember that betting was going on well before match-fixing. I'm afraid we can't really say we have eliminated it."

Dr Paul's inquiry, meanwhile, is going nowhere. The South African authorities have failed to respond to requests for assistance, he says wearily.

Though the odds are a closely guarded - and fluctuating - secret, bets are already being taken on the Asia Cup. Sri Lanka, with their tremendous one-day reputation, appear to be the favourites, ahead of a shattered Indian team and a Pakistan side still reeling from Qayyum's report. The Bangladesh players will be hoping to consolidate their country's bid for full test status. The big question is whether the rain will hold off to allow any cricket to be played at all.

If previous betting patterns are anything to go by, Indian punters will not just bet on who will win the tournament. They will gamble on absolutely everything, including, for example, whether India will score above 100 in the first 15 overs, who wins the toss, the number of sixes and fours, man of the match, bowling order, the upshot of every ball, even the total number of wides.

"India have not played recently," said one source with contacts in the underworld. "People are itching to bet."

Naturally, the subcontinent's cricket officials are adamant that none of the seven scheduled matches will be, well, fixed. Syed Ashraful Haque, the secretary of the Bangladesh Cricket Board, said: "I personally think it's going to be a very, very clean tournament. More so because the players are going to play their best so as to prove these allegations wrong."

Haque is also convinced Cronje has done nothing wrong, declaring: "I don't think he has fixed a match."

Such sentiments appear to be shared by India's cricket establishment. For weeks now it has been in a state of deep, pathological denial. AC Muthia, president of the Indian board, last week declared that "Indian cricket is clean" - a statement greeted with barely concealed sniggers.

Jagmohan Dalmiya, chairman of the International Cricket Council and the most powerful man in Indian cricket, has also dismissed the mountain of evidence implicating India's side in match-fixing. "Most are unsubstantiated allegations," he said.

Messy feud

The Indian board has been involved in a messy feud with IS Bindra, its defiant former president. Bindra has accused a series of top Indian officials, including Dalmiya, of corruption. He also backs Prabhakar's claim that Kapil was involved in match-fixing. Furthermore, he says he was forced to admonish three Indian players for betting on matches they were playing in.

In turn the board has accused him of bringing the game into disrepute. India's Central Bureau of Inquiry, the national police investigation unit, has launched an official inquiry into match-fixing.

An under-fire Dalmiya, meanwhile, has issued writs against three publications after they accused him of selling off the television rights to the 1998 ICC one-day tournament in Bangladesh too cheaply. His lawyers have also filed a case for defamation against Arun Agarwal, an Indian financial adviser. All the officials and players caught up in the scandal have denied impropriety. Outlook's mercurial editor, Vinod Mehta, is said to be relaxed about the ensuing legal battle.

More than ever, then, this Asia Cup is about amour-propre. At stake, for the players, is personal reputation. However, they have less to lose than the ordinary cricket followers who bet badly and fail to pay up.

Rajesh Joshi, a Dubai-based underworld don involved in the betting industry, recently gave an illuminating account of what happens to punters who do not settle their debts. "We shoot some people, murder some and kidnap others," he said.

webTitle: Vicious video in store as rival teams dig in for Battle for Europe

fields.headline: Vicious video in store as rival teams dig in for Battle for Europe
fields.trailText: The BBC has taken to prefacing any programme of vaguely male appeal, like Charlie Dimmock's gardening show - with "This is BBC1, Home of Euro 2000", while ITV counters with their Euro 2000 promo trailer featuring all their big names, and Bob Wilson.
fields.body:
This will be the first of many despatches from the front because, make no mistake, the war has begun. The BBC has taken to prefacing any programme of vaguely male appeal - Grandstand, Alastair McGowan's Big Impression, Charlie Dimmock's gardening show - with "This is BBC1, Home of Euro 2000", while ITV counters with regular plays of the Euro 2000 promo featuring all their big names, and Bob Wilson.

Bob, I notice, does not actually get to say anything, but he is clearly visible in one of the shots in the longer version of the trail, and it is good to see such a decent, honest professional has not been entirely airbrushed out of all the team photos. One assumes Bob's role will be peripheral, though. While Sir Desmond is swanning around the Low Countries in quasi-papal fashion in his specially fitted-out Desmobile, I expect Bob will be given a nearly new Vauxhall Cavalier and told to make sure he gets to the studio in time for the 2am highlights show.

It is a vicious dirty business, TV, and it is going to get even dirtier over the next few weeks, I am pleased to say. The BBC had clearly been stung by all the recent jibes over its lack of top-quality sport, culminating in the embarrassing absence of Grandstand from the schedules the previous weekend, so they are determined to make the most of Euro 2000.

"We can hear the thoughts of David Beckham in a moment," said Ray Stubbs on Football Focus. Only a station that has gone Euro 2000 crazy would consider this to be in any way a come-on. Coming soon, the deep crosses to the far post of A A Alvarez.

ITV can be a little more relaxed, having the rights to highlights of England's three warm-up matches, which gives them a chance to try out a few things in the phoney war period, before the Battle for Europe begins in earnest. Like Kevin Keegan, though, they went for the familiar for the Brazil match; Des, Terry, Clive and Big Ron, very much an Adams, Keown, Campbell and G Neville back four. If they have anything innovative planned, they are keeping their powder dry for a couple of weeks yet.

There was, of course, several million pounds worth of talent on display in the England-Brazil match - and some highly-paid footballers too - but sport can be just as interesting lower down the food chain, as two excellent documentaries illustrated in the past week.

My FC was unusually - almost uniquely - a late-night programme on Channel 5 which a young, predominantly male, audience was invited to view with brain engaged and both hands free. Terry Alderton, a stand-up comic, returned to Southend United, the team he has supported all his life and for whom he played briefly as a schoolboy goalkeeper, until his football career was cruelly cut short.

After saving a penalty, Terry imitated Michael Jackson's moonwalk and conceded an indirect free-kick - which led to a goal for deadly rivals Colchester, and the suggestion that his future might lie elsewhere.

You could tell this was some distance from Euro 2000 because the kit manager John Threadgold was carefully counting out 16 towels for the trip to Leyton Orient. "You have to make sure it's exactly 16," said Threadgold, "Otherwise the buggers will use more than they should."

Manager Alan Little's half-time team talks were satisfyingly foul-mouthed, and should act as useful counterbalance to all the talk about systems and so on that we will be treated to over the next few weeks.

"Let's fucking go and do it," said Little. "These fuckers are no good. For 35 minutes their back four didn't know whether they wanted a shit or a shampoo."

Terry was a likeable guide to his club, and summed up perfectly what supporting a team like Southend means: "It's about being willing to accept a lifetime of frustration for just one day of utter wonderment."

It is a philosophy with which the supporters of Smethwick, perennial fall guys of the Birmingham Cricket League, will readily identify.

Their day of wonderment came when a local entrepreneur, Raja Khan, did a deal to bring one of the world's greatest cricketers, Wasim Akram, to Smethwick for a season. Some £20,000 and a car did not seem an excessive price to pay. Unfortunately Raja did not have £20,000, or anything much really, apart from a certain genial plausibility, and a few friends in the local business community.

It was plain to see the deal was doomed from the start, but still fascinating to watch it end in tears, on When Wasim Came To Smethwick on Channel 4 yesterday afternoon. Quite apart from Wasim's own problems, the money thing was fated to destroy the dream. The writing was on the wall when Abid Mir, rotund owner of a leading west Midlands home and garden centre, was picked for the Smethwick first team.

As Abid was built more on the lines of one of his garden sheds than those of a finely tuned athlete, the supporters were right to wonder whether his selection might be for financial rather than cricketing reasons. Sure enough, the season ended disappointingly for Smethwick and after their brief moment in the limelight, they returned to obscurity. Bob Wilson will know how they felt.

fields.headline: The best Oliver Reed scene
fields.standfirst: Gladiator
fields.trailText: Gladiator.
fields.body:
The second century AD. Roman general-turned-slave Maximus (Russell Crowe), now known only as The Spaniard, stands in the quarters of his new master, former gladiator Proximo (Oliver Reed).

He stares fiercely at Proximo.

"You ask me what I want. I too want to stand up in front of the Emperor, as you did."

Proximo's eyes twinkle.

"Then learn from me. I wasn't the best because I killed quickly. I was the best because the crowd loved me."

He faces Maximus.

"Win the crowd, and you will win your freedom."

"I will win the crowd," Maximus declares. "I will give them something they have never seen before."

Proximo strides toward his window.

"Ha! So, Spaniard, we shall go to Rome together and have bloody adventures, and the great whore shall suckle us until we are fat and happy and can suckle no more!"

He turns back to Maximus, his brow suddenly furrowed.

"And then, when enough men have died, perhaps you will have your freedom."

See also: Oliver!, The Devils, Funny Bones, The Adventures Of Baron Munchausen

Don't see also: Tommy, Parting Shots, Castaway

Pointless trivia: "On the whole," Oliver Reed once declared, "my only regret is that I didn't drink every pub dry and sleep with every woman on the planet."

webTitle: More thought, less populism, to fight crime

fields.headline: More thought, less populism, to fight crime
fields.standfirst: Road to the manifesto
fields.trailText: "Tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime" was one of Labour's most successful soundbites in the run up to the landslide victory of 1997.
fields.body:
"Tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime" was one of Labour's most successful soundbites in the run up to the landslide victory of 1997.

It combined an appeal to the law and order instincts of the Daily Mail reader with the belief of the Guardian-reading classes that tackling crime means tackling problems more deeply rooted in society.

But while some imaginative new policies have been introduced aimed at curbing crime in the medium-to-long term, they have proved less visible than the political auction in which each party seeks to outdo the others to prove their "lock 'em up" credentials.

The next Labour government should show its determination to tackle both crime and the causes of crime by building on its current target to cut car-related offences by 30% - and announce an even more ambitious long-term objective: halving the rate of acquisitive crime from the peak it reached in 1992. This would involve a huge extension of the government's crime reduction programme, based on policies that pass one simple test: do they work?

A whole range of anti-crime measures would be used: dealing with school exclusions, diverting young people from crime, making goods harder to steal, concentrating resources on crime hotspots, improving conviction rates, and making prisons work in preventing criminals offending again.

Public demand for a more visible police presence, demonstrated by the debate on police numbers, should be met by supplementing the use of constables with police-approved community patrol officers. The regulation of the private security industry is essential to engender public confidence in such patrols. This would enable the more skilled constables to be used in intelligence-led "targeted policing" aimed at catching criminals.

Police numbers rose from 110,000 to 125,000 between 1979 and 1997 and budgets almost doubled in real terms. Yet recorded crime soared over the same period. It is time to realise that the most effective policies - such as cutting long-term unemployment, truancy, drug abuse, homelessness and poor parenting - are not necessarily those that produce immediate results.

In the face of rising crime figures Labour must resist the temptation to follow populist policies, and avoid imposing blanket "zero tolerance" arrest policies. It should avoid, too, increasingly punitive mandatory sentences on the alleged "criminal classes" which pay little regard to the seriousness of the crime. Labour should also quietly drop its authoritarian experiments, like child curfews.

It should expand embryonic programmes which tackle the link between addictive drugs and crime - while recognising that alcohol is linked to as much crime as heroin and cocaine.

Arrest referral schemes should be expanded to include drink as well as drug treatment programmes. The law on cannabis causes more harm than it prevents and criminalises large numbers of young people. The sanctions for cannabis possession should be substantially reduced to informal warnings and fixed fines with prosecutions. Prison should no longer be used.

This stops short of legalisation. Cannabis is not a harmless drug - there are physical and psychological health risks from long-term use. Unilateral legalisation would mean Britain swiftly being labelled a "narco state". However the use of cannabis for medical purposes should be legalised.

To increase public confidence, judges need to state in open court the minimum and maximum term a convicted offender will serve and in controversial cases they should be prepared to explain on TV their reasons for passing a lenient or a tough sentence.

Prison governors cannot cope with offending behaviour in overcrowded conditions. A legal limit needs to be set on the numbers in each prison with the "jail full" sign going up when it is reached. Literacy programmes need to undergo rapid expansion.

The successful introduction of the home detention curfew, backed by tagging, should be expanded for less serious offenders. Moreover, it is time the public sector was allowed to bid to run all new prisons.

The next Labour government should give a further injection of resources into our asylum system so that the backlog of 90,000 cases can be brought down. The rapid processing of asylum claims is the most effective deterrent to the abusive asylum seeker. While they wait for their claims to be resolved, asylum seekers should be allowed to work. Those who cannot work should be paid benefits and the voucher system scrapped.

Britain must resist European moves to redefine the Geneva convention on asylum so that it covers only the victims of direct state persecution. It should endorse the decisions of the British courts which say the right to asylum covers those, such as rape victims, whom the state fails to protect.

The commission for racial equality should be merged with the equal opportunities commission into a more powerful human rights commission. The incorporation of the European convention of human rights needs to acknowledge changes in the past 50 years in the rights of women, gays, and ethnic groups.

What happens next ...

Do you think Alan Travis has got it right - or is there more that should be done in the second term? Send your thoughts to our letters page or join the debate at Road to the manifesto

 Next week, transport and the environment

fields.headline: Brown's olive branch to Oxbridge
fields.standfirst:
Extra money earmarked for talent-spotting teams to prevent top students slipping through the net

Magdalen College admissions
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will offer Britain's elite universities - not just Oxbridge - an olive branch in his midsummer spending review when he gives them extra funds to create talent-spotting teams to prevent exceptional students from poor backgrounds slipping through the net.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will offer Britain's elite universities - not just Oxbridge - an olive branch in his midsummer spending review when he gives them extra funds to create talent-spotting teams to prevent exceptional students from poor backgrounds slipping through the net.

Ministers are adamant that they are not backing down from the Brown-led campaign against educational privilege in the face of widespread criticism and charges of "class warfare". John Prescott and David Blunkett will join the fray this week.

But some have been troubled by the chancellor's tone when he cited the Tyneside sixth-former Laura Spence's "scandalous" problems with admission to Oxford without knowing all the details.

"This is not about extremism or envy politics. It's about excellence and extending opportunity to all," one senior minister insisted.

Despite persistent pressure, most of Britain's top 10 universities fail to find the best students from all social classes, ministers and officials stress.

Their US equivalents, Ivy League colleges such as Harvard, Stanford, Princeton and Yale, devote up to 50 staff to talent-spotting and recruiting the ablest pupils, especially the poorest.

Mr Brown has told colleagues that in the 25 years he has known Harvard it has turned from being a "finishing school for elites" into a university that is genuinely open for all.

Tony Blair, who is spending this week at Chequers examining election options and details of Mr Brown's July spending review, remains solidly behind the "opportunity for all" initiatives that party strategists believe will revive support for core Labour values.

"This is not about class warfare or putting up barriers. It is about breaking them down," said a Downing Street official.

Meanwhile the health secretary, Alan Milburn, who has a sharp ear for class politics, said he wanted to widen access to medical schools for poorer pupils, and Robin Cook renewed his attack on the public school/Oxbridge bloc in the Foreign Office. Like Mr Brown, he has often made the case against unwarranted privilege.

But some ministers are uneasy about Mr Brown's style, which revived painful memories of the "War of Jennifer's Ear", a row over NHS treatment during the 1992 election. Then, as now, the individual case became more complex under media scrutiny.

"Gordon saw an opportunity to get something up in lights. We now see that it hasn't been carefully worked through," said one cabinet member.

Education department sources welcomed the chancellor's commitment to tie more government cash in the July review to schemes such as talent spotting, twinning universities with inner-city schools and employing "ambassadors" to encourage students in poorer areas to apply.

As the affair rumbled on, John Stein, senior medical fellow at Magdalen college, revealed that Laura Spence had come only 11th out of 23 candidates chasing five places. She did best in the interview, the part of the application process said to disadvantage comprehensive school students.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, will refer to the controversy in a speech this week at the National Association of Head Teachers' conference. Three weeks ago he announced measures designed to encourage more working-class applications to Oxbridge.

Mr Blunkett has already pledged £4m to identify, recruit and retain bright students in areas without a tradition of sending to university, encouraging them with "opportunity bursaries" of up to £1,000 each. The government is also providing places for 5,000 sixth-formers in university summer schools this year.

Unions are ready to play their part. David Hart, general secretary of the NAHT, will use his conference speech in Jersey to tell comprehensive heads that they have an obligation to do as much as private schools to support children applying for top universities.

 Last night, the Tories were also keen to exploit a leaked Labour focus group report produced by the pollster Philip Gould that found some Labour voters "very unhappy" about the government's alleged failure to deliver on its promises. No 10 denied all knowledge of it.

webTitle: Trimble and Mallon prepare for Stormont return

fields.headline: Trimble and Mallon prepare for Stormont return
fields.trailText: The Ulster Unionist party leader, David Trimble, and the Social and Democratic Labour party leader, Seamus Mallon, were back at Stormont today preparing to resume their roles at the helm of Northern Ireland's government when Westminster hands back devolved power to the assembly at midnight tonight.
fields.body:
The Ulster Unionist party leader, David Trimble, and the Social and Democratic Labour party leader, Seamus Mallon, were back at Stormont today preparing to resume their roles at the helm of Northern Ireland's government when Westminster hands back devolved power to the assembly at midnight tonight.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, dissolved the Stormont assembly in February when Mr Trimble threatened to resign as first minister over the IRA's failure to decommission its weapons. Devolution returns to Northern Ireland at midnight after a narrow vote of approval by the Ulster Unionist party's ruling council at the weekend.

"Been here, done that at least twice before," said Mr Mallon, warning that the political process could not survive another collapse. "I hope we'll be able to get on with the business, that the nonsense will be at an end and we will start doing what we should have done two years ago - give people hope and confidence in an administration that is gearing itself for a new dispensation," he said.

The two were meeting inside the building before sitting down with senior civil servants to receive a briefing on government affairs since the suspension of devolution on February 11.

Mr Mallon said he hoped the decommissioning commission chairman, General John de Chastelain, would be able to produce a report on arms before the end of June. "We know what was stated in the IRA statement, we know the wording of it and we await the action that will be taken in relation to the crucially important confidence-building element in terms of that statement," he said.

"I trust it will be done soon. I hope it will be done soon. And I hope Gen de Chastelain's report will confirm that it has been done soon."

Mr Trimble said that a "very substantial minority" of Unionists were unhappy with the arrangements for decommissioning. "I think those reasons would be addressed or at least diminished significantly if people carried out the undertakings they have given, fully, promptly and with a good spirit," he said.

He added that the attack on Edmund McCoy, who died today after he was shot last night in a pub on the outskirts of Belfast, underlined the need for decommissioning. "We do seem to be launching into a feud between loyalist factions. There have been a number of murders," he said.

"This is quite deplorable, and it is incumbent on all people who have any influence on that situation to bring the problem to an end This underlines the need for that to happen and also underlines the responsibility for mainstream loyalist paramilitaries to address that issue."

fields.headline: When Fox sued News Corp
fields.trailText: The relationship between old and new media - recently like two people who find themselves in bed without having kissed - appeared to have reached a new low last week when one couple ended up in court.
fields.body:
The relationship between old and new media - recently like two people who find themselves in bed without having kissed - appeared to have reached a new low last week when one couple ended up in court.

Fox News Network, the TV channel owned by Rupert Murdoch, showed it was serious about a local dispute by suing online financial news company TheStreet.com and its founder, James Cramer, for breach of contract. It also revealed the changing relationship between new and old media in an environment in which it is no longer clear who has the upper hand: upstart or old-timer?

Fox, which runs a weekly show featuring TheStreet.com on the less-than-peak time of Saturday morning, announced it was seeking unspecified monetary damages from both parties in its lawsuit, filed in the New York Supreme Court last Monday. It also sought separate injunctions that would prevent both parties from appearing on any other network until May 2001 at the earliest.

In launching its lawsuit, the network, better known for Who Wants to Marry a Millionaire? than its financial output, was reacting to TheStreet.com's earlier announcement that it intended to pull the plug on the little-watched show.

For his part, Thomas J Clarke, chief executive of TheStreet.com, said he had been forced to announce the show's cancellation because of its "limited reach" (the show is estimated to attract a weekly audience of 120,000), "breach of contract" (both sides are disputing this one) and "disparagement of the company and its brand".

According to most reports, tension between the two sides began when James Cramer plugged the shares of TheStreet.com, in which he is still a significant shareholder, on the Fox show. The comments prompted some off-the-record nastiness from Fox in the Daily News and hey presto! the New York media scene had a fight on its hands. With perfect timing, TheStreet.com announced its intention to cancel the Fox show on the night of the launch party for Inside.com, the new media site covering, er, new media.

This saga is really much more about the disappointing marriage between TheStreet.com and News Corp than a few off-the-cuff remarks about a shareholding. A month before the market crash that began in April, TheStreet.com talked to Fox's parent company about developing a closer relationship. Some of the Fox side called this "asking for more money", but there appears to have been more to it than that.

It has not escaped the attention of TheStreet.com that most of its competitors have paired up with far bigger organisations that can reach broader audiences. While TheStreet.com runs a joint newsroom with the New York Times, it does not have the sort of relationship that Marketwatch has with CBS and Pearson, or Dow Jones has with CNBC, for example.

It hoped to have such a relationship with News Corp, which, in its rush to the web last year, took a 1.6% stake in TheStreet.com. This seemed a good investment when shares in the company reached a high of $71 (£43) in May last year. But by the end of last week, they were worth less than $6.

Since then News Corp appears to have written off its initial investment in the company and was certainly not keen to provide more money or have a closer relationship. At last month's bells-and-whistles presentation of its internet offering, delivered over four hours, not one word was said of TheStreet.com.

The online company has been looking for a new partner for several months now, with CNN eyed as the most likely contender. The Fox relationship has muddied that search and last week's lawsuit has made the water no clearer.

That Rupert Murdoch has far bigger fish to fry than this Wall Street snapper is obvious. What the spat shows, however, is how the seas have become far choppier for online news organisations.

TheStreet.com, with its discredited subscription model and staff losses, may need partnerships more than most, but the past year has seen a wave of similar deals. The difference this time round is that the needs of the new are just as obvious as those of the old.

A market correction which has wiped billions of pounds from the share prices of internet companies is mostly to blame. But so is America Online's January takeover of Time Warner. One exhausted head of a new media business said last week: "It meant you had to be huge and that there was a new emphasis on profits."

The internet has been described as like a rushing river: businesses need to make a grab for your attention or they'll be swept away. Look out for a lot more waving arms in the coming months.

TheStreet.com, with its discredited subscription model and staff losses, may need partnerships more than most, but the past year has seen a wave of similar deals. The difference this time round is that the needs of the new are just as obvious as those of the old. A market correction which has wiped billions of pounds from the share prices of internet companies is mostly to blame. But so is America Online's January takeover of Time Warner. One exhausted head of a new media business said last week: "It meant you had to be huge and that there was a new emphasis on profits." The internet has been described as like a rushing river: businesses need to make a grab for your attention or they'll be swept away. Look out for a lot more waving arms in the coming months.

webTitle: Sharon Stone falls for the Big Yin in new movie

fields.headline: Sharon Stone falls for the Big Yin in new movie
fields.trailText: It must rank as one of the most improbable movie couplings of all time. Sharon Stone falls hopelessly in love with Billy 'Big Yin' Connolly, who plays a florist's assistant in the new black movie comedy Beautiful Joe
fields.body:
It must rank as one of the most improbable movie couplings of all time.

Sharon Stone falls hopelessly in love with Billy 'Big Yin' Connolly, who plays a florist's assistant in the new black movie comedy Beautiful Joe.

The movie has been made in Vancouver, Canada by producers Steven Haft and Fred Fuchs, the team behind Gwyneth Paltrow's Emma and Robin Williams's Dead Poets Society.

Billy was picked for the role by Sharon Stone herself after seeing Billy in Mrs Brown. Needless to say the humour of an ex-Govan welder playing a romantic role with Sharon Stone is not lost on Billy.

What's more, the shaggy Scotsman has shaved off his hair and will be seen bald in the story, in which he plays a character who requires brain surgery for a deadly tumour.

The sexual chemistry between La Stone and La Scot remains to be seen. But he has assured his former actress wife Pamela Stephenson that there are no Basic Instinct-like situations with the blonde sex siren.

"They actually do have a love scene," says a production source. "But it is low key. Pamela had nothing to fear from Sharon!"

 Beautiful Joe will be released in the US later this summer; no UK release date has yet been announced

fields.headline: Me and my motor
fields.standfirst: Pauline Wilson-Copp
fields.trailText: Pauline Wilson-Copp.
fields.body:
Pauline Wilson-Copp is a mature student at Cheltenham College of Higher Education who recently protested outside the Tate Modern by parking her mirror-covered Ford Capri, entitled Dog On, in front of it. It was removed by the police and placed in their car pound, but they have now decided to release the car.

What's so special about your car?

It's a spectacular piece of popular art accessible to many people.

How did the idea come about?

I kept finding pieces of broken mirrors in my trawls through scrapyards and derelict car businesses. I then went looking for a car - any car - and the first that hit out at me was a Capri. The scrap value was £250 but, as I had no money, I had to wait two months for one I could have for free.

What was your protest outside the Tate about?

It wasn't a protest exactly. My basic plan was to deliver it to London and just live with it. It's difficult to get into establishment art but I wanted in some way to link the car to a major art event and the opening of the Tate Modern was perfect.

What reactions did the car get?

Initially people thought it was a legitimate Tate exhibit. Then, everyone congratulated me on it. Others made a special visit after reading about me in the press. Some said it was sexy and liked its unofficial position. The workers on the site liked it too and even brought me sandwiches. Lots of people fed me - which was lucky as I arrived with no food or money.

What does the name Dog On mean?

Dog is a name for an old banger. Apart from that I'd like people to make up their own minds about its meaning.

How long did it take to make?

I started it in October last year and finished it just before the Tate opened, working round the clock.

Why was it to be crushed?

I couldn't afford to pay the rent at the police car pound.

Why did the police decide to save it?

I think they understood what I was doing. The car made people smile - it had a personality.

Is it roadworthy?

No. It had to be transported by a lorry to London.

What will you do with the car once it's released?

Cheltenham and Bristol Councils are interested in displaying it in the town centres. I'd love to see it outside the Pompidou Centre or included in the Tate exhibition. I'd also like to take it past Buckingham Palace as the Queen didn't get to see it at the Tate opening.

Do you have any other vehicles?

A Vauxhall hatchback that has broken down so I'm currently carless. I only need a car as a means to carry my junk around. When I get some money I will buy myself a new Capri.

webTitle: Clooney in line to star in Kennedy Jr assassination movie

fields.headline: Clooney in line to star in Kennedy Jr assassination movie
fields.trailText: George Clooney, is lined up to take the role of John F Kennedy in a film that suggests the millionaire playboy, who died in a plane crash last year, was murdered
fields.body:
He was the son of America's most loved post-war president and a glamorous, intelligent raconteur in his own right. But John F Kennedy Jr (pictured) was a flawed political gem and a playboy who had real problems keeping his hands off women - even if they were married.

And Washington is preparing itself to be further stunned by fresh revelations in the £40m biopic Like Father, Like Son suggesting that Kennedy Jr was executed last year by the lovechild of Lee Harvey Oswald.

Former ER heartthrob George Clooney, who can now command up to £10m a film is being lined up to take the lead role with new screen beauties Charlize Theron and Cameron Diaz in the running to play Kennedy's wife Carolyn.

Kennedy Jr was 38 when his plane fell out of the sky last July and plunged into the ocean off Martha's Vineyard. He was en route to a cousin's wedding and his wife Carolyn, 33, and her sister Lauren Bessette, 35, also died in the crash.

The script of the tragic tale is currently in pre-production stage, and posits that Oswald had an affair with a waitress later leaving his illegitimate offspring hellbent on seeking revenge on the Kennedy clan and fanatical in his belief of his father's innocence in the killing.

The Miramax film builds to a climax in which the assassin's identity finally becomes known. In a plotline reminiscent of The Day of the Jackal, crack CIA operatives race to a cliff-top house on Long Island where the assassin is about to launch a heat-seeking missile with the aid of fanatical Arab terrorists. The film is scheduled to go into production next spring.

 More about the death of John F Kennedy Jnr

webTitle: Denzel is looking for one good man

fields.headline: Denzel is looking for one good man
fields.trailText: The actor is to make his directing debut with The Antwone Fisher Story, a drama about a young man on the verge of being dismissed from the Navy
fields.body:
When Denzel Washington lost out in the best-actor race to Kevin Spacey at this year's Oscar ceremony, it was the 36th consecutive ceremony in which a black leading man lost out to a white fellow actor. But Washington may help someone else break that streak.

The actor is to make his directing debut with The Antwone Fisher Story, a drama about a young man on the verge of being dismissed from the Navy. He undergoes therapy and recalls many traumatic childhood experiences, then decides to track down the family that abandoned him. The screenplay was penned by the real Fisher.

The role is so juicy, writes USA Today , that the young actor who wins the role would surely have a legitimate shot at an Oscar. Although the film doesn't have a start date (it seems likely that Washington will try to fit in one or maybe two projects before Fisher), a casting director has been hired to find a 17-year-oldish actor (probably an unknown) to play Fisher.

Washington is expected to co-star as the therapist.

webTitle: Travolta in London for Battlefield Earth

fields.headline: Travolta in London for Battlefield Earth
fields.trailText: John Travolta was mobbed by hundreds of screaming fans when he arrived for the UK premiere of his new film Battlefield Earth
fields.body:
John Travolta was mobbed by hundreds of screaming fans when he arrived for the UK premiere of his new film Battlefield Earth on Thursday. The BBC reports that The 46-year-old actor delayed the screening at Leicester Square's Warner Village cinema by 15 minutes while he signed autographs. When he finally made it into the cinema he was given a standing ovation as he told the audience of his joy at being in London.

Travolta plays a giant alien warrior in the sci-fi film, based on a book by Scientology guru L Ron Hubbard. The movie, set in the year 3000, has been savaged by critics since its US release, but it represents a personal triumph for Scientology devotee Travolta, who has spent years trying to raise the finance to make the film.

Before the screening, director Roger Christian defended his picture, saying it was based on a comic strip and was intended as a piece of escapism. He told the audience Battlefield Earth could be described as "pulp science fiction".

Publicity surrounding the film has returned L Ron Hubbard's book to the bestseller list in the US, with one million copies being sold in the last three months alone.

 The film opens in the UK on 2 June.

fields.headline: Hall of shame
fields.trailText: The chronology of Phil Hall's fall from grace.
fields.body:
September 1995: Phil Hall, deputy editor of News of the World, becomes editor, following Piers Morgan's departure to the Mirror. Three revelations swiftly appear - a judge's "Drugs and sex romp with jailbird hookers", Princess Diana's three trysts with Will Carling ("Will and Di at it again") and "Star Emma [Thompson]'s Secret Nights with Movie Hunk".

December 1995: Nine days after her BBC Panorama interview, Princess Diana phones up NoW royal reporter Clive Goodman. "An historic first-ever newspaper interview," trumpets the paper.

August 1996: Furore greets a deal between NoW and prospective mum Mandy Allwood - dependent on number of babies born. According to Hall: "We've agreed a sum of money should she give birth to eight children and we've agreed to discuss the situation with her should it change."

May 1997: Tory MP Jerry Hayes loses his Harlow seat, four months after the NoW's "Tory MP two-timed wife with under-age gay lover" allegations.

March 1998: Newcastle Utd directors Freddie Shepherd and Douglas Hall are taped mocking fans, Geordie women and Alan Shearer. Mazher Mahmood, the paper's investigations editor, is the controversial hit-man. Celebrity scalps succumbing to the NoW's "cocaine sting" this year include: Richard Bacon (fired from presenting Blue Peter), DJ Johnnie Walker (suspended from Radio 2) and ex-England rugby captain Lawrence Dallaglio (fined £15,000 for bringing the game into disrepute).

September 1999: A lenient sentence is passed on the Earl of Hardwicke after a judge accepted that had he not been entrapped into taking cocaine he would not have committed the offence. The paper replied it was exposing "one of the greatest social evils in Britain". John Alford, from TV's London's Burning, was jailed earlier in the year - another victim of the "cocaine sting".

November 1999: "Archer quits as News of the World exposes false alibi". Twelve years after its original allegations about Jeffrey Archer and Monica Coghlan, the paper confronts Archer with a statement by a friend revealing he had agreed to lie for Archer in court. Archer admits all, adding that Ted Francis's decision "to profit by selling his story" to the NoW has saddened him.

December 1999: The NoW's £25,000 "conviction bonus" to the key witness against Gary Glitter is ruled unacceptable by the PCC and called "a clearly reprehensible state of affairs" by the judge. Glitter was cleared of under-age indecent assault in November (but jailed for four months for child pornography offences). Alison Brown, the jury was told, was paid £10,000 by the paper for the story that prompted the case and "stands to make another £25,000 if you convict the defendant on any of the charges".

April 2000: A landmark adjudication by the PCC finds the NoW guilty of intruding on Coronation Street star Jacqueline Pirie's privacy, possibly signalling the demise of the kiss'n'tell staple. Its "Street star's eight-month marathon of lust" story breached clause three of the editors' code of practice: "Everyone is entitled to his or her private and family life."

May 2000: Hall is replaced by Rebekah Wade.

webTitle: 'I've had a few cheque books waved at me'

fields.headline: 'I've had a few cheque books waved at me'
fields.standfirst: Asked last week by Sky to replace Lis Murdoch,  Eileen Gallagher explains why the future is brighter with her independent production company, Shed
fields.trailText: Asked last week by Sky to replace Lis Murdoch, Eileen Gallagher explains why the future is brighter with her independent production company, Shed.
fields.body:
It took a long time for me to pluck up the courage to resign from my comfortable, well-paid job as MD of LWT to form an independent production company with my three Granada chums: Ann McManus, Brian Park and Maureen Chadwick.

Flushed with excitement about my new move, I handed in my notice and booked lunch with a friend who was very senior in Pact at that time. His advice put me off my pudding. Basically, there really were far too many indies right now - it was a saturated market. There was no room for another one. Oops - too late, mate. The deed is done. By the way, we're... er... Shed.

That was 18 months ago. Very recently Shed had its best week. First, we were recommissioned for the third series of our prison drama Bad Girls. With 23 hours already made and a new run of 16 hours ordered, we will have a library of 39 hours of drama by the end of next year. Bad Girls is already our distrib ution company's best-selling drama. A decent run of 39 hours will greatly enhance our export potential.

The second piece of good news is that we have got through to the short list of companies pitching ideas for the new ITV soap that will replace Home and Away. This is ITV's biggest ever single commission and Shed's in with a fighting chance.

Lest this sounds like I'm getting carried away, I'll quickly get to my point.

Shed has been able to build up its business because of an ITV commissioning system which is, very largely, a meritocracy. It is the only commissioning system where an independent body - the ITV Network Centre - is regulated by law to ensure impartiality in commissioning programmes for broadcast.

Under this system independent companies can flourish and get the same deals as their bigger rivals - Granada, Carlton and United - and, critically, retain all international programme rights.

This means that independent companies lucky/good enough to get commissions directly from the Network Centre can establish real businesses with real assets. It also means that ITV can pick the best programmes and talent around, and not be obliged to favour in-house departments or shareholder-tied production companies. No coincidence that ITV is still by some way the highest-rating single channel in the UK.

The TV industry is however on the brink of gigantic change (honest, this time it's for real). Regulation being formed in the minds of government officials right now will determine whether the industry allows indies such as Shed to keep forming and to flourish or whether they will become a thing of the past.

There can be no doubt about the ambitions of the larger companies which own or have stakes in channels and distribution platforms. They want to own content, and own the makers of content. In technical jargon, they strive for "vertical integration". They know content will drive not only the TV channels and distribution platforms of today but the WAP, UMTS and avatars of the very near future.

The last thing broadcasters want is indies owning content and getting a market price for it. Control the content, control the brand, control the talent and control the cost. Soon there's no competition in programme supply. Very simple. Very profitable. But surely the quickest route to a stagnant UK production industry where the real loser is the viewer.

Industry talk of a single ITV owner invariably comes round to the benefit of Carlton/United/Granada controlling the ITV network to get their own programmes commissioned - as if this would be fair, proper or legal.

Similarly, the BBC - increasingly it seems - wants to own its content. One of director-general Greg Dyke's first acts was to axe the Independent Commissioning Group. The BBC has always used its muscle to grab the programme rights of producers. This trend will accelerate. (Of course, Greg would rather not have to negotiate a price with independent producers for product to fill multiple BBC digital and terrestrial channels.)

In a short time Pearson may wholly own Channel 5 (more vertical integration) and "new media" entrants - NTL, Telewest, BT and so on - will follow in a bid to own their own content. This is what's driving the rush for buying up indies with lots of content. Even little Shed has had a few chequebooks waved in its direction.

Then what happens? We hear rumblings behind the scenes (notably at the BBC) that the 25% quota must now be questioned. So many indies are being swallowed up that the sector is in decline. In fact, the opposite is the case - the fact that entrepreneurs are selling their companies for a healthy profit is a demonstration of the sector's strength.

In an ideal world, the 25% independent quota would not be needed. It was brought in to ensure competition in the programme supply market. If we could guarantee that the best ideas, talent and companies win commissions, it wouldn't be necessary. Let's hope this government comes up with a solution which will give the market that guarantee.

As long as conditions allow new independent companies to flourish, there will be new ones of the calibre of Talkback and GMG Endemol to replace those departed - just as there will surely be a new DG of the BBC once Greg has left for pastures new.

As long as conditions allow new independent companies to flourish, there will be new ones of the calibre of Talkback and GMG Endemol to replace those departed - just as there will surely be a new DG of the BBC once Greg has left for pastures new.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Glazer
fields.trailText: Jonathan Glazer.
fields.body:
Newspapers: I'm a browser. I read the Guardian and the Independent, and the Mirror for the footie, the Sunday Times, Sunday Mirror or News of the World. I wouldn't wrap my chips in the Daily Mail.

Magazines: Creative Review, NME, Dazed & Confused. I don't read GQ, or that kind of stuff.

Film: Pre-1970s Italian, current French and pre-1980s US cinema. The 50s, 60s and 70s were the golden periods of British film, when it was all subversive and surrealistic. The best film I've seen in a long time was Todd Solondz's Happiness. Also, Terrence Malick's Thin Red Line and Arsenal: FA Cup Kings. All-time favourite? Maybe On the Waterfront - Elia Kazan.

Television: Best programme is Have I Got News For You. Also, Hollyoaks and any Arsenal footage from the 1998 double-winning season. I don't watch much. I would switch off Emmerdale, anything with Jamie Theakston and the Tonight programme with Trevor McDonald.

Radio: Desert Island Discs, Paxman, Jonathan Ross, a bit of pirate radio, mini-cab firms. That's it.

Books: I've just read for the first time Joseph Heller's Catch 22. It was incredible. I've only ever serial-read Paul Auster. Other recent reads: Stalingrad by Antony Beevor, The Grey Room by Will Self, King of the World - David Remnick's Muhammad Ali biography, Easy Riders, Raging Bulls by Peter Biskind, Bel-Ami by Guy de Maupassant.

Ads: Things which are very clever or very funny. I love the Hamlet and Cinzano ones, when the writing was more considered and structured and passed effortlessly into popular culture. I don't like anything with cars driving round roads in Scotland or women in red bathing costumes selling Special K.

Multimedia: I use a mobile phone which I keep off. And my diary is effectively the back of a packet of cigarettes in my pocket.

 Jonathan Glazer's Guinness "surfer" ad won an unprecedented two Gold Pencils at the D&AD awards last week.

fields.headline: Need to know
fields.standfirst: Suneel Jaitly
fields.trailText: Suneel Jaitly.
fields.body:
Age? 41.

Who is he? MD and co-founder of IllustratedLibrary.com (launching this week), the cyber-salesforce for the Collins & Brown group. Previously MD of C&B's mass-market publishing division.

What's the clever idea? "To replicate what people do when they buy illustrated books in a bookshop. We're giving consumers the ability to browse through products before they buy. If you go to Amazon or other online bookstores all you get is the front page and a little blurb about the book. We're starting with C&B's output, because we have an awful lot of power in certain areas - a 3,000-book backlist with 350 to 500 more to be added this year."

What's the thinking behind it? "Not just having one revenue stream. The internet means we don't have that shelf-space limitation on where we sell our books. While it's great for the group that we sell far more books, our business model enables us to take all the content from the various publishing divisions and sell goods and services around it. So we've built a separate art centre - practical art, vanity art, history of art, taking you through by period and artist, and also architecture and design. Then you've got services that attach to it that you can buy online, such as workshops, holidays, art supplies."

How does it work? "As a user you come to our site, select the category you're interested in, drop down to the sub-category, choose a book and then view the pages. We've reformatted all the texts so you can read them easily on screen. When you print a book, the resolution has to be 1,400 dots per inch. Dorling Kindersley have just taken the book scan they did for printing and put it on the internet - 30 seconds to download one image. We've protected our images and texts and reformatted every image to 72 dots per inch. They're not copyable in any format, and no page takes more than eight seconds to download."

Possible shortcomings? "There's a great shortage of programming skills in the UK, and that's probably the biggest hurdle we face."

What's next? "To harness the share price through our internet activity and acquire more companies, so strengthening areas we may be short of - niche marketing fields particularly. We're launching with 5,000 web pages, rising in a year to 1m. We have an affiliate magazine division with 25m subscribers, we're tied up with Freeserve and will be announcing a co-branded credit card with Marbles. We might go into agreement with other publishers, but it's early days yet."
