webTitle: Wanted: teen soap, must be successful

fields.headline: Wanted: teen soap, must be successful
fields.standfirst: Instead of pulling in an off-the-shelf Austrailian soap to replace Home and Away, ITV is gambling on creating a home-grown hit
fields.trailText: Two words are inked indelibly on the mind of David Liddiment at the moment: "Remember Eldorado." The ITV programming chief is about to take the biggest risk of his tenure since the scrapping of News at Ten, and commission a £15m daily soap for the most fickle of television audiences: teens, young mums and grannies.
fields.body:
Two words are inked indelibly on the mind of David Liddiment at the moment: "Remember Eldorado." The ITV programming chief is about to take the biggest risk of his tenure since the scrapping of News at Ten, and commission a £15m daily soap for the most fickle of television audiences: teens, young mums and grannies. The wrong choice would taint his reputation for good; a success would be the crown ing glory of the Liddiment era. Somewhat typically, he has opted for the hard route.

Liddiment could have snapped up another ready-made Aussie series to fill the gap left by Channel 5's dawn raid on Home and Away, but instead he has delighted British production houses (and set advertisers' nerves on edge) by opting to build a new soap from scratch.

Again taking the risky route, he then opened up the field to whoever wanted to pitch for the slot. It was an opportunity that programme-makers could not miss.

The process of selecting a shortlist would have made a pretty good mini-series in itself. Carlton's PR-minded programming head Lord (Waheed) Alli was the first to break the vow of silence in the bidding process, going public with his audacious campaign to resurrect the shaky 70s soap Crossroads. It was clearly a successful campaign for, however much it irritated Liddiment, a head of steam guaranteed the Carlton pitch a place in the final few. Around 10 others made it to the "beauty contest" stage, and now the list has been whittled down to six (see panel): the short-listed bidders have been asked to come up with three full scripts and story outlines for three months' worth of episodes, for a July deadline.

When Liddiment returns to London from the California sun where he is currently basking on his business-cum-holiday break, he will start the process of sifting through the scripts with his drama chief, Nick Elliott. It will be a hard decision - and before the soap goes on screen, no one really has much idea whether it will work.

"If there was a formula for it, then nobody would ever make a new soap and fail," says Corinne Hollingworth, a former executive producer of EastEnders and now controller of drama at Channel 5. She speaks with bitter experience: at the BBC, she was brought in towards the end of Eldorado in a last-ditch attempt to revive the dying show's fortunes.

ITV is in an even more difficult position now than the BBC was in 1992 when Eldorado was launched: the soap market has almost reached saturation point. "There are three or four long dramas in the UK that have epic status already, and there is a huge loyalty to them," says Hollingworth.

To persuade eight to 10 million people to spend an extra half an hour in front of the television during their increasingly crowded days is a major challenge. "You have to give something to the audience that they are not getting already. What you have to try and do is persuade the audience to make the emotional commitment to make the show part of their lives."

Nevertheless, ITV was right, she believes, to go for a new commission rather than pick an off-the-shelf Australian or American product. "Their audience is not what it used to be. They don't have the epic nature of a Coronation Street or EastEnders, and they don't define a channel. Brookside is quintessential Channel 4 - edgy, set in Liverpool, EastEnders is heavy, it's about issues and clearly BBC1. Coronation Street and Emmerdale are clearly associated with ITV. What you want is something that reflects what the channel is about, and can become a flagship. Nobody would say that Neighbours encapsulates BBC1 or Home and Away encapsulates ITV."

The new show should have a firm contemporary feel, she says. "I think anybody who is approaching a soap has to make it part of its time. Although EastEnders and Coronation Street are monoliths, they are products of their own time. Who wants another one? It has to be something different." It will be a challenge - the budget, £45,000 for half an hour, is tight.

Brian Park, part of the team behind the bid from Shed productions and the "axeman" producer who presided over the traumatic modernisation of Coronation Street, says ITV is clear in its intention to develop a series that is identifiably British, rather than simply an anglicised Home and Away. "What they seem to be implying is that they don't want a British version of Aussie-dom. I would be surprised if they went for a series set on a Cornish beach, all fitness clubs, bronzed pecs and tight T-shirts. I think there is a desire to see something that's home grown and identifiable to young people." Park cannot resist a dig at the rival Carlton bid: "Motels are just not part of the life experience of most young people today."

Mal Young, the head of continuing drama at the BBC and a veteran of many successful series - his latest daytime offering, Doctors, is performing impressively on BBC1 - believes the greatest soaps are "born out of the passion to tell stories". Each of the most successful long-running drama series was created by a programme-maker with a zeal for the genre. Coronation Street had Tony Warren, EastEnders was driven by Julia Smith, Phil Redmond was the force behind Brookside: a large production team on the monster that is a daily soap will need clear direction from the top, he says. "You need a key creative individual who can also be a manager. It is going to need that person at the forefront for a minimum of four years. You can't set it up and walk away. You have to live and breathe it. When you go on holiday, the programme is still going."

And the secret of a good soap? Good storylines, says Park; accessibility, adds Young. "It's as simple and as difficult as that," agrees Hollingworth.

When the new series is finally chosen in July, ITV will have to persuade people to watch it. When it finally comes on air, sometime next year, Home and Away will be well established on Channel 5, and the audience for the teatime slot will have drifted away - unless ITV's plan to screen the celebrity gossip show OK!TV in the interim keeps them happy.

Young says the network will have to play on the tabloid fascination with soap to spread the word. "They are going to have to rely for the first few weeks on word of mouth. They are going to have to use the media, they must create characters that we love - and love to hate - and that compel us to follow their lives."

Family Affairs, he says, suffered because it was unable to build up a head of steam. At the time, few critics took Channel 5 seriously as a broadcaster, and not even the soap magazines were interested in it. Now, times have changed: "Soaps sell newspapers," he says. It is a tactic that could backfire, given the British fascination with building up a success, only to knock it down. "The media would like nothing more than another failure such as Eldorado," says Young.

Still, Park says Liddiment - a Coronation Street veteran - is determined to make a new British soap work. "I think it is something that is close to David Liddiment's heart. He's not one of the Oxbridge elite, he does think it is a very powerful form of drama."

So when, tanned and rested, Liddiment gets back to his desk, it will be with enthusiasm that he throws himself into the task. There will also be a pile of application forms for the newly created post of head of continuing series - the successful candidate will oversee the birth of the new ITV baby. And there is the small matter of the News at Ten issue to be resolved.

The contenders for ITV's biggest ever commission

Producer: Carlton.

Title: Crossroads.

Project leader: Jonathan Powell, Carlton controller of drama.

Idea: Much-trailed resurrection of hotel-based 70s soap. A mere 12 years after Jill Chance sold up, the motel is now a hotel, complete with health spa, conference centre and bar used by locals as well as guests. Viewers will get to know some 30 characters, drawn from a "diverse ethnic mix". No word on Benny, though.

Chances: High-profile hype (auda cious pitch was first revealed by the Guardian) would ensure big initial audiences. But the life experiences of the target teen audiences don't exactly include Midlands motels, so may fall victim to irrelevancy factor.

Producer: Hewland International.

Title: Richfield.

Project leader: Jane Hewland.

Idea: Described as a modern-day Dallas, or EastEnders with cash: London-based glamour soap from makers of Dream Team, the highly successful Sky series based on a Premiership football team.

Chances: Hewland, a small independent, has a good track record in making cheap telly look classy: Richfield must be in with a fighting chance.

Producer: Shed.

Title: Big City.

Writers: Brian Park (ex-Coronation Street), Maureen Chadwick, Ann McManus (Bad Girls).

Idea: Set in a north-west London community (the fictional Hansford Road, NW1), described as an unashamedly urban location. Centred on a dilapidated lodging house, the gateway into the big city for the younger characters, which sits uncomfortably near the more conventional families.

Chances: EastEnders with nobs on by the Bad Girls team: appears ideal for the teatime teens-and-mums-market. With king of soap Brian Park behind it, Big City must be a favourite.

Producer: Yorkshire (1).

Title: Hope Point.

Writers: Jan McVerry (Coronation Street), Roy Boulter (Hollyoaks) and Kevin Sampson (author of Powder).

Idea: Revolves around modern family relationships, which, says an insider, are no longer about "mum, dad and 2.4 children". So expect single parents and broken homes. Sampson's trademark is gruesome sex, prevalent in his graphic novels, but this is unlikely to surface at teatime.

Chances: Creative combination of experienced soap hands and hip novelist should make for a fiery mix, but could be too risky for a 5.30pm timeslot. Unlikely.

Producer: Yorkshire (2).

Title: Big Smoke.

Writer: Jonathan Harvey (Beautiful Thing, Gimme Gimme Gimme).

Idea: Set in a block of flats on a city estate, about a community of people who live in the same environment. Plenty of opportunity for angst and humour.

Chances: Harvey is a deft and intelligent scriptwriter but transferring his talent for clever observational comedy and drama to a mass appeal soap must be a risk. The format is flexible, fits in with ITV's new drive for young, late-night audiences and is far more likely to run as a series in the 10pm slot.

Producer: United.

Title: Life Etc.

Writer: Caleb Ranson (of the Michelle Collins ITV vehicle Daylight Robbery).

Idea: Described as being about a group of friends "watching their children grow up before they have finished growing up themselves".

Chances: United has no real track record in successful soaps, but Ranson is seen as a rising star. An outsider.

fields.headline: Summer of spin
fields.standfirst: The forthcoming communications white paper has led to an open season on speculation.  David Teather  digs for the facts
fields.trailText: The forthcoming communications white paper has led to an open season on speculation. David Teather digs for the facts.
fields.body:
Last week, in reference to the forthcoming communications white paper, one national newspaper ran a story suggesting that legislation would be passed to allow a single ITV network to be formed. Another reacted with the revelation that cross-media ownership rules are to be scrapped. Both have been identified as key areas for discussion by government and both stories appear to have been the result of one or other minister's wish list.

The official line from the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) on the stories is "pure speculation - the government is undertaking discussions and consultations for the white paper and no decisions have yet been taken."

A joint communications reform team from the DTI and the Department of Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) has invited comments on the "blue sky" paper from around 80 interested parties and has set a deadline of June 23 for responses. The white paper will be published in the autumn and new legislation will be introduced in the next parliament.

Comments have been invited on the key issues the government perceives to be controlling the future of communications; the pace and direction of change, needs and concerns of consumers, objectives for economic regulation including cross-media ownership, content regulation, the role of public service broadcasters and the implications for regulators.

The white paper is intended to build on proposals laid out in a report published last June called Regulating Communications: The Way Ahead. That report clearly signalled that the government would favour a light regulatory touch moving forward and also raised the prospect of a single regulator covering media and telecoms, often referred to as Ofcom.

While it is widely agreed that the changes being wrought by digital technology and the internet are forcing a convergence of industries, the issue of shoehorning the varied wants of media and telecoms companies may be more difficult. Respondents to the earlier green paper came from as broad a cross-section as mobile phone manufacturer Motorola, Equity and Capital Radio.

Many of the interested parties have made no secret of what they are lobbying for - the most obvious being the ITV companies, Granada, United News & Media and Carlton Communications. They have each argued for legislation allowing a single ITV company and whoever wins the battle is expected to take control of the network.

The ITV companies would also like to see an end to their licence payments, which they argue would yield £400m a year for investment in programmes.

Over at Isleworth, BSkyB's biggest gripe is open access on the cable networks, which would allow the company to gain wider distribution for its programming. It would also like to see a tighter definition of the role of public service broadcasters such as the BBC. Channel 4 wants the new act to enshrine its status as a public service broadcaster, others would like to see the station privatised.

Meanwhile, broadcasting regulators fear that Britain's cultural health and their role in maintaining diversity of programming will be lost in Ofcom. Others want to see the BBC brought under common regulation instead of relying on its board of governors.

Paul Richards, media analyst at investment bank West LB Panmure, says the consensus is that ownership rules will be eased. "It's expected that there will be a relaxation of the cross-media ownership rules but there will probably be a pay-off paragraph - something about 'as long as it is in the public interest' or something on concentration in local areas. fields.headline: News from the edge
fields.standfirst: The deaths of Miguel Gil Moreno and Kurt Schork in Sierra Leone highlight the dangers of front-line reporting.  Nik Gowing  asks news organisations whether the risk is worth it
fields.trailText: The deaths of Miguel Gil Moreno and Kurt Schork in Sierra Leone highlight the dangers of front-line reporting. Nik Gowing asks news organisations whether the risk is worth it.
fields.body:
Even the most war-hardened cameramen and journalists must have felt that cold shiver of shock. The early radio and agency reports had talked merely of an "American and a Spanish journalist". The blandness conjured up images of young rookie hacks. Of unknowns who were new to war and pushing their luck up country, way out of Freetown. Chancers. Damn fools who should have listened to advice.

Then the American became "veteran war correspondent Kurt Schork working for the Reuter news agency". And the Spaniard became "award winning news cameraman Miguel Gil Moreno of the APTN agency". They were not household names outside the news business. But they were icons of nerve and brilliance to those of us who frequently read Schork's words on our newsroom VDUs and laptops, or viewed Moreno's often stark news video.

How could two of the most savvy and experienced reporters ever be killed in this way?

Two days earlier in Southern Lebanon, Abed Taboush, another name known only in the news business, was killed. Taboush was driving BBC correspondent Jeremy Bowen and his cameraman Malek Kenaan, a Lebanese freelance working for Reuters. Taboush was still inside his car when it was hit by an Israeli artillery shell. Or was he targeted and murdered in a final act of Israeli military spite?

Taboush's death, and Jeremy Bowen's narrow escape on the day the BBC announced he would be the new presenter of the new BBC1 and News24 breakfast programme, also created shockwaves, especially in BBC newsrooms.

In our news world, where reputation, nerve and toughness mean a better chance of professional success, emotion is usually suppressed and rarely comes easily. But last week the mask of macho invincibility slipped.

To the many who have done Chechnya, Kosovo, Bosnia and Sarajevo, this was more than just a personal loss. Whether by design or default, the deaths of Schork and Moreno marked the new assault on an increasingly threatened fundamental issue in the news business - the right and obligation to bear witness. To be there. To report. And then to make information available to all those who want to see the video and need to know the facts, however ghastly.

"I have never seen the industry in such shock. I fear the reaction will be to try to further avoid risk in covering conflicts," says Vaughan Smith, a highly experienced freelance cameramen who survived a Serb bullet in Kosovo two years ago because it hit his mobile phone. "Kurt and Miguel had no peers in conflict news-gathering. It is difficult now to see how we can continue to do this job without them."

Suddenly even the most hardened and experienced are asking: can we ever be safe? Is it worth the risk? And if we don't do it, who will?

The news business is about risks. Where there are bullets and scores to settle, the risks have always been great. Suddenly the consensus is that they have become even greater by an unquantifiable factor. Even the best are now asking themselves: should I stay in the business?

BBC News is moving swiftly to examine the safety implications on location. "We have to re-evaluate and reassess. First we need the facts," says Adrian van Klaveren, head of BBC news gathering. "This is now a really dangerous business and we must not jeopardise human safety. We have already curtailed some reporting. It is not worth the risk".

The new era of lightweight, go-anywhere, ever cheaper video and uplink technology has created a new transparency in war. As we have seen in locations such as East Timor, Kashmir, Zimbabwe and Kosovo, it allows correspondents and cameramen to report more rapidly from more parts of the world than ever. In doing so they have taken risks to expose tyrants, authoritarian rule and the determination of some to commit crimes against humanity.

That is why many fear that the deaths of Moreno and Schork have suddenly marked a victory for terror, shutting down war zones to even those with the rawest of nerves, the best in training and proven intuition in the battlefield. With it there could be a high price for democracy and human rights.

"What the public doesn't realise when they're watching the news is the compulsion to tell the story, which differentiates people like Kurt and Miguel from the rest of us," says US ambassador to the United Nations Richard Holbrooke, who knew both men. "The risks they take to make sure the world knows what is happening in what otherwise would be the dark recesses of people behaving at their absolute worst".

But what price that compulsion now? Most of the major news corporations in Britain already refuse to send staff and freelancers to even medium-risk conflicts without a five-day hostile environment training course and insurance. The Rory Peck Trust - created five years ago after the death of freelance cameraman Rory Peck in a Moscow firefight in 1993 - has finally established a training fund for freelances.

News organisations described collectively as "almost totally remiss" by president of CNN International Chris Cramer, when he launched the Rory Peck Training fund just two weeks ago, are now accepting a responsibility many freelancers have long accused them of ignoring.

But a training certificate and insurance policy will never stop high velocity bullets. Suddenly the issues have become more fundamental. More conflicts than ever are within states, between the power-hungry factions the International Committee of the Red Cross labels the "new warriors". That applies to a wide spectrum, from the rebels of Sierra Leone to the Russian government forces in Chechnya. All these belligerents are determined to do their dirty work un-witnessed by journalists. They consider harassment of journalists an acceptable part of their war. International norms of behaviour mean nothing.

"It is a disgrace that many of the recent deaths of camera operators and reporters in the Balkans and Indonesia remain unsolved mysteries," editor-in-chief of ITN, Richard Tait told the Rory Peck training launch. "Official indifference endangers everyone reporting and filming in war zones. We need to increase political pressure on undemocratic governments to see the protection of news teams as a responsibility which they must take seriously".

But what about the risks to the local freelancers with the kind of £600 camcorder we can all buy in a video store - the unattached opportunists whom the broadcasters might be forced to fall back on even more? How good are they? What about their journalistic reliability? Might they be party to a conflict and therefore not impartial?

Sorious Samura from Sierra Leone, a freelance, won the 1999 Rory Peck Award for outstanding freelance camerawork for a most extraordinary portfolio of war coverage from all three sides in the war in his country. The risks were enormous. His income was a pittance. But he proved that it can be done by a "local".

Recent coverage of Chechnya was a worrying precedent. Because of the active Russian obstruction of the rights of journalists, most major news organizations forbade staff and freelancers to venture into the republic, especially to Grozny itself which, after all, was the focus of the news. The risks were simply too great.

The few broadcasters who bothered and were camped across the border in the freezing squalor of Ingushetia relied on coverage and tapes smuggled out by Chechen freelancers commissioned by satellite telephone. The video filled a void, but often the origin, dates, timing and circumstances were murkier than good journalism required.

In one incident, the BBC felt obliged to announce on the Nine o'Clock News in late February that gruesome pictures of Chechen bodies in pits, and one being dragged across a field, had not come from the German cameraman that had originally been claimed on air, but a Russian.

Moreno was one of the very few willing to take the risk in Chechnya. He spent three weeks living underground and grabbing video footage inside Grozny, then a week with Chechen fighters in the southern mountains. His was compelling video footage of a city struggling desperately to survive the Russian bombardment. As he told me on the day he returned to London and related his Grozny experiences live on air to BBC World: he had never been so scared in his life. But at least - like Schork - he had borne witness to horror.  Nik Gowing is a presenter for BBC News, and committee member of the Rory Peck Trust.

fields.headline: Doorstepping the SAS
fields.standfirst: It is time to end the media pretence that the SAS does not exist in Sierra Leone, says  Alex Thomson
fields.trailText: Well, it certainly made us laugh. For days on end we had ploughed up the road into the jungle from Freetown. Every day a wee bit further as the rebels were pushed back.
fields.body:
Well, it certainly made us laugh. For days on end we had ploughed up the road into the jungle from Freetown. Every day a wee bit further as the rebels were pushed back.

And every day a new army was out there. There was the CDF (citizens' defence force) - all swagger, attitude and rocket-propelled grenades aboard their overloaded pick-ups. Into the jungle and you would meet the Kamajohs: bush boys, big on cowrie-shell fetishes, wigs and rusty AK 47s. There was even the SLA, the regular Sierra Leonean army: all mismatching uniforms and bandoleers of machine-gun bullets.

Most of these various militias were out of their minds on grass, palm wine, fear, hunger, or all of them at once. It is not easy trying to fight a war when you are mashed and also have to deal with white men bearing television cameras at the same time. And yet, to a man, they were helpful to us, polite even. Scary, armed, colourful, unpredictable and wired; but polite all the same.

So what was it that made us laugh? Another militia altogether - white, well-equipped, three-convoy mud-coloured Land Rovers and seriously tooled up: the SAS.

What amused us was that, of all the militias and armies gathered in the Sierra Leonean jungle, the only one to give us any grief was our own. And all because we broke the gentleman's agreement that the SAS is unreportable and, more particularly, unfilmable.

We must have shot all of seven seconds of video, taken from inside our hired car as we followed an SAS convoy up the road, out of Freetown, before its Land Rovers swung off on to a dirt track near Hastings, just outside the capital. A frontline location it was not; even the Jordanian troops with the UN were nearer the action than this point.

But we got the distinct impression that the SAS was offended by our presence. "You fucking know who we are. You know how we fucking operate. You're taking the piss."

I didn't know for sure who they were until they told me. And I didn't know how they operated in Sierra Leone. Fortunately the SAS trooper was kind enough to assist me with the latter point.

"We'll smash your fucking car and your fucking camera - understand?" he said. I was getting the general gist, at any rate.

So there we were, witnessing what is possibly the most obvious SAS operation in the regiment's history, driving past the media hotel in the Aberdeen peninsula of Freetown most mornings to go up into the jungle along the one available metalled road which is equally infested with journalists.

Usually, the SAS deploys much deeper into the jungle than they were when we filmed them. It appears to have little to do with our country's supposed mission to "protect the airport" in Sierra Leone or to "facilitate the evacuation of British subjects". It is working miles away from either of those operations.

Yet we are not supposed to film any of this, or tell our viewers and readers anything much about it. Now none of this would matter very much were it not for the fact that the government generally - and the defence secretary particularly - refuses to be candid with the public about the extent of the British operation in Sierra Leone.

The world of the Ministry of Defence and defence/diplomatic correspondents ensures that the secrecy of the SAS deployment here is preserved: it is simply considered somehow "against the rules" to report it. You do not need military censors when reporters can be relied on to do the job themselves when it comes to the "Hereford walking club".

We witnessed this in stark terms in Sierra Leone. What the government and military wanted was endless coverage of our brave paras directing traffic around Freetown and defending Lungi airport.

The military press officers made sure that was exactly what they got. Fine, in its limited way; but far from the complete military story here.

What they did not want was cov erage of the smaller but much wider and more covert operation to provide spotting, intelligence and observation - at the very least - to the Sierra Leonean army and the UN.

What they did not want was coverage which would give the lie to the supposedly strictly limited airport/evacuation story being peddled back in Westminster.

In a country whose defence department bristles with British advisers, whose police force is run by a Lancastrian and whose international airport now resembles the RAF Odiham Chinook helicopter base, the stated purpose of the British presence here was obviously less than half the full story.

We were taking sides. The SAS was a crucial element in proving we were taking sides and now the government is finally admitting that we are going to arm one side in a west African civil war, apparently because it is the best exit strategy we can come up with to get our own troops out of the jungle.

Thus, the pitfalls of playing the old game of gagging yourself when it comes to the SAS were shown up for what it is: a dismal and dangerous propaganda exercise.

It is time we all grew up a bit over this. When the SAS is parading up and down Freetown with all the covert deployment of the Edinburgh Tattoo, it should expect to get filmed. It should be able to cope with it.

It is time to report that and to put the journalistic convention of pretending the SAS does not exist where it belongs - in the past.

 Alex Thomson is chief correspondent of Channel 4 News

fields.headline: Television needs to get interesting
fields.trailText: Formerly, broadband was a word used only to describe trouser sizes in outsize clothes shops. Now it's the new rock'n'roll. Scarcely a day goes by without a new broadband initiative being announced, as consumers become all-powerful, spoilt for choice and, finally, freed from the tyranny of what broadcasters want them to see.
fields.body:
Settling down in my local cinema to see Gladiator, I was transported back in time by the new British Airways ad cut to the stirring sound of Thunderclap Newman's anthem Something in the Air. It was particularly striking because my first-ever film was a self-funded three-minute pop promo featuring Thunderclap Newman when he was an unknown telephone engineer. Self-funded just meant it was shot in black and white and cost a princely £75. It was flattering to see the marginally more expensive BA ad copy exactly the same Pied Piper concept.

The insistent hook in Thunderclap's song goes: "We'd better get together sooner or later because the revolution's here." Even Thunderclap wasn't prophetic enough to have the digital revolution in mind but the sense of urgency in the song sums up the current media mood very well. We are living through a second industrial revolution. Where there was once Crompton's Mule and the Spinning Jenny there is now ADSL and Tivo.

Formerly, broadband was a word used only to describe trouser sizes in outsize clothes shops. Now it's the new rock'n'roll. Scarcely a day goes by without a new broadband initiative being announced, as consumers become all-powerful, spoilt for choice and, finally, freed from the tyranny of what broadcasters want them to see.

Perversely, this maelstrom of technical and economic change finds mainstream television treading water, thanks to a random confluence of events. The BBC is waiting for the true impact of Greg Dyke's changes to wash through the organisation. The ITV companies circle each other like boxers while the competition commission decides whether there can be a points win, a draw or a knockout punch. Sky is in the corporate changing room waiting for news on the all important soccer rights and Channel 5 staff are on compulsory French and German classes as they measure the impact of the CLT-UFA/Pearson merger.

Yet no organisation can currently afford to stand still for a second. Terrestrial television may be preoccupied with other matters but new media initiatives are being pursued urgently, even recklessly, however uncertain the immediate future. The pace is so electric that everyone just has to go for it.

In this whirlwind of change one of the key challenges is how we access and train talent. In the short term it is the familiar names and brands that will migrate most easily onto new distribution systems, offering certainty in a plethora of choices. The acquisition of talent-based independent producers by broadcasters is a sure sign of this. But the desperate skill-hunt will not just be for established on-screen talent.

Now New Media Guardian advertises more jobs than Media Guardian. While scores of people in old media chase one job, in new media almost the opposite applies - too many jobs chasing too little talent. This generation of creative entrepreneurs, the equivalents of the men and women who set up independent production companies in the 1980s, will start up internet ventures not indies. Until the demise of boo.com the culture of envy ran deep in the TV industry, as everyone discovered that the producer in the next office was starting a net company and threatening to became an instant millionaire. How does mainstream television compete in this new world? We have always had the pick of the crop, but not any more. The lure of an apparent British cinema renaissance has already seduced some top talent and now the excitement of the web world is proving even more attractive.

This has overlapped with a dulling of the television experience. Of course, there are still peaks like The League of Gentlemen or Ali G but, let's face it, there is a huge amount of run-of-the-mill television. New media suddenly seems more exciting. I am very struck by the number of producers who come alive when they talk about the creative challenges of the wired world.

Coincidentally, many of the apparently old-fashioned skills of conventional production - particularly the understanding of narrative - are becoming extremely prized online. As one new media expert baldly said to me recently, "All those techies with ponytails and body piercing need some story-telling skills."

Television now urgently needs to rethink its training and recruitment strategies. We must remove the division between old and new media for our young talent and just train across all media, as well as retraining more experienced staff. Crucially, all of us, young and not so young, have to learn to think differently, to use our traditional skills in a way that bends traditional genres and makes new media as exciting for the consumer as it is for the creator. If we don't, we will disappear from view. Just like Thunderclap Newman.

John Willis is chief executive, United Productions

fields.headline: Get ready with those excuses...
fields.standfirst: Can Rebekah Wade reverse falling sales at the News of the World with a return to celebrity sex, naughty vicars and doorstepping? By  Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: Can Rebekah Wade reverse falling sales at the News of the World with a return to celebrity sex, naughty vicars and doorstepping?
fields.body:
There is, touchingly, still a belief among newspaper controllers - even experienced ones such as Rupert Murdoch and his Wapping supremo Les Hinton - that editors can change the course of history. That's why they have replaced Phil Hall with Rebekah Wade as News of the World editor.

They believe that she might have the qualities - femininity, youth, intelligence, charm and a ferocious work ethic - to reverse the paper's long circulation decline. They also evidently have enough faith in their new choice to allow her to rip the paper apart and start all over again. Though it has been starved of resources in the past couple of years, there will be investment to add value to what has become, in contrast to its middle and up-market rivals, a rather insipid package.

It isn't that Murdoch and Hinton don't appreciate Hall's efforts. True, they did think him just a little too laid-back, almost too ready to accept that the job of editing the NoW has become one of managing decline. But they also recognised that he had done his best and, along the way, achieved some notable successes.

What they seek from Wade is a burst of vitality and a willingness to take risks. Hall had gone a bit soft, it is whispered, becoming too accommodating to the restraints imposed by the editors' code of practice, reinforced by his membership of the Press Complaints Commission (PCC). In other words, he had become too responsible, rather like one of his predecessors, Patsy Chapman, another PCC stalwart who helped draw up the editors' code. She eventually stepped down from the editorship due to illness. Hall, a picture of rude health, required a push.

At first glance his sales record doesn't look too good. When he took over in September 1995, the NoW was selling 4.78m. Last Sunday, I understand, the paper barely sold 3.8m. Its last audited sale, in April, was just above 4m. But the market for the three Sunday red-tops has been going down steeply for 30 years and, in the past six months, has taken a nose-dive. (Could that, incidentally, be a delayed reaction to the demise of Princess Diana?) Despite a mini-revival of fortunes at the Sunday Mirror, Hall's NoW still improved its market share. Though it remains Britain's highest-selling paper, some analysts, not least those in Murdoch's organisation, have been forecasting that within two years it could sell fewer than the Sun, despite the latter also gradually losing sales.

Hinton and Hall are friends, but business is business. It was time for the 12th change of editor in 30 years (an average of one every 30 months). Wade, champing at the bit as deputy to the Sun's David Yelland, was the perfect choice.

Let's scotch one mistaken rumour: she was not appointed because of being offered the Daily Mirror editorship. Piers Morgan is secure. Nor did Trinity-Mirror offer her any other post. She has got the NoW chair because of Hinton's concern at the NoW sales decline and because he regards her as the best hope of turning it round. At 31, she is Fleet Street's youngest editor, but her experience at the NoW goes back a long way. Having joined the paper in 1989, she rose from feature-writing, through junior executive status on its Sunday magazine and on to deputy editor. She was translated to the Sun in the same position in January 1998 and has harboured thoughts of winning the paper's editorship ever since.

When I was first introduced to Wade, her friend and colleague Judy Muggier announced: "This is going to be the first woman to edit a daily tabloid." Well, the Daily Express's Rosie Boycott has taken that honour, but Muggier's prediction speaks volumes about the perception of Wade by other journalists. She has never tried to conceal her ambition, a very un-British quality that has made her the target, if not of envy, certainly of scorn. Every anecdote about her centres on her naked ambition to rise to the top. "She is," says a female friend, with a mixture of admiration and disdain, "extraordinarily motivated."

Men, failing to conceal sexist undertones, are less complimentary. She didn't come up the "right way", I was told. She has never stood on a doorstep for hours. She hasn't been at the sharp end. And here's a giveaway: she started off as a secretary.

Why a man who succeeds after starting off as a messenger boy should be appreciated more than a woman who begins as a secretary is one of those little prejudices that Women in Journalism might like to address. Wade is, after all, the chair of the organisation that campaigns to raise women's profile, and women's issues, in the media.

Anyway, from the age of 14 Wade's single aim was to become a journalist. While still at her Cheshire grammar school, she spent weekends and holidays at Eddy Shah's Messenger titles in Warrington. She took a detour four years later by living in Paris and writing for magazines before returning to Britain in 1988 to work for Shah's short-lived attempt to launch a national paper, the Post.

Ostensibly secretary to features editor Graham Ball, she presented Ball with lists of ideas and spent all the time she could looking over the shoulders of reporters and executives. Everyone I have spoken to talks about how Wade unashamedly looks and learns. A former colleague told me: "You can almost hear her say, 'So that's how it's done.' Unlike others, though, she never forgets the lesson."

Her determination also stands out. Ball recalls that Post editor Lloyd Turner was desperate to run a readers' offer for an aphrodisiac lager available only in Strasbourg. He needed someone to drive there and back. Wade volunteered, enduring an embarrassing search at Dover by customs officials convinced the pale-faced, waif-like girl was more likely to be carrying drugs than drink.

Soon after, she joined the NoW, having been recommended by Sun veteran Charlie Rae, and impressed executives there with her energy, enthusiasm and, above all, her charm. "She was a brilliant fixer," recalls writer Jean Russia. "She could persuade people who would usually run a mile from the News of the World to talk to us. Her sweet-talking telephone manner was astonishing."

There is also unanimity about another of Wade's attributes: her candour. She says what she thinks and wants and, in a business noted for deviousness, she is remarkably straightforward. The famous occasion when she killed a bogus NoW story about the Beast of Bodmin, saving the paper from a humiliating mistake, proves the point. Even so, once a deputy, her relationships with her editors have been rather tense.

She got on well with the man who appointed her, Piers Morgan. When he left for the Mirror, his replacement, Phil Hall, viewed her as something of a threat and was delighted when she was switched to the Sun. Similarly, Stuart Higgins resented the fact that she was wished on him, worrying about her closeness to management. Yelland's relations with her have been distinctly frosty.

Wade's strength shows in that she was allowed to appoint her own deputy, Andy Coulson, the former Sun assistant editor and showbusiness columnist, who has been working on an internet project for the last year. They will make, says a rival editor, a formidable team. Their knowledge of the celebrity circuit will certainly help, though the NoW is regarded with terror by stars and their agents.

And there lies the central problem for Wade. How can she raise sales unless she is prepared to take the NoW back to basics, risking the wrath of the showbusiness world, politicians and the PCC? It is known that she would like to emulate Morgan's NoW editorship, when he stopped the sales rot with a run of high-profile stories that were popular with readers but attracted odium from the establishment and, on occasion, from commentators such as me.

Hall, though more cautious than Morgan, also suffered from complaints, including a recent PCC adjudication that appears to offer some protection to stars who suffer from kiss-and-tell stories. For Wade, to return to the Morgan agenda will be fraught with difficulties. Apart from the PCC's vigilance, and a new willingness of celebrities to use it, judges and juries have taken a dim view of evidence obtained through NoW investigations, leading to acquittals for several celebrities "exposed" by the paper for alleged misdeeds.

To avoid such problems, the paper has tended to concentrate its fire on small-time examples of sex-for-sale operations, trying to overcome the sordid nature of the stories by adopting a humorous approach - which has usually been less than amusing. Though the superbly executed exposure of Jeffrey Archer's fake libel case alibi was a fine example of the formidable investigations team, there have been few revelations about misbehaviour by celebrities and politicians.

If Wade encourages her reporters to return to these targets she will need all her networking skills to maintain her friendships with people such as Tony and Cherie Blair. They are not as close as some papers suggested last week, but they get along well.

Her personal life may suffer too. Her relationship with former EastEnders actor Ross Kemp, and his showbiz friends, will be strained if the News of the World rampages through the bedrooms of the famous once again. It's unlikely that Wade will worry unduly. She still wants, more than anything else, to edit the Sun. This job could be her stepping stone to that job, or the end of a brilliant career. So, if you're famous and you're up to no good, watch out, Rebekah Wade's about!

All the way to the top of the world - Rebekah Wade
Carolyne Ellis

Age 31

Education: Did A-levels at a Cheshire grammar school, then headed to Paris and a job on Architecture Aujourd'hui magazine. Stayed in Paris until 1988.

Early career: Holiday job at Eddie Shah's Messenger Group in Warrington; editorial assistant on Shah's former north-west tabloid, the Post; one year journalism course at the London College of Printing.

The News International ladder: Joins News of the World in 1989, working up from features writer to features editor (Sunday magazine) to assistant editor and finally deputy editor. Nine years after joining the company, Rupert Murdoch moves her to the Sun as deputy editor in 1998 - under first Stuart Higgins and then David Yelland.

Reaches the top: Appointed editor of News of the World, its third female editor, in May 2000.

Private life Engaged to Ross Kemp, ex-EastEnders star, after four-year relationship.

Hall of shame:
September 1995: Phil Hall, deputy editor of News of the World, becomes editor, following Piers Morgan's departure to the Mirror. Three revelations swiftly appear - a judge's "Drugs and sex romp with jailbird hookers", Princess Diana's three trysts with Will Carling ("Will and Di at it again") and "Star Emma [Thompson]'s Secret Nights with Movie Hunk".

December 1995: Nine days after her BBC Panorama interview, Princess Diana phones up NoW royal reporter Clive Goodman. "An historic first-ever newspaper interview," trumpets the paper.

August 1996: Furore greets a deal between NoW and prospective mum Mandy Allwood - dependent on number of babies born. According to Hall: "We've agreed a sum of money should she give birth to eight children and we've agreed to discuss the situation with her should it change."

May 1997: Tory MP Jerry Hayes loses his Harlow seat, four months after the NoW's "Tory MP two-timed wife with under-age gay lover" allegations.

March 1998: Newcastle Utd directors Freddie Shepherd and Douglas Hall are taped mocking fans, Geordie women and Alan Shearer. Mazher Mahmood, the paper's investigations editor, is the controversial hit-man. Celebrity scalps succumbing to the NoW's "cocaine sting" this year include: Richard Bacon (fired from presenting Blue Peter), DJ Johnnie Walker (suspended from Radio 2) and ex-England rugby captain Lawrence Dallaglio (fined £15,000 for bringing the game into disrepute).

September 1999: A lenient sentence is passed on the Earl of Hardwicke after a judge accepted that had he not been entrapped into taking cocaine he would not have committed the offence. The paper replied it was exposing "one of the greatest social evils in Britain". John Alford, from TV's London's Burning, was jailed earlier in the year - another victim of the "cocaine sting".

November 1999: "Archer quits as News of the World exposes false alibi". Twelve years after its original allegations about Jeffrey Archer and Monica Coghlan, the paper confronts Archer with a statement by a friend revealing he had agreed to lie for Archer in court. Archer admits all, adding that Ted Francis's decision "to profit by selling his story" to the NoW has saddened him.

December 1999: The NoW's £25,000 "conviction bonus" to the key witness against Gary Glitter is ruled unacceptable by the PCC and called "a clearly reprehensible state of affairs" by the judge. Glitter was cleared of under-age indecent assault in November (but jailed for four months for child pornography offences). Alison Brown, the jury was told, was paid £10,000 by the paper for the story that prompted the case and "stands to make another £25,000 if you convict the defendant on any of the charges".

April 2000: A landmark adjudication by the PCC finds the NoW guilty of intruding on Coronation Street star Jacqueline Pirie's privacy, possibly signalling the demise of the kiss'n'tell staple. Its "Street star's eight-month marathon of lust" story breached clause three of the editors' code of practice: "Everyone is entitled to his or her private and family life."

May 2000: Hall is replaced by Rebekah Wade.

The paper replied it was exposing "one of the greatest social evils in Britain". John Alford, from TV's London's Burning, was jailed earlier in the year - another victim of the "cocaine sting". November 1999: "Archer quits as News of the World exposes false alibi". Twelve years after its original allegations about Jeffrey Archer and Monica Coghlan, the paper confronts Archer with a statement by a friend revealing he had agreed to lie for Archer in court. Archer admits all, adding that Ted Francis's decision "to profit by selling his story" to the NoW has saddened him. December 1999: The NoW's £25,000 "conviction bonus" to the key witness against Gary Glitter is ruled unacceptable by the PCC and called "a clearly reprehensible state of affairs" by the judge. Glitter was cleared of under-age indecent assault in November (but jailed for four months for child pornography offences). Alison Brown, the jury was told, was paid £10,000 by the paper for the story that prompted the case and "stands to make another £25,000 if you convict the defendant on any of the charges". April 2000: A landmark adjudication by the PCC finds the NoW guilty of intruding on Coronation Street star Jacqueline Pirie's privacy, possibly signalling the demise of the kiss'n'tell staple. Its "Street star's eight-month marathon of lust" story breached clause three of the editors' code of practice: "Everyone is entitled to his or her private and family life." May 2000: Hall is replaced by Rebekah Wade.

webTitle: Dando murder suspect remanded in custody

fields.headline: Dando murder suspect remanded in custody
fields.trailText: A 40-year-old man was today remanded in custody charged with the murder of television presenter Jill Dando.
fields.body:
A 40-year-old man was today remanded in custody charged with the murder of television presenter Jill Dando.

Barry Bulsara was charged under his original name, Barry Michael George. Mr George, of Crookham Road, Fulham, west London, appeared at West London magistrates court in Hammersmith.

He is charged with murdering Dando on April 26 1999 at her home in Fulham. During the 15-minute hearing, he spoke only to confirm his name and address.

He had arrived at the court in a white security van flanked by police motorcycle outriders and a police Land Rover at 9.25am. A large media presence gathered behind special barriers installed outside the court from first light. Two further vans of police officers arrived shortly before 9am.

Mr George, the son of a retired policeman, was arrested at his home at 6.30am on Thursday, and was held for questioning at nearby Hammersmith police station. He was charged just before 7pm yesterday.

He is understood to have changed his name by deed poll to Bulsara after the late rock star Freddie Mercury, whose real name was also Bulsara.

Magistrate Justin Phillips remanded Mr George until June 5 to Bow Street magistrates court but he will not need to appear at that court until June 26. Maryam Syed, representing Mr George, made no application for bail and reporting restrictions were not lifted.

Forty-five officers have been working to solve Dando's murder since she was shot in the head after returning from a shopping trip to her home on Gowan Avenue.

webTitle: IRA accused as victim of gun attack dies

fields.headline: IRA accused as victim of gun attack dies
fields.trailText: A man shot last night in a pub outside Belfast died today amid growing accusations that the IRA was responsible for the murder.
fields.body:
A man shot last night in a pub outside Belfast died today amid growing accusations that the IRA was responsible for the murder.

Edmund McCoy, 28, died in the Royal Victoria hospital in Belfast about 12 hours after being shot in the head and stomach at the Motte 'n' Bailey bar in Dunmurry.

He was hit three times when two men burst into the bar and singled him out from other drinkers. Police were unsure about the motive for the killing, but unionist politicians and human rights campaigners accused the IRA of being responsible.

Vincent McKenna, director of the Northern Ireland human rights bureau, claimed it was the IRA's answer to the vote by the Ulster Unionist council on Saturday. The party agreed to go back into the power-sharing government at Stormont before the IRA decommissioned its weapons.

"The Unionist council have now given the IRA a licence to murder," Mr McKenna said.

Hugh Lewsley, SDLP councillor for Twinbrook in west Belfast, said he had "no doubt" the IRA was behind the attack. "It makes a mockery of republicans saying they are putting guns beyond use," he added.

The gunmen fled the scene of the shooting in a white Vauxhall Cavalier car that was later found abandoned. Police have appealed for anyone who saw the vehicle - registration XXI 7927 - between Saturday and Sunday night to contact them.

Westminster was due to devolve power to the Stormont assembly at midnight tonight with the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, resuming his position as first minister.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, dissolved the assembly on February 11 when Mr Trimble threatened to resign as first minister over the decommissioning issue.

webTitle: Straw agrees deal to stop asylum seekers entering Britain by train

fields.headline: Straw agrees deal to stop asylum seekers entering Britain by train
fields.trailText: British immigration officials will patrol French railway stations to prevent asylum seekers entering the UK by Eurostar under an agreement signed today by the home secretary, Jack Straw.
fields.body:
British immigration officials will patrol French railway stations to prevent asylum seekers entering the UK by Eurostar under an agreement signed today by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

The accord, described as "a major step forward" by Mr Straw, could take a year to be ratified. UK immigration officers are likely to be installed permanently at the Gare du Nord in Paris, the departure point for the Eurostar to London.

France has also pledged to step up its efforts to prevent illegal immigrants getting aboard trains bound for London. French officials could also check passengers' documents at the two Eurostar stations at Waterloo in London and Ashford, Kent, although in practice the flow of people is almost entirely from the continent to the UK. Similar arrangements are already in place with Belgium but legal technicalities meant a new agreement had to struck with France.

Passengers will be asked for passports and visas at the Gare du Nord and at Eurostar stations in Lille and Calais in an attempt to control the numbers of asylum seekers entering Britain from mainland Europe. About 9,000 refugees are believed to have used the route in the last three years.

"The result of this signing will be that British immigration officials will be able to check people's passports and their credentials as they board Eurostar trains," Mr Straw said today. This is a major step forward."

Mr Straw will also sign a criminal intelligence-sharing deal under the Shengen agreement on cross-border controls. The UK will get access to intelligence on organised gangs involved in areas such as drug trafficking and cross-border car theft and illegal trading.

Britain has not signed up to the full Shengen agreement - which would mean freedom of movement with no passports or identity cards between the UK and other signatories.

"The fact that we are bilaterally able to agree with one of the major European players, France, today to strengthen our mutual border controls shows how much other European countries respect the fact that we are in a different position from the mainland continent," Mr Straw added.

fields.headline: Guts and Gore
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: There is a clock ticking on Al Gore's website (www.gore2000.org/.) It's called the Bush "Debate Duck" and it calculates "how long George W Bush has managed to bob and weave away from debating Al Gore". As I write, the clock reads 75 days, 11 hours, 38 mins and 3 seconds.
fields.body:
There is a clock ticking on Al Gore's website (www.gore2000.org/.) It's called the Bush "Debate Duck" and it calculates "how long George W Bush has managed to bob and weave away from debating Al Gore". As I write, the clock reads 75 days, 11 hours, 38 mins and 3 seconds.

Gore has been pressing for twice-weekly televised debates since the end of the primary season in March. Well, he would, wouldn't he? He is the champ when it comes to arguing policy. He doesn't float like a butterfly, sting like a bee. He just belts contenders into oblivion. The Rhodes scholar Bill Bradley could not stand the solar plexus punches in the Democratic primary; Ross Perot's jug ears have been on permanent wilt since Gore clobbered him for hypocrisy in a debate on the North American Free Trade Area. The Gore campaign people see Bush as a man who leads with a glass chin. Certainly he has displayed a talent for gaffes on issues much simpler than the calculations of the social security budget for the next couple of decades.

But Bush is an artful dodger. The latest spin from the Bush camp, which got them the headline "Bush Talking of Early Debate," was that his campaign managers are kicking round the possibility of a couple of "early" debates - which, when you read the fine print, means late August or early September; well, let's say October, shall we... well, anyway, sometime assuredly before the voting in November?

The prevarications have been cleverly crafted so as not to let people conclude GW is a wimp, and so far they have not aroused any negative reaction. "I want to be president" is not yet up there in people's minds with "I want to be a millionaire". Bush can probably spin it out through the party conventions in August. In the meantime, while affecting insouciance, he is doggedly watching videotapes of Gore in debate, and the New Hampshire Senator Judd Gregg is in dialectical training as a sparring partner.

The Democrats, in fact, would be well advised not to cry "chicken" too much. The Republicans are playing another game. It's called expectations. The more the Gore campaign pushes, the more the public will expect to see him emerge as a combination of Mohammed Ali and Demosthenes. Bush has only to be seen standing upright after 15 rounds to be declared a genius.

Bush is good at playing a crowd. There will be a natural sympathy for the intellectual underdog, provided he does not whine. It worked for the recent one-on-one with Barbara Walters. It was supposed to be an ordeal for him, up against television's most unblinking ferret, but he emerged as a charming moderate. This led the religious conservative James Dobson to complain that "Bush sounds a whole lot more conservative when he is talking to conservatives and a whole lot more moderate when he is talking to moderates."

As one Democratic manager put it to me after the show, "Why can't Al dance like that?" The answer is a nine letter word: principle. Save for his stumble on Elian, Gore has stuck to principle, most recently voting for normalising trade with China against his union constituency.

Watching the Barbara Walters show, however, one could envisage GW doing what Reagan did in the celebrated Cleveland debate in the 1980 election. Everyone knew that president Jimmy Carter had a lock on the facts. The Reagan camp had somehow filched Carter's campaign strategy documents, but they didn't need them. It was Carter himself who blew it. He did not know when to stop.

When he charged Reagan with being a threat to world peace and long-established social programmes, Reagan did not respond in kind. He just shook his head in pity and smiled: "There you go again." For weeks afterwards, in offices and kitchens, anyone under attack reached for the Reaganism.

It is entirely possible, of course, that Bush will be Ford rather than Reagan. Ford got so mixed up in his 1976 debate with Carter that he asserted, to derision, that eastern Europe was free of Soviet domination. The Gore camp counts on the debates doing similar damage to Bush. But appearance counts as much as substance in these encounters. In the Kennedy-Nixon debates of 1960, pros listening to radio, including Lyndon Johnson, awarded the first duel to Nixon. But voters watching television voted on what they saw: a shifty guy with a blue jowl trying to sell them a used car.

Gore's bludgeoning style, and his campaign bullying that nice Mr Bush into an argument, carry the same kind of risk. The reticence in the Bush camp may not be weakness, but a trap to provoke the Gore campaign and exploit the public's dislike of rancour. If that's the score, the debate clock is not a clock at all. It's a time bomb.

Harold Evans in the author of The American Century

webTitle: Newcomer Richard Logan on his first five-wicket haul

fields.headline: Newcomer Richard Logan on his first five-wicket haul
fields.standfirst: Richard Logan, 20, is a right-arm fast-medium bowler for Northamptonshire. He  won a scholarship with Northants in 1996, and is in the process of signing a  year's extension to his three-year contract with them at the moment. He was  a member of England's 1998 Under-19 World Cup-winning side. On May 24 he  took 5-61 against Middlesex at Northampton - his first Championship  five-wicket haul in only his fourth first-class match.
fields.trailText: "I made my Championship debut against Notts [in April] but only bowled one over before it rained. I got my first wicket against Middlesex at Lord's earlier this month - Mark Ramprakash - and then I relaxed into my bowling.
fields.body:
"I made my Championship debut against Notts [in April] but only bowled one over before it rained. I got my first wicket against Middlesex at Lord's earlier this month - Mark Ramprakash - and then I relaxed into my bowling.

"At Northampton for this match [the return Championship game against Middlesex], the pitch was fairly flat, but the ball did a little bit off the seam because it was quite damp. It was a pretty good toss to lose really. I was feeling a bit rusty before this game, because there had been lots of rain so I hadn't had any nets. I had a bad start when my first two overs went for 16, but then I got Owais Shah - lbw - in my third or fourth over and started bowling a lot better. I played with Owais in the Under-19 World Cup side - and it is always nice to get one of your mates out, especially as they always try a bit harder against you. I also got Robin Weston lbw. The ball swung away a little bit and he played across it.

"After lunch I got Ramps [Middlesex's top scorer, with 54] again, another lbw. John Hampshire gave them all - they were pretty adjacent. I think you know when they are definitely out or not. These ones were. The ball to Ramprakash probably held up before nipping back a bit. When you are bowling against someone like Ramps you can try too hard. But you have to back your ability. I know it is a cliché but it is true that it only takes one ball to get a wicket. I'd bowled pretty well at him and Justin Langer at Lord's and that gave me confidence. It is nice to bowl to a top player - a more satisfying challenge.

"The fourth wicket was Ben Hutton. I'd just bowled two real four-balls, but the next one nipped across him. He nicked it and David Sales caught it at first slip. David is one of our best fielders. He started fielding at slip last year, caught a few great catches and has made the position his own.

"The fifth wicket was [Phil] Tufnell. They'd put on 20-odd for the last wicket and had edged a couple of fours. Graeme Swann dropped a catch off me at gully, and I didn't think it was going to be my day, but then Tuffers got a top edge and Mal Loye caught it at third man.

"It was my first first-class 'five-fer', though I got a couple in the second team last year. I got a few congratulatory messages on the phone, and my dad was here to watch which was nice. Mike Gatting was here too and he said well done.

"My main aim at the beginning of the year was to cement a place in the first team. It was between me, Darren Cousins and Paul Taylor, but Taylor got injured so Cousins and I have both been playing. I tend to bowl with the spinner, either Graeme Swann or Michael Davies, but I don't mind because they bowl their overs pretty quickly so you don't have time to lose your rhythm."

Match scorecard

Richard Logan was talking to Tanya Aldred. My Day In The Sun is on wisden.com and cricketunlimited every Monday. Click here for previous editions: Nicky Peng (Durham), Steffan Jones (Somerset), Stephen Peters (Essex), Michael Burns (Somerset), Ben Hollioake (Surrey), Vyvian Pike (Dorset)

fields.headline: Scoot to kill
fields.standfirst: It was a beautiful dream - to gently amble through Italy on a classic scooter. Then  Matthew Fort  hit the nightmare streets of Naples
fields.trailText: It was a beautiful dream - to gently amble through Italy on a classic scooter. Then Matthew Fort hit the nightmare streets of Naples.
fields.body:
When a man has ridden a scooter in Naples, he does not need to boast. When others drawl on about wrestling with crocodiles, killing wild boars with their bare hands and bungee jumping from the top the Niagara Falls, the man who has ridden a scooter in Naples has only to say, in a quite voice, "I have ridden a scooter in Naples," and, if they have any sense, those other thrill seekers will look at him with awe. I am one such man.

For a number of years I had dreamed of riding a scooter the length of Italy, from south to north, to write a contemporary portrait of how Italians cook and eat. The slower I moved, I reasoned, the more I would see and eat. The only trouble was that I had never ridden one. However, I decided that it's never, even at 53, too late to learn, and I apprenticed myself to Passmasters.

It is no fault of theirs that I failed my full test when the time came. I had been tutored with careful rapture by Richard and Graham (I say rapture because bike instructors live in a parallel universe of leathers, speed and mechanical obsession), but on a bitterly cold day, when I was frozen to the very marrow, the uncompromising ex-police motorcyclist who was testing me gave me the thumbs down, principally for failing to maintain "sufficient forward momentum". In other words, I wasn't going fast enough. He did not seem to be a man who would be open to the argument that I wanted to go as slowly as possible.

But I didn't need a full test in Italy to ride anything up to 125cc. The Italian authorities seem to believe that Italians have technical riding skills inborn, and so there's no need for anything so mundane as tests, and who is to say that they are wrong? So, helmet, biker jacket, shades and helmet - yes, even Italians have to wear helmets these days - to hand, I set about getting hold of a scooter in Italy, not wishing to spend half a lifetime riding out there.

It wasn't as easy as I had thought. There don't appear to be any scooter hire agencies in southern Italy, where I was going to begin my meandering idyll. In the end, in Rome, I hired an elegant, cream coloured Vespa of all of 50cc from the charmingly named Bici e Baci (Bikes & Kisses) and had it transported down to Reggio di Calabria.

So it was, one sunny morning in April, that I collected Ginger, as it became known (the noise it made suggested a state continuous high-pitched excitement that reminded me of Chris Evans), and off I set, bag of essentials jammed between my knees, bag containing laptop slung over shoulder, awash with nervous sweat, and with a fine sense of heightened awareness

There are things that can be said concerning the treacherous nature of road surfaces in Italy, of the extraordinary frequency with which crucial road signs appear to have been attacked by a maniac with a hammer. You may talk of the habit of closing all petrol stations on public holidays, which can pose logistical problems if your tank only hold 100kms' worth. But I will not hear a word of criticism against the southern road user. They were, without exception, the most considerate, gracious, best mannered I have every come across.

All right, they may have been well advised to give a wide berth to a portly, evidently non-Italian pottering along none too certainly on a Vespa. Nevertheless, I never witnessed a single episode of road rage, bad driving or loss of temper despite conditions that would have lead to blood on the streets in the UK.

That was until I hit Naples.

How can such an experience be described? There is something of the chariot race in Ben Hur about it, and something of the intergalactic battles in Star Wars.

Vehicles come at you from all angles, all the time. There is a general suicidal recklessness. Cars stop without warning, start without warning, pull out without warning, reverse from hidden back alleys into your path without warning. Traffic roars, leaps, hoots, toots, peals away, converges, moves in all directions at once with a terrible intensity.

Streets that are wide enough for a single lane have two. Streets converge, each delivering a stream of traffic into the path of the other, each stream determined to establish right of passage by force majeure.

Traffic lights? Of course there are traffic lights. Traffic lights are for decoration. Thery are to be gone through, whatever their colour, by guile of brute force.

And through all this mechanised chaos weave the scooters at desperate speeds, one or two people perched on their backs, the rider chatting over his shoulder, waving to a friend, stopping for a few words - then scooting off again, from nought to 60 in three yards.

This traffic is a metaphor for life in Naples in general. But don't they know that there is something amiss in this brilliant, nervous, finely tuned mechanised orchestra. Don't they know that there's someone who doesn't know the rules, who does not dare to blink in case he misses the end of his life, who has never ridden a scooter over cobbles before?

Cobbles; the cobbles of Naples are an encyclopedia of tests of technique and nerve in themselves. Some are large and square, never regular, never set at the same height. They deliver a sequence of bone-shuddering crashes through the suspension of your scooter to your body.

Some are small, rounder, even more irregular, lying at odd angles to each other. The scooter leaps, bucks and skids all in the same second. The handlebars twist this way and that. The back wheel slides away from beneath you. At the same moment, in the corner of your eye you notice something streaking up on your inside, register a woman with a baby in a pushchair half on, half off the pavement, talking to someone on the other side the road. You notice these things despite the fact that your head is nodding at incredible speed in tune with your progress over the cobbles.

Which way? This street or that? Decisions need to be made in an instant. And decisions made in the instant have an uncanny way of being wrong. In these instants a rider lives several lifetimes, develops hair-trigger reactions and gains a highly developed sense of self-preservation. He finds resolution in the face of imminent disaster and achieves a kind transcendental tranquillity that only the greatest masters of Buddhism achieve after decades of meditation, when your mind is emptied of everything except here, now, this second . . . whoops, didn't see you coming. No offence.

No offence is taken. This is all part of the mayhem of rush hour in Naples. People are kindly. They don't swear or rage. They don't confront or abuse. No one is stationary long enough for such pointless pursuits. No one is going to waste energy on anger when all energy has to be concentrated on moving, forwards, sideways, backwards, whichever - just so long as it's moving.

Yes, I tell you, when a man has ridden a scooter in Naples, he has no need to boast.

 Matthew Fort is the Guardian's food editor

fields.headline: Dando murder suspect charged
fields.standfirst: More on the Jill Dando case
fields.trailText: Detectives last night charged a 40-year-old man with the murder of the television presenter Jill Dando, who was shot on the doorstep of her home in south-west London 13 months ago.
fields.body:
Detectives last night charged a 40-year-old man with the murder of the television presenter Jill Dando, who was shot on the doorstep of her home in south-west London 13 months ago.

After a tense weekend of questioning at Hammersmith police station, Barry Michael George was charged with murder at 6pm, five hours before a deadline set by magistrates for his release.

Mr George, an unemployed musician who changed his name to Bulsara, was arrested at 6.30am last Thursday at his home in Crookham Road, Fulham, south-west London.

Police described the development then as "highly significant" but refused to elaborate. Although three other men have been arrested and released in connection with the killing, he was the only one to be questioned on suspicion of murder.

Last night Scotland Yard issued a brief statement: "Barry Michael George, aged 40, unemployed, of 2b Crookham Road, Fulham, south-west London, was tonight charged with the murder of Ms Jill Dando on April 26 1999, at 29 Gowan Avenue, Fulham. He will appear at west London magistrates court tomorrow morning."

The decision to charge Mr George came after four days of questioning.

Hopes that the murder squad, which has been under intense pressure since the shooting, might have achieved a breakthrough had begun to recede over the weekend.

The squad, led by Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell, applied for three extensions to continue holding Mr George. The first was granted by a senior officer on Thursday, and two others were sought in closed hearings.

Mr George changed his name by deed poll in honour of Freddie Mercury, the lead singer of the band Queen, whose real name was Bulsara.

Forty-five officers have been working to solve Dando's murder since she was shot in the side of the head as she returned home from a shopping trip. The investigation so far has cost a reported £2m.

Mr Campbell was deluged with information in the weeks after Dando died but none of it proved immediately significant. His team took more than 1,000 statements and saw 3,000 people. More than 4,000 letters were delivered to the incident room in Kensington, west London, and 13,700 emails were sent to the BBC.

Dando, 37, presented the Holiday programme and Crimewatch. She was killed two months after announcing her engagement to gynaecologist Alan Farthing.

webTitle: Army told to shoot to kill as curfew imposed on Fiji capital

fields.headline: Army told to shoot to kill as curfew imposed on Fiji capital
fields.trailText: Fijian soldiers patrolling the capital, Suva, were today ordered to shoot to kill after the army imposed a 48-hour curfew on the city.
fields.body:
Fijian soldiers patrolling the capital, Suva, were today ordered to shoot to kill after the army imposed a 48-hour curfew on the city.

The army's action came after supporters of the coup leader, George Speight, shot dead a policeman and destroyed a television station. The prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and more than 30 members of his government have been held hostage by masked gunmen in the parliamentary compound since May 19.

The 48-hour curfew began at 6pm local time (0600 GMT). Suva's streets were quiet after police advised people to stay at home and recommended schools close. The army supports the elected government and has ordered all its reservists to report for duty.

Mr Speight and his gunmen tried to distance themselves from the killing of the policeman yesterday but is threatening to kill the daughter of the president, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara. The president has little power, but took over the government after the coup and declared a state of emergency.

For days, the mood of the coup supporters inside the compound had been celebratory but that changed yesterday when an armed mob went on the rampage in Suva.

Mr Speight, a member of the indigenous Fijian majority, wants ethnic Indian Mr Chaudhry removed from power and Indians barred from leading the country again. The former insurance salesman was fired by the prime minister last year as the chairman of two local companies involved in managing Fiji's lucrative timber trade. He had been appointed to both posts by the previous government, in which his father was a senior member.

The coup leader told a Sydney radio station today that he had discovered papers in Mr Chaudhry's office that outlined a plot to enhance ethnic Indian influence in the country.

"They had a project - a very comprehensive social, political plan - aimed at all levels of society, but specifically undermining Fijian political and traditional structures with a view to entrenching Indian influence in Fiji," he said.

Mr Speight yesterday rejected an offer from Fiji's tribal leaders for a peaceful solution to the crisis, saying he would not drop his demand that the constitution be rewritten to keep Indians out of power and that the president should be removed.

Fijians of Indian ancestry make up 44% of the population of 813,000 but control much of the nation's commerce, while indigenous Fijians account for 51%. The country had two bloodless coups in 1987 and elected Mr Chaudry as prime minister last year. He is Fiji's first leader of Indian desecent.

The United Nations, Australia, New Zealand and the United States have criticised the Fijian army for failing to crack down on Mr Speight and his allies.

"We strongly condemn the repugnant, criminal actions of George Speight and his band of gunmen who continue to hold hostages in Fiji's parliamentary complex," the US embassy in Suva said in a statement. "We reiterate our call ... that the hostages be released immediately and unconditionally."

Olympic authorities in Sydney have announced that the torch relay, which had been due to go through Fiji on June 3 on its way to the Sydney games in September, would bypass the country.
