fields.headline: Euro 2000 thugs face joint action
fields.trailText: European interior ministers, including the home secretary, Jack Straw, are expected to discuss strategies today for combating the threat of hooligans to the Euro 2000 football tournament.
fields.body:
European interior ministers, including the home secretary, Jack Straw, are expected to discuss strategies today for combating the threat of hooligans to the Euro 2000 football tournament.

The Home Office said that Mr Straw would be discussing the "strongest possible measures" which could be taken against potential hooligans at a meeting in Brussels.

However, the government yesterday rejected a plea from the Football Association to rush through legislation to stop known hooligans heading for Euro 2000. With the tournament in the Netherlands and Belgium due to start on June 10, the FA called for legislation which would allow for the passports of known hooligans to be withdrawn.

The FA said its preparations for the tournament started in November. It added: "In recent days we have asked ourselves again, is there anything more that can be done?"

The Home Office, however, said that with parliament in recess this week and not due to reassemble until next Monday, it would not be possible to introduce such legislation before Euro 2000.
Guardian staff and agencies

webTitle: IoD keeps up its hostility to the euro

fields.headline: IoD keeps up its hostility to the euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Britain is years away from meeting the conditions the government has laid down for joining the euro, business leaders said yesterday. The Institute of Directors - long hostile to the European currency - said that had the pound been one of the starting elements of the single currency, the economy would be seriously overheating by now.
fields.body:
Britain is years away from meeting the conditions the government has laid down for joining the euro, business leaders said yesterday. The Institute of Directors - long hostile to the European currency - said that had the pound been one of the starting elements of the single currency, the economy would be seriously overheating by now.

There are no signs that British growth rates, unemployment and interest rates moving close to those on the continent, as required in the tests which the Chancellor, Gordon Brown, laid out in 1997, according to the IoD.

"Our business cycle remains obstinately out of synch and our measures of capacity utilisation remain adrift," said Ruth Lea, head of the IoD's policy unit. "While these differences persist it would be economic folly to replace the pound with the euro."

The Institute of Directors' warning was spelt out in written evidence submitted to the Commons Treasury select committee, which is conducting an inquiry into European economic and monetary union.

The IoD's submission warns that the economy is not sufficiently flexible to withstand the stresses of joining Emu, the second of the Chancellor's tests.

The IoD said there was no sign that the City was suffering from being outside euroland.

webTitle: Teething troubles in the fight between good and evil

fields.headline: Teething troubles in the fight between good and evil
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: It's what a generation of superannuated hippies have been waiting for - the big screen version of Lord of the Rings. With Sir Ian McKellen as the wizard Gandalf, JRR Tolkien's epic is being filmed in some of the more remote and beautiful parts of New Zealand.
fields.body:
It's what a generation of superannuated hippies have been waiting for - the big screen version of Lord of the Rings. With Sir Ian McKellen as the wizard Gandalf, JRR Tolkien's epic is being filmed in some of the more remote and beautiful parts of New Zealand.

Thirty or so years ago, the book was up there with Sgt Pepper's and the Tibetan Book of the Dead as one of the indispensable counter-culture artefacts for the 60s generation. Although it has always sold well - and to the chagrin of literary critics continues to head lists of readers' favourite books - it was never really as influential in the dour 70s or the nakedly aspirational 80s as it had been in the summers of kaftans and magic mushrooms.

That may all be about to change. Assuming it is not the turkey to end all turkeys - which is a distinct possibility despite having a budget as big as that for Titanic - the celluloid version of the exploits of Frodo Baggins could again become the bible of the counter-culture. Why? Because, the book's story seems to chime perfectly with the arguments deployed by the anti-globalisation protesters in Seattle and Washington.

For those who have never read it - or who were too stoned at the time to remember it - Lord of the Rings is the tale of the bid for world domination by the Dark Lord, Sauron, who has forged a ring of power with which he can enslave the whole of Middle Earth and thereby force every realm to submit to his will. Sauron genetically engineers a race of ugly warriors, orcs, and presides over a military-industrial complex which delights in destruction and the despoiling of the environment.

Patrick Curry in his book Defending Middle-Earth draws the obvious conclusion. "It needs no allegorical special pleading or stretch of the imagination to see that our Ring is the malevolent amalgam of the unaccountable nation-state, capitalism in the form of transnational economic power, and scientism, or the monopoly of knowledge by modern technological science. Like Tolkien's Ring, there are apparently no limits to its potential mastery of nature and, once it's on the finger of its collective principal servants - that is, completely removed from any democratic accountability - no way to control it."

A few years ago, when globalisation was sweeping all before it, this sort of argument would easily have been dismissed as the ridiculous fantasy of those harking back to a golden age that never was. Anybody who didn't sign up to the inexorably logical, efficient and scientific world that global capital served up was branded as one of the "stop the world I want to get off" brigade, and that was it.

Frankly, this was always a ludicrous argument. If you're in a machine hurtling towards the edge of a precipice, of course you want to stop it and get off. The question is whether globalisation can deliver on its promises or whether it is the sort of human, economic and environmental dead end that the "stop the world" clan say it is.

Seattle and its aftermath have forced the supporters of globalisation into a crash re-think. For the first time in years, they have been obliged to find a positive justification for the way the world is heading, rather than simply repeat ad infinitum that there is no alternative. One such justification - and an elegant one at that - is the forthcoming book, A Future Perfect, written by two journalists on the Economist magazine, John Micklethwait and Adrian Wooldridge. Its conclusion is that there are both pros and cons for globalisation, but that there are more pros than cons. "Yes, it does increase inequality, but it does not create a winner-take-all society, and the winners hugely outnumber the losers. Yes, it leaves some people behind, but it helps millions more to leap ahead. Yes, it can make bad government worse, but the onus should be on crafting better government, not blaming globalisation. Yes, it curtails some of the power of nation states, but they remain the fundamental unit of modern politics. Globalisation is not destroying geography, merely enhancing it."

But the economic benefits of globalisation are only half the story, say Micklethwait and Wooldridge. Globalisation has to be put in its proper political context - "as an extension of the idea of liberty and as a chance to renew the fundamental rights of the individual." Globalisation has not - as some of its critics suggest - involved an exchange of master, with the faceless corporation replacing the faceless state, but instead is a force for personal liberation.

This is an interesting turning of the tables, suggesting that if there is a Manichaean struggle between good and evil, we've all got it completely wrong. The globalisers are the hobbits not the dark lords, and the sooner those who care about the poor, the environment and human rights recognise the fact the better it will be for everyone. But especially, no doubt, for those who are already doing very nicely, thank you.

Despite this attempt to hail the new golden dawn of globalisation, what seems to be happening is that the old politics is reasserting itself. Nature abhors a vacuum and a dirty great vacuum was left when communism was brought down by its own internal contradictions. That hole is now being filled, slowly and incoherently perhaps, by those groups railing against the way the world is being run. This would probably be happening even were globalisation running smoothly, but the process is being accelerated by the fact that the new world order has suffered some teething troubles.

These look likely to persist. On Friday afternoon, for example, the dollar fell sharply against the euro on the foreign exchanges as dealers finally woke up to the idea that the party may be over on Wall Street. The correction in the euro-dollar rate has a lot further to go, with the possibility that we are on the brink of the climactic forex crisis of the past decade - that of the mighty greenback. With its massive current account deficit, its wild speculation in unproductive assets and its reliance on hot money from overseas, America resembles the economies of south-east Asia that went belly-up in 1997 and 1998. The difference, of course, is that the US accounts for around 25% of global gross domestic product. We could all be in for a very bumpy ride.

But there is more to the backlash against globalisation than the gyrations of the financial markets. More striking has been the reaction against the notion of scientific progress, epitomised by the resistance to GM foods and expressed in its most public form by Prince Charles.

Now, it seems obvious that some of the wilder accusations against science are not only wrong, but dangerously wrong. Scientific discoveries have brought countless tangible benefits to the world, from labour-saving devices that provide us with more leisure time to drugs that help us to live longer. Yet when it comes to GM foods, and biotechnology more generally, there is a sense that science has been captured by the profit motive and has lost its moral compass. As David Korten put it in his book, the Post Corporate World, the yoking together of objective science and corporate money has resulted in a system "in which power and expertise are delinked from moral accountability, instrumental and financial values override life values, and what is expedient and profitable takes precedence over what is nurturing and responsible".

Scientists would strongly deny that any of this is true, but that, to a large extent, is irrelevant, because more and more people believe it to be true.

In the end, life is not like Lord of the Rings, and we should be thankful for that. We need more than people who know about herbs to keep us healthy and we need more than a hierarchical, feudal system to keep us in food. Middle Earth, as described by Tolkien, was a deeply illiberal place. But if science is now viewed with mistrust, markets with contempt and globalisation with trepidation, the fault lies not with those who have been protesting in Seattle and elsewhere but with those who, piece by piece, have dismantled the institutions that once underpinned the international system, ensured security for the weak as well as the strong, and helped save capitalism from itself.

Larry Elliott

webTitle: Violence escalates as mob runs riot in Fiji

fields.headline: Violence escalates as mob runs riot in Fiji
fields.standfirst: Coup leader's supporters ransack state TV station
fields.trailText: A police officer was shot dead and a TV station ransacked yesterday when a mob supporting the Fijian coup leader George Speight ran riot through the capital, Suva.
fields.body:
A police officer was shot dead and a TV station ransacked yesterday when a mob supporting the Fijian coup leader George Speight ran riot through the capital, Suva.

Mr Speight, who has held the prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and about 30 other people captive since May 19, said earlier he believed the crisis was close to resolution and the hostages could be freed within 48 hours.

Last night the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, expressed alarm at the surge in violence in the Fijian capital. Eight shots were heard, most of them around the sprawling parliament complex where Mr Chaudhry is being held.

Mr Speight and his supporters took Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister hostage after storming the parliament in the name of indigenous Fijians, who comprise about 51% of the population. Ethnic Indians dominate the country's economy.

Last night Suva's FM 96 radio station said four shots had been fired by a group of youths behind Government House, the waterfront home of the president, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, whose daughter is among the hostages. Journalists said shots had been fired into the tyre of a police vehicle.

Police said one of their officers, Filipo Seavula, had died from gunshot wounds last night after getting caught up in a mob of about 100 indigenous Fijians.

Two soldiers and a TV cameraman were shot and wounded early on Saturday during a confrontation between soldiers and Mr Speight's supporters.

Yesterday, most of the mob gathered in the centre of the city before marching towards the parliament, supported by two vans. Two journalists recognised an armed man in one of the vans as a member of Mr Speight's group camped inside the compound.

The mob then attacked the nearby state-owned Fiji Television, which had broadcast a programme on the media's treatment of the crisis, and forced it off the air. The programme contained comments critical of Mr Speight, a former insurance salesman.

"The main studio has been utterly trashed," an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio reporter who went to the building said.

"The cameras have been smashed to pieces, there are windows broken everywhere. Apparently the mob just charged in and all the staff ran out the back."

Mr Speight, who had earlier prayed and sung hymns at a Methodist service inside the parliamentary compound, indicated before meeting a 15-man delegation from Fiji's great council of chiefs that the crisis might soon be over.

"I believe in my heart of hearts that we're very close to a resolution," he said. "If not 24, certainly 48 hours."

The council of chiefs wants an interim government run by a council of advisers under Ratu Sir Kamisese. It also wants the constitution revised to guarantee that only an indigenous Fijian can be prime minister.

The coup leader demands the president's resignation, a new constitution, and the appointment of an indigenous government. Yesterday's talks broke up without a breakthrough.

On Saturday, in an attempt to defuse the crisis, Ratu Sir Kamisese suspended Mr Chaudhry's democratically elected government and said he alone was in charge.

The army has pledged to support him. He is to name a council of advisers and a caretaker prime minister today.

In a statement issued by the Foreign Office, Mr Cook said he had spoken to Ratu Sir Kamisese and urged a return to constitutional government.

"Don McKinnon, the Commonwealth secretary general - to whom I also spoke - took a similar line," the foreign secretary said. "I am concerned by recent reports that armed mobs have taken over the state TV station in Suva.

"I am today sending a message to President Mara reinforcing our support for a peaceful, constitutional resolution to this crisis and for the safe release of the hostages.

"I have appealed to the president not to yield to armed force and to uphold the rule of law. I also repeated to the president my offer to consider any request for help."

Paul Tait is a Reuters correspondent.

fields.headline: A shift in dot.com sentiment
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: It appears everyone has something to say about the recent failure of Boo.com. A taxi driver recently gave me his best half hour on the subject and you'd be a little naive to think he was in any way sympathetic towards (in his words) "a bunch of young people burning their millions on caviar, champagne and concorde".
fields.body:
It appears everyone has something to say about the recent failure of Boo.com. A taxi driver recently gave me his best half hour on the subject and you'd be a little naive to think he was in any way sympathetic towards (in his words) "a bunch of young people burning their millions on caviar, champagne and concorde".

Interest in the dot.com area is as high as ever (somewhat ironically the new media news service NetImperative was never more famous than it was on its deathbed) but sentiment towards the new wave of businesses seems to have shifted substantially.

Enquiries are now more likely to be sceptical and focusing on your burn rate than awestruck and focusing on the size of your marketing budget.

As an early-stage start-up business we have been among the first to feel the cooler but somewhat refreshing winds of change that seem to have been around ever since the disappointing Lastminute.com flotation. In the past month in particular, investor sentiment has definitely turned against dot.coms and we know of a number of internet-based businesses that are struggling to raise critical second-round funds in a difficult environment.

Venture capitalists, never known as speedy movers - despite what you read - appear to be sitting on their hands, waiting for the market to turn again.

Our belief is that, providing there is no wider stock market crash, the downturn represents a short-term shaking out of the market and brings an overdue dose of realism to the sector. At the moment there is little to distinguish the weaker internet companies from stronger online businesses so all are valued in a similar way. It means that when a company is revealed to be performing poorly, the sector as a whole takes a tumble.

In the short term at least we are relatively well protected from the vicissitudes of the market, having completed a major round of funding only last month. However, it is reasonable for our partners and members of the press to ask how we are going to avoid making the same mistakes that Boo appear to have made.

Our priorities are clear. We have to get our systems and operational processes in place before we commit to other significant items of expenditure, particularly on marketing the service. Because we are providing a financial product and our customers will be teenagers, there is an additional imperative to provide a service that is absolutely watertight. We will not launch until we have these critical elements in place.

One criticism that has been levelled at Boo is that it tried too much too early in a market, clothing, that inherently does not lend itself to online retailing. In contrast, we have complete confidence that there is a market for our services, particularly because teenagers have substantial disposable income, are online more than other generations and are keen to buy on the internet.

Some of the unrestrained glee at the collapse of a high profile dot.com business was unfortunate. We have little wish to add to the chorus of opinions being expressed but are seeking to learn from the painful experiences of others.

Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of Rools.com, a service that enables teenagers to buy online without a credit card

webTitle: Scottish section 28 rebel vows to turn up heat

fields.headline: Scottish section 28 rebel vows to turn up heat
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: The Stagecoach tycoon Brian Souter and campaigners plan to "intensify the war" over repeal of section 28 in Scotland if politicians this week reject a move to enshrine the importance of marriage in new legislation.
fields.body:
The Stagecoach tycoon Brian Souter and campaigners plan to "intensify the war" over repeal of section 28 in Scotland if politicians this week reject a move to enshrine the importance of marriage in new legislation.

Mr Souter had indicated that he would drop his opposition to section 28, which bans the promotion of the acceptability of homosexuality in schools, if a marriage-friendly amendment was adopted by the Scottish executive.

However, Jack Irvine, a spokesman for Mr Souter and the Keep the Clause campaign, said yesterday that it looked unlikely that the amendment, tabled by the Labour MSP Michael McMahon, would succeed when it is debated tomorrow.

The amendment, backed by the Catholic church, would add two clauses to legislation stressing that most people find stability in marriage but that children from different types of families should not suffer intolerance or stigmatisation.

The Scottish executive has so far resisted efforts to enshrine marriage in the legislation. A spokesman said yesterday: "Although marriage is an important part in stable family relationships it is not the only form of relationship. We do not want to be prescriptive or stigmatise children because of the lifestyle choices of their parents."

The Scottish parliament recently voted to push ahead with repeal, replacing section 28 with a separate clause that recognised the importance of "stable family life".

Mr Irvine said if the amendment was not adopted, campaigners would turn up the heat: "We will be going into the constituencies of MSPs who have failed to back family values and we will bring the full might of our advertising campaign to bear on them."

The development comes just 48 hours before Mr Souter announces the results of his privately funded ballot on repeal.

webTitle: GM genes can jump species, says expert

fields.headline: GM genes can jump species, says expert
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: A claim that genes used to modify crops can jump the species barrier into other forms of wildlife was last night raising new concerns about the potential threat to human health and the environment.
fields.body:
A claim that genes used to modify crops can jump the species barrier into other forms of wildlife was last night raising new concerns about the potential threat to human health and the environment.

Unpublished work by Professor Hans-Hinrich Kaatz of the University of Jena, Germany, suggests genes from GM rape seed can be transferred to bacteria and fungi in the gut of honey bees, posing serious questions for GM supporters and the biotech industry who believe the chances of gene transfer are very limited.

The findings, if substantiated, could further dent public confidence in scientists and the government, whose handling of the crisis surrounding the growing of GM-contaminated conventional crops over thousands of acres in the last two springs has provoked anger from farmers, anti-GM campaigners and the Tories.

Prof Kaatz has been experimenting for three years with honey bees on a field sowed with GM rape, engineered to resist certain herbicides while surrounding weeds were treated. He removed pollen gathered by the bees on their hind legs when they returned to the hive and in a laboratory fed it to young honey bees which naturally eat it as part of a high protein diet.

Then he took intestines out of the bees and spread the contents on a growth medium to grow micro-organisms. In some bacteria and in a yeast from the gut he found the gene that conferred resistance to the herbicide.

Prof Kaatz told the German television station ZDF that the "bees had obviously taken up these genes. They were in the bacteria in the intestinal tract of the bees and seemed to have come from the genes of the original plant and to have been taken up into their own genetic make-up." webTitle: More thought, less populism, to fight crime

fields.headline: More thought, less populism, to fight crime
fields.standfirst: Road to the manifesto
fields.trailText: "Tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime" was one of Labour's most successful soundbites in the run up to the landslide victory of 1997.
fields.body:
"Tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime" was one of Labour's most successful soundbites in the run up to the landslide victory of 1997.

It combined an appeal to the law and order instincts of the Daily Mail reader with the belief of the Guardian-reading classes that tackling crime means tackling problems more deeply rooted in society.

But while some imaginative new policies have been introduced aimed at curbing crime in the medium-to-long term, they have proved less visible than the political auction in which each party seeks to outdo the others to prove their "lock 'em up" credentials.

The next Labour government should show its determination to tackle both crime and the causes of crime by building on its current target to cut car-related offences by 30% - and announce an even more ambitious long-term objective: halving the rate of acquisitive crime from the peak it reached in 1992. This would involve a huge extension of the government's crime reduction programme, based on policies that pass one simple test: do they work?

A whole range of anti-crime measures would be used: dealing with school exclusions, diverting young people from crime, making goods harder to steal, concentrating resources on crime hotspots, improving conviction rates, and making prisons work in preventing criminals offending again.

Public demand for a more visible police presence, demonstrated by the debate on police numbers, should be met by supplementing the use of constables with police-approved community patrol officers. The regulation of the private security industry is essential to engender public confidence in such patrols. This would enable the more skilled constables to be used in intelligence-led "targeted policing" aimed at catching criminals.

Police numbers rose from 110,000 to 125,000 between 1979 and 1997 and budgets almost doubled in real terms. Yet recorded crime soared over the same period. It is time to realise that the most effective policies - such as cutting long-term unemployment, truancy, drug abuse, homelessness and poor parenting - are not necessarily those that produce immediate results.

In the face of rising crime figures Labour must resist the temptation to follow populist policies, and avoid imposing blanket "zero tolerance" arrest policies. It should avoid, too, increasingly punitive mandatory sentences on the alleged "criminal classes" which pay little regard to the seriousness of the crime. Labour should also quietly drop its authoritarian experiments, like child curfews.

It should expand embryonic programmes which tackle the link between addictive drugs and crime - while recognising that alcohol is linked to as much crime as heroin and cocaine.

Arrest referral schemes should be expanded to include drink as well as drug treatment programmes. The law on cannabis causes more harm than it prevents and criminalises large numbers of young people. The sanctions for cannabis possession should be substantially reduced to informal warnings and fixed fines with prosecutions. Prison should no longer be used.

This stops short of legalisation. Cannabis is not a harmless drug - there are physical and psychological health risks from long-term use. Unilateral legalisation would mean Britain swiftly being labelled a "narco state". However the use of cannabis for medical purposes should be legalised.

To increase public confidence, judges need to state in open court the minimum and maximum term a convicted offender will serve and in controversial cases they should be prepared to explain on TV their reasons for passing a lenient or a tough sentence.

Prison governors cannot cope with offending behaviour in overcrowded conditions. A legal limit needs to be set on the numbers in each prison with the "jail full" sign going up when it is reached. Literacy programmes need to undergo rapid expansion.

The successful introduction of the home detention curfew, backed by tagging, should be expanded for less serious offenders. Moreover, it is time the public sector was allowed to bid to run all new prisons.

The next Labour government should give a further injection of resources into our asylum system so that the backlog of 90,000 cases can be brought down. The rapid processing of asylum claims is the most effective deterrent to the abusive asylum seeker. While they wait for their claims to be resolved, asylum seekers should be allowed to work. Those who cannot work should be paid benefits and the voucher system scrapped.

Britain must resist European moves to redefine the Geneva convention on asylum so that it covers only the victims of direct state persecution. It should endorse the decisions of the British courts which say the right to asylum covers those, such as rape victims, whom the state fails to protect.

The commission for racial equality should be merged with the equal opportunities commission into a more powerful human rights commission. The incorporation of the European convention of human rights needs to acknowledge changes in the past 50 years in the rights of women, gays, and ethnic groups.

What happens next ...

Do you think Alan Travis has got it right - or is there more that should be done in the second term? Send your thoughts to our letters page or join the debate at Road to the manifesto

fields.headline: Forest corruption report covered up
fields.standfirst:
Governments, big business, World Bank and IMF named in investigation

The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: A devastating report about the destruction of tropical forests by multinational companies has been suppressed for three years by the European commission and World Wide Fund for Nature.
fields.body:
A devastating report about the destruction of tropical forests by multinational companies has been suppressed for three years by the European commission and World Wide Fund for Nature.

The report named companies prepared to bribe and bully their way to lucrative logging concessions. It also blamed the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank for inducing countries to sell their forests for a quick cash return to pay off debts to western countries.

The European commission, which paid the researchers nearly £200,000 for the work, was fearful of the repercussions if they named names and asked for a second version with the names taken out - but even this version was watered down.

A third version still makes clear that EU funds being poured into developing countries to ensure forests are carefully managed are frequently being wasted. Forest laws were enacted but no action taken.

The well-respected authors from the World Resources Institute and WWF said they were so disturbed by what they found that they recommended a moratorium on all further logging in 11 countries - Cameroon, Gabon, Congo (Brazzaville), Central African Republic, Equatorial Guinea and the Democratic Republic of Congo in central Africa; Belize, Surinam and Guyana in the Caribbean rim; and Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands in the South Pacific rim. This should last until bribery scandals had been investigated and proper environmental standards enforced, they said.

They also recommended an end to EU aid until these issues were addressed - but no action has been taken. The report says: "The new investments [by Asian multinational companies] have been concentrated in countries with generally weak or outdated environmental and social laws and little enforcement capacity. The governments of these countries are easy pickings to foreign investors as they have weak forest services, poor monitoring capacity, inefficient tax collection and auditing capacity, and in some cases widespread bribery and corruption.

"Many of the countries are suffering severe economic difficulties with large foreign debts, high inflation and unemployment. In the majority of countries studied, decision making is controlled by a small group of powerful people or clans within the government that look at primary forests of their country as a short-term source of personal revenue, not as a productive ecosystem which can generate social, economic and ecological benefits on the long term for the entire country and its people."

Corruption

The Solomon Islands, Papua New Guinea, Cameroon and Belize were all named as suffering large-scale corruption.

"In some countries administrative procedures facilitate widespread corruption. Senior officials in countries such as Papua New Guinea have been shown to be taking decisions to award logging rights in exchange for bribes."

The report says although European companies have in the past indulged in bad practices the scale of the new incursions was much larger and that: "The logging itself is often very careless, with high collateral damage to the surrounding forest. The roads built to extract the timber often hundreds of kilometres long create access to frontier areas that facilitate the entry of commercial hunts, farmers, miners and others who cause further environmental damage." The companies frequently end up in violent clashes with local people and native tribes.

It blames the main donors to these countries - the World Bank, Japan, the EU, France, Germany, the UK and the US - for failing to enforce their own rules to promote forest conservation and responsible management. In fact the World Bank and IMF make things worse by imposing monetary reform on the countries, the report says. These countries are urged to allow in multinational companies and governments are urged to sell their forests for cash to pay back debts.

The report says if substantial action is not taken soon by governments, donor agencies and investors, as well as environmental and social pressure groups, much of the remaining virgin primary forests in the Caribbean rim, Central Africa and Pacific will be lost within five to 10 years, due to the expansion of unsustainable logging operations.

The original report was completed in 1997 and the EU cleared a twice-revised version for publication, printing 5,000 copies. Its press launch in July last year was blocked by the WWF, some of whose employees had carried out the research. The organisation feared that some of the governments concerned, particularly Malaysia, would close down WWF offices.

A weaker version of the report has now been prepared and, because the European commission refused to foot the bill, the WWF pulped the original 5,000 copies and has paid to print 2,000 of the latest version. The organisation claimed in a statement to the Guardian that it had to correct some "inaccuracies" and hopes this new version will be published in July.

Expert authors

The Guardian has seen the first three versions of the report - including the original draft that details the names of companies and individuals involved in bribery scandals. The main authors of the report are Nigel Sizer, an expert for the World Resources Institute in Washington and Dominiek Plouvier, a forestry consultant who works for WWF in Belgium. All their work was peer-reviewed in the countries concerned and by other forestry experts before being submitted.

Mr Sizer said: "Of course I was deeply disappointed that the report was not published. A few things were corrected in the peer review process. We were very careful about the conclusions we drew in the report. The commission was concerned and asked some of the names to be removed but I stand by everything that appeared in the drafts. My reputation and that of the Institute depends on getting things right. Lack of accuracy was not the reason the report was withheld."

A commission spokesman said: "We asked originally for some of the names to be removed and for some revisions but were satisfied with the later versions of the report. It was WWF that intervened to prevent publication last year. The new version of the report has now been delivered by them and will be distributed to interested parties when a list had been drawn up." Officials of the commission would now consider the report's findings.

WWF's senior forest officer, Jean-Paul Jeanrenaud, said WWF had been anxious to name names but was concerned that many of the companies were Asian and the organisation did not want to appear to be Asian-bashing. After the Asian financial crisis the report was held up for updating.
Papua New Guinea

If the forests were sustainably managed and harvested, it is estimated that the annual income to the country could be as much as £2bn. However massive corruption in the issue of timber permits, failure to monitor exports, and low royalties and taxes have reduced government returns. Environmental and social impacts have been serious and well documented.

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: Wireless is proving to be a fatted calf for independents. Last week a modest Bethnal Green-based radio production company, Somethin' Else, previously known only for jazz and alternative arts programming, transformed itself into "the world's first mobile internet entertainment network" and more than doubled its size by announcing deals with Ericsson's WISE portal and Genie Internet. By summer, the XY network will be putting out high-quality audio content over WAP phones. With a daily soap opera and something known as "tamagotchi radio", director Paul Bennun promises they will be "reinventing radio for the interactive age". Arts broadcasters and DJs from ITV, BBC1 and Radio 4 are being signed up (DJ Gilles Peterson for one) and, rumour has it, broadcasting's elder statesman Lord Bragg might be involved. "I really couldn't tell you... but we're talking very famous people", Bennun tantalises. "And new talent as well - we're looking for the next Ali G." Isn't everybody?

Wireless is proving to be a fatted calf for independents. Last week a modest Bethnal Green-based radio production company, Somethin' Else, previously known only for jazz and alternative arts programming, transformed itself into "the world's first mobile internet entertainment network" and more than doubled its size by announcing deals with Ericsson's WISE portal and Genie Internet. By summer, the XY network will be putting out high-quality audio content over WAP phones. With a daily soap opera and something known as "tamagotchi radio", director Paul Bennun promises they will be "reinventing radio for the interactive age". Arts broadcasters and DJs from ITV, BBC1 and Radio 4 are being signed up (DJ Gilles Peterson for one) and, rumour has it, broadcasting's elder statesman Lord Bragg might be involved. "I really couldn't tell you... but we're talking very famous people", Bennun tantalises. "And new talent as well - we're looking for the next Ali G." Isn't everybody?

 Have I Got News for You, BBC2's satirical news gameshow, will soon be available - wait for it! - on your mobile phone. HaveIGotNewsforYou.com, which launched on the web last week, will turn regular jollies such as Odd One Out and Missing Words into interactive games. Paul Zwillenberg, co-creator of the new independent Hat Trick/KPE Interactive, assures us that there will also be opportunities to chat live with Angus Deayton, Ian Hislop and Paul Merton when the mobile site launches in the summer (if they haven't switched off their phones and fled the country by then).

 The News Network reshuffle at News International has reopened speculation about the future of NN controller Alasdair MacLeod, whose role has been cut back to managing the ailing auction site FiredUp and the soon-to-be-launched Revolver.com. The pay-off, if it were to happen, would be phenomenal: MacLeod has served the family firm for 10 years and his salary is thought to be around £300k. There is also the small fact that he is married to Murdoch's daughter Prudence.

 The new media backlash takes some intriguing forms. E-Commerce Cocktails at the Lux gallery last Friday was a "high camp" send-up of the dot.com cash-groping cult, organised by novelist Jim Flint whose next book, Network Network, satirises the First Tuesday phenomenon. John Browning, co-founder of First Tuesday (and former executive editor of Wired), and ex-Economist journalist Azeem Azar, head of E-souk incubator, took part in the discussions, just to show they were in on the joke really.

 Visitors to the Internet World Show at Earl's Court last week were treated to the latest in "smart" jewellery: tiny wireless phones embedded in bracelets, belts, necklaces and wristbands. Never call a dangly earring dumb again.

fields.headline: You've got ads
fields.standfirst: Direct-marketeers have discovered a new medium for their message - email. It offers them the chance to target very specific groups. Better still, it's cheap.  Patrick Barkham  reports
fields.trailText: Direct-marketeers have discovered a new medium for their message - email. It offers them the chance to target very specific groups. Better still, it's cheap. Patrick Barkham reports.
fields.body:
There is an amazing online device that promises to deliver compelling advertisements straight to interested consumers, while leaving enough change in the adman's budget for a celebratory party or three. Direct marketeer pioneers have a name for this technology: email.

Tired of boring banners and annoying interstitials (adverts which pop up and fill your screen while you are browsing the web), the advertising industry is turning back to email, the internet's oldest and best selling point. Through innovative ways of targeting newly sophisticated email ads, the industry hopes to take advantage of tantalising figures from Fletcher Research which show that 10% of permission-based email ads - where users have freely given away their email address to receive such promotions - are clicked on by consumers, compared to 0.5% of banner ads.

First, they have to solve the stigma of unsolicited mail, or spam. A GarterGroup study found that 90% of US internet users are sent junk mail on a daily basis and, judging by the number of militant anti-spam sites there, many detest the unsolicited mail that clogs up their inboxes. Web-based email services such as Hotmail and Yahoo! have responded by setting up filters to allow users to sift out junk mail; people often establish multiple email accounts themselves to do the same.

US businessman Sam Khuri tried email advertising the bad old way. Discarding every rule of respectable direct marketeers, he bombarded email addresses with messages promoting his company, Benchmark Printing, and ended up facing an array of court actions. In March, a US court convicted him of spamming BiblioTech, the first UK firm to take legal action against junk mail, and ordered him to pay undisclosed damages and $1,000 (£600) costs.

There are more profitable ways of advertising and marketing via email. Some campaigns are sophisticated and subtle, such as the e-marketing of American Psycho in the US this spring. More than 40,000 people signed up to receive emails from its main character, Patrick Bateman, and also got to peep at emails he exchanged with his therapist. An email drama played out in their in-boxes and, rather like Freeserve's experiment with e-drama in the shape of Online Caroline, people were soon hooked. "You can't not see the movie after that kind of involvement," says Tara Kole of Lions Gate Films.

The obvious can work too. "Email promotions are massive in the US," says Annie Millar, managing director of Manchester-based online marketeers xxist.com. US emailers enjoy scratch screen offers, in which they can run their mouse over an html email ad (a clickable email which opens up to look like a webpage) to see if they have won anything. "It is instant gratification, instant win," says Millar. Such promotions capture information from customers in a step-by-step fashion as people can sign up for bigger competitions by giving away more information about their consumption habits. As Millar says: "The more you give, the more you win. You are basically being paid to give information indirectly."

All email advertisers need to do is ask. But in Britain they need to get their address books in order first. Millar fears that Europe's stringent, and largely untested, data protection laws mean that "somebody is going to get their knuckles rapped big time in the UK. Some serious players have not sorted out their privacy issues. When you tell companies that they can't put two databases together, they look at you and shuffle in their seats a bit." In America, advertising company DoubleClick caused a storm of consumer protests after it was found piecing together different bits of data without users' consent, to build up secret consumer profiles.

Opting in is the key for eGroups, a community email service with more than 14.8m members worldwide, which launched its UK website last month. Anyone with an email address can sign up for an interest group, one of which is networking group First Tuesday. Its members are sent all its eGroup emails and can use eGroups' facilities, including calendar services, file sharing, message archiving and online polling. In return, eGroups includes discreet html and text ads at the bottom of emails. EGroups offers "very, very focused advertising", capable of selling ad space that reaches specific audiences, says UK general manager Jerry Upshall. For instance, a wetsuit company would pay premium rates to insert an advert into emails exchanged by 5,000 snorkelling enthusiasts.

"There are a couple of rules you have to respect," cautions Upshall. "First, don't send anything to a user that they don't want. And even when you do have permission, be selective. Is an email once a day appropriate? Probably not, but once a week might be. If you expect users to receive these ads, you have to give them something in return. We are giving them a really powerful email group tool and our users love it, which is why we've grown so quickly in a year and a half.

"Email advertising is coming on to the radar screen in a big way," he continues. "This is going to be the marketing tool of the next six months." As well as offering advertisers unrivalled opportunities to court their favourite targets, it also has financial benefits. In the current climate of insecurity, email advertising is reassuringly cheap for nervous online operations wanting to trim ad spends.

Despite dot.com gloom, entrepreneurial siblings Roy and Eldar Tuvey are so confident of the success of their UK email advertising start-up that they have forsaken secure City jobs to launch Mailround.com, backed to the tune of $5m (£3.03m) by venture capitalists Chase Episode 1.

The Tuveys were inspired by old-fashioned franking on envelopes to devise a system whereby users - Mailrounders - download software which "stamps" all their email with html adverts. Users will then receive "gold", "silver" or "bronze" ratings, depending on the number of emails they send and the response rates the ads get. Based on the revenues Mailround generates, Mailrounders are rewarded with tokens exchangeable at six top retailers and a charity.

Roy Tuvey believes that, like eGroups, it could grow exponentially after its launch in July. "It is a viral marketing product. If someone becomes a Mailrounder they can chose when to accept ad stamps in the emails they send, so that important job application does not need to be adorned with an ad. Recipients of email from Mailrounders with the ads enclosed will be a click away from becoming Mailrounders themselves. If we get the customer proposition right, we can grow a very large user-base very quickly."

"From an advertiser's point of view we are offering something no website can offer," claims Tuvey. "First, we guarantee a superior consumer attention. You are getting an email from a friend so you are guaranteed to open it and look at the stamp. Second is the targeting. A lot of websites talk a good game in terms of targeting but we are really built on a one-to-one marketing relationship with consumers. And the third thing is the new demographic. A lot of sites are very keen to grab people at their first point of entry into the internet, which is often email."

Mailround has its doubters. "I think it is viable for certain types of people, such as students. They'll do anything," says Annie Millar of xxist.com. "But I don't think your average A or B users are going to be interested because little chunks of money aren't for them. They just want speed and information."

Too much ad information, in over-complicated animated html emails which slow down many ordinary modem connections, is what direct marketeers are rightly wary of. But they also have to curb their desire to saturate the email ad arena.

If they swamp consumers with email ads, no matter how funky the sell, or how juicy the reward, response rates will drop, just as people have wised up to the "click here" cunning of banner ads. Only by treading carefully will the marketeer-pioneers not destroy the goose that lays the golden email.

fields.headline: RUC row threatens deal
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein yesterday raised the political temperature in Northern Ireland in advance of restored devolution at midnight tonight, as it vowed to embark on a campaign to overturn concessions to Ulster Unionists in the controversial policing bill.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein yesterday raised the political temperature in Northern Ireland in advance of restored devolution at midnight tonight, as it vowed to embark on a campaign to overturn concessions to Ulster Unionists in the controversial policing bill.

Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's chief negotiator, while praising David Trimble, the leader of the Ulster Unionists, for securing a return to all-inclusive government, labelled the legislation to reform the RUC "totally and absolutely unacceptable". He said it was a pale shadow of Chris Patten's recommendations for reforming the force.

Mr McGuinness, the former IRA chief of staff, will be back in government as education minister tomorrow as the 12-member power-sharing executive gets a second chance. It will have its first meeting on Thursday.

Mr Trimble on Saturday managed to persuade his ruling Ulster Unionist council to support a return to government with Sinn Fein, on the back of an IRA offer to put weapons beyond use, by the slim majority of 53% to 47%. Critics within his party warned that it could soon split.

Republicans said last night they would be making fresh representations to Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, about the policing bill, due to receive its second reading next week. The SDLP and senior Labour figures are expected to table amendments.

Sinn Fein last week warned that the IRA's unprecedented initiative to put arms beyond use and allow weapons inspectors to examine some of its dumps was at risk because the policing bill departed from Mr Patten's report. That altered the context in which the offer was forwarded.

A senior Sinn Fein source said last night: "We have many, many friends at Westminster. We will be asking them to lobby for us. The changes to Patten clearly fall outside the Good Friday agreement, but it is up to the IRA to make any decision on its offer."

The British and Irish governments are confident that the pact will remain intact. They expect that the IRA will soon invite Cyril Ramaphosa, the former secretary general of the African National Congress, and the former Finnish president Martti Ahtisaari to inspect arms dumps in its confidence-building measure.

One ugly spat that augured badly for the reformed executive came when Mr Trimble talked after his victory of "house training" Sinn Fein. Asked if that was to compare republicans to dogs, he retorted: "That's your language, not mine."

Mr McGuinness said yesterday: "Many of us find that terminology highly offensive. We believe that it is quite racist and highly sectarian and it has no place in the world of conflict resolution." A senior government source said last night: "If this is to work this time, they have got to get away from provoking each other. There has to be much more a collective consensus and all sides have to get away from the in-your-face approach which was a major problem last time around."

Another worry will come next Monday, when the 108-member assembly meets. Mr Trimble's opponents within unionism will immediately aim to forward a motion to exclude Sinn Fein from government.

They need 30 signatures to force the debate, and have promises of 29, including from one-time Ulster Unionist assembly member Peter Weir. Pauline Armitage, who also no longer takes the party whip, and Roy Beggs Jr say they will consider siding with the "No" Unionists.

The move to bar Sinn Fein cannot succeed because it needs the support of nationalists. But it would highlight that a minority supported Mr Trimble, wounding his authority.

Mr Trimble's opponents within his party also promise no let-up in their opposition to the Good Friday agreement. Willie Ross, MP for East Londonderry, called it the worst possible result for the party.

Mr Mandelson suspended the executive on February 11 after 72 days. His hand was forced after Mr Trimble said he would resign as first minister over the IRA's failure to begin decommissioning.

Had Mr Trimble been allowed to quit, the complex cross-community voting rules in the assembly would have made it virtually impossible to have him re-elected.

 Irish police were last night interviewing six men associated with the Real IRA, the dissident republican group that murdered 29 people in the Omagh car bombing in August 1998. They included the organisation's leader, held for the first time since the atrocity.

 A man was shot in a bar in Dunmurry on the outskirts of Belfast last night. He was in a critical condition and no motive had been established for the attack.

fields.headline: Flood warnings
fields.standfirst:
Bank holiday washout

The weather: special report
fields.trailText: The tradition of awful spring bank holiday weather was maintained this weekend as floods closed roads and people prepared to be evacuated.
fields.body:
The tradition of awful spring bank holiday weather was maintained this weekend as floods closed roads and people prepared to be evacuated.

In East Sussex, the river Uck burst its banks and police in Kent told people in four villages to prepare to leave because of floods.

The Met Office predicted more rain with north-east England and north Scotland expected to have a high risk of thunder, sleet and hail. The weekend's rainfall is forecast to match that for the whole of May in previous years.

A Met office spokesman said: "This weather is part of a pattern of May bank holiday storms which is worsening year by year. The highest temperature on Saturday was 16C (61F)in the south-east, well below the seasonal average of 18C (64F)."

The Environment Agency issued 29 flood warnings in the Midlands, East Anglia and the south-east.

AA Roadwatch warned that roads in Essex and East Sussex had been closed and surface water on the M25 and other motorways would slow drivers down. Police in Dorset, Kent and London warned drivers to stay put.

The foul weather also scuppered a commemorative voyage of 80 boats from Dover to Dunkirk, and sailors were rescued from fishing boats off the Kent coast. One man in Kent was pulled from a 30ft hole in a subsided road.

webTitle: As Kim Basinger wasn't telling me the other day

fields.headline: As Kim Basinger wasn't telling me the other day
fields.trailText: In his satirical classic The Devil's Dictionary, the late American journalist Ambrose Bierce defined an interview as "a confession where vulgar impudence bends an ear to the follies of vanity and ambition". Now a ground-breaking new definition of the form is being offered in Hollywood.
fields.body:
In his satirical classic The Devil's Dictionary, the late American journalist Ambrose Bierce defined an interview as "a confession where vulgar impudence bends an ear to the follies of vanity and ambition". Now a ground-breaking new definition of the form is being offered in Hollywood.

The German magazine Süddeutsche Zeitung has published an apology to its readers for what it describes as "a betrayal of monumental proportions". It has had to admit that one of its Los Angeles freelance writers, Tom Kummer, has been, perhaps, too creative in some of his "interviews" with the stars.

It all came to light when other German journalists were asked by their editors why they were unable to come up with such spectacular exclusives. "We had our editors ringing up and saying 'why can't you go fishing with Bruce Willis, riding with Robert Redford and playing golf with Kevin Costner?'," said one journalist in Los Angeles last night. "He was coming up with all these great exclusives - being invited to Kim Basinger's cottage and things like that."

Holger Hötzel of Focus magazine decided to do some checking after an interview with Courtney Love, famously protective of her privacy, who was "outraged" to discover that she had supposedly been sharing her thoughts with Kummer. Many of the interviews turned out to be bogus. "They were conversations with himself. A lot of quotes came from a book he had written."

When Hötzel confronted Kummer, the latter attempted to justify his technique. "He is not apologising. He said that what stars say is an insult to any person's intelligence."

When the Focus article appeared two weeks ago, Kummer's own magazine pressed him for tapes of a supposed interview with Christina Ricci, star of The Opposite of Sex. He was apparently unable to provide them.

In an interview in Der Spiegel, Kummer explained his style as "montage reporting", part of the school of "borderline journalism". He explained: "Readers of my generation want to be entertained."

Last night he was said to be in Heidelberg giving a lecture on "Modern Myth". But in the spirit of borderline journalism, we joined him and Marlon Brando for champagne on the roof of the Beverly Hilton just before his departure from LA, where he told us: "Hey, that's showbiz."

fields.headline: High-speed train project collapses
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's revolution in 140mph trains was in tatters last night after Railtrack pulled the plug on the £5bn upgrade to the west coast main line, industry sources confirmed.
fields.body:
Britain's revolution in 140mph trains was in tatters last night after Railtrack pulled the plug on the £5bn upgrade to the west coast main line, industry sources confirmed.

The project, which was launched with Richard Branson's Virgin Trains, promised a high-speed link that would have seen tilting trains cutting journey times between London and Manchester to a little more than one and half hours.

Railtrack now wants to pull out of part of the project and offer instead a cut-price version.

The upgrade, the biggest rail improvement project in western Europe, was to come in two stages. The first, costing more than £2bn, should be ready by 2002, and would allow the 70 tilting trains ordered by Virgin Trains to be used.

But sources say Railtrack will not be able to complete the hi-tech signalling system - the centrepiece of the £3bn second stage - by the target date of 2005. This will stop the new trains running at 140mph and could mean a loss of more than 40 high-speed services a day between London and Scotland and the north-west.

Rising costs are blamed for the collapse of the second half of the project. The bill for the full west coast upgrade has doubled in less than two years to £5.4bn for the 400-mile main line between London and Glasgow.

Railtrack is prepared to offer Sir Richard Branson £250m in compensation because it cannot complete the project. But a legal action over the project is possible, though Virgin Trains said last night that it did not want to travel that route.

It will say later this week when it publishes its annual results - which will show little change from its profits of £428m last year - that it has not got sufficient funds to meet the escalating costs of the line.

Railtrack has been pressing the government to invest more into the industry, despite its big profits. It insists that it needs at least £1bn in state aid in the short term to help it rebuild Britain's crumbling railway system, which is in a worse state than before privatisation.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who is asking the chancellor for considerable backing for public transport over the next three years, is to ask Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority, to rescue the west coast project. This will inevitably mean the infusion of more public money into the plan.

The development of Britain's most important rail artery has been facing problems for some time, arousing the suspicions of the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, who has always been sceptical that the project could be completed. The project, which was launched with Richard Branson's Virgin Trains, promised a high-speed link that would have seen tilting trains cutting journey times between London and Manchester to a little more than one and half hours. Railtrack now wants to pull out of part of the project and offer instead a cut-price version. The upgrade, the biggest rail improvement project in western Europe, was to come in two stages. The first, costing more than £2bn, should be ready by 2002, and would allow the 70 tilting trains ordered by Virgin Trains to be used. But sources say Railtrack will not be able to complete the hi-tech signalling system - the centrepiece of the £3bn second stage - by the target date of 2005. Rising costs are blamed for the collapse of the second half of the project. webTitle: Tories woo elderly with £60m benefits package

fields.headline: Tories woo elderly with £60m benefits package
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservatives yesterday moved to embarrass the government over its policies towards the elderly for the second time in a week by unveiling a £60m package to increase pensioners' independence.
fields.body:
The Conservatives yesterday moved to embarrass the government over its policies towards the elderly for the second time in a week by unveiling a £60m package to increase pensioners' independence.

The most eye-catching of the six proposals to end what the Tory social security spokesman, David Willetts, called age discrimination on health and benefits was a symbolic decision - launched on the 60th anniversary of the Dunkirk evacuation - to restore war widows' pensions to women who remarry.

Only 2,500 women would be affected, at a cost of £40m a year. The move prompted immediate Labour charges of hypocrisy because William Hague rejected the reform when he was junior social security minister in 1995 and because the Tories are also committed to cutting the overall tax burden when busily making spending pledges.

But ministers know they face a tricky problem. When the idea was floated last year they set up a review which has still not reported. Last week cross-party peers decided to wait no longer and amended the pensions bill to give back war pensions to widows who remarry.

Tony Blair and the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, will now have to decide whether to force Labour MPs through the Commons division lobbies to reverse the peers' amendment or use the review to bow gracefully to the change in election year.

Mr Darling said that pensioners had not forgotten shabby treatment they received in the Thatcher/Major years, including the loss of free eye tests, now restored.

Mr Willetts was unapologetic about the Tory u-turn. "We've listened and we've learned," he said. As for extra spending, he admitted that large sums are not involved since much of the money which Mr Hague wants to add to basic pensions - last week's initiative - is a "better" re-packaging of Labour's plans.

"This is broadening our attack on Labour for not respecting pensioners. We have put forward common sense proposals to help pensioners, specifically to tackle discrimination in the benefits system against pensioner," the former Treasury official explained.

The Tories also pledged a further £20m to remove an anomaly whereby carers who apply for an invalid care allowance or its income support equivalent cannot do so once they pass 60 - though they keep it past 60 if they first got it at 59 or younger. That would benefit 55,000 people.

The Tories also said they would extend breast screening for cancer for older women between the ages of 65-69 and end the policy of mixed-sex hospital wards. "This is another spending commitment without any explanation of where the money is coming from by the Conservatives," Mr Darling said. "Last week the Tories announced a package for pensioners which turned out to be an attempt to bribe them with money they are already getting."

The opposition believes that pensioners are eager to be wooed because, their private research shows, they are not only cross about Gordon Brown's 75p a week pension rise last month, but feel that Blairite rhetoric about a "young country" excludes them.

"Labour are institutionally ageist. They are preoccupied with the young and glamorous and have forgotten about the older generation," Mr Willetts claimed.

The other two Tory plans would protect old people in need of medical supervision being pushed out of hospital too soon in order to ease NHS "bed-blocking" and an end to the rule which requires personal pensions to be converted into an annuity at 75 - a rule which exists to prevent pensioners spending their nest egg and ending up on benefit.

webTitle: Inch by inch, Trimble moves forward

fields.headline: Inch by inch, Trimble moves forward
fields.standfirst:
Unionist diehards showed their anger, but behind the taunts lay a recognition that the power-sharing executive is here for keeps

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Unionist diehards showed their anger, but behind the taunts lay a recognition that the power-sharing executive is here for keeps
fields.body:
What shall we do with the traitor Trimble
What shall we do with the traitor Trimble
What shall we do with the traitor Trimble
Early in the morning?
Burn, burn, burn, the traitor
Burn, burn, burn, the traitor
Burn, burn, burn, the traitor
Early in the morning

They have had plenty of opportunity to practise, and they were an imaginative lot outside the Waterfront Hall in Belfast. Gleefully they switched the mode of death for the Ulster Unionist leader from burning to hanging, and then to shooting. But the vociferous crowd opposing what they saw as the sell-out of the Good Friday agreement was smaller this time, the gaggle of uncompromising women in red, white and blue had shrunken. They promised to be back, but there was a half-hearted pitch to it.

Saturday was a strange day. A world weariness seemed to have set in after so many days of history in Northern Ireland. The meeting of the 863 Ulster Unionist delegates was a much tamer affair, with David Trimble's narrow win greeted in silence.

Unlike the situation in November, when Mr Trimble won 58% conditional backing to go into government with Sinn Fein, none of his opponents said they would leave the party. Only Willie Ross, anti-agreement MP for East Londonderry, mustered some passion, saying that Mr Trimble should quit now. "The unexpected tends to happen unexpectedly," he said with understated menace.

So there will be crises ahead. The running sores over concessions to Ulster Unionists in the policing bill present republicans with their get-out clause, should they wish to exercise it. And Ulster Unionists fear Sinn Fein ministers will make life difficult.

Ken Maginnis, Ulster Unionist MP, warned of daily battles as the party tried to work the world's only such power-sharing executive. But inch by inch, he said, progress towards peaceful democracy would be made, and he proclaimed defeatism had itself been routed.

Saturday may prove to have been the defining moment in Northern Ireland's political progress, when the summit of the decommissioning obstacle was finally negotiated and they reached the valley of the agreement. Mr Trimble now has a good chance to discover how fertile is this new land, perhaps until party conference in October.

There are big differences from the arrangements in November. On Saturday, Mr Trimble managed to scrape through without setting pre-conditions. His petty swipe about having to house-train Sinn Fein can be seen as an ungracious substitute. While last time around, he himself set the date for council review, delegates who want to force him out of government will now have to requisition another council meeting. That alone alters the dynamics. It is also clear that sacking Mr Trimble from government is a much taller order than withholding permission to let him go into it.

Nor is the government likely ever again to suspend the institutions. Mr Trimble told delegates it still retained the power to do so. It does, but London and Dublin emphasise that a formal review would take place - and this would act as a brake on the unilateralism of the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson.

Mr Trimble will, over the summer, try to push through party reforms, primarily to loosen the links with the Orange order that saw several non-party members voting on Saturday. Those moves are expected to boost his own position by about 10 percentage points. He has the bonus of flushing out would-be leadership rival, Jeffrey Donaldson, who last week was forced to unveil his own package to government with Sinn Fein. That highlighted hitherto disguised and fundamental differences among Mr Trimble's opponents.

Some detest power-sharing, while others are focused only on the weapons issue. Mr Donaldson has been pulled closer to the pro-agreement camp, and has been offered the opportunity to come back on board - but only on Mr Trimble's terms.

Mr Trimble enjoyed throwing the spotlight on to the Democratic Unionist party, which will decide tomorrow whether it will hold on to its two ministries. Ian Paisley, DUP leader, is believed to be opposed, while his deputy, Peter Robinson, is thought to favour re-entry. Mr Paisley believes the DUP will benefit in the long-term electorally if it relinquishes places - which would stop Ulster Unionist accusations of DUP hypocrisy.

While Mr Robinson and Nigel Dodds, minister for social development in the executive, were effective ministers, the DUP's refusal to sit at a cabinet table with Sinn Fein caused more problems than they had supposed. Finance was one problem. Mr Trimble and Seamus Mallon, deputy first minister, quashed DUP hopes of doing side-deals outside executive meetings, and money from their departments was re-directed to deal with the new year flu crisis.

Turning down their ministries could carry big benefits for the DUP if the executive runs into problems. But it is risky. Should the executive be a success, stay-at-home Ulster Unionists may be enticed to vote in next year's council elections and expected general election; that could cost the DUP dear, and the percentage game may mean resuming as before.

Saturday's vote was the 22nd at various levels within the Ulster Unionist party on matters arising from the agreement, and it was the narrowest. But at midnight, Mr Trimble will once again become Northern Ireland's first minister. This time, devolution should be for keeps.

Where they go from here

Midnight tonight: Devolution restored to Northern Ireland. Formal power over most areas of political life returned to local leaders.

Tomorrow: UUP, SDLP, and Sinn Fein ministers in office again. The DUP decides tomorrow night whether ministers Peter Robinson and Nigel Dodds go back; if not, DUP seats go to the Alliance Party and the UUP.

Thursday: First formal meeting of the executive.

Monday June 5: First assembly meeting. Dissident UUP members may attack Mr Trimble. The DUP could force a vote on excluding Sinn Fein from the executive.

Tuesday 6 June: Commons debate on the policing reform bill. Seamus Mallon, SDLP deputy, has pledged to scour bill to withdraw amendments offered to Unionists. Tories will oppose bill's key elements.

Early June: IRA expected to keep promise to open arms dumps to inspectors. Commons debate on restoration of devolution.

webTitle: Last UN captives on way home

fields.headline: Last UN captives on way home
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Sierra Leone's rebel movement is believed to have released the remaining hostages who were among some 500 UN personnel captured in early May, UN officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
Sierra Leone's rebel movement is believed to have released the remaining hostages who were among some 500 UN personnel captured in early May, UN officials said yesterday.

UN spokesman David Wimhurst said 85 captives were being airlifted in three batches by helicopter to Liberia's capital of Monrovia from the border town of Foya.

Mr Wimhurst said four peacekeepers were unaccounted for and were believed to have been killed in fighting when the hostage crisis began on May 6.

"The UN believes we have got all the hostages out subject to confirmation," he said.

Twenty-three Indian peacekeepers remained surrounded by rebels in the eastern village of Quiver. It was not known if they were being evacuated.

The reasons behind the rebels' decision to release their hostages, mainly Zambians, are unclear although some of the captives said the hostage-takers said they never had any intention of harming them.

Despite the releases, fighting between rebels and pro-government forces was reported at the crossroads of Rogberi Junction, about 50 miles east of Freetown, Mr Wimhurst said.
