webTitle: Peace first. Then normality. They're not the same thing

fields.headline: Peace first. Then normality. They're not the same thing
fields.standfirst:
Northern Ireland needs a real opposition - to help it forget history

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland needs a real opposition - to help it forget history
fields.body:
After the perils of Pauline, the triumphs of Trimble. And with yet another bound, our unlikely hero is free, until the next time. The peace process is saved: mainland Britain switches its attention over to England against Brazil: Peter Mandelson prepares to concentrate on the next election campaign. A crisis averted becomes inside page news for yesterday's papers. This is politics as usual, which disguises the fact that there is nothing usual about Northern Irish politics.

What, for instance, would any normal party leader do if his deputy drifted off to Taiwan for the vital days of decision-forming? What would Blair do to Prescott? He would drop big John into oblivion from a great height, not greet him home and fete him as some mighty prophet. Yet John Taylor, preened with self-importance, is hailed merely because he agrees to support his boss.

You don't have to be loyal to be a loyalist. Jeffrey Donaldson and the rejectionists, playing to a bizarre audience of 860 grandees, won't give up. Paisley's DUP will probably stalk away from the reconvened assembly and rail outside the walls. Even without the IRA's dumps of mystic verbiage, words put beyond use where Cyril Ramaphosa keeps his dictionary, the scope for trouble remains almost infinite.

It is painfully easy, amid such confusion, just to recite the word "process" as some kind of mantra and to forget what it means. Pause, though. What is this peace process? It is a formula for reconciliation and quiet on the streets. It puts London and Dublin in a settled context. It persuades once mortal enemies to sit side by side as ministerial colleagues, deciding about jobs and schools and hospitals. By this transference of power, too, it seeks to make Ulster politics real at last, freed from a time warp of rhetoric and opposition posturings: the most necessary devolution of the lot.

But here there are other connections. Real politics also means winning and losing elections. It means change to the pulse of democracy - the eventual boot for Blair, the rise of the pensioner's friend. It involves ebb and flow.

We know that already from the matching devolutions of the last three years. Alun Michael has ebbed for ever. Donald Dewar may soon be gone with the flow. If you give voters assemblies and executives to elect, the voters become sovereign. You may make it difficult for them by installing the drag anchors of proportional representation: Scotland and Wales have those. They're stuck, by design, with coalition administrations.

They, though, can change the weighting of those coalitions and the faces who front them. One fine day, there'll be a Scots Nat chief minister in Edinburgh. One predictable day, Labour will be cut out of the Cardiff action. The question for Belfast, the hole in the heart of this process, is where the reality of politics bites there.

Let's assume that the assembly is back in business, stronger than before because of the worsting of Donaldson and the guarantees of the IRA. Trimble and his other (useful) deputy, Seamus Mallon, resume work: Martin McGuinness is more interested in A level results than Armalite stocks.

That, crucially, is the first base camp of reconciliation. Everybody who stood for election and still wants to play has a guaranteed part of the action. Badmouthing the British government doesn't stop the leaks in school roofs or improve ambulance response times. The focus inevitably shifts to practical policies and their delivery. Who cares about the Battle of the Boyne when there are jobs wanted now?

Getting there: got that. You could tell, even from the first few weeks of assembly life, how power and accountability can alter perspectives. (It's the old Yasser Arafat test: make him responsible for clean tap water and electrical supplies and he is seen in a different light.) The practical politicisation of politicians is the underpinning of peace.

But how, thereafter, does Northern Ireland move on the next camp, to the stage where leaking school roofs or job losses bring electoral retribution? The difficulty with the Good Friday agreement is that it doesn't know: it never envisages a Bad Saturday. Our old chum d'Hondt, with his mathematical system to share out the fruits of proportional representation, operates relentlessly.

The assembly, monitored by equality commissioners, has inclusion engraved on its founding statutes. If you're one of the chosen 108, you have a stake: you have to register as a nationalist or a unionist or something other and your vote matters, by parallel consent or weighted majority, in the choice of every committee, every chairman, every minister.

It seems an odd question to put, but where is the opposition in such a controlled, infinitely balanced arena? Answer: except for Paisley, stomping on the lawn outside, there won't be an opposition that matters. The big boys within the walls are yoked together for all Good Fridays.

We ought to be clear that that fix, however essential it currently seems, is also a terrible snare. It freezes the religious divides and histories in another time warp. It makes party labels the key to power and seals them in their own little boxes. It purposely delays the moment when the Unionists or Sinn Fein or the SDLP will look out from their own sectarian audiences and begin to match their policies to the orientations of London or of Dublin. In short, to practise the real politics which can free Northern Ireland from its infernal cocoon.

I want to see Sinn Fein's policy bag emptied on to the floor for wider inspection so that I can see how its old collection of sub-Marxist nostrums is changing (just as the ANC in South Africa has changed). I want to hear about hospital waiting lists and bobbies on the beat. I want to see David Trimble and Gerry Adams locked in debate about gay rights. I want a relevance which doesn't end at the ferry terminal. I would even (ye gods!) love a good row over the euro.

The latest wobbly triumph of Trimble is a million miles from such mundane joys. It is still locked in its own, claustrophobic cage, still absorbed with the symbolism of flags and guns fallen silent but not destroyed: the whether, not the how. In mainland Britain, we have handed in all our guns, because that is the law. In Belfast, the legacy of Dunblane doesn't count. The debate remains wholly internalised.

Devolution, within the United Kingdom, means finding a different kind of balance. It means finding a matching political system that fits. It means the political ability to talk about the same things in the same tone of voice and to exact the same kind of electoral punishment in failure. That is the only real culmination of what we glibly call the "peace process". A new rhythm and new beginning which one distant day may be called normality.


Peter Preston

It means change to the pulse of democracy - the eventual boot for Blair, the rise of the pensioner's friend. It involves ebb and flow. We know that already from the matching devolutions of the last three years. Alun Michael has ebbed for ever. Donald Dewar may soon be gone with the flow. If you give voters assemblies and executives to elect, the voters become sovereign. You may make it difficult for them by installing the drag anchors of proportional representation: Scotland and Wales have those. They're stuck, by design, with coalition administrations. They, though, can change the weighting of those coalitions and the faces who front them. One fine day, there'll be a Scots Nat chief minister in Edinburgh. One predictable day, Labour will be cut out of the Cardiff action. The question for Belfast, the hole in the heart of this process, is where the reality of politics bites there. Let's assume that the assembly is back in business, stronger than before because of the worsting of Donaldson and the guarantees of the IRA. Trimble and his other (useful) deputy, Seamus Mallon, resume work: Martin McGuinness is more interested in A level results than Armalite stocks. That, crucially, is the first base camp of reconciliation. Everybody who stood for election and still wants to play has a guaranteed part of the action. Badmouthing the British government doesn't stop the leaks in school roofs or improve ambulance response times. The focus inevitably shifts to practical policies and their delivery. Who cares about the Battle of the Boyne when there are jobs wanted now? Getting there: got that. You could tell, even from the first few weeks of assembly life, how power and accountability can alter perspectives. (It's the old Yasser Arafat test: make him responsible for clean tap water and electrical supplies and he is seen in a different light.) The practical politicisation of politicians is the underpinning of peace. But how, thereafter, does Northern Ireland move on the next camp, to the stage where leaking school roofs or job losses bring electoral retribution? The difficulty with the Good Friday agreement is that it doesn't know: it never envisages a Bad Saturday. Our old chum d'Hondt, with his mathematical system to share out the fruits of proportional representation, operates relentlessly. The assembly, monitored by equality commissioners, has inclusion engraved on its founding statutes. If you're one of the chosen 108, you have a stake: you have to register as a nationalist or a unionist or something other and your vote matters, by parallel consent or weighted majority, in the choice of every committee, every chairman, every minister. It seems an odd question to put, but where is the opposition in such a controlled, infinitely balanced arena? Answer: except for Paisley, stomping on the lawn outside, there won't be an opposition that matters. The big boys within the walls are yoked together for all Good Fridays. We ought to be clear that that fix, however essential it currently seems, is also a terrible snare. It freezes the religious divides and histories in another time warp. It makes party labels the key to power and seals them in their own little boxes. It purposely delays the moment when the Unionists or Sinn Fein or the SDLP will look out from their own sectarian audiences and begin to match their policies to the orientations of London or of Dublin. In short, to practise the real politics which can free Northern Ireland from its infernal cocoon. I want to see Sinn Fein's policy bag emptied on to the floor for wider inspection so that I can see how its old collection of sub-Marxist nostrums is changing (just as the ANC in South Africa has changed). I want to hear about hospital waiting lists and bobbies on the beat. I want to see David Trimble and Gerry Adams locked in debate about gay rights. I want a relevance which doesn't end at the ferry terminal. I would even (ye gods!) love a good row over the euro. The latest wobbly triumph of Trimble is a million miles from such mundane joys. It is still locked in its own, claustrophobic cage, still absorbed with the symbolism of flags and guns fallen silent but not destroyed: the whether, not the how. In mainland Britain, we have handed in all our guns, because that is the law. In Belfast, the legacy of Dunblane doesn't count. The debate remains wholly internalised. Devolution, within the United Kingdom, means finding a different kind of balance. It means finding a matching political system that fits. It means the political ability to talk about the same things in the same tone of voice and to exact the same kind of electoral punishment in failure. That is the only real culmination of what we glibly call the "peace process". A new rhythm and new beginning which one distant day may be called normality. Peter Preston

fields.headline: Country 'heading in wrong direction'
fields.standfirst:
Unhappy people losing faith in God and their leaders, poll finds

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: People are losing faith in God and are less happy than they were a decade ago but most are still proud to call themselves British.
fields.body:
People are losing faith in God and are less happy than they were a decade ago but most are still proud to call themselves British.

These are among the findings of one of the most comprehensive surveys of values and beliefs. It also found that half the population believes that Britain is "heading in the wrong direction", while 45% believe that the decline of traditional religion has made this country a worse place to live.

The poll, commissioned by the BBC for a TV series, Soul of Britain, revealed that Britons are becoming uncertain about their personal moral judgments and are losing confidence in the country's moral and political leadership.

The results of the survey, conducted by Opinion Research Business among a representative sample of 1,000 people, found that 49% feared the nation was going in the "wrong direction".People are also less happy with their lives than they were 10 years ago, when 38% of people said they were "very happy". That figure has now fallen to 29%, with a corresponding increase in the proportion describing themselves as "quite happy". The same proportion of people described themselves as "unhappy" in 1990 and 2000.

Nevertheless, 83% of the population are still proud to be British and 66% are willing to fight for their country in the event of a major war.

The poll also found that 62% of people believe in God, down from 76% in 1980, yet only 23% of people have attended a religious service in the past month - the same figure as a decade ago.

Most people retain their faith in family values and the institution of marriage, al though there has been a move away from organised religion, with those regarding themselves as belonging to a particular religion falling from 58% in 1990 to 48% today, the Church of England suffering the biggest drop, from 40% in 1990 to 35%.

About 27% described themselves as "spiritual", rather than "religious", with 25% believing in reincarnation and 55% in fate. And despite the finding that 45% of Britons never attend church, 69% of the population believe they have a soul - up from 64% 10 years ago. The survey also found that just over half the population believes in an afterlife, up from 44% a decade ago.

Although the belief in a personal god has consistently fallen over the past 40 years, from 41% in 1957 to 32% in 1990 and to 26% now, a larger proportion, 32%, still believe in the devil. While 52% profess to believe in heaven, only 28% are convinced that hell exists - figures that have changed little over the past 20 years.

A large number of people are in favour of church leaders speaking out on moral issues such as poverty (82%), racial discrimination (75%) and global inequality (70%).

And despite the main problems facing society today - thought to be crime by 47%, NHS funding by 24%, and unemployment, 20% - eight out of 10 Britons still believe in marriage and 76% expect theirs to last a lifetime.

A spokesman for the Archbishop of Canterbury said the survey results "seemed to go against the idea that religion is dead". He added: "Religion is far more important to people than a lot of commentators think."

 Soul of Britain, presented by Michael Buerk, will be broadcast on BBC 1 on Sundays from June 4.

webTitle: Why they won't let Mr Kwik quit

fields.headline: Why they won't let Mr Kwik quit
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: When Kwik Kian Gie, Indonesia's senior economics minister, blurted out in a recent interview "if I were a foreign investor, I wouldn't come to Indonesia", few people were shocked, except by his honesty in stating what everyone already knew.
fields.body:
When Kwik Kian Gie, Indonesia's senior economics minister, blurted out in a recent interview "if I were a foreign investor, I wouldn't come to Indonesia", few people were shocked, except by his honesty in stating what everyone already knew.

Foreigners have indeed been giving the sprawling archipelago of 17,500 islands a wide berth in recent months. "People are not even testing the water at the moment," said investment adviser Ken Conboy of Control Risks Group. "There is just too much going on that makes people uneasy."

As in 1997 when south-east Asia's economies toppled like dominoes, there is already a contagious effect in neighbouring countries. The only difference this time round is that most analysts believe the reforms demanded by the International Monetary Fund in the aftermath of the last crisis would prevent total regional collapse this time if the bottom were to fall out of the Indonesian economy.

The problem starts at the very top, with President Abdurrahman Wahid. Since taking office last October, following Indonesia's first democratic general election in 44 years, the half-blind Muslim cleric who is recovering from two recent strokes, has had an uneasy ride.

He has proved himself to be an extremely skilled politician in that he has contained regional unrest to the point of ensuring the nation is not going to disintegrate, he has greatly reduced the political power of the armed forces and he has successfully marginalised political opponents such as General Wiranto.

But his competence in these fields has only magnified his ineptitude in matters economic. Monetary reform initially dawdled along so slowly the IMF suspended its bail-out funding at the end of March. A new letter of intent has just been signed but there is no guarantee that the government will stick to it, particularly as the currency has fallen almost 15 % in the past month, making budget calculations meaningless.

Mr Wahid has tried to compensate for his economic shortcomings by surrounding himself with myriad layers of advisers. In addition to his ministers he has at least four economic advisory committees.

Rather than clarifying matters, the situation in the palace has become so confused no-one seems to know who is in charge. Ostensibly it should be Mr Kwik, but his position has been so undermined in the past month he has tried to resign on several occasions.

"The problem is that the government is a weak coalition of different political parties," according to economist Mari Pangestu. "The ministers all come from different parties and have different backgrounds and different priorities."

The bickering is becoming increasingly voluble and increasingly public. "If you were to liken the cabinet to a ship, it would have to be the Titanic," one western analyst wrote in a memo to a client this month. "However this one has struck not one but several icebergs and is letting in water rapidly."

Policy paralysis is the result. Few ministers are initiating any legislation to kick-start the economy and the major priorities left over from the previous regime, most notably bank recapitalisation, corporate debt restructuring and sales of newly nationalised assets are proceeding at a snail's pace.

This is partly because of a non-functioning legal system. Of the first 100 bankruptcy cases brought to trial in the new commercial court, the plaintiffs won only one fifth, thanks largely to rampant judicial corruption. The absence of legal certainty is considered a major reason for foreign investors staying away.

Corruption, collusion and nepotism are not confined to the judiciary. The president appointed his brother Hasyim to be the deputy head of the debt restructuring agency despite him having no relevant skills or experience. Hasyim Wahid resigned last week as a result of the public outcry.

The president has raised eyebrows by starting to take decisions on technical matters such as the debt-restructuring of several well connected companies.

Ms Pangestu blames over-optimistic popular hopes for much of the crisis. "We had too high expectations last October," she said.

"Look at the Philippines. It took the Aquino administration five years to sort out restructuring."

She believes the good times are not going to return any time soon, as they have in Korea, Malaysia and Taiwan.

"We are not going to fall off the end of the earth but the consequence is going to be many ups and downs and very slow growth."

fields.headline: The Balkan trilogy
fields.standfirst:
Europe could be left to find a solution

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The renewed fighting in the Presevo valley, in southern Serbia, between Yugoslav army units and ethnic Albanians is one of several, recent reminders that the situation in the Balkans, nearly a year after the "liberation" of Kosovo, remains volatile.
fields.body:
The renewed fighting in the Presevo valley, in southern Serbia, between Yugoslav army units and ethnic Albanians is one of several, recent reminders that the situation in the Balkans, nearly a year after the "liberation" of Kosovo, remains volatile. The final status of Kosovo, a de facto UN-Nato protectorate but still sovereign Yugoslav territory, is nowhere near being resolved. In Serbia, the indicted war criminal, President Slobodan Milosevic, has been conducting a crackdown on what his regime describes as "western-backed terrorists". This instability, which extends to Montenegro and is intensifying ahead of scheduled local elections which Mr Milosevic's party is expected to lose, has been exacerbated by a spate of unexplained assassinations of Milosevic associates and the continuing economic dislocation caused by Nato bombing and western sanctions.

The potentially explosive situation within Serbia, and its worrying implications for overall, European-led efforts to bring lasting political and economic stability to the Balkans, will be on the agenda in Moscow today when Romano Prodi, the EC president, and Antonio Guterres, the Portuguese prime minister whose country holds the EU presidency, are due to meet President Vladimir Putin. Russia remains deeply ambivalent about the methods employed by the west to force democratic change in Serbia. It has undermined attempts to isolate Mr Milosevic and bring him and his cronies to justice in The Hague by giving the regime loans and welcoming Dragoljub Ojdanic, the Yugoslav defence minister and an indicted war criminal, to Moscow.

Although Mr Putin's men now say this invitation was a mistake, they sent another hostile message last week when Russia boycotted a meeting of the multilateral committee set up to ensure observance of the 1995 Dayton peace accords in Bosnia. The Russians' sympathy for their beleaguered fellow Orthodox Slavs is undoubtedly partly responsible for the mixed signals from Moscow. But a new factor is Mr Putin, whose inclinations are far from clear. Europe's broader hopes of building a stronger political and trade relationship with Russia rest very much on securing a common approach in the Balkans. Put plainly, this matters far more to the EU states than another area of dispute - Mr Putin's ruthless war against the Chechens.

Russia is not the only problem. China, which has never forgiven US and Nato "global hegemonists" for attacking Serbia and bombing its Belgrade embassy, is reinforcing its ties with Mr Milosevic. But the biggest threat to Europe's Balkan policy is emerging in an entirely different quarter - in America. Only intense lobbying by the White House prevented the US congress passing measures earlier this month which could have forced a US troop withdrawal from Kosovo by next summer and suspended American reconstruction aid. This narrow squeak does not mean the argument is over. The conviction that the Balkans are a European problem which must be solved by Europeans and that Europe (as usual) is not bearing its fair share of the burden appears to be gaining ground in political circles.

After his Moscow summit, Mr Prodi and Mr Guterres visit Washington on Wednesday to meet President Bill Clinton. They will doubtless seek (and receive) assurances about America's Balkan commitment. But, increasingly, lame-duck Mr Clinton is not in a position to deliver. Europe has to find a way to get out of this Russian-Chinese-American squeeze. The only person it helps is the deeply undeserving Slobodan Milosevic.

fields.headline: Second chance for Ulster
fields.standfirst:
Sweat to come, but no more blood and tears

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble does not always win plaudits for his leadership, but today he deserves them. At midnight tonight, responsibility for Northern Ireland will be transferred from Westminster back to Belfast, where it belongs.
fields.body:
David Trimble does not always win plaudits for his leadership, but today he deserves them. At midnight tonight, responsibility for Northern Ireland will be transferred from Westminster back to Belfast, where it belongs. For that achievement partial credit should go to the man who will settle back in his First Minister's chair on Thursday: Mr Trimble. Even the ungenerous will admire his skills (like those of the best parliamentary whip) in calling the numbers so accurately in Saturday's vote of the Ulster Unionist party's ruling council. That body was due to vote on re-entering devolved government with Sinn Fein a week ago. But Mr Trimble read the runes cannily enough to know he did not have the votes he needed: he duly postponed the meeting and, in the intervening seven days, closed the gap. That shows a feel for his own party's tides and currents which would be the envy of many a politician.

Others will give Mr Trimble more profound credit. They will say he has dragged his party, albeit kicking and screaming, into the land of realism. He has forced them to give up the comfortable delusions spun by Jeffrey Donaldson and Willie Ross - in which the clock can be turned back and Unionists can have everything and give up nothing - and face reality. Admittedly he has never offered the soaring rhetoric and vision deployed by the world's more starred peacemakers - but perhaps that was wise, given the sensibilities of the Unionist community. Instead, David Trimble has gritted his teeth and recommended compromise only as a means of exposing the bad faith of the enemy. That has been his style and it is not always appealing to outsiders; and yet the Ulster Unionist leader has taken a community which had made a semi-religion of stubbornness and led them toward compromise. For that he deserves credit.

The detail is welcome, too. In order to win Saturday's razor-thin margin for a return to government, Mr Trimble might have made a battery of promises he could not keep or which might later have undermined the peace process. He did not do that. He established an internal party committee to keep an eye on IRA progress on decommissioning - but he did not set another deadline for IRA guns. He clearly learned from the experience of the last such demand, which led to the collapse of the executive in the first place, back in February. Nor did he raise Unionist expectations of a victory on the vexed question of the name of Northern Ireland's future police force. His deputy, John Taylor, waved a piece of paper which purported to be a British government promise to keep the name of the Royal Ulster Constabulary. But Mr Trimble himself went in for no such gestures. The result is that the leader's weekend victory may be narrower than previous ones but, unlike them, it will not be a millstone around his neck. It does not commit him to an outcome he cannot achieve.

What now? An immediate onus falls on to the IRA. They will be called upon soon to take their promised confidence building measure, by opening up several arms dumps to international inspection. The sooner arrangements are made for that, the better. For the speedier and more serious the process is, the more the Trimble-ites will be vindicated against the rejectionists. When it becomes clear that IRA guns are indeed being put beyond use, the Donaldson position will become increasingly irrelevant.

A burden falls on the British government, too. It needs to play straight on Northern Ireland: the side-letters and side-promises of the past have brought only trouble. The old tactic, whereby an agreement is reached one day only to be undermined by a side arrangement with Unionism the next, should be dropped. In its place there needs to be a firm resolve. Take policing. The government asked Chris Patten's independent commission to make recommendations. It did so and one of them was a change of name for the RUC. If the government believes that Patten was right, as common sense and international opinion agrees it was, then it should implement it. That, after all, was the commitment London made in its joint statement with Dublin of May 5 - the document which, let us not forget, triggered the IRA breakthrough.

Finally, there is a task for the politicians of Northern Ireland. The last three months of talk are over; from tonight politics in the province will be about action - on health, education and the business of regional self-government. That leaves little room for the old sectarianism and bigotry: Mr Trimble should be ashamed of his crude attempt to placate Unionist hardliners by claiming that republicans need to be "house-trained in democracy and brought to heel". That language has no place in an inclusive society. Instead all Northern Ireland's leaders should heed the advice of one of the sagest among them, the SDLP's John Hume. He said the time had come to "start spilling sweat instead of blood" as they join together in governing the land they all share. Today they have a second chance to do that - and we wish them all possible luck.

They will be called upon soon to take their promised confidence building measure, by opening up several arms dumps to international inspection. The sooner arrangements are made for that, the better. For the speedier and more serious the process is, the more the Trimble-ites will be vindicated against the rejectionists. When it becomes clear that IRA guns are indeed being put beyond use, the Donaldson position will become increasingly irrelevant. A burden falls on the British government, too. It needs to play straight on Northern Ireland: the side-letters and side-promises of the past have brought only trouble. The old tactic, whereby an agreement is reached one day only to be undermined by a side arrangement with Unionism the next, should be dropped. In its place there needs to be a firm resolve. If the government believes that Patten was right, as common sense and international opinion agrees it was, then it should implement it. Finally, there is a task for the politicians of Northern Ireland. The last three months of talk are over; from tonight politics in the province will be about action - on health, education and the business of regional self-government. That language has no place in an inclusive society. Instead all Northern Ireland's leaders should heed the advice of one of the sagest among them, the SDLP's John Hume. He said the time had come to "start spilling sweat instead of blood" as they join together in governing the land they all share. Today they have a second chance to do that - and we wish them all possible luck.

webTitle: Soldiers fire as Lebanese scale fence into Israel

fields.headline: Soldiers fire as Lebanese scale fence into Israel
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israeli soldiers fired to disperse a crowd of Lebanese sightseers who had scaled a border fence at Metullah yesterday, injuring at least three people, in an encounter underlining the precarious nature of the calm along Israel's northern frontier.
fields.body:
Israeli soldiers fired to disperse a crowd of Lebanese sightseers who had scaled a border fence at Metullah yesterday, injuring at least three people, in an encounter underlining the precarious nature of the calm along Israel's northern frontier.

It was the third time in as many days that Israeli soldiers have fired to turn back a stream of Lebanese civilians visiting the border to gaze out at Metullah's red roofs and to taunt the troops sitting high above them in their sentry boxes.

An Israeli military spokesman said three people were injured by ricocheting bullets. Other reports said the troops had fired rubber-coated bullets straight into the crowd.

The Israeli government sealed the crossing at the weekend to keep its own civilians away from the fence and to defuse the potential for confrontation.

The army has adopted new rules of engagement along the northern frontier, and is under orders to fire only if their lives are in danger. But the new rules do not seem to have been applied yesterday. "What has been happening these few days is that these young guys want to look very brave and plant a Hizbullah flag on Israeli soil," the spokesman said. "We have to show them that this is not a game. This is an international border."

Some of the exchanges with the Israelis have been good-humoured, and marshals from Hizbullah, who are now master of Israel's abandoned security zone, have restrained the crowds .

But with United Nations peacekeepers and Lebanese government troops yet to enter the vacuum left by Israel's hasty retreat, tension has been growing.

Israel complained to the UN at the weekend about the potential for trouble on the border. While a UN team of cartographers has been deployed to ratify Israel's withdrawal to the international border, it is still too early for a fullscale UN force to be in place.

There were also fears yesterday for the safety of Christians, and those with links to the South Lebanon Army after a Christian man was shot dead in Rmaish village. Despite widespread fears of reprisal, and the flight of 7,000 SLA troops and their families to Israel, the killing was the first since Hizbullah swept through the south.

Despite the relatively minor incidents, Israel is hoping that these days of calm will gather momentum. "In light of the delicate and fragile conditions in the area, every day that passes quietly contributes to the chances of stabilising the situation," the prime minister, Ehud Barak, said in a statement yesterday.

However, a spokesman from his office denied press reports that Israel had quietly agreed an understanding with the Hizbullah guerrillas on the need for a ceasefire.

A statement confirmed that the army had blown up two small outposts and a section of road near Shebaa farms in its occupation zone.

However, Israel had no intention of yielding to Hizbullah demands to return the area, claiming that 90% of it was not part of Lebanon.

 Israel's deputy prime minister resigned yesterday after being formally charged with sexual assault and harassment.

Yitzhak Mordechai, who also served as transport minister, is accused of assaulting an employee of his ministry last February and two other women during his days as an army officer.

webTitle: Refugees tell of new atrocities by rebels

fields.headline: Refugees tell of new atrocities by rebels
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone witnesses describe dozens of mutilations, including legs hacked off woman who resisted rapists

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Sierra Leone witnesses describe dozens of mutilations, including legs hacked off woman who resisted rapists
fields.body:
Josephine Swaray is a victim of the hidden war in Sierra Leone, the one not mentioned at United Nations briefings about its abducted peacekeepers or the numbers of casualties in the latest fighting between British-backed government forces and rebels.

The 24-year-old mother of two bled to death after Revolutionary United Front rebels hacked her legs off and discarded them in the bush as a punishment for resisting rape. Her sister, Allieu, witnessed the murder near Port Loko.

"We were captured by the rebels two weeks ago. They wouldn't even let my sister collect her children. They tried to rape her, but she bit one of them so they dragged her to the bushes and mutilated her and let her die. They told me if I went to help her they would do the same to me," she said.

The murder was just one among a new wave of killings, mutilations and mass rapes by the rebels since Sierra Leone's war flared again earlier this month. The tactic is reminiscent of similar atrocities when the rebels occupied a large part of Freetown at the beginning of last year.

The numbers of victims this time is unclear because only a few survivors have escaped from RUF territory. But those who have, as the government army advances, describe a reign of terror against the population.

Some say the RUF is punishing civilians for the casualties inflicted by the government's forces. Others say that the rebels accuse them of spying for the army.

Survivors from Malal, seven miles north of Port Loko, report dozens of amputations, raising the spectre that a rebel unit specialising in mutilation is in the area. One 12 year-old girl called Fatimah said the rebels hacked the hands and a foot off her elder sister who bled to death. It was one of three amputations the girl witnessed during the four days she was in rebel hands.

Other witnesses describe the rebels slicing a man's nose and lips off, the amputation of ears and the gouging out of eyes. But most of the mutilations appear to be of hands and feet. Many of the victims die for lack of treatment.

"I saw several amputations," said Emile Jalloh, who spent six days in rebel hands. "Some of the people died. Those who live don't have anywhere to go for treatment. The rebels warn them that if they try and come to Freetown they will be killed, so they must try and survive in the bush or village. I think most of them will die."

The RUF is also once again carrying out mass rapes.

Asiatu, a woman in her early twenties, is among those who have escaped the rebels in the past few days. The RUF found her hiding in the bush a fortnight ago with her five month-old baby after they seized the town of Masiaka.

"I was stripped naked and raped by seven of them. All of them used me. They don't care who is watching. I tried to beg them, saying 'I have a baby'. They kicked me in the back," she said. She and the other abductees were taken to the rebel camp where they were forced to work, carrying supplies, cooking and cutting wood.

"Even in the camp they use you when they want, even if you are cooking, they come and take you whenever they want. I cannot remember how many times I was raped. They were doing it in turns, one after another," she said.

Like many of the survivors of rebel atrocities, Asiatu escaped during an attack by the government's army. She finally made her way to Waterloo, east of Freetown, a week ago.

The rebels are also killing civilians at random. Assam Kamara is still stunned by what he witnessed. The small and slight 15-year-old was snatched in Port Loko with his elder brother, Lamina.

"My mother sent us out to collect some money from another village. The rebels found us and hit m e on the head with a gun. They gave us loads to carry and we were forced to walk to Masiaka. After four days my elder brother said he was tired of carrying the load. So they said: 'If you are tired, we are going to leave you here', and told him to walk in the other direction. Then they shot him," he said. "They said if I cry they will shoot me too. They kicked me and told me to shut up."

The boy has a large lump on his forehead where he was beaten with the gun. His brother was not the only one murdered on the forced march. He said the rebels stabbed a man in the back for refusing to go with them.

The UN said yesterday that another 30 of its peacekeepers had been released by the rebels and were now in the Liberian capital, Monrovia.

David Wimhurst, a spokesman, told Reuters in Freetown it was hoped that more would be freed soon.

The UN said 59 peacekeepers were still being held, following the seizure of more than 500 UN troops earlier this month. In addition, 23 Indian peacekeepers are surrounded at the eastern town of Kuiva, but retain their weapons.

fields.headline: Back to the USSR
fields.standfirst: Vladimir Putin was officially inaugurated only three weeks ago. But already he seems to be leading Russia down the familiar road to totalitarianism. Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Vladimir Putin was officially inaugurated only three weeks ago. But already he seems to be leading Russia down the familiar road to totalitarianism.
fields.body:
In the final hours of the last millennium - not long after news of Boris Yeltsin's surprise resignation had been broadcast to the world - Vladimir Putin found time to sit down at his Kremlin desk to start work on his vision of a new Russia.

One of the first decrees to be signed that night by the novice acting president ordered the resurrection of compulsory military training for all Russian pupils - forcing every Russian schoolboy to supplement his studies of Dostoevsky and algebra with a detailed understanding of how to load and fire a Kalashnikov. Under this edict, from September, teachers will be obliged to hold classes explaining the historical significance and current strength of the Russian army.

At the end of the summer term, every boy aged between 15 and 16 will be subjected to 40 hours intensive military instruction. Here he will learn army tactics, basic weapon handling and how to stride in synchronised unison across the training field.

With these parades, Russia is marching back into the past. Under Josef Stalin, similar classes were used to remind every school child that the Soviet Union was surrounded by an imperialist enemy, poised to attack. But military training for schoolchildren was outlawed nine years ago, in one of Yeltsin's first reforming measures as he stripped away the symbolic baggage of Soviet society.

"This represents a step backwards to a militarised Soviet state. These training classes will have almost no practical use - but they are hugely significant from a psychological point of view," human rights activist Sergei Kovalyov said. "It is a clear attempt to manipulate the mood of society - and just one of many instances of the increasing militarisation of society under Putin."

The announcement of these training classes unleashed a subtle taste of neo-authoritarianism in Putin's new-look Russia. This is a flavour that began to emerge with the appointment of the former KGB colonel as prime minister last August, which is becoming more powerful with every week that he presides over the Kremlin.

Again and again as he takes his first steps in political life, Putin has made a show of drawing on nostalgic themes from Russia's totalitarian past. He has made no secret of his fondness for the KGB, where he spent 16 years, and has paid tribute to those who presided over the security force's harshest clampdowns on Russia's dissident society.

Last year, he restored a plaque to former president and KGB leader Yury Andropov on the walls of the Lubyanka (ripped down with the reforms of the 90s). Recently, he unveiled another plaque honouring Russia's war heroes - with Stalin's name listed first. A commemorative coin decorated with Stalin's face has been issued and there are plans to install a new bust of the Soviet tyrant at Russia's main war memorial.

Putin is a modern politician - acutely sensitive to image and presentation - and these symbolic tributes to authoritarianism are made for calculated effect. The chaos and humiliations of Russia's decade of reforms left the population with a thirst for a strong leader capable of imposing order. Putin shrewdly built his appeal around a promise to restore stability, promising to crack down on corruption, crime and economic disarray.

But Russia's liberals - horrified by the country's new iconography - are wondering what else he plans to subject to a crackdown, anxious to establish whether this authoritarian streak runs deeper than mere symbolism.

When a band of former Soviet dissidents declared in February that Putinism was nothing short of modernised Stalinism, they were widely dismissed as hysterical prophets of doom. "Authoritarianism is growing harsher, society is being militarised, the military budget is increasing," they warned, before calling on the West to "re-examine its attitude towards the Kremlin leadership, to cease indulging it in its barbaric actions, its dismantlement of democracy and suppression of human rights."

In the light of Putin's actions during his first days in power, their warnings have gained an uneasy new resonance.

Putin's first steps - his structural political reforms, his government's handling of the press, his attitude towards democratic freedoms - all seem to indicate a step away from Russia's nascent democracy in a more repressive direction.

It is now three weeks since he was officially inaugurated and already his much-scrutinised enigma appears to be fading. While he has yet to announce any coherent plans to reinvigorate Russia's economy, or to improve life for its impoverished population - a third of whom live beneath the official poverty line - the new president has already set an apparently authoritarian seal on the future style of government.

It looks probable that his liberal inclinations, which he made much of to selected audiences before his election, will be restricted to economic reforms rather than to guiding his broader political aspirations.

Determined to grab power back from the country's rebellious regions, last week Putin carved up Russia into seven slices and appointed seven new presidential representatives.

These appointments are a stark portent of the future. Responsibility for Russia's north-western districts was entrusted to the sinister figure of Victor Cherkesov - deputy director of the FSB, the reorganised KGB - a man feared and hated by Russia's liberal population. In the 1970s and 1980s, Cherkesov was responsible for surveillance of the media and trade unions and enthusiastically pursued intellectual opponents of the Soviet regime.

The country's central region was given to another former KGB apparatchik, General Georgy Poltavchenko, while the Urals region was handed to a senior figure in the police force, General Pyotr Latyshev. The Caucasus region - where Russia's brutal war against Chechen rebels drags on - was allocated to one of the toughest generals behind the campaign, General Viktor Kazantsev, the man jointly responsible for the thousands of civilian deaths in the region. Only two of the seven districts are to be headed by civilian figures.

This elevation of former KGB men to important government positions continues a trend started last autumn. And a further hint of the role old KGB tactics could play in Putin's new Russia emerged this month with the publication of a leaked Kremlin strategy document, advising Putin to establish a new FSB-run "presidential political directorate" - to strengthen the president's power.

The body would gather dirt on opposition figures, and would whip the press into submission. "Opposition media should be driven to financial crisis, their licences and certificates withdrawn and conditions created where the work of every single opposition medium is either controllable or impossible," the document stated.

A media crackdown is already well under way. Ten days ago, more than 2,000 people - including the leading lights of Russia's media elite - gathered in central Moscow to protest against severe press restrictions exerted under Putin.

"It has become hard for journalists to breathe," the editor of the daily Moskovsky Komsomolets declared.

The mysterious, spurious tax raid on MediaMost, Russia's largest inde pendent media empire - which has been consistently critical of Putin's new regime - precipitated the final surge of alarm.

In the clear daylight of a cold May afternoon - just four days after Putin's inauguration - some 40 machine gun-wielding government security agents in black balaclavas and camouflage gear stormed their way into MediaMost's Moscow offices. The paramilitaries left several hours later, confiscating tapes and transcripts. Journalists working for MediaMost's leading daily newspaper, Sevodnya, and its | popular television station, NTV, saw the attack as an attempt to intimidate their dissenting voices into conformity.

Sevodnya's editor, Mikhail Berger, said that Putin's approach towards the press was strongly reminiscent of the Soviet era. "Putin has divided the media into two categories - those organisations that give him total, utter, unquestioning support and those that don't. He views the latter not simply as papers or television companies, but as enemy units which he has to fight," he said.

"Under the Soviet Union, everything was categorised either as Soviet or anti-Soviet. Now under Putin, everything is either state or anti-state. MediaMost has been repeatedly accused by the Kremlin of having an 'anti-state' position. In terms of press freedoms, I think we could see a swift return to the Soviet Union, not just to the 70s, but the 40s under Stalin."

Protesters returned to the streets last Friday to campaign against the forced sale of the broadcast licence of another television company, TV Centre, which has been consistently critical of the Kremlin.

This drive to stifle Russia's newly independent media began last autumn. Putin was determined to crack down on press coverage of his battle in Chechnya - to avoid the critical reports (and resulting public disillusionment) which plagued the government during the last war.

More troubling still is the role Russia's state-controlled media played in helping Putin ascend to power. Brazen manipulation of Russia's two nationwide television stations (with the collusion of their part-owner, Russia's oligarch supremo Boris Berezovsky) led to the political destruction of Putin's two serious presidential rivals - Moscow mayor Yury Luzhkov and former prime minister Yevgeny Primakov. In a vicious smear campaign, prime-time broadcasts portrayed Luzhkov as a corrupt murderer, and Primakov as a frail has-been. Putin's own ratings soared from 2% to 53%.

Meanwhile, the same television stations, ORT and RTR, helped promote a new pro-Putin political grouping - Unity, also known as Medved, the Bear. Like Putin, the faction rose to victory from nowhere, without ever pausing to detail its political intentions. Gradually, in the months since the election, Russia has seen its once-strong political opposition melt away, with even the once- intractable communists ready to compromise with the new order.

A deeper unease lurks in the minds of those dismayed by the neo-Soviet tendencies in Putin's new Russia - overshadowing everything else by its potential monstrosity. The memory of the unresolved September spate of apartment block bombings continues to unnerve those who question the official line that the attacks were orchestrated by Chechen terrorists.

The theory that the horrific attacks - in which almost 200 civilians were crushed to death - could have been an FSB ploy designed to drum up support for the Chechen war and thus aid the elevation of Putin to power, continues to be debated, although there is no more evidence for this version of events than for the terrorist scenario.

"Even thinking about the bombings chills my heart," Ludmila Alexeeva, president of the International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights, said. "I only know one thing - it was extremely unlikely to have been done by the Chechens; it just wasn't in their interests."

Despite this oppressive multitude of foreboding signals, a sense of perspective has to be maintained. Although harassed, Russia's press remains at liberty to continue criticising the government; while Stalinist symbols have been resurrected, there is no evidence of any return to the horrors of Stalinist oppression.

And even the extent of Putin's own power to indulge his authoritarian inclinations is still unknown. Eased into the Kremlin with the assistance of powerful behind-the-scenes tycoons from Yeltsin's camp, Putin remains at their mercy.

Since his debut on the political arena, Putin has struggled to play to conflicting audiences - presenting himself as liberal reformer to the West, as the firm hand of law and order to his own people and as the preserver of continuity to the forces who helped him into power. It is conceivable that his recent actions were designed primarily for domestic consumption and could later be supplemented by a more liberal programme, when his administration finally resolves which direction Russia should take. Alongside the KGB heavies and the powerful businessmen who surround Putin, a small group of liberals remain - who have yet to prove how much influence they can wield.

"I still have no idea whether Putin wants to reintroduce Stalinism or go in the direction of democracy - because if you listen to him, he says first one thing and then the other," Alexeeva said. "I don't think it's simply that we don't know what he stands for, I think he doesn't know either."

While he has yet to announce any coherent plans to reinvigorate Russia's economy, or to improve life for its impoverished population - a third of whom live beneath the official poverty line - the new president has already set an apparently authoritarian seal on the future style of government. It looks probable that his liberal inclinations, which he made much of to selected audiences before his election, will be restricted to economic reforms rather than to guiding his broader political aspirations. Determined to grab power back from the country's rebellious regions, last week Putin carved up Russia into seven slices and appointed seven new presidential representatives. These appointments are a stark portent of the future. Responsibility for Russia's north-western districts was entrusted to the sinister figure of Victor Cherkesov - deputy director of the FSB, the reorganised KGB - a man feared and hated by Russia's liberal population. In the 1970s and 1980s, Cherkesov was responsible for surveillance of the media and trade unions and enthusiastically pursued intellectual opponents of the Soviet regime. The country's central region was given to another former KGB apparatchik, General Georgy Poltavchenko, while the Urals region was handed to a senior figure in the police force, General Pyotr Latyshev. The Caucasus region - where Russia's brutal war against Chechen rebels drags on - was allocated to one of the toughest generals behind the campaign, General Viktor Kazantsev, the man jointly responsible for the thousands of civilian deaths in the region. Only two of the seven districts are to be headed by civilian figures. This elevation of former KGB men to important government positions continues a trend started last autumn. And a further hint of the role old KGB tactics could play in Putin's new Russia emerged this month with the publication of a leaked Kremlin strategy document, advising Putin to establish a new FSB-run "presidential political directorate" - to strengthen the president's power. The body would gather dirt on opposition figures, and would whip the press into submission. "Opposition media should be driven to financial crisis, their licences and certificates withdrawn and conditions created where the work of every single opposition medium is either controllable or impossible," the document stated. A media crackdown is already well under way. Ten days ago, more than 2,000 people - including the leading lights of Russia's media elite - gathered in central Moscow to protest against severe press restrictions exerted under Putin. "It has become hard for journalists to breathe," the editor of the daily Moskovsky Komsomolets declared. The mysterious, spurious tax raid on MediaMost, Russia's largest inde pendent media empire - which has been consistently critical of Putin's new regime - precipitated the final surge of alarm. In the clear daylight of a cold May afternoon - just four days after Putin's inauguration - some 40 machine gun-wielding government security agents in black balaclavas and camouflage gear stormed their way into MediaMost's Moscow offices. The paramilitaries left several hours later, confiscating tapes and transcripts. Journalists working for MediaMost's leading daily newspaper, Sevodnya, and its | popular television station, NTV, saw the attack as an attempt to intimidate their dissenting voices into conformity. Sevodnya's editor, Mikhail Berger, said that Putin's approach towards the press was strongly reminiscent of the Soviet era. "Putin has divided the media into two categories - those organisations that give him total, utter, unquestioning support and those that don't. He views the latter not simply as papers or television companies, but as enemy units which he has to fight," he said. "Under the Soviet Union, everything was categorised either as Soviet or anti-Soviet. Now under Putin, everything is either state or anti-state. MediaMost has been repeatedly accused by the Kremlin of having an 'anti-state' position. In terms of press freedoms, I think we could see a swift return to the Soviet Union, not just to the 70s, but the 40s under Stalin." Protesters returned to the streets last Friday to campaign against the forced sale of the broadcast licence of another television company, TV Centre, which has been consistently critical of the Kremlin. This drive to stifle Russia's newly independent media began last autumn. Putin was determined to crack down on press coverage of his battle in Chechnya - to avoid the critical reports (and resulting public disillusionment) which plagued the government during the last war. More troubling still is the role Russia's state-controlled media played in helping Putin ascend to power. Brazen manipulation of Russia's two nationwide television stations (with the collusion of their part-owner, Russia's oligarch supremo Boris Berezovsky) led to the political destruction of Putin's two serious presidential rivals - Moscow mayor Yury Luzhkov and former prime minister Yevgeny Primakov. In a vicious smear campaign, prime-time broadcasts portrayed Luzhkov as a corrupt murderer, and Primakov as a frail has-been. Putin's own ratings soared from 2% to 53%. Meanwhile, the same television stations, ORT and RTR, helped promote a new pro-Putin political grouping - Unity, also known as Medved, the Bear. Like Putin, the faction rose to victory from nowhere, without ever pausing to detail its political intentions. Gradually, in the months since the election, Russia has seen its once-strong political opposition melt away, with even the once- intractable communists ready to compromise with the new order. A deeper unease lurks in the minds of those dismayed by the neo-Soviet tendencies in Putin's new Russia - overshadowing everything else by its potential monstrosity. The memory of the unresolved September spate of apartment block bombings continues to unnerve those who question the official line that the attacks were orchestrated by Chechen terrorists. The theory that the horrific attacks - in which almost 200 civilians were crushed to death - could have been an FSB ploy designed to drum up support for the Chechen war and thus aid the elevation of Putin to power, continues to be debated, although there is no more evidence for this version of events than for the terrorist scenario. "Even thinking about the bombings chills my heart," Ludmila Alexeeva, president of the International Helsinki Federation for Human Rights, said. "I only know one thing - it was extremely unlikely to have been done by the Chechens; it just wasn't in their interests." Despite this oppressive multitude of foreboding signals, a sense of perspective has to be maintained. Although harassed, Russia's press remains at liberty to continue criticising the government; while Stalinist symbols have been resurrected, there is no evidence of any return to the horrors of Stalinist oppression. And even the extent of Putin's own power to indulge his authoritarian inclinations is still unknown. Eased into the Kremlin with the assistance of powerful behind-the-scenes tycoons from Yeltsin's camp, Putin remains at their mercy. Since his debut on the political arena, Putin has struggled to play to conflicting audiences - presenting himself as liberal reformer to the West, as the firm hand of law and order to his own people and as the preserver of continuity to the forces who helped him into power. It is conceivable that his recent actions were designed primarily for domestic consumption and could later be supplemented by a more liberal programme, when his administration finally resolves which direction Russia should take. Alongside the KGB heavies and the powerful businessmen who surround Putin, a small group of liberals remain - who have yet to prove how much influence they can wield. "I still have no idea whether Putin wants to reintroduce Stalinism or go in the direction of democracy - because if you listen to him, he says first one thing and then the other," Alexeeva said. "I don't think it's simply that we don't know what he stands for, I think he doesn't know either."

webTitle: Picnics and pilgrimages on day of victory

fields.headline: Picnics and pilgrimages on day of victory
fields.standfirst:
Lebanon celebrate: thousands pour south to visit liberated territory, but border incident raises fears

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: From all over Lebanon they came in their tens of thousands. Banners along the road proclaimed "the day of victory". A silver Buick had its boot lid tied down over a picnic table, the flag of Hizbullah fluttering gaily from its roof.
fields.byline: Brian Whitaker  in El Khiam, southern Lebanon
fields.body:
From all over Lebanon they came in their tens of thousands. Banners along the road proclaimed "the day of victory". A silver Buick had its boot lid tied down over a picnic table, the flag of Hizbullah fluttering gaily from its roof.

The country roads were nose to tail with cars as, on the first weekend since the Israeli withdrawal, the Lebanese flocked south in bank holiday mood. For some it was a homecoming, for others a family outing.

A strip of broken road beyond al-Nabatiyeh marked what, until a few days ago, had been an Israeli checkpoint. Shattered concrete blocks on either side testified to its recent demolition. In the distance, a man with a hammer was busy attacking the roof of a concrete pillbox, perhaps hoping to break off a souvenir. Traffic halted as families stopped by a burned-out tank to photograph their children sitting in its turret.

El Khiam, a village which last Tuesday afternoon earned its place in Lebanese history, had never seen so many people or such heavy traffic fumes, and the shops were almost out of food, drinks and cigarettes. Felds became car parks - to which Hizbullah men courteously directed motorists. The place that everyone had come to see was the notorious hilltop prison. Over the last 15 years, 2,000 people who had offended Israel's ally, the South Lebanon Army, had been held there, and 12 of them died.

The villagers told how, last Tuesday, 50 of them went up to the prison gates and gave the SLA a choice: leave immediately or wait for Hizbullah. The guards left but took the keys, so the people had to break in. They freed 145 prisoners, including four women.

At the weekend the prison was packed with visitors exploring every cell and passageway, some with video cameras, others licking ice creams. In places the smell was so appalling that people covered their noses and turned back, but a man in religious garb urged them on: "It's good for you," he told them.

The cells, some with 12 or 14 bunk beds, were strewn with wretched belongings and the remains of food. There was a half-finished carton of milk: best before 22.05.00.

The punishment cells were less that two metres long, and not much more than a metre wide. A woman spent six years in one of them, the visitors were told, for attacking the SLA's leader, Antoine Lahd.

After a visit by the Red Cross in 1995, conditions improved slightly. One addition was a small open area with a caged roof where women prisoners could sun themselves for 10 minutes once every 10 days.

In the yard, Ali Kosheish, 32, who spent 11 years in the prison, pointed to a steel pylon where, he said, his wrists were tied and he was tortured. Two other prisoners died as a result of this treatment, he said.

Outside the prison gates, ice cream vans chimed and the fat sizzled on a felafel stall. Nearby, Nijmi - one of the country's top football teams - arrived for a photo call. Dressed in their club colours, they posed on an SLA truck, giving victory signs.

Across the valley in Marjayoun, a Christian town, there were no festivities. The streets were empty, the shops were closed and the houses shuttered. Many people here, for want of other employment, had allied themselves to the SLA, and had fled.

Nearby, in Ebel el Saqi, the owner of the Down Town restaurant was looking forward to the arrival of UN reinforcements. He opened his business next to the Unifil checkpoint and, while the Norwegians manned it, trade was good. But the Norwegians were replaced by Indians who, he said, spent no more than $100 in the last 18 months.

A white-haired man introduced himself as the mayor. He was elected in 1973 and, as there had been no real government in these parts for 25 years, he had remained in office, after a fashion, ever since. Did he think there would be peace? "I'm 65 and have known wars all my life," he said. "We can't be sure. The Lebanese army should have moved in, but they haven't. There are bad things going on. Cars are being stolen."

There were hugs and handshakes all round as a man in his twenties, wearing an Adidas shirt and baseball cap, entered. He had just arrived home after four years' absence, someone explained. "He had to leave because he kidnapped a Palestinian - an Israeli agent - and handed him to the Lebanese authorities. The Palestinian was hanged."

fields.headline: BNFL sale plan is undermined
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: The government's on-off plans for a partial privatisation of British Nuclear Fuels suffered a potentially fatal blow yesterday when it emerged that the long-term liabilities at the state-owned atomic energy company are far higher than hitherto suspected - on a scale likely to deter would-be investors.
fields.body:
The government's on-off plans for a partial privatisation of British Nuclear Fuels suffered a potentially fatal blow yesterday when it emerged that the long-term liabilities at the state-owned atomic energy company are far higher than hitherto suspected - on a scale likely to deter would-be investors.

The full extent of the extra liabilities, said in one report to be up to £9bn, is due to be disclosed in BNFL's annual accounts later this summer but Whitehall insiders admitted yesterday the £27bn assumed so far was an underestimate.

The new liabilities relate to the costs of cleaning up BNFL's Sellafield site in Cumbria which is the centre of its controversial business for reprocessing nuclear waste, including spent fuel rods.

The extra costs were discovered by a management team sent in by ministers to re-examine BNFL's liabilities after it took over Magnox Electric, the nuclear generator which owns eight of Britain's oldest reactors.

The merger took place in January 1998. Both government sources and the company insisted last night that this report was incomplete and had yet to go to BNFL's auditors or its main board.

Ministers, far from being embarrassed by the findings, see them as a vindication of their policy of encouraging transparency and bringing in more commercially minded managers at BNFL.

The new estimates have come to light just two days after the Commons trade and industry select committee slammed successive governments for failing to get to grips with the company's finances and effectively giving it a free rein to embellish its accounts.

 Twelve of Europe's largest power utilities - including United Utilities, Northern Electric and National Grid - will announce plans this week for an online procurement exchange through which they will do business worth €22bn (£13.7bn) a year.

webTitle: Power players learn art of sharing

fields.headline: Power players learn art of sharing
fields.standfirst:
Vote puts end to whispering campaign

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Mandelson's efforts finally paid off on Saturday when the Ulster Unionists voted to return to government with Sinn Fein, ending at a stroke a whispering campaign that the Prince of Darkness had lost his touch.
fields.body:
With a wave of his hand Peter Mandelson leant back in his plush armchair and peremptorily interrupted his Unionist audience.

"Have you met Bobby," the Northern Ireland secretary enquired in a manner bordering on the regal. "You must come out and see him."

The Unionist delegation, who had been summoned to meet Mr Mandelson at his palatial residence at Hillsborough Castle soon after his arrival in the province, ignored the offer to meet his beloved golden retriever and returned to berating him.

"It was all a bit naff," one of the Unionists said. "But you've got hand it to Mandelson - it was a classy way to shut us up."

Bobby has less value as a prop these days, after the friendliness of Mr Mandelson's initial encounters with Northern Ireland's political leaders gave way to months of relentless hard bargaining. His efforts finally paid off on Saturday when the Ulster Unionists voted to return to government with Sinn Fein, ending at a stroke a whispering campaign that the Prince of Darkness had lost his touch.

The vote showed that the deft Mandelsonian skills, which played such a crucial role in establishing New Labour, had paid off in the infinitely more labyrinthine world of Northern Irish politics. Once again Mr Mandelson had been personally saved from disaster, no doubt allowing him to dream of stepping into his grandfather's shoes as a future foreign secretary.

Any thoughts of another cabinet role are said to be a long way down the road, with government sources suggesting that Mr Mandelson will remain in Belfast to nurse devolution through its early stages. If the executive works success fully, then Mr Mandelson is expected to play an increasing role in Labour's general election planning, although he will be on call to return to the province at a moment's notice.

The impending election battle with the Tories is likely to prove, for Mr Mandelson at least, more sedate than his ex perience in Northern Ireland. Over the past eight months both sides have launched vitriolic attacks on him, though the venom is currently coming from nationalists who believe that Mr Mandelson has tilted the balance too far in favour of Unionists. The latest issue of the Dublin current affairs magazine Magill contains a devastating attack on Mr Mandelson, saying that his tenure at Hillsborough owes more to the Raj than to 21st century Belfast.

Mr Mandelson's friends, however, insist that he is fulfilling the brief he was given when Tony Blair despatched him to Belfast last autumn. His role was to restore confidence among Unionists, who had fallen out with Mo Mowlam, without losing the faith of nationalists.

Friends say that Mr Mandelson has achieved this in the three crucial tests he has faced since coming to Belfast.

Within weeks of his arrival, Mr Mandelson played a pivotal role in ensuring that Mr Trimble won his party's backing to form an administration with Sinn Fein ahead of IRA disarmament. In the run-up to the vote in November, Mr Mandelson sent a series of emollient signals to the Unionist community by praising the RUC and arranging for the force to be awarded the George Cross.

The executive was formed, but less than two months later Mr Mandelson faced his most trying moment when Mr Trimble carried out his threat to pull the plug, claiming that the IRA had failed to abide by a commitment to disarm. In the face of opposition from Sinn Fein, the SDLP and the Irish government, Mr Mandelson suspended the executive to ensure that it could be revived at a later date.

His move, which delighted Unionists, horrified nationalists who felt that Mr Mandelson had caved into Unionist pressure. The Irish government was so angry that the Dublin cabinet secretary was said to have interrupted the Taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, during a telephone conversation with Mr Blair, to denounce Mr Mandelson.

Sinn Fein and the SDLP are still smarting at the decision, although Mr Mandelson is now widely praised for his move. Kevin McNamara, the former Labour Northern Ireland spokesman who is sympathetic to nationalist thinking, said that the IRA's offer to open up its arms dumps had vindicated his decision.

Although the executive is to be restored once again this week, the suspension in February has left a sour taste in the mouths of nationalists.

In his third test - the imple mentation of the Patten report on police reforms - Mr Mandelson will have his work cut out to restore the faith of nationalists, without losing the Unionists.

Nationalists have been outraged by a series of concessions to the Unionists over the police, which were designed to strengthen Mr Trimble's hand in the run up to Saturday's vote. Mr Mandelson responded to Unionist concerns by promising to keep alive the name of the RUC, which Mr Patten wanted to abolish, in the forthcoming legislation that will create the new police force.

Government sources suggested yesterday that Mr Mandelson will reach out to nationalists by keeping an "open mind" to SDLP amendments to other areas of the policing bill when it reaches committee stage in the commons.

One government source said that the reform of the RUC symbolised the delicate balancing act Mr Mandelson has tried to achieve. "It is all about trying to create an equilibrium and navigating a good path between both sides," one source said. "The aim is to include everybody's point of view to create an effective police force. But there is no point in creating a police service free from the shackles of the past which is then vulnerable to political intrusion."

When Mr Trimble sits down again with Sinn Fein this week, Mr Mandelson will take a back seat as local leaders once again assume the reins of power.

But Mr Mandelson will know that a crisis can blow up in Northern Ireland seemingly out of nowhere, with the potential to inflict serious political damage to the resident of Hillsborough Castle.
