webTitle: Loyalist feud 'poised to escalate into war'

fields.headline: Loyalist feud 'poised to escalate into war'
fields.standfirst:
Police fear outcome as UFF takes sides in drugs battle

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Detectives in Belfast and mid-Ulster fear a simmering dispute between two loyalist groups is set to explode as it threatens to drag the largest loyalist paramilitary organisation into what they fear would be a vicious war.
fields.body:
Detectives in Belfast and mid-Ulster fear a simmering dispute between two loyalist groups is set to explode as it threatens to drag the largest loyalist paramilitary organisation into what they fear would be a vicious war.

The development follows the murder three days ago of Mark Taylor, 35, a father of two, in north Belfast, the fourth victim of the loyalist feud in as many months. He was raked with gunfire as he repaired a garden wall for a friend .

The hardline Loyalist Volunteer Force, the breakaway group founded four years ago by the late Billy Wright, is believed to have been behind the attack. Its intended victim was Taylor's friend, a suspected Ulster Volunteer Force member. He escaped serious injury. The 29-year-old man, from Dungannon, Co Tyrone, said he had been tipped off about an imminent attack.

That was, in turn, in response for a failed UVF murder bid on an alleged LVF man nearby in north Belfast two days earlier.

Although the dispute is between the LVF and UVF, the Ulster Freedom Fighters are becoming involved. The UFF has long been at odds with the UVF in Belfast, and, through west Belfast commander Johnny Adair, is forging links with the LVF in Portadown, Co Armagh.

Detectives believe the burgeoning drugs trade lies at the heart of the dispute. The LVF and UFF are seen as big players, while the UVF insists it is trying to keep dealers out of its areas.

Relations between the UVF and UFF are at a dangerous low on the Shankill Road, Mr Adair's territory. Each has been defacing the other's murals, heightening tensions, and there are fears of an escalation.
fields.bodyText: Detectives in Belfast and mid-Ulster fear a simmering dispute between two loyalist groups is set to explode as it threatens to drag the largest loyalist paramilitary organisation into what they fear would be a vicious war. The development follows the murder three days ago of Mark Taylor, 35, a father of two, in north Belfast, the fourth victim of the loyalist feud in as many months. He was raked with gunfire as he repaired a garden wall for a friend . The hardline Loyalist Volunteer Force, the breakaway group founded four years ago by the late Billy Wright, is believed to have been behind the attack. Its intended victim was Taylor's friend, a suspected Ulster Volunteer Force member. He escaped serious injury. The 29-year-old man, from Dungannon, Co Tyrone, said he had been tipped off about an imminent attack. That was, in turn, in response for a failed UVF murder bid on an alleged LVF man nearby in north Belfast two days earlier. Although the dispute is between the LVF and UVF, the Ulster Freedom Fighters are becoming involved. The UFF has long been at odds with the UVF in Belfast, and, through west Belfast commander Johnny Adair, is forging links with the LVF in Portadown, Co Armagh. Detectives believe the burgeoning drugs trade lies at the heart of the dispute. The LVF and UFF are seen as big players, while the UVF insists it is trying to keep dealers out of its areas. Relations between the UVF and UFF are at a dangerous low on the Shankill Road, Mr Adair's territory. Each has been defacing the other's murals, heightening tensions, and there are fears of an escalation.

webTitle: Six soap scripts challenge hopes of Crossroads revival

fields.headline: Six soap scripts challenge hopes of Crossroads revival
fields.trailText: Soaps written by the gay playwright Jonathan Harvey and the controversial novelist Kevin Sampson are competing with the planned revival of the 1970s series Crossroads for the lucrative ITV slot vacated by Home and Away.
fields.body:
Soaps written by the gay playwright Jonathan Harvey and the controversial novelist Kevin Sampson are competing with the planned revival of the 1970s series Crossroads for the lucrative ITV slot vacated by Home and Away.

The Guardian has learned that a shortlist of six ideas, currently being considered by programming chiefs, includes projects by some of the most experienced drama producers in television. The resurrection of Crossroads is by no means certain.

ITV has decided to order a home-grown series to replace the Australian beach-based soap Home and Away, snatched in a bidding war by Channel 5, instead of buying another "off-the-shelf" programme. It is ITV's biggest-ever single commission.

The move is high-risk: new soaps are notoriously difficult to produce. The BBC suffered an ignominious failure with Eldorado in the early 1990s, and ITV's Albion Market and Families were similarly short-lived. This time, ITV wants to be seen to be developing British talent, particularly in the light of criticism over its revamped evening schedule.

Commissioning editors have whittled down a long list of about ten ideas to six projects from five programme-makers. The list is headed by Crossroads, promoted by Carlton's director of production, Lord Alli.

Since the revival plan was revealed in the Guardian last month, viewers and some of the soaps former stars have contacted Carlton to support the project, although the broadcaster is refusing to say whether any of the original characters will return.

It can be revealed, however, that some 12 years after the series ended, the famous motel has been refurbished, equipped with a plush health spa, swimming pool and conference centre.

Mr Harvey, writer of Beautiful Thing, is developing a soap opera called Big Smoke, set in a block of flats on a city estate - one of two ideas put forward by Yorkshire television, the makers of Emmerdale.

A pilot episode is already in production, and the format is described as "flexible". The idea was first proposed when ITV's director of programmes, David Liddiment, took over at the network in 1997, and may be commissioned for the 10pm time slot instead of early evening.

Yorkshire, for its second pitch, Hope Point, has teamed Sampson - a former manager of the rock band The Farm - with two experienced soap writers. The programme will explore "modern family relationships", and Sampson's hard-core realism, portrayed in his novels Powder and Awaydays - about a band and football hooligans respectively - will bring an edgy feel.

Hewland International, makers of Sky's Dream Team, a series about a Premiership football team, have come up with Richfield, set in an affluent district of the south-east of England. The idea is described as "Dallas meets EastEnders".

Brian Park, a veteran of Coronation Street, is leading the team behind Big City, from another independent producer, Shed. The show would centre on a dilapidated north London lodging house popular with teenagers newly arrived in the capital.

United News and Media, which owns the ITV companies Meridian, Anglia and HTV, is proposing Life Etc, which revolves around a group of friends "watching their children grow up before they have finished growing up themselves".

All six soap teams must come up with a set of scripts and story ideas by July, and a decision is expected by August. The series will then go into production later in the year, but is unlikely to make it to the screens until well into 2001. Home and Away ends on ITV in the second week of June, and will transfer to Channel 5 - which is also bidding for BBC1's Australian soap, Neighbours - in July next year.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Car seat risk to children
fields.body:
Car seat risk to children

Parents are buying second-hand car seats without knowing where they have come from, how to fit them or whether they are suitable for their children, according to a survey by WhichCar? It found that four out of 10 parents did not know how to fit their child's car seat properly, only 10% knew their history and only 15% knew the weight of their child, which is a key factor in choosing the right seat.

Rupert annual fetches £16,500

A rare Rupert Bear annual which cost 53p when it was bought in 1973 was sold yesterday for £16,500. The book was one of only a dozen printed that year which showed Rupert with a brown face. The other 500,000 annuals showed him with a white face. The annual had been expected to fetch around £8,000 at the Hamer 20th Century Books auction in Todwick, near Sheffield, South Yorkshire.

Hutchence estate pays out

Paula Yates is to get £400,000 from the estate of the rock singer Michael Hutchence, while their three-year-old daughter, Heavenly Hiraani Tiger Lily, will get up to £2m which will be held in trust until she is 25 , according to reports yesterday.

Four share £7m

Four tickets shared Saturday's £7.38m National Lottery jackpot with numbers 21, 23, 33, 34, 43 and 45. The bonus was 40. There was one winner of the £250,000 Thunderball with numbers 4, 5, 7, 20 and 24. The Thunderball number was 2.

webTitle: Fashanu's guilt over suicide of brother

fields.headline: Fashanu's guilt over suicide of brother
fields.trailText: Footballer John Fashanu yesterday revealed the guilt he felt about ignoring his brother Justin's last telephone call before he committed suicide.
fields.body:
Footballer John Fashanu yesterday revealed the guilt he felt about ignoring his brother Justin's last telephone call before he committed suicide.

The former Wimbledon player and presenter of the television programme Gladiators said he was haunted by a call he received on his mobile phone the day before Justin, 37, was found hanging in a garage in Shoreditch, east London, in May 1998.

At the time of his death newspapers wrongly reported there was a warrant out for his arrest in America for allegedly molesting a 17-year-old boy earlier that year.

In a frank television interview with Esther Rantzen, Fashanu said he would always blame himself for his older brother's death because he thought he could have done more. "Just before he committed suicide there was a telephone call to my mobile phone that night and the person wouldn't speak. I could hear breathing, I could feel that it was somebody from my family.

"I could feel that it was Justin, but I didn't reach out. I just put the phone down and thought: 'Oh, it's him again'. And of course the next day he committed suicide."

In a suicide note, Justin Fashanu, the former England under-21 and Nottingham Forest player who in 1990 became the first professional footballer to come out as a homosexual, said he wanted to die rather than put his friends and family through any more unhappiness.

Yesterday John Fashanu said he had not accepted Justin's sexuality, or how desperate his plight was, and the pair had not been on speaking terms for many years. "Justin confessed that he was gay, and he was living in America at the time. I think that he had - no, we had - created a situation where we isolated him. I don't think that we had accepted that he was gay. When I say 'we', I am probably trying to protect myself. I am saying 'me'.

"And I think that what happened was there were allegations that Justin was involved with some problems in America which have been published in the newspapers, and I think that he panicked and could not take it any more, and thought that the best thing to save the family from embarrassment, which he had written in the suicide note, and he committed suicide.

"Sadly and unfortunately I was not on speaking terms with him at the time. Hindsight is a lovely word. I don't think I realised the depth of loneliness and despair that he was going through. I don't think that I really, in a selfish way, understood exactly what was going on.

"I think we are all scared of what we don't understand."

The Fashanu brothers were both placed in a Barnado's home by their mother after their father left Britain to return to Nigeria. They grew up with a foster family in Attleborough, Norfolk, and were spotted as schoolboys by Norwich City scouts.

Justin became the first £1m black player but his career was cut short by a series of knee injuries. He moved to North America where he coached teams in the US and Canada.

John Fashanu, who lives in London, said he had spoken about the death to publicise the work of the Samaritans, an organisation he supports and had phoned for advice in the past. "The fact that Justin committed suicide really alerted to me that whether you are rich and famous, or whether you are poor and not famous, people have problems, and people will reach out and look for help."

fields.headline: 1m 'unknown diabetics'
fields.trailText: Up to 1m people in Britain may be unaware they have diabetes because of public ignorance about the disease, according to a report published yesterday.
fields.body:
Up to 1m people in Britain may be unaware they have diabetes because of public ignorance about the disease, according to a report published yesterday.

Lack of knowledge about symptoms and risk factors means people were not being treated. A survey by the charity Diabetes UK found that less than half knew the disease could kill.

Three-quarters of people in high risk groups did not know they had an increased chance of developing the condition. High risk people are those in two or more of the following groups: over 40 years old; family history of diabetes; from an ethnic minority; overweight.

About 1.4m people know they have diabetes but campaigners want to target the "missing million". A nationwide campaign highlighting symptoms is to be launched on Tuesday.

Press Association

fields.headline: Lamplugh car lead 'significant'
fields.trailText: Police investigating the murder of estate agent Suzy Lamplugh were hoping yesterday for a "significant development" after seizing a car they believed may have been used in her abduction 14 years ago.
fields.body:
Police investigating the murder of estate agent Suzy Lamplugh were hoping yesterday for a "significant development" after seizing a car they believed may have been used in her abduction 14 years ago.

Detectives from Scotland Yard's serious crime group are conducting forensic tests on the car which was driven by one of the key suspects - believed to be John Cannan, jailed in 1989 for rape and murder - at the time Ms Lamplugh disappeared after going to show a man round a house in Fulham, west London.

Fingerprints have been taken from the vehicle - and new scientific techniques are expected to be used to assess if Ms Lamplugh and the suspect can be linked to the car.

The development emerged after a new witness came forward after the investigation was re-launched earlier this month.

The case was closed in 1987 but was re-opened following fresh evidence from a witness which suggested more than one person was involved, together with advances in forensic techniques and a review of the original investigation.

"Since we announced the reinvestigation ... a further witness has come forward with new information which officers view as significant," A Scotland Yard spokeswoman said.

The latest informant told officers he had lent the car to the suspect for a few days at the time of Ms Lamplugh's disappearance. He had long since sold it. Police found the car at a used-car dealership where it had been parked for several years.

Ms Lamplugh's mother, Diana, said she was trying hard to control her excitement at the possible breakthrough.

John Cannan, now 45, was jailed for life in 1989 for crimes including the rape and murder of Shirley Banks, a Bristol sales manager, in 1986. He was interviewed three times by officers on the Lamplugh case and denied killing her.

fields.headline: Morality plays
fields.standfirst:
Blair the pragmatist preaches peace in Sierra Leone while flooding Africa with guns

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Two images dominated last week's news. Both were of children. One lay sleeping on the floor alongside his doting father; the other posed, British gun in hand, with a cocky nervousness. They were separated by 14 (or so) years, skin colour, several thousand miles and every conceivable circumstance which will ensure that one is likely to grow up never hungry, never in fear of his life, while the other will be lucky to reach his 18th birthday alive, even luckier to fill his stomach or get an education.
fields.body:
Two images dominated last week's news. Both were of children. One lay sleeping on the floor alongside his doting father; the other posed, British gun in hand, with a cocky nervousness. They were separated by 14 (or so) years, skin colour, several thousand miles and every conceivable circumstance which will ensure that one is likely to grow up never hungry, never in fear of his life, while the other will be lucky to reach his 18th birthday alive, even luckier to fill his stomach or get an education.

The complicated tangle of morality, economy and global politics which weave through the lives of these two boys has every good liberal wrestling with his or her conscience. There are always more questions than answers. How did such inequality ever come to pass? Whose fault is it, and therefore whose responsibility? What is a British gun doing in the hands of this child? And always that crushing imperative - that this is intolerable and something must be done.

It is this which seems to fuel this government's fidgety interventionism. No sooner have we completed a crusade in one corner of the globe, than New Labour is sending our boys off to sort out another messy, brutal war. There is a curious irony that the Labour party of the early 80s, so in love with pacifism and nuclear disarmament, has bequeathed us a government with probably the most interventionist record since the days of Palmerston's gunboat diplomacy. Much is made of this government slaying Labour's ghost of economic incompetence, but Tony Blair's slaughter of another ghost - Labour's hands-up defence policy - has been equally comprehensive.

We are told that this country went into Sierra Leone because Blair thought it was "morally the right thing to do". Curious thing, this morality business of Blair's. We heard a lot about it during Kosovo, then all went quiet over Chechnya, and there wasn't a murmur about morality when the new military leaders in Pakistan wanted their next consignment of aircraft or Zimbabwe was due its instalment of spare parts to meddle in the Congo. Number 10 overruled the Foreign Office on both arms deals, for fear of undermining Britain's reputation as one of the world's biggest arms suppliers. When Putin needed a boost in his election campaign, Blair hotfooted it to St Petersburg to do business with a man who has pursued a war as vicious as any of those conducted by the west's pet hate figures, such as Milosevic or Saddam Hussein.

Blair's "morality" is deeply pragmatic; that much even he admitted in his crucial Chicago speech in April 1999, when he was trying to persuade the US of the virtues of the Kosovo war. "Our actions are guided by a more subtle blend of mutual self interest and moral purpose in defending the values we cherish." This kind of morality sounds like a brand of instant coffee. It also sounds like the kind of moral purpose with which Palmerston infused his gunboat diplomacy. Pax Britannica was supposed to bring peace and prosperity to the world. In reality, it brought a hugely lucrative drugs trade to Asia and constructed a global economic system which supplied Britain with plentiful, cheap raw materials and large markets for our manufactured goods. It was an ideology thinly veneering our often brutal economic exploitation.

VS Naipaul describes this beautifully at the beginning of his novel A Bend In The River, when he compares the European traders on the east coast of Africa with the Indians and Arabs: "The Europeans could do one thing and say something quite different; and they could act in this way because they had an idea of what they owed to their civilisation. It was their great advantage over us. The Europeans wanted gold and slaves, like everybody else; but at the same time they wanted statues put up to themselves as people who had done good things for the slaves... they got both the slaves and the statues."

Our colonial past isn't just history. The British still use a moral narrative to explain and justify our position and power in the world. We want to feel good about ourselves, and so, on to the conveniently distant canvas of Africa, we can project a wonderful tale about our altruistic morality, how a few of our wonderfully trained and disciplined soldiers will sort out the whole Sierra Leone mess. Newspapers talk without a trace of irony of the white man's burden, and our commander in Freetown, Brigadier David Richards, sounds uncannily like a late 19th-century imperialist, such as Gordon or Rhodes.

What is implicit in this modern morality tale is our own superiority, and the unquestioned benefits of European style progress and civilisation. What we wilfully chose to forget is our on-going complicity in the political instability and poverty of Africa. We mount such charades as Sierra Leone while we glut the continent with weapons - between 1995-97 the UK supplied small arms to over 100 countries.

Earlier this year, the former head of the IMF, Michel Camdessus, pleaded with the west that the biggest thing it could do for Africa was to stop exporting arms to the continent. We agonise about Africa's inability to feed itself, while we benefit from the collapse of commodity prices which have destabilised dozens of African economies, and milk millions in interest on loans we made to prop up corrupt regimes.

If Blair was really motivated by morality over Africa, he would have shown more interest in backing the campaign to meet the UN's educational targets by 2015, or would have done more to push Gordon Brown's debt relief efforts, which have still to produce tangible benefits for any African country apart from Uganda. But those are the sort of worthy things which don't have much resonance with the electorate, beyond some Guardian readers.

Instead, Blair falls easily back into a tradition of showcasing British moral superiority - a tradition which appears the more naive and ill-thought-through for its parallels with another story of peace-making, this time in our own backyard. Why should conflict in Sierra Leone prove any simpler to resolve than in Northern Ireland?

But such common-sense questions get swept aside by an enthusiastic moral narrative which won't admit that our budget and appetite for this African adventure will run out long before peace is secured. The suspicion has to be that this action is a substitute for the government having any other ideological vision. When domestic economic and political policy amount to an unglamorous pragmatism, what better way to tart it up than with a brave crusade or two?

Just don't expect it to do much in the long term for the tragic people of Sierra Leone: we'll find a way to wriggle out, leaving our guns behind.


Madeleine Bunting

The complicated tangle of morality, economy and global politics which weave through the lives of these two boys has every good liberal wrestling with his or her conscience. There are always more questions than answers. How did such inequality ever come to pass? Whose fault is it, and therefore whose responsibility? What is a British gun doing in the hands of this child? And always that crushing imperative - that this is intolerable and something must be done. It is this which seems to fuel this government's fidgety interventionism. No sooner have we completed a crusade in one corner of the globe, than New Labour is sending our boys off to sort out another messy, brutal war. There is a curious irony that the Labour party of the early 80s, so in love with pacifism and nuclear disarmament, has bequeathed us a government with probably the most interventionist record since the days of Palmerston's gunboat diplomacy. Much is made of this government slaying Labour's ghost of economic incompetence, but Tony Blair's slaughter of another ghost - Labour's hands-up defence policy - has been equally comprehensive. We are told that this country went into Sierra Leone because Blair thought it was "morally the right thing to do". Curious thing, this morality business of Blair's. We heard a lot about it during Kosovo, then all went quiet over Chechnya, and there wasn't a murmur about morality when the new military leaders in Pakistan wanted their next consignment of aircraft or Zimbabwe was due its instalment of spare parts to meddle in the Congo. Number 10 overruled the Foreign Office on both arms deals, for fear of undermining Britain's reputation as one of the world's biggest arms suppliers. When Putin needed a boost in his election campaign, Blair hotfooted it to St Petersburg to do business with a man who has pursued a war as vicious as any of those conducted by the west's pet hate figures, such as Milosevic or Saddam Hussein. Blair's "morality" is deeply pragmatic; that much even he admitted in his crucial Chicago speech in April 1999, when he was trying to persuade the US of the virtues of the Kosovo war. "Our actions are guided by a more subtle blend of mutual self interest and moral purpose in defending the values we cherish." This kind of morality sounds like a brand of instant coffee. It also sounds like the kind of moral purpose with which Palmerston infused his gunboat diplomacy. Pax Britannica was supposed to bring peace and prosperity to the world. In reality, it brought a hugely lucrative drugs trade to Asia and constructed a global economic system which supplied Britain with plentiful, cheap raw materials and large markets for our manufactured goods. It was an ideology thinly veneering our often brutal economic exploitation. VS Naipaul describes this beautifully at the beginning of his novel A Bend In The River, when he compares the European traders on the east coast of Africa with the Indians and Arabs: "The Europeans could do one thing and say something quite different; and they could act in this way because they had an idea of what they owed to their civilisation. It was their great advantage over us. The Europeans wanted gold and slaves, like everybody else; but at the same time they wanted statues put up to themselves as people who had done good things for the slaves... they got both the slaves and the statues." Our colonial past isn't just history. The British still use a moral narrative to explain and justify our position and power in the world. We want to feel good about ourselves, and so, on to the conveniently distant canvas of Africa, we can project a wonderful tale about our altruistic morality, how a few of our wonderfully trained and disciplined soldiers will sort out the whole Sierra Leone mess. Newspapers talk without a trace of irony of the white man's burden, and our commander in Freetown, Brigadier David Richards, sounds uncannily like a late 19th-century imperialist, such as Gordon or Rhodes. What is implicit in this modern morality tale is our own superiority, and the unquestioned benefits of European style progress and civilisation. What we wilfully chose to forget is our on-going complicity in the political instability and poverty of Africa. We mount such charades as Sierra Leone while we glut the continent with weapons - between 1995-97 the UK supplied small arms to over 100 countries. Earlier this year, the former head of the IMF, Michel Camdessus, pleaded with the west that the biggest thing it could do for Africa was to stop exporting arms to the continent. We agonise about Africa's inability to feed itself, while we benefit from the collapse of commodity prices which have destabilised dozens of African economies, and milk millions in interest on loans we made to prop up corrupt regimes. If Blair was really motivated by morality over Africa, he would have shown more interest in backing the campaign to meet the UN's educational targets by 2015, or would have done more to push Gordon Brown's debt relief efforts, which have still to produce tangible benefits for any African country apart from Uganda. But those are the sort of worthy things which don't have much resonance with the electorate, beyond some Guardian readers. Instead, Blair falls easily back into a tradition of showcasing British moral superiority - a tradition which appears the more naive and ill-thought-through for its parallels with another story of peace-making, this time in our own backyard. Why should conflict in Sierra Leone prove any simpler to resolve than in Northern Ireland? But such common-sense questions get swept aside by an enthusiastic moral narrative which won't admit that our budget and appetite for this African adventure will run out long before peace is secured. The suspicion has to be that this action is a substitute for the government having any other ideological vision. When domestic economic and political policy amount to an unglamorous pragmatism, what better way to tart it up than with a brave crusade or two? Just don't expect it to do much in the long term for the tragic people of Sierra Leone: we'll find a way to wriggle out, leaving our guns behind. Madeleine Bunting

fields.headline: I wasn't off the rails
fields.trailText: Not to hog your letters page - but, yes, I understood that what John Baker deplored was the use of an accusative pronoun in place of a nominative pronoun. "It wasn't me, miss," was what we said in primary school, and I see no reason to abandon the demotic of the 21st century when addressing Guardian readers.
fields.body:
Not to hog your letters page - but, yes, I understood that what John Baker deplored was the use of an accusative pronoun in place of a nominative pronoun. "It wasn't me, miss," was what we said in primary school, and I see no reason to abandon the demotic of the 21st century when addressing Guardian readers. To the extent that there is such a thing as correct English usage, "it isn't me" and "it wasn't them" is part of it, and "it isn't I" and "it wasn't they" verges on the pedantic. God, of course, uses the English of the King James Bible, but that's His business.
Alan Ryan
New College, Oxford alan.ryan@new.oxford.ac.uk

 A pity the photograph with your story about bus delays (Maths team keeps buses on time, May 26) was also running behind schedule. The bus congestion in Sheffield High Street was at least 10 years ago. Supertram, one of Europe's most modern urban transit systems, now runs on that spot - which is why Sheffield no longer faces that sort of problem.
Phil Andrews
Head of PR, Sheffield Council p.andrews@sheffield.gov.uk

 Why don't train companies encourage commuters to play musical chairs (Letters, May 26)? Not only would it liven everyone up in the morning, but losers could be welcomed by Tories handing out refunds at the ticket barrier.
Gareth Wall
Chelmsford, Essex

 In BBC management, when the music stops they put out another chair.
Fritz Spiegl
Liverpool fritz@scousepress.co.uk

 The Queen's Household Division - great colour co-ordination, and not a black face among them (Front page, May 27). Looks like blatant racism to me. What's the royal household's explanation?
Anne Thomas
Halesworth, Suffolk

fields.headline: University challenged on discrimination
fields.trailText: On reading your article (Brown scorns Oxford elitism, May 26), I was alarmed at the similarity of Laura Spence's position with my own
fields.body:
On reading your article (Brown scorns Oxford elitism, May 26), I was alarmed at the similarity of Laura Spence's position with my own. I have seven A*s and four As at GCSE and am predicted five A-grades at A-level. At the start of this year, I applied to King's College, Cambridge to study medicine. I received two interviews. I had the same experience as Laura, in that the interviewers seemed very interested in trying to trip me up, rather than finding out my potential. Your quote from the Oxford don is ironic, considering that references to my accent were made in one of the interviews I attended, which made me extremely uneasy.

In addition, references to my ethnic origin were made, as I was asked why I had a B grade in Urdu (the lowest grade on my CV). He was referring to the fact that I had got A* and A grades in French and German, which should supposedly have been harder for me. He failed to realise I don't speak Urdu at home; he just assumed that I should for some reason have an advantage in learning this language.

I have written countless letters, emails and made many phone calls to try and find out exactly why I was rejected and have received only one reply, which ignored all of my questions and did not enlighten me in the slightest bit. As soon as they consider the selection process to be over, the applicant's view doesn't really seem to matter. It would be unfair of me to suggest that Cambridge or Oxford are the only universities practising such inappropriate and blatantly discriminatory methods of selection. Such discrimination is quite the norm in practically all university selection, as I have personally experienced.
Nadia Ashraf
Nottingham
nadiaashraf@yahoo.com

It's intellectual diversity and variety that scares the crows at Oxbridge. University tutors abhor being upstaged by their students, especially those wearing lipstick and army boots. The culture of archaic politeness and deference in higher education has to go. And let's recognise that the pressures to succeed at these establishments have caused breakdowns and suicides. A degree is not worth that amount of unhappiness.

Kath McMullen
Hove, E Sussex
kath.mcmullen@cwcom.net

fields.headline: Sylvia's site
fields.trailText: I was intrigued to learn (Struggle renewed, May 25) that Michael Heseltine heads a team of worthies who want to place a statue of Lloyd George on College Green. They should revise their plans immediately - we have claimed the site for a statue of Sylvia Pankhurst.
fields.body:
I was intrigued to learn (Struggle renewed, May 25) that Michael Heseltine heads a team of worthies who want to place a statue of Lloyd George on College Green. They should revise their plans immediately - we have claimed the site for a statue of Sylvia Pankhurst, the feminist socialist who built the suffrage movement in London's East End. Our statue, subject to planning permission, will be unveiled on June 20, 2001. On the same day over 80 years ago, Sylvia threatened to continue indefinitely a hunger and thirst strike unless the Liberal government agreed to meet a deputation of working-class women suffragettes from the East End. As a result Asquith and Lloyd George, who had smeared the suffrage campaign as a middle-class "escapade", met for the first and only time a delegation of women workers. It would be unthinkable to permit Lloyd George even posthumously to reverse the tide of history. College Green is for Sylvia and the ignored force of history - working-class women.
Mary Davis
Sylvia Pankhurst Memorial Committee m.davis@unl.ac.uk

fields.headline: Ian Black @Brussels
fields.standfirst: The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Sir Stephen Wall, Britain's ambassador to the European Union, has been telling Euro-MPs a heart-warming story about a sniffer dog, codenamed Fido, at Heathrow Airport. One day the faithful hound sniffs suspiciously at a package from central America: it is full of high-grade heroin.
fields.body:
Sir Stephen Wall, Britain's ambassador to the European Union, has been telling Euro-MPs a heart-warming story about a sniffer dog, codenamed Fido, at Heathrow Airport. One day the faithful hound sniffs suspiciously at a package from central America: it is full of high-grade heroin.

But there is more to this canine coup than meets the eye. Fido finds the drugs, the story continues, because customs officers have been alerted to look at a particular container by a communications intercept from a country not a million miles away from Colombia.

Scenes like this happen across Europe because, Sir Stephen concludes, Britain shares the fruits of its secret intelligence-gathering - much of it conducted with the US - with European partners fighting their own wars against highly-organised criminals. Electronic eavesdropping, therefore, is a socially useful activity.

The ambassador has been talking about Fido because some concerned Euro-MPs think otherwise. Thanks to their efforts, the interception of communications will be raised at an EU meeting in Brussels today. Reading each other's (e)mail is common enough; talking about it is highly unusual.

Jack Straw and fellow interior ministers are to have what British officials hope will be no more than a brief lunchtime tour d'horizon of the nether world. All governments spy, at home and abroad. None really want to open this can of worms.

Yet this embarrassing subject is not going to go away: interest has been fuelled by revelations about Echelon - a network of satellites and listening posts reportedly capable of intercepting millions of telephone, fax and email messages.

A parliamentary committee is investigating allegations that Echelon, run by the US, Britain, Canada, Australia and New Zealand, has been used to spy on European companies. French MEPs are incensed by reports that the US used it to beat the European consortium Airbus to a deal with Saudi Arabia.

Britain is squirming because the issue has been presented as one where a choice has to be made between the US and Europe. Fido's contribution to the drugs war is designed to divert attention from the fact that most intelligence is clearly not shared with our 14 partners.

HMG says the interception of communications is covered by strict guidelines, ministerial control and parliamentary oversight. The need to "safeguard the nation's economic well-being," it insists, does not involve commercial advantage for British companies.

Exactly what Echelon can do is not known. Most experts assume that, as well as providing information on terrorists, rogue states or drug smugglers, it has given British ministers advance knowledge of the negotiating positions of EU colleagues.

As Charles Grant points out in a new paper for the Centre for European Reform, the row is symptomatic of the lack of trust between Britain and the rest of the EU over the special relationship with the Americans - where GCHQ's partnership with the National Security Agency enables our spies and customs men to punch far above their weight. All very unfortunate, since the British are leading efforts to give the EU some modest military muscle to match its economic weight - and to assuage US anxieties that this will undermine Nato.

Still though, the Anglo-American relationship creates real problems in Europe, especially for the French - no slouches themselves when it comes to espionage. And the difficulty goes far wider, of course, than the arcane world of intelligence: Britain is the only EU member to actively back the US over Iraq. It is also doing little to shoot down Bill Clinton's controversial plans for a national missile defence system.

It comes down, at the end of the day, to the fact that Britain wants it both ways: to maintain its privileged links with Washington and be a big player in Europe. Or, as Fido might growl after a successful bust, have a bone and eat it too.

fields.headline: Policing and the RUC
fields.trailText: Ronan Bennett gives a timely reminder of the dangers of diluting reform of the RUC (Brute force, May 27). In the early 1990s I lived in the north of Ireland to gather data for a degree dissertation. My experiences of the way the RUC operates and its attitudes to the two communities conforms exactly to Bennett's.
fields.body:
Ronan Bennett gives a timely reminder of the dangers of diluting reform of the RUC (Brute force, May 27). In the early 1990s I lived in the north of Ireland to gather data for a degree dissertation. My experiences of the way the RUC operates and its attitudes to the two communities conforms exactly to Bennett's.

Unfortunately, the RUC is not a police force in the sense that we understand it on the mainland. I recall being herded out of a pub at gun-point - I am talking rifles here, held by soldiers and RUC men, while the pub was "cleared". The reason for our summary eviction? We were playing traditional Irish music. Needless to say, the chances of having your car stopped and searched, and many other routine inconveniences of living in a militarised zone, are far higher for Catholics than Protestants.

What is surprising is the Catholic community's tolerance of this bigotry and willingness to compromise to gain peace. Root and branch reform is the only alternative to disbanding the RUC, which is what should have happened.

Name and address withheld

 If, say, some faceless black Londoners in February 1985 had launched a mortar attack on Stoke Newington police station, randomly blowing nine Metropolitan police officers to bits to the point where their mutilated bodies could not be identified; if other black Londoners were routinely setting car bombs under the private vehicles of off-duty Met officers endangering them, their wives, their children and passers by; if yet more were passing on information about white and black Met officers in the community - their movements, their cars, their telephone numbers, their addresses - and this information was then used to kill them; if black Londoners routinely harassed, threatened, abused and even killed other black Londoners simply because they were relatives of, or friends with, a Met officer; if faceless black Londoners had regularly gunned down Met officers on normal police duty; and if all of this had gone on for over 30 years, then Ronan Bennett's analogy between the Metropolitan police and the RUC might be a more interesting one.
Tim Pritchard

webTitle: About turn in a load of warm fat

fields.headline: About turn in a load of warm fat
fields.standfirst:
Driving out hot dog sellers is a denial of New Labour's core values

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Driving out hot dog sellers is a denial of New Labour's core values
fields.body:
Another attempt will soon be made to drive the Buckingham Palace hot dog men from the pavements around the Victoria Monument. And it seems that it may well succeed. At present the police can do no more than move them on. But a private member's bill proposes the confiscation of the heated trolleys in which sausages are bathed in warm fat until they reach the temperature at which germs feel most at home, and the government is going to support the backbench initiative. Even allowing for the government's disposition to extend police powers whenever an opportunity arises, the decision to turn up the heat on hot dog salesmen is astonishing. Their business represents everything in which New Labour believes.

Although I feel severe nausea at the thought of those ministers who changed overnight from leftwing council leaders into perfect Blairites, I do not accuse the government of intentionally encouraging stomach disorders. Indeed, I am only grateful that, having passionately promoted every other activity which begins with e-hyphen, it has made an exception for e-Coli. It is not what the hot dog men sell that should endear them to New Labour. It is the way in which they sell it. First and foremost, they have chosen work rather than welfare. Instead of registering themselves as unemployed, they have shown the quality which ministers most admire - private enterprise.

These men have used their initiative and the limited amounts of capital at their disposal to set up new businesses. There is no doubt that they are meeting a demand. On this bank holiday Monday, tourists will be queuing up to experience what they believe to be traditional English food. If over the years no one had bought hot dogs, their assembly and distribution would have gone the way of the Rover company and its franchise holders. They prosper without subsidy, are almost certainly not unionised, and I doubt if those who employ an assistant are troubled by the inadequate level at which the minimum wage has been set. Their lives are New Labour industrial policy made flesh.

Yet a government which regards intervention as a sin against the Holy Ghost is prepared to intervene to put them out of business. Ministers who usually argue that regulation blunts the cutting edge of competition are prepared to regulate the sale of sausages. The flexible labour market is, they argue, essential to efficiency. But they are inflexible about the rules governing trade in frankfurters.

I am not a hot dog man myself. Their produce emits such a noxious smell that even my dog - who eats sheep turds when he gets the chance - shudders as he walks past. But the government which brought us the Greenwich Dome is not in a strong position to defend its authoritarian conduct on aesthetic grounds. And it is hard to imagine what else could justify this petty tyranny. I am assured that Rupert Murdoch has no intention of going into the hot dog trade. So my initial suspicion that the field was being cleared for him to take over the business proved groundless. Since hot dog men are part of the private sector, if the government were consistent, it would argue that they behave in a way which all public agencies and institutions ought to envy and copy.

About four years before he became president of the United States and five minutes after he presented me with the California Liberty Medal (second class), Ronald Reagan advanced a theory of unemployment which, until the hot dog crisis arose, I assumed was shared by the government - namely that it is all voluntary. Anyone who wants a job, he said, can get one. The example he gave was the Founding Fathers of the Republic. Nobody handed them welfare cheques. They never claimed that they lacked essential skills. Instead of hanging about feeling sorry for themselves, they went out into the wilderness and chopped wood, planted corn and shot turkeys. For some reason I no longer recall, Governor Reagan thought the turkey shooting had a special significance.

These days the unemployed are not presented with such opportunities. Wood chopping, corn planting and turkey shooting are prohibited in the Royal Parks. But, until the law is changed, there is a modern equivalent open to any resourceful young man who does not mind letting his cigarette ash fall into hot fat. Yet the government is to connive at closing down that one big chance. Where are these entrepreneurs to find an alternative outlet for their passion for market capitalism? A few might be employed running the local authority schools which the Chief Inspector believes would improve under private ownership. Others may find work managing old people's homes, prisons, the air traffic control system or any of the other services which Tony Blair wants to expose to the rigours of competition. But one question remains. Why, if he is so sure that the future lies with free enterprise, will he support it being snuffed out on the Mall?

These men have used their initiative and the limited amounts of capital at their disposal to set up new businesses. There is no doubt that they are meeting a demand. On this bank holiday Monday, tourists will be queuing up to experience what they believe to be traditional English food. If over the years no one had bought hot dogs, their assembly and distribution would have gone the way of the Rover company and its franchise holders. They prosper without subsidy, are almost certainly not unionised, and I doubt if those who employ an assistant are troubled by the inadequate level at which the minimum wage has been set. Their lives are New Labour industrial policy made flesh. Yet a government which regards intervention as a sin against the Holy Ghost is prepared to intervene to put them out of business. Ministers who usually argue that regulation blunts the cutting edge of competition are prepared to regulate the sale of sausages. The flexible labour market is, they argue, essential to efficiency. But they are inflexible about the rules governing trade in frankfurters. I am not a hot dog man myself. Their produce emits such a noxious smell that even my dog - who eats sheep turds when he gets the chance - shudders as he walks past. But the government which brought us the Greenwich Dome is not in a strong position to defend its authoritarian conduct on aesthetic grounds. And it is hard to imagine what else could justify this petty tyranny. I am assured that Rupert Murdoch has no intention of going into the hot dog trade. So my initial suspicion that the field was being cleared for him to take over the business proved groundless. Since hot dog men are part of the private sector, if the government were consistent, it would argue that they behave in a way which all public agencies and institutions ought to envy and copy. About four years before he became president of the United States and five minutes after he presented me with the California Liberty Medal (second class), Ronald Reagan advanced a theory of unemployment which, until the hot dog crisis arose, I assumed was shared by the government - namely that it is all voluntary. Anyone who wants a job, he said, can get one. The example he gave was the Founding Fathers of the Republic. Nobody handed them welfare cheques. They never claimed that they lacked essential skills. Instead of hanging about feeling sorry for themselves, they went out into the wilderness and chopped wood, planted corn and shot turkeys. For some reason I no longer recall, Governor Reagan thought the turkey shooting had a special significance. These days the unemployed are not presented with such opportunities. Wood chopping, corn planting and turkey shooting are prohibited in the Royal Parks. But, until the law is changed, there is a modern equivalent open to any resourceful young man who does not mind letting his cigarette ash fall into hot fat. Yet the government is to connive at closing down that one big chance. Where are these entrepreneurs to find an alternative outlet for their passion for market capitalism? A few might be employed running the local authority schools which the Chief Inspector believes would improve under private ownership. Others may find work managing old people's homes, prisons, the air traffic control system or any of the other services which Tony Blair wants to expose to the rigours of competition. But one question remains. Why, if he is so sure that the future lies with free enterprise, will he support it being snuffed out on the Mall?

fields.headline: Stop the brickbats for Brit-flicks
fields.trailText: Jacques Peretti's venomous attack on the British film industry (Shame of a nation, Friday Review, May 26) is at the outset predicated on the belief that the industry is a single organism somehow rotten at the core
fields.body:
Jacques Peretti's venomous attack on the British film industry (Shame of a nation, Friday Review, May 26) is at the outset predicated on the belief that the industry is a single organism somehow rotten at the core. As in every art, there are failures. However most of the big flops that Peretti derides are actually based on the American model which he eulogises. In fact, beyond these lacklustre imitators there is a rich and vibrant industry.

As a director of photography, I have worked in Britain and the US, on films with high and low budgets and I have come to realise that applying national colours is pointless and divisive. I can talk with personal experience about High Fidelity, based on Nick Hornby's London-based novel and shot in Chicago. Far from "completely junking any Hornby element", the final screenplay was one of the most faithful adaptations of a novel, by the screenwriters' own admission. The first Hollywood adaptation of the script was a limp, predictable and schmaltzy version, jettisoned by writers John Cusack, DV DeVincentis and Steve Pink, who returned to Hornby's original.

Peretti's assertion that Americans took the book and did it properly might be tempered by a closer look at some non-American names on the credits: director, Stephen Frears; producer, Tim Bevan; editor, Mick Audsley; and director of photography, Seamus McGarvey. And post-production was by a British team. The film was made in a completely collaborative way by people from many countries - it just happened to be shot in the US. This cul-de-sac preoccupation with nation can only crush a diverse, burgeoning industry in Britain. Our concern, while forging a film industry here, should be about ideas rather than misplaced national identity. In cinema there is no nation but the imagination.
Seamus McGarvey
Glasgow mcseamie@aol.com

 Any serious points made by Jacques Peretti are undermined by the juvenile attempt to tar most of the least successful British productions with the same brush. His reporting of Alan Parker's observation that the script is everything is quite correct and Alexander Walker's attacks on the misuse of lottery funds are becoming occasionally persuasive. There is need for urgent discussion on where things have gone wrong, but please don't invite Mr Peretti.

As one of the anointed godfathers of "Brit Shit", the producer of Absolute Beginners and executive producer of Fever Pitch, I have no axe to grind with Peretti's critique, but it's irksome that he attacks the money wasted on British turkeys over the last five years, without noting that these have been five of the most financially successful years in the recent history of British cinema. The Full Monty, Notting Hill, The World Is Not Enough (which between them took over £100m in Britain alone), Bean, Trainspotting, Sense And Sensibility, Little Voice, Lock, Stock, East is East etc have dominated world box offices. This phenomenal success is what has created an environment for imitators hoping to repeat such success. He singles out Fever Pitch as being a commercial flop in his list of "five of the worst", when it was both critically well received and a modest commercial hit in cinemas and on video.

Far from being "soaringly ambitious" - an accusation against Absolute Beginners - most of the films Peretti attacks are renowned for their lack of ambition. It is important that ambition isn't used as a dirty word. In his haste to degrade Natural Nylon productions your journalist manages to dump on Warzone, one of the most critically acclaimed films of 1999.

It is facile to dub every movie that doesn't gross $100m as Brit Shit and pathetic to trash actors of the calibre of Jude Law and Rhys Ifans for some of the movies that don't work, whilst ignoring the ones that do. This kind of irresponsible Brit backlash is the reason that actors like Michael Caine feel so insecure working in their own industry. This witless piece is definitely on my list of one of the worst five articles on the film industry ever published in the Guardian.
Stephen Woolley
Company of Wolves

 Jacques Peretti may have a point regarding the effects of lottery money, but there is no justification in denigrating everything that has come out of the British film industry in recent years. Some of those films made a strong impression on audiences in Europe and elsewhere, including Gary Oldman's film Nil By Mouth, Shane Meadows' TwentyFourSeven, Ken Loach's My Name Is Joe, Mike Leigh's Secrets And Lies and I could easily extend this list of titles.

If he does not like "hardship movies", there are also gems of comedy, such as Peter Chelsom's Funny Bones or Andrew Kotting's Gallivant. There are very promising new British film directors, for example, Carine Adler, whose film, Under the Skin, rightly received the critics' award in Toronto, or Nichola Bruce, whose recent first feature, I Could Read The Sky, was shown at the Berlin Film Festival.

True these films are not the kind that meet Oscar expectations. But if Jacques Peretti should try to convince me that Danny Boyle's Hollywood film The Beach is a better film than those Brit-flicks, I would be worried about a sad state - not of British film production, but of film criticism over there.
Dr Jurgen Enkemann
(Film critic), Berlin

fields.headline: Executive powers
fields.standfirst:
Modernise is still one of the government's favourite words - but not when it means giving MPs greater powers to scrutinise Whitehall

Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The other day, with no press release, no public announcement and certainly no briefing by Number 10, the Blair government issued a major constitutional statement. That is to say it reiterated its distinctly unmodern version of how the House of Commons should work. It screwed down, ever more tightly, a doctrine of executive supremacy in which MPs at large are little more than also-rans, lobby fodder. Whatever "modernisation" means, it does not cover giving most MPs a larger share in deciding our collective destiny.
fields.body:
The other day, with no press release, no public announcement and certainly no briefing by Number 10, the Blair government issued a major constitutional statement. That is to say it reiterated its distinctly unmodern version of how the House of Commons should work. It screwed down, ever more tightly, a doctrine of executive supremacy in which MPs at large are little more than also-rans, lobby fodder. Whatever "modernisation" means, it does not cover giving most MPs a larger share in deciding our collective destiny.

In an obscure document which it did not even bother to put on the internet, preferring instead to lodge it in a parliamentary pigeonhole called the Vote Office, the government effectively told MPs to forget any attempt to increase their powers of scrutinising Whitehall, examining spending or calling ministers to account. Windows for reform close all too quickly. This will probably be MPs' only chance. In rejecting their bid for more powers, Tony Blair has ensured he will leave intact the unassailable might of parliamentary executive.

Select committees are chaired by veterans and senior people - mainly Labour but including Tories and Liberal Democrats. In March these banded together to challenge the government (Select Committee on Liaison: Shifting the Balance: www.parliament.uk.). They were not asking for much. They wanted bigger budgets, staff, more time for debates on their reports. Most of all they wanted recognition by ministers that making law and policy is a consensual business, in which MPs are partners not mere subordinates.

Commons select committees were reformed just after Margaret Thatcher took power in 1979, and in the two decades since have become a fixture, most of them focusing on specific Whitehall departments. According to Giles Radice, Labour chair of the Treasury committee and leader of the March exercise, these specialist committees had provided bargain basement scrutiny.

Some observers of parliament have been less complimentary, finding they have had little influence on policy. Too often it has suited party whips (the Tories when they were in power, Labour vice versa) to put Commons amateurs on them and starve them of the resources they need to give their work intellectual credibility. Even the public accounts committee, despite its formal powers of investigation and the 800-odd National Audit Office staff it commands through the comptroller and auditor general, has too often seemed to be running to catch up.

What the advent of a strong Labour government offered, said the March liaison committee report, was a chance to "shift the balance between legislative and executive". If MPs were more involved in scrutinising bills, defects might be spotted. But that would mean backbench MPs would have to start shaping up, employing proper staffs - and probably also working normal hours.

Mr Radice and colleagues wanted to build an "alternative career path" with good MPs making a name for themselves not as ministers but as scrutineers. They did not consider the political implications of their suggestions - weaker party discipline pointing forward, perhaps, to the introduction of proportional representation for Westminster.

The plan was to discipline ministers who came to committees and gave a "a sub-standard response". The implication was that, for the first time since the 17th century, legislators would face down the executive, maybe even by depriving ministers of office.

Revolutionary talk, which the government has now rejected with contempt (The Government's Response, Cmnd 4737). Adopting the sort of tone you use with recalcitrant pets or unruly children, the government makes no concessions. This is par for the course on reform of the Commons, where chief whip Ann Taylor and ultramontane Margaret Beckett, leader of the house, have been veritable forces of conservatism.

There is praise. The government says the select committees are "an entrenched part of our constitutional arrangements as never before". But as for any practical increment in their powers, forget it. The MPs' attempt to wrest control of their own committee membership away from the whips is rejected. The government will continue to choose who gets what assignment on the select committees, which basically means the executive will, once again, control the process by which it is assessed and monitored. Take the matter of staffing the committees, which pay their advisers paltry sums.

Staffing is "not a matter for the government", it says; but only if you believe the cock-and-bull story that MPs are free to vote without reference to party whips and executive orders.

We are cooperating more with select committees, says the government, citing multiple appearances by ministers. Since May 1997 defence ministers have given evidence on 26 occasions, Foreign Office ministers on 23 occasions. We have condoned a "huge increase" in select committee activity. The average annual total of reports they now issue is well above that in the Tory years. In 1997-98, select committees issued 186 reports, 175 the next year compared with 137 in 1992-93, the Tory maximum.

But MPs must not get above themselves. Their attempt to reconstitute their committees to reflect the government's own policy priorities is turned down. For all the Cabinet Office's talk of "joining up" public policy, there are to be no joined-up select committees capable of following spending and decisions through more than one department. And the reason the government gives is telling. Joining up the scrutiny of policy could mean Treasury officials get called too often and, it seems, Gordon Brown is having none of that kind of accountability.

And no surprise: "the government sees no reason to change the current arrangements for accountability of the intelligence and security services". For the executive state, it remains business as usual.

Commons select committees:

 15 committees scrutinise Whitehall departments

 Seven "cross-cutting" committees cover areas ranging from deregulation to public accounts

 250 support staff

 175 reports issued (1998-99)

David Walker

fields.headline: Crime rap
fields.trailText: Fifty detectives have spent 12 months on the Dando investigation (Report, May 26). We read of the shortage of police personnel, yet here we have 100,000 hours of time devoted to one case.
fields.body:
Fifty detectives have spent 12 months on the Dando investigation (Report, May 26). We read of the shortage of police personnel, yet here we have 100,000 hours of time devoted to one case. Imagine all the crimes of theft, assault and robbery which went unheeded as a result of there being no one to investigate.
SJ Hill
St Albans, Herts Jackill@cwcom.net

 Whatever happened to being innocent until proven guilty? I can't believe you published the name of the Dando murder suspect. If I'm ever arrested for something I may not have done, please at least spell my name properly as you throw my reputation to the mob.
Julia McKiernan
London

webTitle: Bestfoods dismisses bid talks with Unilever

fields.headline: Bestfoods dismisses bid talks with Unilever
fields.trailText: Bestfoods, the group behind brands such as Knorr and Hellmann's mayonnaise, last night said it would not be persuaded to open talks with Unilever, which is trying to launch a $18.4bn (£12.3bn) takeover of the US company.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor  and Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
Bestfoods, the group behind brands such as Knorr and Hellmann's mayonnaise, last night said it would not be persuaded to open talks with Unilever, which is trying to launch a $18.4bn (£12.3bn) takeover of the US company.

Unilever is expected to try to lure Charles "Dick" Shoemate, Bestfood's chief executive, into discussing the takeover by raising its $66 (£44) a share offer to as much as $72.

Unilever, which is determined to add Knorr and Hellmanns to its global brands, has so far failed to engage in any concrete negotiations with Bestfoods and is thought to be reluctant to launch a hostile bid for the group.

While Bestfoods' shareholders are said to be frustrated at management's refusal to engage in talks, a spokesman for Bestfoods, which is based in Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey, maintained the company was still opposed to the takeover.

"Bestfoods has no interest in speculation about Unilever or Unilever's business decisions," the spokesman said. However, he said the company was in "an ongoing dialogue" with its investors, who have seen the company's shares rise since Unilever made the takeover approach earlier this month.

Unilever last night refused to comment on the possibility of a higher bid being tabled but did point out that a proposal of $66 was on the table, and said the company still hoped to begin discussions.

Bestfoods, perhaps in an attempt to squeeze out a higher offer, has told its investors that it believes the combined businesses could create cost savings of $1bn. Unilever has put the figure at closer to $500m.

Bestfoods

Brand value: Hellmann's mayonnaise, Thomas' English muffins and bagels, Mueller's pasta, Mazola cooking oil, Knorr soup, Skippy peanut butter

Global reach: Distribution in about 110 countries. Roughly 60% of sales come from outside North America

Recent history: Following failed merger talks with Heinz, Bestfoods has already rejected a bid from Unilever

<s

Unilever

Brand value: Lipton, Popsicle, Vaseline, Q-Tips, Helene Curtis, Lever 2000, Pepsodent, Wisk, and Country Crock

Global reach: 300 operating units in 88 countries with 246,000 staff worldwide

Recent history: In the process of scrapping 25,000 jobs over five years in a global restructuring operation costing £3.3bn. Also just bought Ben & Jerry's ice cream in a deal worth more than £200m, and Slim-Fast foods for £1.44bn

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Sunday Business
fields.body:
Sunday Business

Greg Hutchings, chairman of Tomkins, is under pressure from institutional shareholders to quit. The call for his resignation centres around corporate governance issues and the group's strategy.

Railtrack will warn this week that next year's profits will be well down on forecasts because of higher than expected spending. The rail infrastructure group will also warn that if the new charging regime imposed by the rail regulator is too tough it will appeal to the competition commission.

Bass is preparing a £1bn bid for Posthouse, the hotel chain owned by Granada GroupGranada announced alongside its plan to merge with Compass Group earlier this month that Posthouse was not likely to be a core growth brand.

Sunday Telegraph

Scottish Provident, the mutual life insurer, has put itself up for sale after a four month strategic review by Flemings. Scottish Provident could command a price tag of of up to £1bn, and result in average windfalls for the mutual's 400,000 qualifying policyholders of between £2,250 and £2,500.

Royal & Sun Alliance is considering a £1bn bid for If, the non-life insurance joint venture between Skandia, the Swedish insurance group, and Storebrand, the Norwegian insurer. The move comes after plans to merge If with the non-life insurance business of Pohjola, the Finnish insurer, collapsed two weeks ago.

Sunday Times

Germany's T-Online aims to pre-empt rival bidders by negotiating a rapid deal to buy Freeserve, the British internet group 80% owned by Dixons. The electrical chain is looking for a bid of more than £6.5bn, well above Freeserve's current value of just below £4bn.

Dan Wagner, head of Bright Station, has profited from Britain's first big e-commerce failure, Boo.com, and helped salvage a second dot.com collapse. The information technology firm, formerly known as Dialog, had snapped up technology from the collapsed online clothing retailer Boo.com for £250,000.

Mail on Sunday

Bosses of Britain's biggest companies saw their pay soar by more than 30% last year - six times the growth in average earnings and more than 13 times the rate of inflation.

Sunday Express

fields.headline: France Telecom wins Orange
fields.standfirst: Vodafone Airtouch puts final touches to £30bn deal
fields.trailText: Advisers to Vodafone-AirTouch were last night scrambling to finalise details of the £30bn sale of Orange, the mobile phone network, to France Telecom.
fields.body:
Advisers to Vodafone-AirTouch were last night scrambling to finalise details of the £30bn sale of Orange, the mobile phone network, to France Telecom.

The deal is expected to be presented to shareholders at Vodafone's annual results meeting tomorrow and will be made up of cash and France Telecom shares of around £24bn. The French company will assume a further £6bn in debt, including the cost of Orange's third generation mobile licence the British company won in the recent state-sponsored auction.

If the transaction goes through it will be third time lucky for the French company which has long made its intention to enter the British market clear.

France Telecom tried and failed to acquire One2One which ultimately fell to Deutsche Telekom and, through NTL in which it has a significant stake, was the last to drop out of the running for the fifth licence in the recent third generation auction.

The former state-owned monopoly is the leading mobile operator in its domestic market, where it has 10m subscribers, but has failed so far to build any scale outside of France. Advisers though were cautioning that the sale was still not yet a done deal.

France Telecom is expected to pool its mobile assets and relist a minority stake on the London and Paris stock exchanges - a move which would likely defuse a potential dispute with Orange chief executive Hans Snook who has lobbied hard to retain a degree of autonomy.

Mr Snook is understood to have conducted separate negotiations with France Telecom and has taken the gamble of letting it be known that he would otherwise quit the company.

Vodafone acquired Orange when it won the fiercely contested battle for Germany's Mannesmann. The subsequent sale or demerger of Orange was a condition imposed by regulators in Europe but will represent a tidy profit for Vodafone. Mannesmann acquired Orange for just £19.8bn last October.

The gain in value in the eight months since Mannesmann agreed to acquire Orange in the face of a slump in world markets underlines the long term value being ascribed to mobile phone companies.

It is understood that Vodafone will arrange the cash and shares mix so it ends up with less than 10% of France Telecom. Those shares will be divested as and when Vodafone needs the extra cash.
Hans Snook, chief executive of Orange, can afford to play hardball. As often seen in his trademark leather blazer and Orange cufflinks as a conventional suit, Mr Snook has made no secret of what he wants from France Telecom - a separate stock market listing of the business and full management control.

Advisers to the company who slavishly intone the Snook mantras would like to believe that the man who admittedly has been key to the success of the business is now pivotal in its sale.

His brief unhappy experience with Mannesmann was a clear indication that Mr Snook doesn't like playing by other people's rules. Mannesmann believed in fixed and wireless integration, Mr Snook as anyone who has spent more than five minutes in his company will know, believes in a fully wirefree future.

Mr Snook made an estimated £45m from the deal. If all goes according to plan, his bank account is likely to swell further - one report yesterday suggested to £100m.

fields.headline: Football chiefs mull pay TV
fields.standfirst: Premier League may cut out middleman and launch its own channels
fields.trailText: The Premier League will this week consider plans to launch its own network of pay-television channels instead of selling the rights to a third party broadcaster.
fields.body:
The Premier League will this week consider plans to launch its own network of pay-television channels instead of selling the rights to a third party broadcaster.

Brian Deutsch, a pioneer of pay-TV who founded Westminster Cable in the early 1980s, will present proposals for a series of channels screening everything from the Premier League to grass roots games. They have options on satellites which would provide space for 24-channels.

Mr Deutsch has approached a number of City investment banks to discuss a bond issue which would be securitised against future earnings of the channels and enable him to deliver clubs an upfront sum. The various football authorities would also retain control over online merchandising and a share of operating profits under the plan.

If football officials sign up to the project, other sports would be invited to climb on board.

"The idea is that football would maximise revenues for itself by cutting out the middleman," said one source close to the negotiations. "If you look at BSkyB they have created a £30bn company on the back of carrying football and why shouldn't the game do the same?"

The channels would be made available to all existing satellite, cable and digital terrestrial platforms in much the same way that Sky Sports is currently distributed.

The Premier League is currently meeting with broadcasters to discuss their bids for the next set of broadcasting rights starting with the 2001/2 season. The bidding is expected to be hotly contested and reports at the weekend suggested cable company NTL had made a £1.75bn offer for the main package of live rights plus the secondary pay-per-view package.

In the last round of negotiations in 1996, BSkyB won the live rights package for £670m over five years and the BBC secured a highlights package for £73m.

United News & Media and a consortium of the Mirror Group and Carlton Communications put forward bids to set up new channels with the aim of profit-sharing in 1996. They were rejected at the time for the more certain upfront cash from Rupert Murdoch, who already had an established distribution platform in BSkyB.

The advent of digital television and the number of channels it offers, plus the introduction of pay-per-view, may now favour the launch of an own-branded network.

Digital technology has already led to the launch of a series of club-specific channels, including Manchester United's MUTV and Middlesbrough's Boro TV. Clubs will have delayed rights to show their own games.

The Premier League is offering a number of packages including a main bundle of 66 live games, pay-per-view rights over 40 live games and two sets of highlights.

Mr Deutsch, who also chaired the former City Centre Cable in London, later bought the Hulton picture library which housed the Picture Post collection of prints in the late 1980s for £1m. He sold it on for a reported £10m in 1996.

British Telecom, which owned Westminster Cable, was forced by regulators to sell the business last year because of its involvement in British Interactive Broadcasting. The franchise was bought by NTL.

Both Mr Deutsch and Premier League officials declined to comment.

Mr Deutsch has been advised by Anderson Consulting.
