webTitle: Ethiopia puts its puppets into Eritrea

fields.headline: Ethiopia puts its puppets into Eritrea
fields.standfirst:
Ultimate goal in Addis Ababa is control of Horn of Africa

Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: Ethiopian aircraft yesterday bombed a new power plant financed by Middle East and Italian backers near the Red Sea port of Massawa, according to the Eritrean foreign ministry.
fields.body:
Ethiopian aircraft yesterday bombed a new power plant financed by Middle East and Italian backers near the Red Sea port of Massawa, according to the Eritrean foreign ministry.

This followed the launch yesterday of a large-scale Ethiopian offensive pushing deeper into the Eritrean heartland and sending tens of thousands of Eritrean civilians fleeing from their homes.

This war is about much more than remote border claims. It is a product of resurgent nationalism within Ethiopia's northern Tigray region - home of the country's ruling party - that has merged with a powerful Ethiopian nationalism whose supporters were never happy to see Eritrea break off from Ethiopia a decade ago, when it won its independence after a 30-year war.

The question now is whether Eritrea will be forced by international inaction to fight its way out of the corner or whether pressure will be brought to bear on Ethiopia. Calls by the EU, the UN and the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) to halt the fighting have fallen on deaf ears.

Ethiopian leaders are now publicly voicing what Eritreans always feared - that this war was never really about borders. It is a power struggle over who will dominate the strategic Horn of Africa.

Now that Ethiopia has gained the upper hand, its army is pressing on to restructure Eritrea's leadership while trying to cripple its ability to hit back in the future. These tactics may backfire, however, and fuel more fighting.

Ethiopia's prime minister, Meles Zenawe, said last week that he will not stop the war until Eritrea's military capacity has been substantially reduced, even if Eritrea pulls its forces out of all disputed territories, as it offered to do on Wednesday. Meanwhile, Ethiopian commanders inside Eritrea are giving control of captured cities and towns to Eritrean surrogates groomed for the purpose.

These forces, grouped under the banner of the Alliance of Eritrean National Forces, include the Democratic People's Movement of Eritrea and Saghem, extreme leftwing parties that were sheltered by the Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF) within Tigray from the mid-1980s after they were driven out of Eritrea by the independence movement. Others represent an Islamist right nurtured by neighbouring Sudan until recently. Their presence in the alliance masks deep and potentially explosive differences.

Several of these opposition groups were given bases within Tigray in the late 90s, as tensions mounted between the two neighbouring states. After war broke out, Ethiopia gave the dissident groups radio facilities, though there was no sign of them as recently as March when I toured the areas of western Eritrea that are now under Ethiopian control.

But these surrogate militias could set the stage for civil war within Eritrea after an armistice is reached.

Unless the international community succeeds in bringing the two countries to the negotiating table soon, the war itself could escalate. Ethiopia holds a clear edge now, but that may not last.

The coalition that rules Ethiopia is flexing its political and military muscle, both within the country and against its former Eritrean mentors. In the mid-90s, the government redrew its internal boundaries to reflect ethnic identity.

The upshot was a federation of mini-states, with Tigray dominant for the first time since the dawn of the 20th century. The Tigrayans then turned their attention to Eritrea, seizing control of small border communities, until the Eritreans sent in tanks to assert their claims on May 12 1998. The next day Ethiopia declared war.

This war is a bid by the Tigrayan nationalists to whittle down their feisty northern neighbour. The cost in human terms is already staggering and will almost certainly worsen. Since the fighting started two weeks ago, more than half a million people have been displaced within Eritrea. This comes on top of an estimated 200,000 driven from their homes in earlier rounds of fighting.

With at least this many also threatened with starvation by persistent drought affecting much of the famine-prone region, at least a quarter of Eritrea's 3.5m people are now at risk. Should fighting continue into the summer rainy season, preventing Eritrea's subsistence farmers from planting their annual grain crops, the country could face a humanitarian catastrophe.

With such highly charged forces unleashed, there is little chance that diplomatic shuttles between the two capitals will slow the killing, unless strong sanctions are applied to force both a ceasefire and the immediate and full implementation of an OAU peace plan which has been on the table for nearly a year.

There is no other way to settle this dispute that will not lead to renewed fighting in the future. However, the longer the conflict continues, the more possible it is that wars-within-wars will keep the region off-balance and open the door to a resumption of fighting once the pressure is off.

 Dan Connell is the author of Against All Odds: A Chronicle of the Eritrean Revolution (Red Sea Press).

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Thief Of Baghdad | Manon Des Sources | The Devil's Own | Armageddon
fields.body:
The Thief Of Baghdad
(Ludwig Berger, Michael Powell, Tim Whelan, 1940)

7pm, Carlton Cinema

A treasure-trove of magical special effects and colourful adventure, created by the wizardry of producer Alexander Korda, the Spielberg of his time. Little Sabu stars in the Arabian Nights tale as a thief who teams up with genie Rex Ingram to confound grand vizier Conrad Veidt.

Manon Des Sources
(Claude Berri, 1986)
8pm, FilmFour

This picks up the story of Berri's masterly Jean De Florette, 10 years on. Manon (Emmanuelle Béart), daughter of the now dead Jean, is a beautiful shepherdess seeking revenge on Soubeyran (Yves Montand) and his nephew Ugolin (Daniel Auteuil) for appropriating her father's farm. She blocks the spring that supplies the village, and emotions and events well up, in a poignant conclusion to Berri's adaptation of Pagnol's novel, L'Eau Des Collines.

The Devil's Own
(Alan J Pakula, 1997)
9pm, 3am, Carlton Cinema

A Hollywood excursion into the troubles of Northern Ireland - don't expect too many insights. Harrison Ford is a humble Irish-American NY cop playing unwitting host to IRA man Brad Pitt, who's busy shipping missiles home. Pakula's made better thrillers, but the two stars play off well against each other in a tale of political imperative versus a simple sense of justice.

Armageddon
(Michael Bay, 1998)
9.30pm, Sky Premier

Doomsday scenario: an asteroid the size of Texas is headed for Earth. Send for top driller Bruce Willis and his bunch of loveable roughnecks to save the day. Among them is Steve Buscemi's standard weirdo, and Ben Affleck, a son-in-waiting, in love with Brucie's daughter, Liv Tyler. Awesome effects, all incredibly loud, presided over by Willis, playing it so straight he must be kidding. Mustn't he?

Who? Renowned ladies' man George came to fame playing the hunky Doctor Doug in ER; sadly, however, his initial transition from big to small screen was not as successful as he might have hoped. Basically, we're talking about Batman & Robin, for which he has since publicly apologised. But he's managed to escape his past by choosing roles in lower budget, but higher quality films - his pairing with Jennifer Lopez for Out Of Sight was one of those rare moments of real screen chemistry, and he was recently in Cannes to promote his latest effort, the highly anticipated new Coen brothers movie O Brother, Where Art Thou? At 39, George remains single, and shares his house with a pot-bellied pig, Max.

The role: Yep, a lip-synching transvestite. That's right, our George stars as the "entertainment" in a sleazy Mexican nitespot, visited by Charlie Pope (Miguel Ferrer) as he investigates an organs-for-sale operation. Clooney was convinced to take the role by Ferrer, who is also his cousin.

Best line: He doesn't have a line, but does have a nice pair of false breasts.

Cringe factor: Let's just recap: we've got George Clooney as a lip-synching transvestite, complete with blonde wig, mini-skirt and full make-up. So, not embarrassing at all, then...

Other wannabes: Leilani Sarelle, who stars as the femme fatale with whom Pope hooks up, went on to play Sharon Stone's lesbian lover, Roxy, in Basic Instinct. She's also related to Ferrer (being his wife).

Also not starring in: Return Of The Killer Tomatoes in 1988 and the TV movie Without Warning: Terror In The Towers in 1993.

 Harvest, Sky MovieMax, Friday June 2, 12.40pm.

fields.headline: Pills and thrills
fields.trailText: The Chemical Generation | The Dad's Army Story | Roman Polanski: Scene By Scene
fields.body:
Two great bank holiday traditions - raving and sitting in the garden with a warm sandwich - were celebrated at the weekend, The Chemical Generation (C4) and The Dad's Army Story (BBC1) covering bases admirably. It was a toss-up as to which group of pundits had told their stories more often.
In the first, Matthew Collin, dance music historian, was wheeled-out to sit behind a revolving turntable. His job was to tell us the only three interesting things about club culture: yes, ecstasy brought football hooliganism to an end (well, for a bit); promoters preached the summer of love whilst counting their Thatcherite booty. Oh, and have you heard the one about the doorman who holds a mirror to a punter and says: "Would you let yourself in?" (yes, for the thousandth time).
Strangely, the Chemical Generation interviewees now look indistinguishable from Wendy Craig and Victoria Wood on the Dad's Army doc. My, how we've all aged. Was it the drugs, do you think? Judge Jules looked like Cyril Fletcher from That's Life, even down to the embossed leather armchair and 15-minute anecdotes without a punchline. Ken Tappenden, approaching retirement back in 1988 as divisional commander of Kent's police, recalled how his detective powers stirred again like a bear after a long winter: "I noticed a large amount of traffic up and down the motorway," he recalled "and it never started till one in the morning, which was a most unusual time to have traffic on the motorways." Clouseau was onto something.
Kent had seen nothing like it since rush hour five hours previously. It was bumper- to-bumper ravers in their mums' Triumph Dolomites, all thinking the M25 was a gorgon-headed psychedelic river, having taken just one of them E things. "I felt ten-feet tall," someone said, rather unsurprisingly, "and I could see multicoloured things flying around, and I could hear people talking a hundred yards away, as if they were in me ears." Amazing.
Arnold Ridley, who played Godfrey in Dad's Army, experienced similar feelings after just one cup of tea. Sitting in a deckchair, smoking an expensive cigar, Arnold looked less the sweet First Aid chappie than Mr Big Stuff. A darker side to his personality emerged through the smoke. He would order his wife to "drive him to Thetford" to buy "booze" (was it?). They might have said custard creams. My heart sank at the prospect of yet another film about British sitcom's greatest creation, but The Dad's Army Story found life in the old dog still. "This is a fighting unit, not a girl guides outing," Mainwaring said to his platoon of wheezing old men. The truth, as Jimmy Perry revealed, was that most of them were as unfit as they looked. "They thought their careers were over, and suddenly they had a new lease of life." The film ended movingly with a shot of a country village war memorial, Mainwaring's Churchillian bluster gaining gravitas as he built: "Anyone who tries to take away our homes and our freedom, they'll find out what we can do. There are thousands like us all over England". "And Scotland," Fraser adds.
Roman Polanski: Scene By Scene (BBC2) was gripping stuff. Polanski and interviewer Mark Cousins were well-matched for their bout on the roof of the Musée D'Orsay, each trying to out-louche the other. Discussing the cut-glass beauty of Chinatown, Cousins asked him: "What does Chinatown symbolise?" Polanski sighed, took a long puff on a sumptuous cigar borrowed from Dad's Army's Godfrey. "Christ, you keep asking me questions I'm embarrassed to answer. It's like asking a poet to explain a metaphor. I don't do this." The match was squaring up to a replay of Peter Bogdanovitch interviewing John Huston in the desert. When Bogdanovitch asked Huston about the lost innocence of America, symobolised by The Searchers, Huston looked stony-faced into the camera and shouted: "Cut!" We saw a clip of Sharon Tate dancing. "Today's kind of girl," the cheesy news report said. After Tate's death, Polanski used his films to do his dreaming for him. Sex loomed large. There was Mia Farrow's rape in Rosemary's Baby, sex with a 13-year-old girl in The States, followed by the fictional rape of Tess in the dust of Normandy (standing in for Wessex). Was all this penetration, Cousins gulped, symbolic? Polanski dusted off his trousers. Was this what the PR meant by a plug for the new film?

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Secret Parts | Why People Hate Them
fields.body:
A brief but welcome return of the 90-minute radio drama for the bank holiday. David Edgar has adapted The Secret Parts (2.15pm, Radio 4), a crime novel by his late wife Eve Brook. Celia Imrie plays the crusading Labour councillor who finds one of her staff with his head bashed in. Her nastiest prejudices emerge when she also encounters her most right-wing opponent making an out-of-hours visit to the council buildings. Politics, romance and suspense intertwine.

Quite fortuitously, the play's plotline ties in nicely with the second instalment of Roger Childs' series Why People Hate (8.0pm, Radio 4). Boris Johnson, Spectator editor and a former Tory parliamentary candidate, tries to discover why the Conservative Party arouses such vehement hostility. Among those he turns to for enlightenment are Tory defector Emma Nicholson, Billy Bragg and Neil Hamilton's nemesis, Martin Bell.

fields.headline: Effing good show
fields.standfirst: Tonight, a Channel 4 documentary examines the history of the most famous swearword of them all.  Mark Lawson  discovers a valuable lesson about modern Britain in among the expletives undeleted
fields.trailText: Tonight, a Channel 4 documentary examines the history of the most famous swearword of them all. Mark Lawson discovers a valuable lesson about modern Britain in among the expletives undeleted.
fields.body:
Once - about a fortnight after the transmission of a Radio 4 programme - the producer and I received a memo from the BBC's complaints department. An elderly female listener had been appalled at the use of what we will for the moment call the copulatory gerund at just after 9am in the morning. Could we please explain why the word had been transmitted, and, furthermore, transmitted without an apology from the presenter?

We listened to the tape twice, but didn't hear the word that was being complained about. Finally, tipped off by the correspondence unit that the foul-mouthed contributor was a woman, we concentrated on the female speakers. Eventually we found a reference - in an anecdote from a distinguished female journalist about attending the Henley Regatta - to something which had occurred while she was "forking my smoked salmon". Curiously, the listener had been less shocked by the mental image of a Fleet Street grande dame having sex with cured fish at Henley than by the use of a word she still considered taboo.

But the story shows that some consumers of broadcasting are just sitting there wanting to be offended. Such people are going to have a huge bank holiday phone bill from ringing the duty office to complain about A Brief History Of The F-Word (tonight, 10.50pm, Channel 4). This is a brave programme to be showing at a time when the Mail On Sunday is running a campaign against swearing on television.

Produced by David Jeffcock - whose interest in forbidden words may in part result from schoolyard teasing about his surname - the documentary manages, unlike other recent offerings on shocking subjects on Channel 4 and elsewhere, to educate as well as titillate. The lexicographer John Ayto reveals that, despite its most popular euphemism, the word has no Anglo-Saxon roots. And while some of the stories are familiar - the use by Peregrine Worsthorne, Kenneth Tynan and the Sex Pistols of the F-word on TV - there is also much fresher material, such as the account of how a pranking printer inserted the verb in a Times article in 1882. You get a genuine social history through the consideration of the gradual unstiffening of British lips.

Nothing screws up a documentary of this kind more quickly than skimpy film research. But the archive used here is distinctive and illuminating. In black-and-white footage, decorously excited 60s readers queue to buy the newly legalised Lady Chatterley's Lover and discover what Mellors and Lady C called what they did to each other. "One copy only," instructs a stern saleswoman as men grab one for each hand. "I shall shortly be doing a course on the modern novel at university," insists one young man, to justify his purchase. Later, there's a cleverly uncovered clip from a Wendy Craig domestic sitcom in which the dizzy mum has heard her son use "the word" which she never specifies.

Even the sequence which has recently become obligatory in shocker documentaries - the one where young women sit around talking about their sex lives - is here relevant because they are discussing the fascinating and apposite question of in which circumstances lovers can use the word to each other.

The word itself is spoken without apology or disguise at least a hundred times in clips or commentary. But, where many controversial documentaries become juvenile, this is a wholly grown-up show. And a brave one, because many in middle England will be put off their stroke if they're sitting there forking their salmon.

Many BBC executives were surprised when Michael Jackson - who had been scheduling both BBC television channels - left the Corporation to become chief executive at the single-network Channel 4. But there are some kinds of programmes which are only possible beyond White City.

A BBC2 controller who transmitted a detailed documentary about the copulatory oath would soon have the chair of the governors roaring F-words down the phone and the editor of the Daily Mail demanding their resignation. Born before swearing was acceptable, the BBC has never found it easy to catch up with the language.

There are signs, however, that Jackson's successor at BBC2 - Jane Root - is, in a quieter way, testing the barriers of profanity. Foot In The Door (Thursday, 9pm, BBC2) - a sort of business version of Blind Date in which three applicants for a job are followed by the cameras - begins with chef Charlie Rushton looking for an under-cook. Modern celebrated restaurateurs seem, for some reason, to possess tongues which could burn caramel, and remarkably all of Rushton's swearing goes unbleeped.

Perhaps surprisingly, the show which precedes the history of the F-word - Madonna's boyfriend's movie spin-off drama Lock, Stock (Tonight, 9pm, Channel 4) - makes relatively little use of the linguistic licence which the network possesses. Perhaps - like the activity it describes - using the F-word is most exciting when forbidden.

Making a drama for a channel where anything at all could be said, and the producers just couldn't be fucked.

fields.headline: Take it away
fields.trailText: Television remains the only major art-form which people are encouraged to feel guilty about enjoying. Newspapers spasmodically challenge a family of their readers to go without it, and now - rather like tobacco companies sponsoring research into lung cancer - the medium itself issues the challenge.
fields.body:
Television remains the only major art-form which people are encouraged to feel guilty about enjoying. Newspapers spasmodically challenge a family of their readers to go without it, and now - rather like tobacco companies sponsoring research into lung cancer - the medium itself issues the challenge in Can You Live Without... Television? (Tuesday, 8.30pm, Channel 4), the first of a new series that boasts the basic concept of turning Lent into a gameshow.

The Kenny family from Liverpool must survive for three weeks without any of their entertainment systems. Admittedly, the fact that TV is the only part of art regarded as disposable follows, paradoxically, from being the only area of culture to have become apparently indispensable to the public. You couldn't make a show called Can You Live Without... Poetry? - to most of Britain it would be a rhetorical question. Television's power is the weakness that snobs exploit.

This is, though, a notably odd programme, because the attempt by the Kennys to live without television is being witnessed by television cameras - an anomaly that gives the proceedings the feel of a philosophy exam. Those being counselled for addiction are routinely advised not to replace one dependency with another. How self-denying is a TV-obsessed family being if their struggle will result in a video of their own appearance on the cherished medium?

This ambiguity is at its strongest in what the producers clearly regard as the stand-out scene. The family matriarch - filmed visiting her mother who suffers from Alzheimer's - describes her trip directly to camera on her return. Commenting on her mother's mental absence, she weeps and pleads "I want my mum back", before - in a gesture now indelibly associated with confessional TV shows - waving the camera away. Her assumption that this emotional disclosure belongs on TV - and the way in which her body language copies the medium's previous weepers - instantly answers in the negative the programme's title. It's a bit like someone checking into rehab while carrying a hip flask.

fields.headline: An assassin in Leo's family
fields.trailText: This is the biggest story of its kind since the sensational discovery (true, really) that Gwynneth Paltrow was related to the late Lord Chief Justice, Lord Taylor. It turns out that young Leo, on his mother's side, is related to the well-known assassin John Wilkes Booth, whose assassinee, Abraham Lincoln, was of course a lawyer.
fields.body:
This is the biggest story of its kind since the sensational discovery (true, really) that Gwynneth Paltrow was related to the late Lord Chief Justice, Lord Taylor. It turns out that young Leo, on his mother's side, is related - I promise this is fact - to the well-known assassin John Wilkes Booth, whose assassinee, Abraham Lincoln, was of course a lawyer. I am not sure how, scientifically, legal blood can flow down the generations by way of a homicide victim, but it can be no accident that Cherie took up the calling of a man killed by one of her distant relatives. There is a more direct, though more boring, link: Cherie's direct ascendant six generations back was Richard Booth, described as a lawyer. Leo's father, by contrast, need look only one generation back to find his legal genes, to his own father, a barrister and law lecturer. I understand that none of Tony's relatives murdered any presidents whatsoever.

It is instructive and pleasurable, though puzzling, to study the regular reports of the disciplinary proceedings taken against barristers for professional misconduct, or at least lapses. Take the stuff I read last week. One woman barrister was disciplined for shouting at and insulting another woman by calling her a cow, in the Enfield Family Proceedings Court, no less. She and another woman barrister were also reprimanded for distracting the proceedings by the "frequency" of the objections they raised during a case. They must have seen too many American movies, since it is not the English habit to jump up and down shrieking "objection".

I suspect the reason why barristers go in for slanging and shouting is that it's their only outlet for rebellious emotions. Solicitors, on the other hand, have clients' monies to fiddle with and misuse; that's their most frequent category of professional misconduct. Or it may be the other way around. People with a penchant for shouting and insulting tend to go to the Bar; those inclined to defrauding their clients prefer to become solicitors.

I would not go quite so far as to claim that there are no discernible differences between university law faculties and football clubs, but in one respect there's a startling resemblance. They both spend a lot of time - I wouldn't dream of using the term poaching - persuading the top practitioners of their art to leave one outfit and join another. And none is more adept at this persuasion than University College London, the Manchester United of the academic legal world. They've just landed a big one, a veritable Beckham. He's not, perhaps, as widely known in the outside world, but Basil Markesinis is a name to be reckoned with. He founded and heads the deeply respected Institute for European and comparative law at Oxford; and he's sensationally transferring to UCL to start a centre for global law, global being a bigger deal than mere European, and exceeded only by galactic. I do not, alas, know details of his transfer fee.

The other week I was complaining that children under 14 weren't allowed into court. It seems that under a law passed last year while I wasn't looking, children of 13 and younger may be allowed to sit in court, but only if the judge gives permission. I find it deeply shocking that the government had reformed the law behind my back even before I'd urged them to do so.

My constant quest for links between law and horseracing (usually manifested in profitable investments on fleet-hoofed horses with legal names) has taken a strange turn. I find myself in the world of fund managers and defamation. It started with an advert published by asset managers Johnson Fry, trying to persuade investors to buy their ISAs. The picture on the ad showed the finish of a race, with a horse labelled Johnson Fry coming in first, and one called Jupiter a far-away third. "Why get your ISA from an also-ran?" the legend read. This was too much for Jupiter Unit Trust Managers. The ad, it claimed, suggested that Jupiter was a bad and inefficient company in which investors would be foolish to invest. This, it claimed, was highly defamatory of its trading reputation. Not so, said the judge. There was no libel. Quite right. A judicious each-way bet can bring in a lot of money when placed on horses who finish third, though I expect the judge had a more legal reason for his decision.

There is a more direct, though more boring, link: Cherie's direct ascendant six generations back was Richard Booth, described as a lawyer. Leo's father, by contrast, need look only one generation back to find his legal genes, to his own father, a barrister and law lecturer. I understand that none of Tony's relatives murdered any presidents whatsoever. It is instructive and pleasurable, though puzzling, to study the regular reports of the disciplinary proceedings taken against barristers for professional misconduct, or at least lapses. Take the stuff I read last week. One woman barrister was disciplined for shouting at and insulting another woman by calling her a cow, in the Enfield Family Proceedings Court, no less. She and another woman barrister were also reprimanded for distracting the proceedings by the "frequency" of the objections they raised during a case. They must have seen too many American movies, since it is not the English habit to jump up and down shrieking "objection". I suspect the reason why barristers go in for slanging and shouting is that it's their only outlet for rebellious emotions. Solicitors, on the other hand, have clients' monies to fiddle with and misuse; that's their most frequent category of professional misconduct. Or it may be the other way around. People with a penchant for shouting and insulting tend to go to the Bar; those inclined to defrauding their clients prefer to become solicitors. I would not go quite so far as to claim that there are no discernible differences between university law faculties and football clubs, but in one respect there's a startling resemblance. They both spend a lot of time - I wouldn't dream of using the term poaching - persuading the top practitioners of their art to leave one outfit and join another. And none is more adept at this persuasion than University College London, the Manchester United of the academic legal world. They've just landed a big one, a veritable Beckham. He's not, perhaps, as widely known in the outside world, but Basil Markesinis is a name to be reckoned with. He founded and heads the deeply respected Institute for European and comparative law at Oxford; and he's sensationally transferring to UCL to start a centre for global law, global being a bigger deal than mere European, and exceeded only by galactic. I do not, alas, know details of his transfer fee. The other week I was complaining that children under 14 weren't allowed into court. It seems that under a law passed last year while I wasn't looking, children of 13 and younger may be allowed to sit in court, but only if the judge gives permission. I find it deeply shocking that the government had reformed the law behind my back even before I'd urged them to do so. My constant quest for links between law and horseracing (usually manifested in profitable investments on fleet-hoofed horses with legal names) has taken a strange turn. I find myself in the world of fund managers and defamation. It started with an advert published by asset managers Johnson Fry, trying to persuade investors to buy their ISAs. The picture on the ad showed the finish of a race, with a horse labelled Johnson Fry coming in first, and one called Jupiter a far-away third. "Why get your ISA from an also-ran?" the legend read. This was too much for Jupiter Unit Trust Managers. The ad, it claimed, suggested that Jupiter was a bad and inefficient company in which investors would be foolish to invest. This, it claimed, was highly defamatory of its trading reputation. Not so, said the judge. There was no libel. Quite right. A judicious each-way bet can bring in a lot of money when placed on horses who finish third, though I expect the judge had a more legal reason for his decision.

fields.headline: Europe defends a free press
fields.trailText: Case of the week
fields.body:
The editor awoke, a beatific smile on his face. He'd dreamed that his newspaper lost a libel action and had to pay out big bucks in damages and costs. But then he'd taken the case to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, claiming it was all a breach of the right to free speech and the court agreed. What's more, the Strasbourg judges had ordered the government to reimburse the paper all the costs and damages it had paid out in the libel claim, because the state's courts had violated its freedom of expression in ruling against it.

He pinched himself and the smile faded. Of course it must have been just a dream. But wait. He switched on his computer and called up the European Court's website (www.echr.coe.fr). And there it was in black and white. It was an editor's dream all right, but it was a reality. True, it happened in Norway, but the Strasbourg court holds sway in Britain too. Our newspapers and journalists have the same right to freedom of expression. And once the Human Rights Act comes into force in October, our judges will have to take account of the case law from Strasbourg in deciding cases in our courts.

The Norwegian newspaper Bergens Tidende published the accounts of several women who had been operated on by a Bergen plastic surgeon they claimed had left them scarred and mutilated. As a result of the articles, the surgeon was driven out of practice. He sued for defamation, winning in the city court, losing on appeal to the High Court, and then winning again on a final appeal to the Supreme Court. The Strasbourg court held that the outcome of the case had infringed the rights of the paper, its former editor-in-chief and a journalist under article 10, which guarantees the right to freedom of expression. The paper's account had been essentially correct, dealt with a matter of public interest, and showed proper, balanced reporting.

The Norwegian government was ordered to pay £365,000, the damages and costs it had to pay to the surgeon. The ruling is "highly significant" for newspapers, says the human rights law expert Lord Lester QC. "It means that provided newspapers have acted ethically in accordance with their code and in good faith, even if they make mistakes, there is a wide latitude."

webTitle: Time for Labour to get tough

fields.headline: Time for Labour to get tough
fields.standfirst: A victory over the NHS for Pamela Enderby and colleagues doesn't mean the equal pay battle is over.  Clare Dyer looks to government to make the law work
fields.trailText: A victory over the NHS for Pamela Enderby and colleagues doesn't mean the equal pay battle is over.  Clare Dyer looks to government to make the law work.
fields.body:
It took 14 years, but this month 351 NHS speech therapists lifted their profession's glass ceiling, in a deal which will cost the NHS £12 million. An extended career ladder will reward those who reach the top with pay rates £12,000-15,000 higher than was possible under the old structure - putting the profession, whose recruits are mainly women, on a par with clinical psychologists and pharmacists, jobs which draw larger numbers of men.

But Pamela Enderby, who launched a test case in 1986, credits the victory not to Britain's equal pay laws, but to a change in the party in power. Despite a win for women in the European Court of Justice in 1994, the case dragged on, the Tories unwilling to come up with a settlement. "It wouldn't need equal pay laws if the culture and politics espoused the cause of equality," she maintains.

Labour makes the right noises - last week Gordon Brown pledged to speed up and simplify the workings of employment tribunals - but so far has not done much to redress the pay imbalance. Enderby, her progress barred by the glass ceiling but ambitious to rise higher, lost patience long before the changeover at number 10. She eventually left clinical practice for academe and is now professor of rehabilitation at Sheffield University, though universities themselves are not exempt from pay apartheid: a recent survey found women academics earning £8,000 a year less than men doing the same jobs in the same subjects.

The Equal Pay Act 1970, which the Labour government of the day hoped would close the chasm between men and women, is 30 years old today. Yet the gap, described by Cherie Booth as "a significant and widespread case of discrimination against women in the workplace", stubbornly persists. Research by the government's women's unit found that a "mid-skilled" woman worker without children earned £240,000 less over her lifetime than her male equivalent - the so-called "female forfeit". If she had two children, the shortfall rose to £380,000.

The act got off to a slow start, its implementation delayed five years till the end of 1975, to allow employers time to alter their pay structures voluntarily. By 1977 women's pay aver aged 75% of men's. Today, 23 years later, the gap has hardly narrowed: the average hourly rate for women working full-time is still only 80% of the average man's. Yet in that time a workplace revolution has seen women flooding into job areas previously reserved mainly for men - such as the law, where women now account for more than half the new entrants.

The slight narrowing of the earnings gap could be accounted for simply by this movement and the growing numbers of mothers who work through their children's early years. It may be that the equal pay laws have achieved little or nothing. Alan Lakin, legal adviser at the Equal Opportunities Commission believes the law has provided redress for individual women but has done nothing to address the earnings gap. "What the legislation doesn't do is provide a solution to the pay gap. If we're concerned about that we have to look elsewhere."

The Equal Pay Act was not long in force before its shortcomings became obvious. To claim equal pay a woman had to find a male co-worker doing the same or broadly similar work for higher pay. But most women were stuck in single-sex jobs and in 1982 only 39 women brought claims under the act. That year the European Commission took enforcement proceedings against the UK government, claiming its equal pay laws failed to comply with the European directive requiring EC states to bring in effective laws to remove the pay gap.

The government was forced to bring in new "equal pay for work of equal value" rules, allowing women to claim the same pay as male co-workers holding down jobs that were different but equal in terms of skill, training, physical and mental effort, and decision-making. But that law was so complex that cases take years to reach a successful conclusion. Lord Denning said in the House of Lords: "Its tortuosity and complexity are beyond compare."

Trade unions brought cases and won significant victories, especially for women in low-paid jobs, including cooks, school dinner-ladies, warehouse workers and sewing machinists. Teresa Higgins, a dinner lady in Cleveland, helped recruit 1800 women into a union. They won £5m in compensation. "One of the most magical things to come out of it was that the women got pride back in their work," she says.

But as a tool for narrowing the gender gap the law has had limited success. Only 372 equal-value claims - some on behalf of large groups of women - were lodged between 1985 and June 1997. Of those, 44 were upheld by tribunals and 72 rejected, with the rest settled, withdrawn or still pending. The Trades Union Congress and the EOC, the two bodies which have made most of the running on equal pay, want the law changed.

The TUC contends that employers should be put under a legal duty to adopt equal pay policies, and public authorities should be required to enforce compliance as part of any deal with contractors. Women should be able to compare their pay with those of men outside their own workforce, they argue. Ultimately, however, the law will go only so far.

Even in the US, land of affirmative action, the gender gap is stubbornly persistent, despite an Equal Pay Act which has been on the statute book since 1963, when "women made 64 cents to a man's dollar - now we make 73 cents", notes the National Committee on Pay Equity, a US campaigning group

The EOC has set up an employer-led equal pay task force, which has been meeting around the country to identify what steps need to be taken. Bob Mason of BT, task force chair, says: "Every employer has a responsibility to act on this issue, and an important step would be to conduct a thorough audit of their pay system. Only then will they be able to set about eliminating the gap."

One of the law's weaknesses is the lack of provision for group claims, the EOC believes. Although typically a whole group suffers from pay discrimination - such as the speech therapists and dinner ladies - each claim is an individual case.

EOC chair Julie Mellor argues: "There should be an effective method for group claims, and tribunals need the powers to make general findings and recommendations, rather than only considering each individual's case. This is an issue about which everyone needs to develop a sense of urgency. If the government does decide legal changes are needed as a result of their review we will be urging them to introduce those changes in the next session."

She points out that there is currently no obligation for employers to monitor their own pay system, and adds, "If they do not begin to do so on a voluntary basis, and soon, then we believe the government should make pay audits mandatory. If it really wants to show leadership on this issue, then the best start would be a standard for all government suppliers to demonstrate they provide equal pay. Taxpayers' money should not be going to support businesses that systematically discriminate against women."

webTitle: His name is Francisco Toledo, but everyone calls him El Maestro

fields.headline: His name is Francisco Toledo, but everyone calls him El Maestro
fields.standfirst: Christopher Goodwin meets the great Mexican artist
fields.trailText: Christopher Goodwin meets the great Mexican artist.
fields.body:
Francisco Toledo has an almost pathological aversion to being photographed or interviewed, particularly by those with whom he is not familiar. It is an instinctive, perhaps a primitive fear, of being captured, defined, in someone else's notion of him.

But that is just a fragment of the man. Those who know him best say he is a creature of unfathomable complexity. Physically and intellectually elusive, he is also immediate and accessible, surely the most accessible artist of his stature in the world. And as the retrospective of his work at London's Whitechapel Gallery shows, Toledo is one of the great artists of our times. If he is little known outside Latin America, it is only because he courts anonymity, not celebrity.

Most mornings Toledo can be found on the quiet, shaded patio of the Instituto de Artes Graficas, a burnt-red adobe building across the square from Santo Domingo, the magnificent 16th-century Dominican church in the southern Mexican city of Oaxaca. Toledo's presence can be felt throughout the city, thanks to his patronage of a multitude of artistic and environmental organisations. He founded the centre in 1988 by donating the large colonial building in which it is housed, together with the core of its collection of more than 7,000 prints and 25,000 books.

It is easy to miss Toledo. He is the darting figure in white cotton peasant clothes and dusty brown sandals. His hair is thick and distracted, and at the age of 60 his handsome face is as heavily etched as much of his art. His eyes are so fierce that they linger on you only sparingly, as if out of politeness; a moment longer and they would disturb the secrets of your soul. But then he smiles.

Toledo always seems to appear out of nowhere, as if by magic. His presence is a mirage, fleeting, evanescent. Turn around and he is gone. Yet, at the same time, he inhabits the most tangible physical space of anyone I have ever met. Toledo, a friend says, is a man who fosters "variable truths and contradictions". You might tag him as shy and modest, but look at the photographs he has taken recently - his erect penis and testicles thrusting through the mottled skin of an iguana that he has draped over his naked body.

Toledo's is the art of shamanism, in which people are transformed into beasts and animals may take on human characteristics. It is the art of the nagual , in which an animal is identified with a human, their fates intertwined. And it is the art of primal eroticism, in which an army of toads with human penises ejaculate in a joyous frenzy. "Subjects emerge from one another," wrote Veronica Volkow, a Mexican poet who has known the artist for many years. "A deer from a lion, an iguana from a woman, a cricket from the mouth of a toad. A chain joins all beings in the meshing of the gears of their devourings, their copulations, their mirrors, their metamophoses. The entire universe seems to be joined unto itself, emerging from and terminating in a circle that may begin from any mouth, any sex, any eye, any orifice, any touching."

In Oaxaca people approach Toledo every day, with the deference reserved for the man universally known as "El Maestro". He is a towering presence in the civic life of the city, its most valued and significant citizen, a "Promethean figure", the New York Times called him, but his sense of civic responsibility is also a heavy burden, too heavy say some.

Oaxaca (pronounced Wah-ha-ca) is the capital of the state of the same name, a city of some 300,000 people about 350 miles south-east of Mexico City. The state is one of the most beautiful but also most impoverished in the country, stretching from the cool, dense pine forests of the north to the thick, humid, mosquito-infested swamps along the Pacific coast.

Oaxaca sits at just over 5,000ft, in a high valley dominated by the ancient site of Monte Alban, a huge, ruined temple complex and ceremonial city first settled by the Zapotecs around 600 BC. Of the state's more than 3m inhabitants, around a third, made up of at least 14 Indian peoples, speak no Spanish.

Toledo is a Zapotec, born into a poor family in a small village just outside Juchitan on the hot Pacific coast. His grandfather was a cobbler, his grandmother's family were pig-slaughterers. When he was a child his father moved to a small town near the port and oil refining centre of Veracruz, where he became a successful shopkeeper.

Toledo remembers a childhood roaming "the rivers and mountains", where he was first exposed to the teeming animal and insect life that later populated his art. He remembers armies of toads invading the house, thick clouds of bats, crabs, iguanas, grasshoppers, scorpions and crocodiles - creatures that had sacred meaning to the Indian peoples and are still the repository of potent myths. Toledo's aunt would tell him about such fabulous creatures as the four-eyed fish - two eyes to see the world above the water, two to see below - and the milkmaid snake, which could quiet babies' cries by stuffing its tail into their mouths.

Toledo started drawing and painting early and was sent to Oaxaca to study when he was 12. There the library offered him his first exposure to modern painting, photography and the world beyond Mexico. He pored over the work of artists that would later inspire his own painting: Goya, Blake, Picasso, Hogarth, Klee and Tamayo, a fellow Zapotec and the pre-eminent figure in Mexican art. "I didn't know it was possible to be a painter until I came here," Toledo says.

When he was 17 he moved to Mexico City to study lithography, etching and engraving at the Instituto Nacional de Bellas Artes. He was soon noticed by a prominent dealer and had his first exhibitions at the age of 19, in Mexico City and Fort Worth, Texas. With the money he made, Toledo moved to Paris. It was a difficult but valuable time: he was poor, painfully shy and lonely, but also very productive. He worked almost continuously under the dark stairway of the university dormitory in which he lived. Tamayo and the Nobel prize-winning Mexican writer Octavio Paz, who were living in Paris, took him under their wings. "It was wonderful," says Toledo. "Tamayo invited me to his house and he started to sell my paintings. When the collectors would come to visit him, he'd say, 'Here is a young painter whose paintings are much cheaper than you can buy mine for'."

He was taken up by two prominent dealers who got him shows all over Europe, then moved back to Mexico in 1965, desperate to reconnect with his roots. "I wanted to have a family from Juchitan," he recalls. "I wanted them to speak Zapoteco like my family." He moved back to Juchitan and married a Zapotec woman, with whom he had a child.

But almost as soon as he returned, he began to miss Europe and the sophisticated life he had tasted there. Over the next two decades his restlessness became a kind of rootlessness, as he moved back and forwards between Paris and Mexico, between New York and Oaxaca. He divorced and in 1969 married a prominent Mexican poet and sociologist, with whom he had two children.

He became mythologised as a kind of artistic vagabond, a man who had no home and no possessions other than what he needed to work with. He has always been astonishingly prolific, working on the ground, almost spontaneously, his fingers nimble, darting, fierce; he is as likely to work with tortoise shells or ostrich eggs as canvas or paper.

In the past 10 years Toledo has done little painting, although he continues to work as a printmaker and has begun spending more time on his photographs. He has undertaken a couple of major commissions, one for the Mexican presidency, the proceeds of which, and all his other art, he has used for his artistic endeavours in Oaxaca.

His personal needs are slight. He lives with his third wife, Trine Ellitsgaard, a Danish weaver with whom he has two young children, in almost extreme austerity and simplicity.

The critic Andre Pieyre de Mandiargues summed up Toledo's extraordinary world in 1964. "I know of no modern artist who is so pervaded, and so naturally, by a sacred sense of life, none who is bound to myth and magic with such seriousness and such simplicity; none who is so purely inspired by rite and fable."

 At the Whitechapel Gallery, London E1 (020-7522 7888) till June 7.

The state is one of the most beautiful but also most impoverished in the country, stretching from the cool, dense pine forests of the north to the thick, humid, mosquito-infested swamps along the Pacific coast. Oaxaca sits at just over 5,000ft, in a high valley dominated by the ancient site of Monte Alban, a huge, ruined temple complex and ceremonial city first settled by the Zapotecs around 600 BC. Of the state's more than 3m inhabitants, around a third, made up of at least 14 Indian peoples, speak no Spanish. Toledo is a Zapotec, born into a poor family in a small village just outside Juchitan on the hot Pacific coast. His grandfather was a cobbler, his grandmother's family were pig-slaughterers. When he was a child his father moved to a small town near the port and oil refining centre of Veracruz, where he became a successful shopkeeper. Toledo remembers a childhood roaming "the rivers and mountains", where he was first exposed to the teeming animal and insect life that later populated his art. He remembers armies of toads invading the house, thick clouds of bats, crabs, iguanas, grasshoppers, scorpions and crocodiles - creatures that had sacred meaning to the Indian peoples and are still the repository of potent myths. Toledo's aunt would tell him about such fabulous creatures as the four-eyed fish - two eyes to see the world above the water, two to see below - and the milkmaid snake, which could quiet babies' cries by stuffing its tail into their mouths. Toledo started drawing and painting early and was sent to Oaxaca to study when he was 12. There the library offered him his first exposure to modern painting, photography and the world beyond Mexico. He pored over the work of artists that would later inspire his own painting: Goya, Blake, Picasso, Hogarth, Klee and Tamayo, a fellow Zapotec and the pre-eminent figure in Mexican art. "I didn't know it was possible to be a painter until I came here," Toledo says. When he was 17 he moved to Mexico City to study lithography, etching and engraving at the Instituto Nacional de Bellas Artes. He was soon noticed by a prominent dealer and had his first exhibitions at the age of 19, in Mexico City and Fort Worth, Texas. With the money he made, Toledo moved to Paris. It was a difficult but valuable time: he was poor, painfully shy and lonely, but also very productive. He worked almost continuously under the dark stairway of the university dormitory in which he lived. Tamayo and the Nobel prize-winning Mexican writer Octavio Paz, who were living in Paris, took him under their wings. "It was wonderful," says Toledo. "Tamayo invited me to his house and he started to sell my paintings. When the collectors would come to visit him, he'd say, 'Here is a young painter whose paintings are much cheaper than you can buy mine for'." He was taken up by two prominent dealers who got him shows all over Europe, then moved back to Mexico in 1965, desperate to reconnect with his roots. "I wanted to have a family from Juchitan," he recalls. "I wanted them to speak Zapoteco like my family." He moved back to Juchitan and married a Zapotec woman, with whom he had a child. But almost as soon as he returned, he began to miss Europe and the sophisticated life he had tasted there. Over the next two decades his restlessness became a kind of rootlessness, as he moved back and forwards between Paris and Mexico, between New York and Oaxaca. He divorced and in 1969 married a prominent Mexican poet and sociologist, with whom he had two children. He became mythologised as a kind of artistic vagabond, a man who had no home and no possessions other than what he needed to work with. He has always been astonishingly prolific, working on the ground, almost spontaneously, his fingers nimble, darting, fierce; he is as likely to work with tortoise shells or ostrich eggs as canvas or paper. In the past 10 years Toledo has done little painting, although he continues to work as a printmaker and has begun spending more time on his photographs. He has undertaken a couple of major commissions, one for the Mexican presidency, the proceeds of which, and all his other art, he has used for his artistic endeavours in Oaxaca. His personal needs are slight. He lives with his third wife, Trine Ellitsgaard, a Danish weaver with whom he has two young children, in almost extreme austerity and simplicity. The critic Andre Pieyre de Mandiargues summed up Toledo's extraordinary world in 1964. "I know of no modern artist who is so pervaded, and so naturally, by a sacred sense of life, none who is bound to myth and magic with such seriousness and such simplicity; none who is so purely inspired by rite and fable."  At the Whitechapel Gallery, London E1 (020-7522 7888) till June 7.

fields.headline: Giving up the ghosts
fields.standfirst: Dulwich Picture Gallery looks smarter than it has for centuries - right down to its en-suite mausoleum. But is that a good thing, asks  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: Dulwich Picture Gallery looks smarter than it has for centuries - right down to its en-suite mausoleum. But is that a good thing?
fields.body:
What an extraordinary place Dulwich Village is. Surrounded on all sides by some of the poorest, roughest, toughest London quarters, a world of intersecting railway arches, scrapyards, estates by the concrete-mixer load, bumper-to-bumper traffic and trains with scratch-tagged windows, it is a leafy, middle-class idyll, all ladies with discreetly loud voices talking about how well Johnny is doing at private school, men in Vyella shirts murdering lawns, gleaming estate cars and no, definitely no, McDonald's. If I lived here I would feel like Patrick McGoohan in The Prisoner, trapped in a pretty-pretty village from which there is no escape, even though the number 12 to Piccadilly Circus passes close by.

The one oddly macabre note struck in this sylvan London village has, for the best part of 200 years, been Dulwich Picture Gallery and its slightly sinister mausoleum devoted to its founders, Noel Desenfans (1745-1807) and Francis Bourgeois (1756-1811). Mrs Desenfans lies here too. One of the four Neo-Classical sarcophagi in this Regency stage-set tomb was reserved for the gallery's architect, Sir John Soane (1757-1837). Perhaps even Sir John felt that the mausoleum he had created was disturbingly claustrophobic; he opted to be buried in old St Pancras churchyard, his bones rattled today in his crumbling tomb by the twin-turbo diesels that throb north from William Barlow's Victorian trainshed.

The idea of combining a Graeco-Egyptian Regency mausoleum with an art gallery was a curious one in Soane's day. One could argue, though, that a picture gallery devoted largely to portraiture is a memento mori of sorts - all those long dead, long-faced English aristocrats peering at visitors through layers of varnished oils, Dutch burghers, foxy Italian models posing as saints, vulpine Hispanic grandees - and that this macabre building is actually rather sane.

It certainly seems sane now that the Queen has been to open the revamp and extension of this, one of Britain's best loved art galleries. Closed for an £8.3m rebuild - courtesy of the Heritage Lottery Fund and private donors - in January 1999, the Picture Gallery reopened this weekend. No one coming here will doubt that the money has been well spent. Soane's building has been lovingly reconstructed, intelligently rehung and walled on three sides by a brand new glass cloister designed by Rick Mather, master-planner of the South Bank Centre and an architect with a grace and lightness of touch that has made him a natural when it comes to extending old museums. Mather's cloister offers a gentle, beautifully lit walk around the borders of the gallery's old walled garden. Shafts of sunlight slice through the low white ceilings, lit subtly at night.

The cloister faces a three-quarter quadrangle of rooms the Picture Gallery's director Giles Waterfield has long wanted. These include a bright and airy 60-seater cafe whose walls slide back on sunny days; a lecture-theatre that doubles up as a gallery, with a clever update of a classic Soane pendentive vault above the audience's and speaker's heads; a classroom; conservation workshop and new lavatories. From the leafy street, these rooms are concealed by a red brick, ever-so-English garden wall. Although the gallery wanted these new spaces, they had to be as discreet as possible so as not to detract from nor upstage Soane's much loved architectural sonnet.

But, what the immaculate and sensitive new work has done is somehow to sanitise Britain's oldest public picture gallery. A part of its magic lay in it being hidden away in curious Dulwich and not visited in the kind of numbers expected of museums and galleries at the beginning of the 21st century. The idea of the offbeat, eccentric space that visitors chance upon happily or go to because they can have it virtually to themselves is frowned upon today by government, local authorities and even curators. Whether every museum or gallery benefits from the high numbers game or not, they are required to pack 'em in.

Dulwich used to be quiet for a fair bit of the week - enjoyably so for those who came to escape the crowds of central London, who came to enjoy Soane's idiosyncratic buildings, its odd setting and its wonderful collection of grand old portraits.

Some of the ghostly magic of the picture gallery has been exorcised. It was, until Giles Waterfield arrived in the 80s, woefully shabby. Walls that are now a pale Soanian terracotta were civil service gray. The floors were covered in squeaky cork tiles, space for hanging pictures was occupied by clanking lavs, the mausoleum was menacingly funereal. Electric lighting was harsh as only fluorescence can be, the display of books and postcards in the entrance hall meagre. I thought it then, along with the Soane Museum in Lincoln Inn's Fields, one of London's best kept secrets.

It isn't shabby now. The floor is of brand new oak boards. Soane's skylights - wooden lanterns bringing daylight down to the paintings - have been renewed. New electric lighting washes the walls of the gallery in a semblance of sunlight. The old lavatories have been flushed away. The collection - Rembrandt, Van Dyck, Claude, Rubens, Cuyp, Poussin, Watteau, Gainsborough - has been elegantly rearranged with, in Waterfield's words, the "beer drinkers" (Brits, Dutch) on one side of the entrance hall-mausoleum axis, and "wine drinkers" (French, Italian, Spanish) on the other. The glass in the mausoleum has been cleaned so it is less spooky than it was before.

These works have been carried out meticulously, but in shining an arc-light into the romantic gloom of the gallery, curator and architect have blasted away the ghost of Soane - and of Ruskin, who strolled here from Herne Hill to look at the pictures. Small wonder a pin-up Italian St John the Baptist looks so shocked, caught all but naked in his gilded frame. In a strange way, all this fresh paint and wood and light makes the gallery look a little too close in texture and spirit to Robert Venturi's Sainsbury Wing of the late 80s at the National Gallery. Venturi adopted the look and the form of his top-lit galleries from Dulwich. The two blur into one another in the mind's eye.

It's a tricky job, revamping galleries. Dulwich Picture Gallery needed more care and attention than Waterfield and his finances could stretch to before the advent of the lottery. Many things have been added to make the gallery work as a better local art centre and visitor attraction. But something of its magic has gone. The selfish pleasure of idling through the gallery in the gloom, the same pleasure one took in the least visited of the churches of Venice with their secret Tintorettos, the pleasure one takes in country churches visited by vicars once a month, is fast dying. Perhaps it should. But perhaps the new look Dulwich Picture Gallery will age gracefully too. In any case, its special collection of paintings remains a must, as does the curious nature of Dulwich Village itself.

 Dulwich Picture Gallery is in College Road, London SE21. The opening times are Tuesday-Friday 10am-5pm, weekends and bank holidays, 11am-5pm. Details: 020-8693 5254.

fields.headline: Army tests women for frontline
fields.trailText: Women soldiers are to train for combat roles in the British army alongside their male comrades in trials which could lead to women being allowed to fight on the frontline for the first time.
fields.body:
Women soldiers are to train for combat roles in the British army alongside their male comrades in trials which could lead to women being allowed to fight on the frontline for the first time.

The trials to be held later this year to establish how female soldiers would fare in frontline combat, are part of a drive to enhance equal opportunities within the military. They could be the first step in bringing the British army into line with the US, Canada, Holland, Norway and Israel, where frontline troops already include female soldiers.

The army has traditionally held the view that women cannot cope with the heavy physical demands of frontline fighting, and that mixed gender armoured units were impractical.

A report, A Study of Combat Effectiveness and Gender, is to be submitted to ministers next year. The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, commissioned the inquiry last year.

The trials are expected to test the viability of mixed gender tank crews and all-women crews, mixed and all-women infantry units. The field exercises will also examine how men react to women on the battlefield.

There are about 17,000 women in the army, with 24% of the jobs reserved for men only. Most of those are in the Household Cavalry division, the Royal Armoured Corps and the infantry.

The trials will not necessarily result in a relaxation of the restrictions, but if the presence of women appears not to have a negative impact on combat capability, the case for change would be strengthened.

The Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, Menzies Campbell, said: "The last time British soldiers were involved in serious close combat was in the Falklands, when they cleared Argentinian soldiers out of trenches out of Mount Tumbledown using the bayonet.

"It will be some time before British public opinion is ready to accept women in that type of role."

fields.headline: Button fined for 141mph M-way drive
fields.trailText: The formula one driver Jenson Button picked up his first speeding ticket, for doing 141mph in a BMW owned by the BMW-Williams race team.
fields.body:
The formula one driver Jenson Button picked up his first speeding ticket, for doing 141mph in a BMW owned by the BMW-Williams race team.

Button, 20, was stopped on Saturday on a French motorway near Montpellier, bound for Monaco for next weekend's Grand Prix. He was fined 5,000 francs (£500), on the spot.

Button was not carrying any cash and the police had to follow him to a nearby cashpoint.

Button was not available for comment yesterday. But his father, John, said: "This is the first time Jenson has been done for speeding but he didn't get any points on his licence or anything. "I suppose it was down to the empty roads."
Guardian staff and agencies

fields.headline: Highly strung
fields.standfirst: Young Musician triumphs despite breaking string
fields.trailText: A 19-year-old cellist won a major music competition at the weekend despite enduring one of the worst calamities that can befall a soloist on a concert platform.
fields.body:
A 19-year-old cellist won a major music competition at the weekend despite enduring one of the worst calamities that can befall a soloist on a concert platform.

Guy Johnston, from Harpenden, Hertfordshire, was three minutes into Shostakovich's first cello concerto on Saturday night when a string broke.

The audience at the Bridgewater Hall in Manchester, including his parents, gasped as he fled to the wings to fit a new string. He returned to play the entire concerto without further problems with the BBC Philharmonic under Yan Pascal Tortelier, and to become the BBC's Young Musician 2000.

Mr Johnston was presented with a cheque for £4,500 by the Duchess of Kent and will now go on to represent the UK at the Eurovision young musician contest in Bergen.

"He didn't win because of a sympathy vote," said an insider. "You could tell he was going to win in the minutes before the string broke."

Mr Johnson said: "During the week before the contest, I dreamed that a string was going to break.

"It happened in the worst place because I was all on my own playing loud chords. I went off and tried to keep really calm but there's not really much you can do. It must have taken me a couple of minutes to change the string and I had to play a few scales before I went back on."

The audience gave Mr Johnston a welcoming roar as he returned to the platform.

Other finalists were pianist Tom Poster, 19; euphonium player David Childs, 19; oboist Elizabeth Childs, 20; and percussionist Owen Gunnell.

fields.headline: US cadet cleared of rape
fields.trailText: A US naval cadet accused of raping an English woman, was cleared of the charge at a US court martial yesterday.
fields.body:
A US naval cadet accused of raping an English woman, was cleared of the charge at a US court martial yesterday.

Christopher Riley, 23, a midshipman first class, was accused of subjecting the 24-year-old woman to such a savage attack that her injuries were equivalent to childbirth.

The woman claimed she was lured into a dark room at a party, thrown against a wall and brutally raped by Mr Riley on the last night of his week-long exchange visit.

Mr Riley, claimed sex was consensual and her injuries came from heated and rough intercourse.

They met in March last year while Mr Riley was staying at the Royal Britannia naval college in Dartmouth, Devon.

Captain Gerald T Hatch - the US navy's most senior judge in Europe - delivered his verdict after considering the two versions of events for 90 minutes.

The verdict came at the end of the five-day US naval court martial held at a Ministry of Defence base at Eastcote, west London. Some witnesses had flown from the US and Europe for the hearing.

fields.headline: A hard act to follow
fields.trailText: Bad news. Today is the 30th birthday of the Equal Pay Act and we are still not equal.
fields.body:
Bad news. Today is the 30th birthday of the Equal Pay Act and we are still not equal. This anniversary churns up ghastly memories for my friend Mrs X, an academic in her 50s who not so long ago was lecturing in a London poly. Suddenly along came a young squit in plus fours and quickly became senior lecturer, manager, then principal lecturer. This was galling for Mrs X. This upstart had been a pupil of hers years ago. Now here he was, in charge, emailing colleagues in adjoining rooms, writing poetry and sucking up to the head of department, another bloke. Plus fours had done no lecturing before and had to take a quick course on the job.

And of course he earned more than his female colleagues. We could never quite work out why. He didn't teach more, he didn't teach better and his trousers looked silly, but he did awfully well and soon managed to sack a number of older women colleagues, including Mrs X.

But he was only a sign of things to come. Men in the academic world are still earning more than women (18% on average), especially older women, who aren't much fun and remind them of their mothers.

The trouble with women academics, so I am told, is that they are too emotional, too involved with their students and have no sense of perspective. What they should be concentrating on is research. Research, research, research.

Take the career path of a typical academic male in his early 20s. He must find a professor (male), suck up, obtain a post-doctoral research contract for three years, which gets the professor's name on a book (which earns him more money), perhaps do another three years' researching and grovelling, and with luck the professor will find him a permanent job or promotion. It's a sort of public school fagging system for grown-ups. The more publications you have your name on, the quicker you can zoom up the national pay scales, and you do this by being at the cutting edge, thrusting, energetic, rigorous, good at figures and objective, which means not getting bogged down in teaching, human contact and students' problems or overburdened by marking, seminars, going home at teatime, having babies and bringing up children. Some of us are more equal than others.

He didn't teach more, he didn't teach better and his trousers looked silly, but he did awfully well and soon managed to sack a number of older women colleagues, including Mrs X. But he was only a sign of things to come. Men in the academic world are still earning more than women (18% on average), especially older women, who aren't much fun and remind them of their mothers. The trouble with women academics, so I am told, is that they are too emotional, too involved with their students and have no sense of perspective. What they should be concentrating on is research. Research, research, research. Take the career path of a typical academic male in his early 20s. He must find a professor (male), suck up, obtain a post-doctoral research contract for three years, which gets the professor's name on a book (which earns him more money), perhaps do another three years' researching and grovelling, and with luck the professor will find him a permanent job or promotion. It's a sort of public school fagging system for grown-ups. The more publications you have your name on, the quicker you can zoom up the national pay scales, and you do this by being at the cutting edge, thrusting, energetic, rigorous, good at figures and objective, which means not getting bogged down in teaching, human contact and students' problems or overburdened by marking, seminars, going home at teatime, having babies and bringing up children. Some of us are more equal than others.

fields.headline: Two dead in fairground accidents
fields.trailText: Accident investigators were yesterday examining fairground rides where two people died in separate incidents.
fields.body:
Accident investigators were yesterday examining fairground rides where two people died in separate incidents.

Officers from the health and safety executive were called to the fairs in Redruth, Cornwall, and Shepherd's Bush, west London.

In Redruth, a 13-year-old girl died yesterday when she was hurled from a ride called Top Spin and thrown around 10 metres to the ground, hitting another girl.

The girl on the ground received minor injuries but the 13-year-old later died of her injuries in Treliske Hospital, Truro.

In Shepherd's Bush, a 28-year-old woman died last night when the car she was in flew off a ride called Super Trooper and crashed on top of a tent. Two other people in the car were taken to hospital.

A 24-year-old man was transferred to Charing Cross hospital with critical head injuries and an 18-year-old man was said to be in a stable condition in the same hospital.

An HSE spokeswoman said: "We are investigating both sites but it is too early to say what are the causes of the accidents. We will carry out a full investigation. If we find the rides are safe, then the owners could open them again."

fields.headline: Bye-bye love
fields.standfirst: Did romance die with Barbara Cartland?  Polly Vernon examines the evidence
fields.trailText: Listen: hear that strange, rustley, twisty turny noise? That's Barbara Cartland, that is, rotating in her cardboard coffin, getting her pink burial garb into a terrible tangle. The week she shuffled off this mortal coil wasn't even out and already her legacy of strictly non-sexual fluff was fading.
fields.body:
Listen: hear that strange, rustley, twisty turny noise? That's Barbara Cartland, that is, rotating in her cardboard coffin, getting her pink burial garb into a terrible tangle. The week she shuffled off this mortal coil wasn't even out and already her legacy of strictly non-sexual fluff was fading.

A mere two days after she was lowered into the manicured ground of her Hertfordshire manor, the consumer trends journal Euromonitor printed a report on the state of contemporary wedding lists and it spoke sorry volumes about the condition of good loving, Dame Barbara-style. It would seem that recently betrothed couples of the 21st century boast cheeks flushed red not with a lust-tainted wonder at the miracle of each other, but with the excitement of consumer rush. Where once they skipped round Peter Jones, giddily eyeing up the dinner services and gravy boats that would accessorise, but certainly not define, their union, they now hot-foot it round the Conran Shop, equipped with the latest Wallpaper magazine wish lists. A wedding has become a lifestyle event, a graspy, no-holds-barred, unapologetic consume-athon. Mine's the limited edition ivory le Creuset set.

Virtually simultaneously, that curious sub-popular icon variant Fern Brittan married her man in a register office, in front of two hurriedly rounded-up strangers. There was no pomp, no ceremony, no wood nymph-styled flower girls.

Is this how it is to be? Was Dame Barbara the last solid embodiment of old skool romance? Did it die with her? Did it gasp its last gasp as Fern tied the knot in the midst of overwhelming ordinariness? I do hope so.

Romance is a horrid, tasteless, squirmy little Hallmark card of an emotional context. It's an empty, cheap expectation wrapped in cellophane and trimmed with a moulting garage-bought rose. It's a template for a feeling, the preserve of Patrick Swayze-fancying weirdos, and it only ever ends in crocodile tears. It's the dirty little cliché that leaves far too many people feeling shortchanged on one sorry day in the middle of February.

The casualties of romance limp among us like silly broken things. The latest is poor Patsy Kensit, languishing in a private clinic, trembling on the brink of Ophelia-like misery and madness, beaten to an emotional pulp by her attachment to Liam Gallagher. A friend of hers explained yesterday: "Basically, Patsy is a romantic who believes that love conquers all." The sooner romance dies for Patsy, the sooner she can get happy.

Romance was specifically designed as a sturdy, disapproving, matronly force to persuade women from the pursuit of empty, meaningless, extravagant sex. Romance is the fly in your libido, the cataract in your lustful glances, the closing snuggle scene in your otherwise flawless bonkbuster. It's not guilt or sexual inadequacy or morality that whispers in your ear before you embark upon an affair or an ill-advised, one-night-only tumble: "This isn't what you want, not really, you're an old fashioned gal at heart, you want diamonds and sweetness and erection-free slow dancing." It isn't lapsed Catholicism or the ghost of parental guidance. It's romance.

We get the vote, we get the pill, we get Black Lace erotic fiction and Jessica Rabbit vibrators, but still everything from Sex And The City to Cosmopolitan is geared towards convincing us that, for ladies, romance is the end goal. In these frightfully modern times, sex might be the means but romance is still first prize. Use your sex wisely, girls, and you might just get a dreamy walk in the moonlight for your pains.

If romance must exist - and it would appear that it finds a way even in the absence of Barbara Cartland - then let it be limited in format. Last week, something happened that tickled my fancy and raised my goose bumps in a way that a cheap box of chocs and an unexpected Interflora delivery never quite have. And the thing was this: an unnamed collector paid £450,000 for the ruby slippers that Judy Garland wore in The Wizard Of Oz. Nearly half a million for the ultimate in camp chic.

But Dorothy's shoe fetish embodied a romantic ideal of sorts: girlie ambition, possibilities over the rainbow, vividness and Technicolor, adventure and the opportunity to get the hell out of a dull situation. Sentimental, fantastical silliness, undoubtedly. But still very much my kind of romance.

fields.headline: Police guns face hi-tech monitoring
fields.trailText: Details of a "black box" data recorder which can be fitted to police handguns are to be shown to senior officers at a conference in the Netherlands, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Details of a "black box" data recorder which can be fitted to police handguns are to be shown to senior officers at a conference in the Netherlands, it emerged yesterday.

The Accu-Counter is being developed by SIG ARMS and marketing of the finished product could begin later this year.

Its potential will be outlined to about 70 police delegates by Mike McBride, of Cheshire police, during a two day conference in Maastricht starting on June 6.

Insp McBride, an advisor on firearms, said the tiny device had the ability to record details such as the precise direction and exact time of each shot fired.

The information can then be downloaded on to a computer for analysis.

"The device will allow investigators to reconstruct events with complete accuracy," Mr McBride said. "It will support any officer who fulfils his assignment professionally. Questions of how and why can now be clarified objectively immediately after data evaluation."
Guardian staff and agencies
