fields.headline: Girl power
fields.standfirst: Could you catch a running a man (leaving aside the question of whether you'd want to)? Throw a tomahawk? Look good in Lycra? You, too, could be a Glamazon!  Anita Chaudhuri reports
fields.trailText: Could you catch a running a man (leaving aside the question of whether you'd want to)? Throw a tomahawk? Look good in Lycra? You, too, could be a Glamazon!
fields.body:
Go on, be honest. Who hasn't at some point secretly fantasised about being superhuman? Who wouldn't, in the interests of truth, justice and attracting the attentions of a particularly aloof hero, trade places with Xena: Warrior Princess for a few hours? The cult of the super-strong, daredevil heroine is upon us like never before, thanks to pop culture icons such as Lara Croft, Buffy the Vampire Slayer and Tank Girl. For some women, though, attaining an implausible level of physical strength is not merely a fantasy but a way of life.

Later this week, Glamazons, a contest that challenges women's strength, speed and endurance, hits our TV screens. A cross between Gladiators and Miss World, it features eight finalists who have travelled from across the globe to Florida's Universal Studios Theme Park (an appropriately surreal venue) to slug it out.

Participants must undertake a variety of tasks to show whether they are worthy of the Miss Glamazon title. These include catching a running man, tomahawk throwing, a race to pull 11 men on rollerblades in the fastest time and hanging from a fireman's ladder by a burning building.

Meeting the Glamazon women face to face is not for the faint-hearted. Yes, they may be strong, yes, they may be goddesses, but boy do they take themselves seriously. "I've still got six pounds to lose before the Euro- pean bodybuilding championships," complains Lynn Perrott, a former Miss Universe from Swindon. Thus lunch is a glass of Berry Blast, a pink "nutritional supplement" that looks positively radioactive. "I eat six small meals a day, all protein-based, very little fluids. I need to eat like that to keep the skin thin, it enhances muscle definition. And I have a salt-free, sodium-free diet so I never get PMS."

With her big hair and high-calorie mascara, Perrott does bear a passing resemblance to Xena. What do people make of her back home? "Oh, no one notices me, I look perfectly normal with my clothes on," she insists.

Despite her obsession with putting away 20 egg whites and six chicken breasts a day, depleting her body fat and inflating her muscles to popping point, Perrott appears to have a postfeminist agenda. "For a woman to have control of her body, it's brilliant, it's empowering. Control your body and you control your mind, your relationships, the rest of your life. I know that I can be any weight I want to be. How many women can say that?"

She is unusual in that she did not begin bodybuilding until she was 36 - practically geriatric. "My husband was on kidney dialysis and I was taking him to the hospital, as well as looking after our daughter. I wanted to do something for myself. I saw a picture of Miss Universe in a fitness magazine and I cut it out. When I told friends "I'm going to be her" they thought I was mad, but I went ahead and did it anyway. If you don't believe it, you can't achieve it." Now 42, she says she'll retire soon. "There's no money in it, I need to do something else."

Talk to the Glamazons for any length of time and you soon get embroiled in the politics of bodybuilding. Shannon Hartnett is a former competitive bodybuilder who now runs her own women-only gym in California. "I got out of competing because it had very little to do with sport or skill, and everything to do with how you looked. I saw the bikinis getting smaller and smaller, and the breasts getting bigger, the make-up heavier - it was like a goddamned beauty pageant. All the judges are men and it's totally subjective. That's why I signed up for Glamazons, because there's a clear set of rules."

Yet Glamazons still trades on the way women look - is Hartnett happy with that? "No. If it was down to me, I wouldn't be wearing this," she says of her Puma-sponsored miniskirt.

She turned to other sports, most bizarre of which is the international highland games movement (HQ California). She is a champion caber-tosser and competes in the all-American sport of "truck pulling". Did she always want to be strong? "I've always enjoyed sport and I began to realise physical strength gives you self-esteem, makes you less depressed, more focused, more in control."

Control is a recurring theme with contestants. How far would Hartnett go for control? "How d'you mean?" Steroids? "Oh no, that's not the issue in bodybuilding now, not among women at any rate. Now it's all about plastic surgery. Bodybuilders have to reduce body fat, but now there's a requirement for female contestants to have Erin Brokovich-style breasts. Low body fat and large breasts cannot exist in one physique, it's not possible. So more and more girls are paying for implants. I tell the girls who go to my gym not to do it."

And what do men think about the way she looks? (She resembles a pumped-up Cybill Shepherd, while her boyfriend, a 19-stone Australian highland games champion, is a dead ringer for the Incredible Hulk.) "What do men think?" she repeats incredulously. "Who cares! That's the problem with most women - they spend way too much time worrying about what men think. You can be sure they're not worrying about what we think of the way they look."

Not all the Glamazons are bodybuilders. Heimi Koivuniemi has competed in athletics and won a bronze in the Finnish jujitsu championships. "I got most of my strength helping my father with his business," she explains. He runs a gym? "No, he builds log cabins. I would never get involved in professional weightlifting, I hate that obsession with dieting."

Over the course of the three-day event, emotions begin to run high. There are ugly rumours of eggs going missing from one girl's motel room and of a contestant entertaining a (shock, horror) local man in her room.

"It's getting really bitchy backstage," Perrott confides mournfully. "They're all taking it so seriously, they keep staring at one another, trying to psyche each other out like boxers do. It's very silly ... I hope I win, though. I need the money." What will she do with it? "Get a boob job. Or at least one breast, it'd be a start." Alas for Perrott, she is placed last, with former Gladiator Pauline Richards from Wolverhampton taking the crown.

Although the physical prowess of the contestants is impressive, there is still something anachronistic about seeing professional athletes forced to compete in tiny Lycra bra tops, nightclub make-up and big hair. What is this really achieving? "Oh, it's a total girl power thing," a female TV executive gushes. "I mean, yesterday, we did some title shots and we had one girl wrestling with an alligator. That's such girl power, isn't it? And then we had another one driving a chariot. It's amazing, so empowering."

Or not. The fact that the presenter chosen to front the Glamazons on TV is Page Three girl Gail McKenna probably says more than anything about the extent to which Glamazons is about empowerment. A quick internet search for the term confirms the worst: the name is already being used, not by sussed female athletes but by a large online cosmetics firm.  Glamazons is on Channel 5 on Friday at 8pm.

fields.headline: Question time
fields.standfirst: Like his father, he is the voice of the nation - the broadcaster who quizzes politicians and steers us through state weddings and funerals. But who is the man behind the smooth interrogations and seamless narrations?
fields.trailText: Like his father, he is the voice of the nation - the broadcaster who quizzes politicians and steers us through state weddings and funerals. But who is the man behind the smooth interrogations and seamless narrations?
fields.body:
In the lobby of the Dorchester Hotel, where I go to interview David Dimbleby, is a man in a suit - a member of the public - who greets Dimbleby like a long lost friend. "Hey! Hello! You live in my street!" he calls. Dimbleby, who is often mistaken for other walk-on parts in people's lives (he tells a good anecdote about being confused for a paint salesman on a train), sashays smoothly over to correct the mistake. He doesn't look completely delighted when it turns out the man really is his neighbour. "Oh really, oh really," he says, continuing to smile and nod even when the man says: "Your father, what a great broadcaster he was."

Dimbleby is halfway back across the room when the man adds: "I'll be watching you on Question Time on Sunday."

There is a beat. Dimbleby doesn't turn round. "Thursday," he says grimly, under his breath. "The programme goes out on Thursday."

It is a hard task to get Dimbleby to crack. He is the crackless man. Even his complexion is relatively line-free for a man of 61, as if the anxieties and troubles of his life have eased away into the ether before reaching his face. A face that doesn't do dishes. A face that registers neither ambition nor professional fear, nor familial competition, nor the fallout of divorce.

Safe face. Safe hands. Just what you need to steer a big occasion through the dangerous waters of a live broadcast. Just the man you want on hand for this royal wedding or that election night, for this Queen Mother birthday parade, if not that. He kept his eye on the compass on millennium night, a working jib to Jamie Theakston's spinnaker. On Sunday he'll handle the BBC's Dunkirk 60th anniversary tribute. You know there'll be just the right amount of information and thoughtfulness and emotion, but with Dimbleby, the good old-fashioned Englishman, it is emotion recollected in tranquillity. And if he shows his heart on his sleeve, he'll have polished it just a tiny bit first.

Sitting in the Dorchester, he is full of Dunkirk. He says, in his nicely posh Charterhouse/Oxford voice: "I think all the hyperbole about it was justified. I think Dunkirk was a miracle. It was a real pivotal turning point." He talks in detail about what it meant then, and with hindsight. He reflects about Churchill's standing before and after, about the views of Halifax. He says "as you know" a couple of times, and "you will have read", taking responsibility for your ignorance, and once he says with feeling: "Thank God we're an island."

But he's at his best conjuring it up, describing tumult in the calmest of ways: to find civilians getting into a boat and going off to help and coming under appalling attack, gunfire and being bombed and seeing bodies in the water and ships sinking all around them, and the sky completely black. It must have been terrifying.

"I was so moved by reading about it," he says. "I came out into my garden in Sussex, which is right by the sea at Eastbourne, on a brilliant summer day, I thought, this is something that is very rare, a moment when a country has been saved by the people's courage, this way of being stalwart in disaster. It is very hard to work out what Dimbleby is really thinking, or feeling. He appears at first to be controlled about many things. He used to be a "chronic fiddler" (his father advised him when on camera to keep away from swivel chairs), but you would never know it to look at him. Only his knees move in time with his words. He claims to suffer from pre-broadcast nerves but you would never know that either.

And he abides by certain conversational rules. He never talks about his younger brother, the broadcaster Jonathan Dimbleby: "It would be undignified." He has always neatly summed up the influence of his father, Richard, "the voice of a nation", by saying he helped him "get in" to the BBC, but he has "got on" by himself. He is "Trappist" on the subject of his wife of 25 years, the cookery writer Josceline Dimbleby, whom he left in 1992 for his much younger assistant, Belinda Giles. He is almost monosyllabic about the local newspaper business he inherited from his father and about which he is said to care deeply. "It ticks over," he says, clipped. Several times he refers to the "nobility" of the BBC and of his own heritage - "journalists for five generations". But he talks about himself as someone who sort of wandered into the street and found himself on camera. "I've never been ambitious. I've rather had ambition thrust upon me." He simply likes what he does, he says. "It's fun and it's relatively well paid and varied which is nice and you don't have the burden of big decisions. He has caused only two major furores: once for implying a visit by Richard Nixon was a con; once for quizzing Harold Wilson on how much he got for his memoirs. He outmanoeuvred Jeremy Paxman and Sue Lawley to the Question Time chair. And, in a culture increasingly attacted to youth, he has seen off John Birt, against whom he spoke out, and grins and bears it under Greg Dyke: "It's too early to say."

He would have liked to have been director-general. "Yes I would. I think I would have been all right. There was a tradition of broadcasters being director-general and I was a broadcaster and I didn't like the tradition of people who had been administrators. They chose an accountant and I can't remember what Dyke did but I think in my bit, news and current affairs, which is perilous territory politically, you need to feel you're being led by someone who really understands the nature of it. And that's what I thought I might like to do. But there was a moment and it passed."

He becomes increasingly expansive after this, as if taking refuge in his home life. The Trappist father would not have approved, but he let slip quite a lot about life chez Dimbleby, lives one and two. He and Josceline lived in Putney's "media gulch", he sighs. They had to hide from Jilly Cooper in the end because she wrote about them so much in her Common Years newspaper column. In life mark two, he divides his time between a redbrick semi in north London and a house on the Downs. He and Giles aren't married. "Keeps them on their toes", he murmurs.

In the summer, they're moving to the country full-time. "It's very raffish, very laid back. People don't complain down there." He talks at length about the school arrangements for his two stepchildren - "common-law step I should say" - which is rather touching. Nine-year-old Joe does a mean impression of Chris Tarrant on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? "He's a very good mimic," says Dimbleby, though he admits to not having seen the show. (He never watches television and only listens to news on radio. Not even The Archers? "Not even The Archers.")

He has three grown-up children about whom he is "quite soppy. I dote on them all." He also has a two-year-old, Fred. Dimbleby can't understand the furore over the Blair baby. "It seems to me an entirely private matter. I can't see it as a vote winner. The idea that you parade a one-year-old and everyone votes for you. Blair's sleepless nights." He adds, unnecessarily: "Fred was a genius. He slept from almost the beginning."

Who is going to inherit his newspapers? "That is one of the problems. I don't know. I don't know. If you leave a bit to everybody it collapses. If you leave it all to one the others all feel pissed off. It's impossible to tell. One child's a jazz musician, one is a painter, one is a management consultant and one is two. I think my hopes are on the two-year-old."

He laughs. Then he says: "I do have a hope - or is it a fear? - that at the moment, just at this moment, things seem so exciting and enjoyable and right in my life, both on the work front and privately, I'm really loving every day... that my hope is that that won't suddenly be disrupted or destroyed. Nothing we can do about it. Fate is fate. You know what life's like, don't know what will happen next."

His father died at 52. Does this anxiety come from being nine years older than that? "It is odd. I think of it as extra time. I keep asking myself whether I've done the right things in my life, whether the things I've done have been right, this is time he didn't have. Shouldn't you be doing more? Achieving more. You can't just chunter on like this . . ."

He breaks off. "After all it's only telly," I say. Seamlessly, he says: "I agree. It's nothing. It's nothing. It's only telly."

fields.headline: Letters:  Sir John Gielgud
fields.trailText: Alma Cohen writes: My most cherished memory of Sir John Gielgud (Obituary, May 23) was his entrance in the pre-London, first-night performance of A Day By The Sea at the Liverpool Royal Court theatre. This was his first stage appearance after his 1953 court ordeal, and the whole audience rose to its feet and applauded.
fields.body:
Alma Cohen writes: My most cherished memory of Sir John Gielgud (Obituary, May 23) was his entrance in the pre-London, first-night performance of A Day By The Sea at the Liverpool Royal Court theatre. This was his first stage appearance after his 1953 court ordeal, and the whole audience rose to its feet and applauded.

N Williamson writes: I was a young drama student in Edinburgh in the early 1950s, when a group of us went to see A Day By the Sea at the Lyceum, on its pre-London tour. We had front-row seats in the gods, and applauded keenly with the rest of the audience as each member of the star-studded cast made their entrances, as was then the custom.

Then came John Gielgud. Silence. It was only a few months after his heart-breaking court case, and the Edinburgh audience didn't seem able to salute the greatest actor of our time. We timorous students also kept silent, horrified and ashamed as we were were at our inaction. His courage in going on night after night in front of provincial audiences only adds to the shining quality of a great man.

Ann Hummel writes: When Charles Chabot and I were making the BBC Omnibus programme for Sir John Gielgud's 90th birthday, we filmed him at the Old Vic, the scene of his classic triumphs in the 1920s. He did some readings for us from his own books about key moments in his nine decades of theatrical life.

While chatting to Sir John, I mentioned that my grand-father, a long-forgotten actor more noted for "Anyone for tennis" type roles, had acted with Sybil Thorndike in the 1924 premiere of Shaw's St Joan. "What part did he play?" Gielgud asked. "Dunois," I replied. "Horton," he responded without a pause for thought - and indeed my grandfather's name was [Robert] Horton. I have this memory of Sir John, impeccably dressed in matching pink tie and shirt, Savile Row pinstripe suit (just a hint of a flare), slowly walking the stage deep in thought.

fields.headline: No: 1644
fields.standfirst: The Archers
fields.trailText: The Archers.
fields.body:
What have they been up to now? Not sex in the shower again. Don't be smutty. They're celebrating their 50th.

Phil and Jill's golden wedding? If you'd been listening properly, you'd know they haven't been married that long. Phil's first wife, Grace, was alive as recently as 1955.

What happened to her? She was barbecued in a burning barn.

Nasty. Very. Legend has it that Grace was sacrificed to draw attention away from the launch of ITV. The BBC would stop at nothing in those days. Today, it can't even run to televising the cup final.

Never mind that. What's all this about the big 5-0 in The Archers? Tonight marks the 50th anniversary of the pilot episode of The Archers of Wimberton Farm, on the BBC Midlands Home Service. Not bad for a soap that began as propaganda.

Propaganda? For the Country Code. In the early days, you couldn't get through 15 minutes without lengthy discussions on the need to keep gates shut and take home your picnic wrappings.

Doesn't sound as much fun as sex in the shower. They didn't have showers in those days. And sex didn't rear its ugly head until the 70s when Shula lost her virginity in a cornfield with a reporter from the Borchester Echo.

So will the programme last another 50 years? Funny you should ask. The fall of the house of Archer has seemed imminent just lately. Elizabeth has had them at each other's throats.

Why? She thinks she's being diddled out of her inheritance by Phil and Jill and Ruth and David and Shula.

Elizabeth? Isn't she married to the chinless wonder with the stately pile? Surely she has enough already. That's what Phil, Jill, David, Ruth and Shula keep telling her.

With all this money and sex, it sounds more like Dallas than Ambridge. In Dallas, the shower scene turned out to be a dream.

Don't say: Anything about pigs to Phil, ferrets to Eddie, and what Sid and Jolene have been doing in Cathy's hearing.

Do say: Shut that gate.

fields.headline: Francis Lederer
fields.standfirst: Hollywood romantic hero inhibited by shyness and foreign birth
fields.trailText: It could be argued that a pair of lederhosen made the Czech-born actor Francis Lederer, who has died aged 100, into a Hollywood star. He wore them in Dodie Smith's play, Autumn Crocus, first in London, and then on Broadway.
fields.body:
It could be argued that a pair of lederhosen made the Czech-born actor Francis Lederer, who has died aged 100, into a Hollywood star. He wore them in Dodie Smith's play, Autumn Crocus, first in London, and then on Broadway in the role of a young married Tyrolean innkeeper with whom an English schoolteacher falls in love. James Agate, reviewing it at the Lyric theatre in April 1931, wrote: "The whole piece hangs or falls by the innkeeper's charm, and the amount of this commodity produced by Mr Lederer is colossal. In addition, he is an extremely fine actor."

Unfortunately, being a foreign actor, Lederer never really fulfilled his potential in America. "The studios didn't know how to handle him or how to buy stories for him," wrote Ginger Rogers, his co-star in Romance In Manhattan (1934). "Hollywood was a very parochial place, and once classified, actors could not easily break out of the mould." Lederer believed his inherent shyness - he hated to do publicity for his films - worked against his becoming as big a romantic star as, say, Charles Boyer.

Born Frantisek Lederer in Prague, the son of a leather merchant, he won a scholarship to the city's academy of music and dramatic art before he was 18, and began a stage career while still in his teens. By the late 1920s, he was a matinee idol in Berlin, Vienna and other European capitals, notably as Romeo to Elisabeth Bergner's Juliet in a celebrated Max Reinhardt production.

In 1930, Lederer, who could sing and dance, came to London to appear in Meet My Sister, for which he learned his part phonetically, as he had little English. After it flopped he went into Autumn Crocus, opposite Fay Compton, which ran for 18 months. His success on Broadway in the same play in 1934 led to a contract with RKO studios.

He had made around half a dozen films in Europe previously, including Pandora's Box (1929), a classic of the German silent cinema, in which he played the young writer Alva, one of many men destroyed by femme fatale Lulu (Louise Brooks). There was an intimate scene between Lederer and Brooks, in which the director GW Pabst insisted she wear nothing underneath her dress. "Who would know?" Brooks asked. "Lederer," Pabst replied.

In The Wonderful Life Of Nina Petrova (also 1929), he made it perfectly clear to audiences why Brigitte Helm should give up her jewels, villa and rich lover to live modestly with him, a penniless young lieutenant.

Lederer's Hollywood debut in Man of Two Worlds (1934), was, strangely for someone bought by RKO as a romantic European lead, as an Eskimo introduced into the complexities of western civilisation, a role he played with an ingratiating blend of naivete and bemusement.

In many of his following films, he showed a deftness for light comedy, playing an illegal immigrant helping chorus-girl Ginger Rogers in Romance In Manhattan (1935); a prince posing as a bellboy in William Wyler's The Gay Deception, (also 1935), and an actor who causes a scandal by accidentally kissing Ida Lupino in the cinema while under the spell of the picture in One Rainy Afternoon (1936). In 1938, he took the title role in The Lone Wolf In Paris, as a jewel thief turned detective - perhaps the only time he appeared as a true American.

After playing a gigolo on whom Claudette Colbert uses her charms to distract him from John Barrymore's wife in Midnight (1939), Lederer demonstrated more range and depth than he had been able to hitherto in three anti-Nazi movies.

I n Confessions Of A Nazi Spy (1939), as a downtrodden German-American who steals secrets and becomes a Nazi agent to support his family, he managed to imbue this unsympathetic weasel with humanity. In The Man I Married (1940), he played an initially lovable German-American who becomes a rabid Nazi after visiting his father in Germany, and in Voice In The Wind (1944) he was a Czech pianist who is tortured by the Nazis and looses his memory. He was also superb in Jean Renoir's The Diary Of A Chambermaid (1946) as Joseph, the sadistic valet, given to piercing the throats of geese with a needle. Lederer then returned to the stage for a few years, appearing in Noel Coward's Relative Values in Germany, and as Anne Frank's father in The Diary Of Anne Frank in America. When he went back to the screen, his image had eased into a narrower range of character parts.

However, he was still able to be both a charming and sinister vampire in The Return Of Dracula (1958). "They wanted me to wear fangs," he explained, "but I refused, saying it was old hat and I would have looked foolish." Neither did he use a cape, but merely wore his overcoat over his shoulders. In his last feature, Terror Is A Man (1958), a Filipino horror film, he was a mad doctor who turned a leopard into a leopard man.

Aside from his stage and screen work, Lederer did a great deal of television, for which he adapted Ibsen's A Doll's House, and was the chief villain in the first Mission Impossible (1967). He also taught acting for many years, helped found the American National Academy of Performing Arts and the Holly wood museum, was active in civic affairs, and made a fortune from property.

Since 1942, he lived on a ranch in the San Fernando valley with Marion Irving, his third wife.

 Francis Lederer, actor, born November 6 1899; died May 25 2000

I n Confessions Of A Nazi Spy (1939), as a downtrodden German-American who steals secrets and becomes a Nazi agent to support his family, he managed to imbue this unsympathetic weasel with humanity. In The Man I Married (1940), he played an initially lovable German-American who becomes a rabid Nazi after visiting his father in Germany, and in Voice In The Wind (1944) he was a Czech pianist who is tortured by the Nazis and looses his memory. He was also superb in Jean Renoir's The Diary Of A Chambermaid (1946) as Joseph, the sadistic valet, given to piercing the throats of geese with a needle. Lederer then returned to the stage for a few years, appearing in Noel Coward's Relative Values in Germany, and as Anne Frank's father in The Diary Of Anne Frank in America. When he went back to the screen, his image had eased into a narrower range of character parts. However, he was still able to be both a charming and sinister vampire in The Return Of Dracula (1958). "They wanted me to wear fangs," he explained, "but I refused, saying it was old hat and I would have looked foolish." Neither did he use a cape, but merely wore his overcoat over his shoulders. In his last feature, Terror Is A Man (1958), a Filipino horror film, he was a mad doctor who turned a leopard into a leopard man. Aside from his stage and screen work, Lederer did a great deal of television, for which he adapted Ibsen's A Doll's House, and was the chief villain in the first Mission Impossible (1967). He also taught acting for many years, helped found the American National Academy of Performing Arts and the Holly wood museum, was active in civic affairs, and made a fortune from property. Since 1942, he lived on a ranch in the San Fernando valley with Marion Irving, his third wife.  Francis Lederer, actor, born November 6 1899; died May 25 2000

fields.headline: Anthony Hartley
fields.standfirst: Writer, editor and intellectual with broad vision of politics and arts
fields.trailText: Anthony Hartley, who has died aged 74, was one of a rare and influential generation of British journalists who were also writers, and political and foreign affairs experts who were also devoted to the arts. Including such key postwar figures as Andrew Shonfield, David Watt and Anthony Sampson, they were the nearest equivalent to those who, in continental Europe, would be called, unblushingly, "intellectuals".
fields.body:
Anthony Hartley, who has died aged 74, was one of a rare and influential generation of British journalists who were also writers, and political and foreign affairs experts who were also devoted to the arts. Including such key postwar figures as Andrew Shonfield, David Watt and Anthony Sampson, they were the nearest equivalent to those who, in continental Europe, would be called, unblushingly, "intellectuals".

Alert, learned and endlessly well-informed, Hartley was kind as well as witty, and a patriot, as well as an Atlanticist and a francophile European.

He was debarred by ill-health from war service, and read English at Exeter College, Oxford, from 1943 to 1946. But his family lived at Blackheath, south London, which was bombed, and - as he recalled - "my first inkling of the insecurity which lies behind all civilisation came with the sight of landmarks that I had known for most of my life disappearing overnight in a cloud of dust and rubble." Characteristically, he went on: "I do not want to overdramatise this; it was an experience common to many people."

In 1947, he went to the Sorbonne in Paris, where at length he became a docteur-es-lettres. There, still more than in Britain, "it was all too evident what effect the loss of power has on an old nation accustomed to its place in the world."

These reflections of Hartley are taken from A State Of England, published in 1963, when Britain was smarting from de Gaulle's veto on her joining the Common Market. In 1972, Hartley wrote the general's political epitaph, in Gaullism: The Rise And Fall Of A Political Movement. But his feeling for France, and for poetry, was best expressed in his two volumes (19th and 20th centuries) of the Penguin Book Of French Verse, first published in 1957 and 1959, and several times reprinted and revised. His introductions are still models of haute vulgarisation, with neither vulgarity nor hauteur.

All this time he had been writing and reviewing verse himself, as a poet in the magazine Listen, and as a critic in the Spectator, where he was responsible for foreign affairs and the arts, championing Kingsley Amis, Philip Larkin, and John Wain, reviewing the first night of John Osborne's Look Back In Anger, and repeating (but not inventing) the phrase "angry young man".

After Hartley's stinging review of an Edith Sitwell volume in 1954, she asked the editor to have him stuffed and put in a glass case. Instead, in 1962, he became the paper's deputy editor, notably publishing, in full, FR Leavis's attack on CP Snow, during the "two cultures" controversy, but resigning a year later when Iain Macleod replaced Iain Hamilton as editor.

In 1967, Hartley moved with his wife, Rhea, to New York, where he edited the political magazine Interplay. He had long been an Atlanticist, opposing Britain's 1956 Suez adventure because America would not wear it, attacking (with Kingsley Amis, Robert Conquest and Peregrine Worsthorne) critics of US foreign policy, and defending the Congress for Cultural Freedom (later shown to have been CIA-financed) that supported Encounter and other magazines.

Backing poets, writers and Sovietologists was, Hartley thought, preferable to financing the Bay of Pigs. He wrote frequently for Encounter, and became its co-editor just before its demise in 1990. He also appeared in the Sunday Telegraph and, latterly, the Tablet. His last polemic was a pamphlet on the Maastricht treaty, arguing that Europeans must abandon unitary-state ambitions so as to keep US troops in Europe at a time of "explosive peace in Eastern Europe". That, presciently, was in 1992.

I first met Hartley in the 1950s, in the old Spectator offices at 99 Gower Street. We discussed the arts in Rome (where I was going), French literature, and the Maghreb potentate El Glaoui, about whom he seemed to know a lot. I was impressed by his learning and his languages; his German was as fluent as his French.

In 1973, as the European Commission's chief representative in Britain, I secured his appointment as my deputy, and was again impressed - this time by his brilliance as a political intelligencer in both Brussels and London, often over informative lunches at the Travellers' Club.

We worked together again when I co-edited Encounter, and, although we often disagreed, we seldom quarreled. He was a thoughtful, erudite friend, a voracious reader of recondite books, and an innate sceptic. As with every true intellectual, there was always something awkward nagging at his mind.

Hartley overcame, unobtrusively, virtually lifelong asthma and endured, with the support of his daughters, some three years as a widower after the death of his devoted and distinguished wife, to whom he had been married for nearly 40 years.

 Anthony Archer Hartley, writer, born July 29 1925; died May 16 2000

fields.headline: Julie Dawn
fields.standfirst: Danceband singer who found new fame as radio's sympathetic ear
fields.trailText: From the night of her debut at Quaglino's restaurant in July 1939, Julie Dawn, who has died aged 79, sang with some of the biggest British dance bands of the 1940s - Geraldo, Eric Winstone, Harry Roy, Carroll Gibbons, Billy Ternent and Harry Leader. In the 1950s, she worked with Cyril Stapleton's BBC Showband and featured on the Goon Show. For a decade from the late 1970s, she compered a highly successful BBC Radio 2 show.
fields.body:
From the night of her debut at Quaglino's restaurant in July 1939, Julie Dawn, who has died aged 79, sang with some of the biggest British dance bands of the 1940s - Geraldo, Eric Winstone, Harry Roy, Carroll Gibbons, Billy Ternent and Harry Leader. In the 1950s, she worked with Cyril Stapleton's BBC Showband and featured on the Goon Show. For a decade from the late 1970s, she compered a highly successful BBC Radio 2 show.

Dawn was the daughter of Italian immigrants; her father was the Savoy hotel's head waiter. She sang in her convent school choir and, from 13 to 15, took a piano and music course at the Guildhall School of Music. She sang popular songs in English, Italian and French, which her father taught her; from the broadcaster Maurice Elwin she learnt microphone technique.

Then, one Christmas, her violinist brother Ubaldo (known as Mossie) took her to a party. Singing J'attendrai in French, and accompanying herself on the piano, she was spotted by Ernest Quaglino, who invited her to appear at his famous restaurant in St James's. Collie Knox, the Daily Mail entertainment columnist, advised her to anglicise her name, and thus did Juliana Mostosi become Julie Dawn. In late 1939, she made her first studio broadcast.

After Italy entered the second world war, Dawn's parents were interned until 1945, to her anger and distress - she once waited in Downing Street to complain to Winston Churchill about their treatment. In 1940, she joined the Harry Roy Band, touring the Moss Empires. But one night in Glasgow, singing Ferry Serenade, she slipped into Italian. It turned into a legendary confrontation. Roy was furious; Dawn walked off the stage - and was fired.

In 1941, she made records and worked with Harry Leader. Then came engagements with Eric Winstone's swing quartet, with whom she sang some songs in Romany. In 1942, she recorded The Organ, The Danceband And Me with Billy Thorburn. In 1944-45, she worked with Carroll Gibbons and the Savoy Hotel Orpheans, after which she took on a 17-day tour of France, Belgium and Holland with Geraldo, who then led Britain's top swing band. By the end of the war, she was playing in Germany with Eric Winstone.

After demobilisation, Dawn joined Art Thompson at the Embassy Club. Then came Cyril Stapleton's BBC Showband, with studio audiences and three two-hour broadcasts a week. Later, she got a short regular slot on the Light Programme (now Radio 2).

Her big radio break came in the late 1970s, when she was invited to host Julie Dawn's Penfriends Programme, a thrice-weekly show putting listeners who lived alone in touch with others in similar circumstances, and reading out their letters. The programme's huge success lay in Dawn's sympathetic approach and soothing voice, and her understanding of her listeners' problems. Her postbag topped 1,000 letters a week.

In recent years, she entertained meetings of the Harry Roy Appreciation Society and was one of the founder members of the musicians' rendezvous, the Coda Club. Her husband, David, predeceased her in 1992.

fields.headline: Dymphna Clark
fields.standfirst: Historian setting straight Australia's heritage
fields.trailText: A commonly held perception of those who knew the Australian linguist and historian Dymphna Clark, who has died aged 83, was of her perspicacious intelligence; yet, without regrets, she subjugated her own intellectual vocation in favour of her husband, the historian Manning Clark.
fields.body:
A commonly held perception of those who knew the Australian linguist and historian Dymphna Clark, who has died aged 83, was of her perspicacious intelligence; yet, without regrets, she subjugated her own intellectual vocation in favour of her husband, the historian Manning Clark. She assumed responsibility for research, translation and editing the text of his six-volume A History Of Australia and other works; without her efforts, her son Andrew believes, he could not have completed the mammoth task.

Dymphna Clark's own achievements were, nonetheless, considerable. In 1978, she was appointed to the five-strong council of the Aboriginal treaty committee, at a time when Australia was the only former British colony not to recognise native title to land. She drafted the council's preamble, for consideration by both houses of parliament, and the historic 1992 high court Mabo decision ratifying the principle of land rights for Aborigines derived from the comm- ittee's findings.

Together with Peter Sack, Clark translated and edited the German New Guinea Annual Reports (1979). The importance of this work lies in the presentation of a western view of colonial history to the people of the former colony. It was particularly relevant to Papua New Guinea as German had long ceased to be the territory's official language.

Clark's magnum opus was her translation of the botanist Baron Carl von Hugel's vast New Holland Journals 1833-1834. Von Hugel was responsible for cultivating the newly fashionable "New Holland" (or Australian) plants in European public gardens from Italy to St Petersburg. His work had never before been translated, let alone published. Clark was not a botanist, yet the scholarship of her botanical indexing of the 19th and 20th centuries is recognised as a major contribution to the nomenclature.

Her father, Augustin Lodewicz, was professor of Germanic languages at Melbourne University, where her mother, Anna Sophia, taught Swedish. Their daughter became fluent in Dutch, German, French, Italian, Swedish and Norwegian and possessed a good command of Spanish, Portugese, Bahasa Indonesian and Russian. Descended from Flemish, Norwegian and Swedish stock, she stressed her Flemish origin.

She was educated at the Presbyterian Ladies College in Melbourne and the Gymnasium of Luisen Strasse, Munich. At 15, she returned to Melbourne to study at her father's school, graduating in 1936. The following year she began a PhD in Bonn.

When Manning Clark first saw Dymphna Lodewycz, he became, as he recalled, "weak in the knees" - she was a woman of extraordinary beauty. In 1939, he tele-graphed her in Bonn from Oxford, beseeching her to come at once; she abandoned her studies and the couple married in Oxford.

Manning Clark died in 1991. Dymphna, by then in her 70s, still possessed prodigious energy and became editor of Clark & Pryor's Select Documents In Australian History, a volume of her late husband's lectures and speeches, and the third volume of his autobiography, A Historian's Apprenticeship.

She set up her home in Canberra as Manning Clark House and refused the inclusion of her own name. Six days before her death, she received the East Timor resistance leader, Jose "Xanana" Gusmao and presented him to the Australian prime minister, John Howard.

She leaves a daughter, five sons and 15 grandchildren.

 Dymphna Clark (nee Lodewyckz), linguist and historian, born December 18 1916; died May 12 2000

webTitle: Australians apologise, but PM won't say the word

fields.headline: Australians apologise, but PM won't say the word
fields.trailText: A formal treaty between aborigines and non-indigenous Australians, 212 years after the first settlers arrived, was back on the agenda yesterday as more than 150,000 people marched across Sydney Harbour Bridge calling for reconciliation.
fields.body:
A formal treaty between aborigines and non-indigenous Australians, 212 years after the first settlers arrived, was back on the agenda yesterday as more than 150,000 people marched across Sydney Harbour Bridge calling for reconciliation.

But despite a huge turnout, which organisers said could exceed 250,000, the prime minister, John Howard, again refused to say "sorry" for the dispossession of land and reparations for the "stolen generations" of black children removed from their families.

The chairman of the main lobby group, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner, Geoff Clark, said the huge turnout gave a mandate for some form of official agreement between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians

"There's a clear message that people from all walks of life have all walked together here for a single purpose and that's to unite the country in what I believe is an agreement and a treaty," he said.

In a carnival atmosphere the bridge was closed to traffic and an aeroplane wrote the word "sorry" high above the procession.

The weekend marked the anniversary of the 1967 referendum in which Australians voted overwhelmingly to include aborigines and Torres Strait islanders as citizens. But for many the full spirit of the referendum was never realised as black Australians continued to suffer poverty, ill health, high rates of imprisonment and deaths in custody and marginalisation.

Among the walkers was Marty Thomas and his partner Toni Wright who were both brought up in aboriginal missions after their families were removed from their traditional lands. "A lot of people have pulled me up today and said sorry. It made me feel more welcome, feel better and its puts the aboriginals' confidence up," said Mr Thomas.

"We were born in the 60s when they never counted us as anything so we feel special today because we are being really counted," said Ms Wright.

But the reconciliation minister, Philip Ruddock, said any treaty with aborigines would split the country and an agreement was enough. "Nations have treaties and we're about uniting Australia, not dividing it," he said.

Missing from the walk was the prime minister who drew the fury of many of the crowd at the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation's "Corroboree 2000" on Saturday. Mr Howard again declined to apologise for the policies which led to the "stolen generations". He said that while he deeply regretted the past he could not say sorry for the actions of others. He was howled down by some of the 2,000 people gathered to hear the culmination of the 10-year process for reconciliation.

Aden Ridgeway, only the second aborigine to become a senator, said the hostile reception given to Mr Howard showed how much anger and hurt was still being felt by aborigines and their supporters and how vital reconciliation was. "It's not going to happen overnight; I think it's a far-off destination that has to be worked at. Reconciliation is an imperfect thing but you have to start from somewhere," he said.

fields.headline: Final curtain for seaside variety
fields.standfirst: Competition from free entertainment in pubs and sun-filled holidays abroad forces resorts to adapt
fields.trailText: It's time to pack away the tap shoes and the pierrot ruffles: according to a report published today, the traditional seaside variety show is dead.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
It's time to pack away the tap shoes and the pierrot ruffles: according to a report published today, the traditional seaside variety show is dead.

"It's still twitching, but there is no doubt that although live entertainment will continue at seaside resorts, the variety show's days are over," said Steve Hayler, author of the report on cultural trends.

"It's not necessarily bad news, what we are seeing is evolution. The theatres are still there, but the summer months will increasingly be like the winter ones - one night specials, concerts, touring shows."

The variety show, the dancers, singers, magicians and comedy turns, in a theatre on the seafront or actually on the pier, was as much part of the resort formula as fat lady postcards and candy floss.

Mr Hayler found visitors still expected the show to be there, like the sand and the deckchairs, but that did not mean they bothered going. "It's the hotel swimming pool syndrome," he said, "guests expect one, but may never set foot in it."

Competition from free entertainment in pubs and hotels has also hit audiences, and the changing patterns of holidays, with more and more people taking their main holiday abroad, and visiting the British seaside only for day trips or short breaks, mean visitors no longer have many evenings to fill. The locals, who have often regarded the summer shows with fine contempt, stay away in droves.

The result is that local authorities and a handful of remaining independent owners are abandoning the trouble and expense of mounting a special summer show.

There are few statistics. Mr Hayer is the first academic to attempt to collect systematic evidence about summer variety. He has launched a monitoring project for the British Resorts Association, which will inevitably chart the slow death of a genuine popular art form, whose origins lie in Victorian music hall.

In the 1950s there were shows in dozens of resorts and many of the theatres which housed them survive. Each of the top 20 resorts still has at least one theatre, but last summer Mr Hayer could find just 10 variety shows and one ice show, in eight resorts - two in Blackpool, three in Bournemouth, and one each at Bridlington, Clacton-on-Sea, Cromer, Eastbourne, Ilfracombe, and Weston-super-Mare.

Margate in Kent, which once attracted national names, became the first major resort to scrap its summer show in 1989. The manager of the Winter Gardens, Chris Wolfe, told Mr Hayer that it was difficult to find quality acts, and almost as difficult to find quality audiences: "There is a new breed of audience, not conversant with theatre etiquette. Behaviour is poor, we have to employ licensed doormen."

Mr Hayler knows his subject from the boards up and is the grandson of noted Victorian tenor, Douglas Lott. Mr Hayler toured his own show, The Sinatra Years, on the cabaret circuit in the 1970s, has worked as an hotel and resort entertainment manager, and still performs in the Burlington Hotel in Eastbourne. "To be honest I can do no wrong there," he said.

He lives in Worthing, one of many south coast resorts where the tide seems to have gone out for good. Worthing still had the Fol-de-Rols, descendants of the Pierrot shows, until 1982. Now, he notes, the council has stopped even promoting the town as a seaside resort, pushing its position on the edge of the Sussex Downs instead, and the entertainment policy places more emphasis on cinema than stage shows.

Cromer is one extraordinary exception to the rule: variety is flourishing at the theatre which was converted almost a century ago from a Victorian bandstand, perched on a pier on the north coast of Norfolk.

The report points out that the traditional variety show at Cromer, now billed as "the last end of the pier show", is growing. Last summer it added extra performances, including three matinees a week, and achieved a box office figure of 91%, a figure for which the Royal Shakespeare Company would kill.

Its new show opens next month. "It's very hard work, nine shows a week for 10 weeks, we need people with loads of stamina," said Steve Baker, entertainments manager. "No big stars, the show is the star."

webTitle: Both Siamese twins die in separation attempt

fields.headline: Both Siamese twins die in separation attempt
fields.trailText: The parents of Siamese twins who died during surgery in Sicily to separate the babies have refused job offers from Italians and will return to Peru after the girls' funeral today.
fields.body:
The parents of Siamese twins who died during surgery in Sicily to separate the babies have refused job offers from Italians and will return to Peru after the girls' funeral today.

The desperate journey by the Peruvian parents hoping for the successful separation of the three-month-old twins, who shared a heart, ended in sorrow on Saturday when the twins died during surgery.

Doctors knew the chances of success were slim, but hoped that by sacrificing the weaker girl, Milagro, they could save the other, Marta.

But six hours after Milagro's death during the surgical separation at a Palermo hospital, Marta died, too. The funeral will take place in Palermo cathedral.

Italian television reports said yesterday that the parents, a poor couple who have a four-year-old son, refused job offers that would have enabled them to stay in Italy.

The Milan daily Il Giornale said that the mayor of Palermo, Leoluca Orlando, had urged the couple to accept offers of work made by Palermo citizens who were moved by the drama.

The couple refused the jobs, but were accepting the gift of a car for the father, who drives a taxi in Lima.

There was criticism of the way in which the Italian media covered the drama. The head surgeon was interviewed on television just before entering the operating theatre to perform surgery on the girls.

"Let everybody please shut up a bit," the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano pleaded.

 Reuters in Rome

webTitle: Cheeky comics brave gales at end of Blackpool pier

fields.headline: Cheeky comics brave gales at end of Blackpool pier
fields.trailText: Backstage at Blackpool's North Pier theatre on the first night of the summer season, hail stones battered the roof and flies circled dressing room doors. The Grumbleweeds blotted their lipstick.
fields.body:
Backstage at Blackpool's North Pier theatre on the first night of the summer season, hail stones battered the roof and flies circled dressing room doors. The Grumbleweeds blotted their lipstick.

The 1980s TV comedians are this summer's "headline stars" at the North Pier, which in the 1960s hosted Morecambe and Wise and Frankie Howerd to packed audiences. Now the theatre reaches 70% capacity only on certain weeks in July and August.

The Grumbleweeds' summer act is the Big Big Laughter Show, a variety night compered by Stu Francis, a children's TV performer famed for his worn-out line: "Ooh, I could crush a grape."

This bank holiday weekend, the 1,500-capacity theatre has been one-third full. Over three-quarters of the audience were pensioners who had paid £10 for their tickets and clung to them valiantly while being blown sideways by gale-force winds on their way down the pier.

"This is our 35th British summer season," said Graham Walker of the Grumbleweeds. "In that time we have seen the casts of summer shows shrink in size. There are no longer 30 singers and dancers in a show. First-half finales have been axed and 20-week runs have been reduced to six weeks all over the country.

"Entertainers are having to work the caravan parks and holiday camps.

"But, in a declining industry, Blackpool has kept afloat. Our show runs for five months until the end of the illuminations in October. And we are booked for summer seasons for the next two years."

Jane Seddon, director of tourism in Blackpool, said there were 10 summer shows this year, playing in eight different theatres. This compared with an average of one or two shows in other resorts, and the town sustained 35,000 jobs in the entertainment industry.

She said Blackpool had 30,000 seats on sale each night in the summer season, including cabaret shows, working men's clubs and circuses. Around half of these seats were filled.

"Blackpool has survived the death of the seaside pier show because we have adapted," Mrs Seddon said. "Our walk-up ticket sales have fallen, so we market packages to hotels and coach tours. Stars don't want to forfeit television work by coming here for the season so we alternate shows to offer audience variety instead."

Jim and Mae Cairns, 70, came from Falkirk, Scotland, to see the Grumbleweeds. "I have been going to summer shows for 50 years," Mr Cairns said. "Audiences are not as full as they were and the shows have gone downhill. But tonight, the Grumbleweeds were excellent, particularly their joke about a melting plastic hip."

After the final curtain, pier show promoter Duggie Chapman lit a cigar. "I have lost a lot of money in this business," he said. "Audiences are dying off and success depends on the weather." This weekend the weather was not there to help.

webTitle: Dead heat as Mexican presidential poll nears

fields.headline: Dead heat as Mexican presidential poll nears
fields.trailText: Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary party (PRI), which has governed the country for 71 years, is looking decidedly shaky as the presidential campaign enters the home straight. But then the PRI candidate's main challenger is not so sure-footed either, hampered in his quest to unite the opposition behind his candidacy by his rightwing roots and a loose-cannon image.
fields.body:
Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary party (PRI), which has governed the country for 71 years, is looking decidedly shaky as the presidential campaign enters the home straight. But then the PRI candidate's main challenger is not so sure-footed either, hampered in his quest to unite the opposition behind his candidacy by his rightwing roots and a loose-cannon image.

The substantial lead enjoyed by the PRI's Francisco Labastida at the start of the campaign has faded away, with the most recent opinion polls showing him running neck and neck with Vicente Fox of the National Action Party at about 40%. The veteran leftwinger Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, of the Party of the Democratic Revolution, has most of the remaining votes.

"It looks like it is going to be a dead heat until the last minute," said a political analyst, Alejandro Proire, after a televised debate between the three main presidential candidates last Friday set the scene for the final push for votes before the election on July 2.

No one doubts that the PRI's party machine remains powerful, but most observers agree that it can no longer guarantee victory to its candidate, or - amid the unprecedented level of electoral monitoring - orchestrate the fraudulent practices of the past, should disaster strike.

So it was a relatively vulnerable Mr Labastida, made even more so by his grey bureaucratic image and 36 years of service in the PRI, who faced the two main opposition candidates in the debate. They attacked his party's reputation for endemic corruption, economic mismanagement and decades of broken promises in a country where 40m people live in poverty.

"His situation is very very difficult. It is very hard for him to defend himself from the fact that he comes from the PRI, and it is very easy to blame the PRI for all the problems that his country has. Given these difficulties I think he performed OK, but it is not going to win him any extra votes. The question is whether it stops people abandoning him," said Carlos Elizondo, who heads the Cide thinktank in Mexico City.

Mr Fox, meanwhile, is under pressure to repair the damage he did to himself earlier last week by a series of petulant outbursts that blocked talks on the terms of the debate and opened him up to ridicule as a spoilt child and a potentially authoritarian leader.

The blunder, played out on live television, appeared to threaten Mr Fox's painstaking efforts to built a broad-based movement appealing to all those who want "change", stretching far beyond his own conservative party and its reputation for elitism and Catholic intolerance.

In the debate, Mr Fox "managed to neutralise the curse of his mistakes earlier this week," said Mr Elizondo. However, the post-debate consensus is that this former rancher and one-time Coca-Cola executive is unlikely to attract many more supporters to a political project that has built up steam largely through his idiosyncratic mixture of cowboy-style audacity and sharp marketing. But it is precisely those qualities that deter a significant number of committed opponents of the regime from giving Mr Fox their tactical vote.

Intent on reinforcing such concerns, the PRI has been bombarding the mass media with political advertising dedicated to attacking Mr Fox as unreliable, contradictory and a danger to stability.

"Labastida's advantage is that he spent less at the start of the campaign and Fox could be running out of money," said Mr Elizondo, adding that Mr Fox's sturdy performance in the debate would probably offset the PRI's offensive.

The candidate with the most possibility of making an impact on the result is the one with no possibility of winning himself. Mr Cardenas, who many believe was cheated out of victory in 1988 presidential election by fraud, was languishing at around 12% of the vote until he took a more clearly leftwing nationalist stance and climbed to 16%.

The polls show he is stealing votes from both front-runners, after he blossomed into an ironic wit in the controversy in the run-up to the debate, that did so much harm to Mr Fox, and reinforced this during the TV debate itself, in which he directed most of his attacks against Mr Labastida.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Warsaw crisis
fields.body:
Warsaw crisis

Poland's Freedom Union party, led by the finance minister, Leszek Balcerowicz, has voted to quit the Solidarity-led coalition government, party spokesman Andrzej Potocki said yesterday.

The liberal pro-business party voted to withdraw its ministers in protest at Solidarity's failure to back reforms it considers vital for Poland's future. Solidarity is expected to form a minority administration. Reuters, Warsaw

Algeria violence

An armed group slit the throats of four shepherds, three of them children, in violence that left at least 17 people dead in a three-day period, according to press reports yesterday.

The daily Le Matin said the shepherds were killed by Islamic insurgents on Saturday near Miliana, 50 miles east of Algiers. Thirteen others have died in violence since Friday, it said. Reuters, Algiers

Peruvians vote

The Peruvian president, Alberto Fujimori, risked international isolation in his quest for a third term yesterday, despite a consitutional ban on serving three consecutive terms. Mr Fujimori counted on support among Peru's poor majority to deliver victory in the runoff election boycotted by his rival. AP, Lima

Dutch storms

Three people were killed yesterday as violent winds swept across the Netherlands, tearing up trees and toppling traffic signs. The national weather service issued a severe storm warning, predicting winds of up to 75mph Reuters, Amsterdam

webTitle: $1m fish highlights the threat to California's inland sea

fields.headline: $1m fish highlights the threat to California's inland sea
fields.standfirst: Salt build-up kills wildlife in Rat Pack's old watering hole
fields.trailText: Anglers from all over the US will be descending today on an inland desert sea in California in the hope of hooking a fish worth a million dollars from its murky waters. The competition is being held to draw attention to as an ecological crisis: a sea that could "choke itself to death" if action is not taken urgently.
fields.body:
Anglers from all over the US will be descending today on an inland desert sea in California in the hope of hooking a fish worth a million dollars from its murky waters. The competition is being held to draw attention to as an ecological crisis: a sea that could "choke itself to death" if action is not taken urgently.

At risk are more than 400 types of birds, including three endangered species, many of which use the lake as a vital part of their migration. The sea also contains the largest quantity of inland fish anywhere in the world and the struggle to save it will be seen as a sign of the government's commitment to the environment.

The Salton Sea is a strange and other-wordly stretch of water 35 miles long and 15 miles wide, just south-west of Palm Springs in California. Created accidentally in 1904 when engineers seeking new water supplies tried to divert the Colorado river, it became a fashionable weekend resort in the 1950s and 60s, patronised by Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin and others in the Rat Pack.

But it was different types of rare and exotic creatures that were to give the sea its significance. More than 400 species of bird have been spotted there, including the endangered Californian brown pelican and the Yuma clapper rail. As wetlands along the coast were surrendered to the developers' dollar, the Salton Sea became increasingly vital to migrating birds on the Pacific Flyway.

But the sea has no natural outlet and the build-up of salt, which makes it 25% more salinated than the Pacific, started to affect the wildlife, depriving the fish of oxygen. Dead fish were washed up in the tens of thousands, birds caught dis eases and a pungent smell from the algae drove visitors and investors away.

Environmentalists warned of the approaching demise of the sea but little action was taken. Then a local congressman, the former pop singer Sonny Bono, took up the sea's cause and in 1998 a bill he pioneered which authorised research into how the sea could be saved was passed. Bono was killed in a skiing accident as time started to run out.

Now the research has been done and the local consultation process about how best to save the sea ended this month. There are five main proposals, which include the creation of evaporation ponds or mechanical devices such as turbo-mist evaporators that will take the saline from the water. But the question is whether the rescue has been left too late.

Effectively, to save the sea, around 10m tonnes of salt will have to be pulled from it annually for the next 30 years. "This is an ecological time-bomb," said Tom Kirk of the Salton Sea authority, the government body that is overseeing the plans. "If we don't get it right, the sea's ecosystem will collapse.

"A lot of people have considered it toxic, but in fact the sea is too vibrant for its own good. It's so full of life that it literally chokes itself."

Mr Kirk and his colleagues warn that urgent action is needed. "Time is of the essence and delaying action could allow major aspects of the eco-system to collapse."

Meanwhile, what was once a thriving community around the banks of the sea feels beleaguered and misunderstood by the Angelenos who used to throng there and now scorn it as the "dead fish sea".

Hence the "fishing derby", the idea of a local restaurateur, Mack Brinegar. He has tagged 20 corvina, which are like sea bass, and put them in the sea. Anglers who catch one will be eligible for a draw from 50 envelopes, one of which will contain a $1m prize. The chances of anyone actually winning are about as slim as a gutted whitebait, but Mr Brinegar's purpose is to try and save the sea's reputation.

"We're trying to get people down here and show them what it's really like," Mr Brinegar said. "There are almost a billion telapia in there, and we've been told it's the biggest fishery in the world." He believes the sea and its environs have been the victim of politics, and that probably only 20,000 people now live around the sea, which is the colour of stewed tea.

The fishing derby is temporary light relief before the serious business begins. Mr Kirk and his colleagues believe that only if action is taken soon can an ecosystem every bit as important as the Florida Everglades be saved, and with it countless species of birds who have come to regard the Rat Pack's old watering-hole as their own.

But the question is whether the rescue has been left too late. Effectively, to save the sea, around 10m tonnes of salt will have to be pulled from it annually for the next 30 years. "This is an ecological time-bomb," said Tom Kirk of the Salton Sea authority, the government body that is overseeing the plans. "If we don't get it right, the sea's ecosystem will collapse. "A lot of people have considered it toxic, but in fact the sea is too vibrant for its own good. It's so full of life that it literally chokes itself." Mr Kirk and his colleagues warn that urgent action is needed. "Time is of the essence and delaying action could allow major aspects of the eco-system to collapse." Meanwhile, what was once a thriving community around the banks of the sea feels beleaguered and misunderstood by the Angelenos who used to throng there and now scorn it as the "dead fish sea". Hence the "fishing derby", the idea of a local restaurateur, Mack Brinegar. He has tagged 20 corvina, which are like sea bass, and put them in the sea. Anglers who catch one will be eligible for a draw from 50 envelopes, one of which will contain a $1m prize. The chances of anyone actually winning are about as slim as a gutted whitebait, but Mr Brinegar's purpose is to try and save the sea's reputation. "We're trying to get people down here and show them what it's really like," Mr Brinegar said. "There are almost a billion telapia in there, and we've been told it's the biggest fishery in the world." He believes the sea and its environs have been the victim of politics, and that probably only 20,000 people now live around the sea, which is the colour of stewed tea. The fishing derby is temporary light relief before the serious business begins. Mr Kirk and his colleagues believe that only if action is taken soon can an ecosystem every bit as important as the Florida Everglades be saved, and with it countless species of birds who have come to regard the Rat Pack's old watering-hole as their own.
fields.bylineHtml: Duncan Campbell in Desert Shores

webTitle: Indonesians gather for a Highland fling

fields.headline: Indonesians gather for a Highland fling
fields.trailText: As a Highland gathering venue, Lippo Karawaci has neither the majesty of Braemar nor the historical romanticism of Glenfinnan.
fields.byline: John Aglionby in Lippo Karawaci, west Java
fields.body:
As a Highland gathering venue, Lippo Karawaci has neither the majesty of Braemar nor the historical romanticism of Glenfinnan.

But that mattered little to the thousands of people who flocked to this modern city half an hour from Jakarta yesterday to experience one of the biggest festivals of traditional Scottish sporting culture outside Scotland.

There was plenty to keep the purists happy. A posse of 20-stone giants came from Scotland to compete in heavy events such as tossing the caber, and Highland dancers performed against a background of bagpipe music.

However, this was a uniquely Asian gathering. A striking Sikh contingent from Malaysia and four Gurkhas attached to the Singapore police were the stars of the piping competition, and a couple of locals kept up with the giants for a couple of events before collapsing exhausted. Dozens of competitors had made their way from Bangkok, Australia and Hong Kong.

"This is not only a celebration of Scottish culture, it's an event for all Indonesians," said Rab Spiers, chieftan of the Java St Andrew Society. "We want everyone to have a good time and enjoy themselves."

He was relieved that the event was happening at all. Ten days before the 1998 gathering, the riots erupted that destroyed many parts of Jakarta and Lippo Karawaci and led to the toppling of the dictator Suharto. In May 1999 the situation was considered still too uncertain for the festival to take place.

"We now see this as our way of saying to the world that Indonesia is safe and stable again," Mr Spiers said.

The fact that so many Indonesians came demonstrated the high level of curiosity about the Celtic culture, although more than a few seemed bemused by the Scottish accents and the fact that more men than women were wearing skirts.

"I am looking for a Scottish dictionary, so then I might be able to understand what is going on," said Yulianti, a 20-year-old student from Jakarta, who was browsing the stalls.
